headline.main: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Aid workers in Kandahar, Afghanistan, have buried a man originally identified by the Taliban as an American, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today. Citing privacy concerns, Red Cross officials here would not identify the man or release his nationality, saying only that he was not an Afghan or an American.

headline.main: Number Overstated for Storm Evacuees in Hotels

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The Red Cross and federal government said Tuesday that they had been significantly overreporting the number of Hurricane Katrina evacuees in hotels. Instead of 600,000 people, 200,000 remain in hotels, the charity said. Although the lower number means that the Federal Emergency Management Agency and cities receiving evacuees will find new housing for far fewer people, the count shows the lack of knowledge that FEMA has about the relocations and its limited oversight over the money it is committed to spend on such housing.

headline.main: RED CROSS SIFTING INTERNAL CHARGES OVER KATRINA AID

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross, the largest recipient of donations after Hurricane Katrina, is investigating wide ranging accusations of impropriety among volunteers after the disaster. John F. McGuire, the interim president and chief executive of the Red Cross, and Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said some of the actions might have been criminal.

headline.main: Red Cross Offers to Refund Gifts for Sept. 11

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross, reacting to criticism of its fund-raising for Sept. 11 relief, said yesterday that it would return donations to any contributor who requested a refund. The Red Cross, which has collected roughly $500 million for the victims, announced earlier this month that not all of the money would go to the Sept. 11 victims. Of the $564 million dollars donated to the organization, about $150 million has gone directly to victims and their families so far.

headline.main: Red Cross Seeks $7 Million in Federal Money for Staffing

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross, which is struggling with a $200 million deficit, is asking for federal money to help it meet government requirements as part of a national plan to address major disasters. The Red Cross has traditionally avoided asking for federal money, concerned that doing so would confuse donors, many of whom already think incorrectly that it is a federally financed organization, according to surveys.

headline.main: Woman Is Indicted In 9/11 Aid Fraud

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A Missouri woman was indicted yesterday on federal charges that she concocted a story about having lost a younger brother in the World Trade Center disaster to collect more than $60,000 in financial aid from the American Red Cross and several other disaster-relief organizations. The 10-count indictment, announced by the United States attorney's office in Kansas City, Mo., charges that the woman, Cassaundrea Montgomery, 41, of St. Joseph, filed a false missing persons report with the New York Police Department regarding a 23-year-old brother, who the authorities say does not exist. She said that her brother, Jeffrey, had been in Lower Manhattan on Sept. 11 for a job interview with the financial services firm Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Red Cross Policy On Gays

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross has adopted a policy that defines family in a ''broad and inclusive'' way to includes gay domestic partners. After receiving reports that the gay partners of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks were having trouble gaining assistance, the charity issued 16 criteria for determining a financially interdependent couple, trained volunteers to interview same-sex partners, and appointed an ombudsman to oversee their cases. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

headline.main: Red Cross Agrees to Database

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross has tentatively agreed to participate in the creation of a central database that would keep track of how donations raised in the aftermath of Sept. 11 are distributed to victims' families. The agreement, announced last night by Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, represents an important step in the effort to coordinate the distribution of more than $1 billion in charity. It also marks a major policy reversal for the Red Cross, the nation's largest disaster relief organization and the recipient of $505 million in donations since the attacks.

headline.main: Red Cross Interviews 14 Qaeda Terrorism Suspects at Guantánamo

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A team from the Red Cross has met in recent days at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is thought to have been the chief planner of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and 13 other prisoners identified by the United States government as senior officials of Al Qaeda, Red Cross officials said Thursday. Until recently, the 14 had been held by the Central Intelligence Agency at undisclosed prisons for as long as four years. The meetings with the delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross are believed to be, for many, their first contact since their capture with someone not connected with the United States government.

headline.main: As Its Coffers Swell, Red Cross Is Criticized On Gulf Coast Response

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: In New Orleans and the coastal flood plains of Mississippi, many people are complaining that the American Red Cross was missing in their worst hours of need and are worried that its billowing relief fund may bypass them entirely. The organization did not open shelters in flood-prone areas and was therefore unable to provide food and other necessities to people closest to the coast ravaged by Hurricane Katrina.

headline.main: Red Cross Is Pressed To Open Its Books

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Driven by anger and concern over the performance of the American National Red Cross in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, federal and state officials are demanding fuller disclosure of the relief agency's finances and are moving to enforce more stringent monitoring of its disaster aid operations. Partly in response to the increasing pressure, Red Cross officials plan a news conference today in Washington to lay out what the organization describes as ''major changes'' in its fund-raising practices.

headline.main: Senators Press Red Cross For a Full Accounting

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee began an inquiry into the American Red Cross yesterday, seeking a broad range of information about its governance, its handling of money donated for disaster relief and its compensation policies. Congressional scrutiny of the organization started shortly after Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast, as widespread criticism of the Red Cross response to the disaster mounted. The abrupt announcement this month that Marsha J. Evans, the group's president and chief executive, would step down at the end of the year intensified interest on Capitol Hill in revising the organization's charter.

headline.main: August 18-24: NATIONAL; 9/11 MENTAL HEALTH AID

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: In an ambitious effort to address the emotional needs of disaster victims, two charities agreed to underwrite extended mental health treatment for people directly affected by last year's terrorist attacks. About 150,000 families meet the eligibility requirements set by the American Red Cross and the September 11th Fund, including relatives of people killed in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks, people injured in those attacks, rescue workers and displaced residents.

headline.main: Red Cross Halts Collections for Terror Victims

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: American Red Cross officials announced yesterday that they would immediately suspend fund-raising for the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, saying that the $547 million pledged so far should be enough to cover the costs of the organization's immediate and long-term relief efforts. The announcement is a notable example of a shift among charities that are now focused less on collecting new donations and more on deciding how best to spend some $1.2 billion already pledged to them. It also comes after days of increasingly angry complaints from families about the pace at which the Red Cross is distributing cash assistance.

headline.main: Red Cross President Plans Visit to Washington on Question of Detainees' Treatment

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross said Tuesday that the organization's president, M. Jakob Kellenberger, was hoping to visit Washington soon to press senior Bush administration officials about the treatment of detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Committee officials in Washington, and at the organization's headquarters in Geneva, said that Mr. Kellenberger had made visits to Washington before. But it was clear that any coming visit would be used to raise at a high level the issues contained in a Red Cross report charging that the American military had used psychological and physical coercion on detainees that was ''tantamount to torture.''

headline.main: Officer Says Army Tried to Curb Red Cross Visits to Prison in Iraq
headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: ABU GHRAIB

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Army officials in Iraq responded late last year to a Red Cross report of abuses at Abu Ghraib prison by trying to curtail the international agency's spot inspections of the prison, a senior Army officer who served in Iraq said Tuesday. After the International Committee of the Red Cross observed abuses in one cellblock on two unannounced inspections in October and complained in writing on Nov. 6, the military responded that inspectors should make appointments before visiting the cellblock. That area was the site of the worst abuses.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gas Price Gouger To Pay Refunds

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: An Iowa company that charged sharply higher gasoline prices at stations in Illinois after the terrorist attacks must give refunds to customers under a settlement reached with the Illinois attorney general, Jim Ryan. Mr. Ryan filed a lawsuit two weeks ago accusing the company, Casey's General Stores Inc., of charging customers as much as $5 a gallon. The company must also donate $25,000 to the American Red Cross and pay $5,000 to cover state legal expenses. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

headline.main: Firing Stirs New Debate Over Red Cross

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Just as it seemed to have turned a corner, the American Red Cross finds itself in the spotlight again. A day after the organization shocked its staff members and donors by firing its chief executive, Mark W. Everson, for having an affair with a subordinate, all its historic problems -- including governance, past failures in its disaster relief efforts and continuing failures in its blood business -- were up for discussion.

headline.main: Metro Matters; Take the Cash. You're Making Us Look Bad.

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: IT does not happen with great frequency that people are offered money that they will admit they do not need. But nothing is quite as it should be in New York right now. Hence the battle of conscience being waged below Canal Street, brought to you by the American Red Cross.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Charged With 9/11 Fraud

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan woman was charged yesterday with fraud, accused of filing false papers indicating that her father had been missing since the attack on the World Trade Center and receiving $75,000 from a relief fund established by the American Red Cross. The police said the woman, Rosalba Wild, 50, of 435 East 79th Street, was arrested at 8 a.m. and charged with grand larceny. The arrest followed dozens of others in recent months in which people have been charged with various schemes to defraud charities and government agencies working in Sept. 11 disaster relief. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Report Says Charities Would Be Lacking in a Big Disaster

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The major charities that respond to disasters would be unable to address fully the need for food, shelter and other services after a catastrophic event like Hurricane Katrina or a major earthquake, a report by the Government Accountability Office says. ''In a worst-case, large-scale disaster, the projected need for mass care services would far exceed the capabilities of these voluntary organizations without government or other assistance,'' said the G.A.O., which does research and analysis for Congress.

headline.main: Red Cross Announces Plans For Rest of Disaster Funds

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross yesterday announced how it would distribute another $360 million from its giant Liberty Disaster Fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Former United States Senator George J. Mitchell, who now oversees the fund, said $240 million would be paid in direct financial assistance to families, $80 million would go for long-term services like mental health treatment, and $25 million would be spent on immediate disaster relief, like the maintenance of support centers. The plan, announced at a news conference in Manhattan, also allows for an additional $15 million to help extended or ''nontraditional'' family members who have compelling financial needs, said David T. McLaughlin, chairman of the agency's board of governors.

headline.main: Hurricane Fraud Cases Surprise Even Officials

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: There is the Louisiana woman who reportedly used her aunt's New Orleans address and her brother's name to file a false claim for federal aid for Hurricane Katrina. There are the Red Cross contract workers in California who are accused of cashing in on benefits for fictitious hurricane victims. And there are the two Florida residents who turned to the government for help, citing two hurricane-damaged houses in Slidell, La., that investigators say do not exist.

headline.main: In Congress, Harsh Words For Red Cross

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross came under scathing criticism today from members of Congress who expressed outrage and astonishment over the agency's recent decision to withhold more than $200 million in charitable donations intended for the families of the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. Representative Billy Tauzin, chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, accused the nation's largest disaster relief organization of siphoning millions of dollars away from thousands of victims' families, misleading millions of donors and using bad judgment that could imperil the fund-raising efforts of all charities. ''Something's wrong,'' Mr. Tauzin, a Republican from Louisiana, said angrily.

headline.main: Survey Finds That Grief Is a Constant Companion for Those at the Scene of the 9/11 Attacks

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A survey being released today by the American Red Cross shows that for many of those directly affected by the Sept. 11 attacks, grief remains a constant companion nearly five years later. The report shows that two-thirds of the responders, survivors and victims' relatives who sought help from the Red Cross to deal with their emotions in the aftermath of 9/11 believe that grief still interferes to a large or moderate extent with their lives.

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; KURDISH LEADER KILLED

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Gunmen from the militant group Ansar al-Islam assassinated a Kurdish minister of Parliament and two security officials in northern Iraq. The gunmen posed as peace negotiators in sessions with the minister, finally luring him away from his security. He was killed while refining terms for a possible peace settlement between the secular government and a faction of the Islamic group, which the U.S. says is supported by both Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. C.J. Chivers

headline.main: Islamic Militants Clash With Kurdish Forces in Northern Iraq

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Renewed fighting broke out today between Kurdish forces and Islamic guerrillas in the mountains along the Iran-Iraq border when a surprise attack by the guerrillas, reported to have links to Al Qaeda, briefly overran Kurdish positions, Kurdish officials said. Casualty reports varied during the day, but late tonight the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, whose forces have been battling the guerrillas in the area, said 42 Kurdish combatants had been killed. An earlier estimate said only six of the Kurdish fighters, known as pesh merga, had been wounded.

headline.main: 4 Killed in Suicide Bombing at Checkpoint in Northern Iraq

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: A man detonated a bomb he was wearing near a Kurdish military headquarters in northern Iraq today, killing himself and three others in what the authorities described as the first Kurdish suicide bombing. The authorities said the attack, at a military checkpoint in Zamaqi, was probably the work of Ansar al-Islam, a militant Islamic group that the United States contends has connections to both Al Qaeda and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. It occurred late in the morning, when a sport utility vehicle used as a taxi was stopped at a checkpoint by Kurdish guards. A Kurdish security official said the guards were suspicious of the taxi's passenger and asked him to leave the vehicle for an inspection. ''When he was about to be checked, he pressed the button,'' the official said.

headline.main: Kurdish Targets Are Struck In Iraq by Turkey and Iran

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL -- Turkish warplanes attacked 60 targets in the mountains and border areas of northern Iraq early Thursday in pursuit of Kurdish separatist rebels suspected of responsibility a day earlier for a deadly quadruple bombing ambush on a military convoy in southeast Turkey, the army headquarters said. Turkish news reports and Kurdish officials in northern Iraq reported more Turkish warplane sorties late Thursday night.

headline.seo: Turkey and Iran Strike Kurdish Targets in Iraq
headline.main: Turkey Attacks Kurdish Targets in Northern Iraq After Ambush
headline.print_headline: Kurdish Targets Are Struck In Iraq by Turkey and Iran

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Turkish warplanes were in pursuit of Kurdish separatist rebels who killed nine security officials and wounded 15 in an ambush a day earlier, army headquarters said.

headline.main: Kurdish Forces Prepare To Attack in Northern Iraq
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: SECOND FRONT

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Kurdish officials said today that Kurdish guerrillas had been acting as guides and scouts inside Iraqi-controlled territory, helping small teams of American soldiers to enter Iraq for missions behind the Iraqi lines. Larger groups of Kurdish soldiers were seen moving into at least four front-line villages around Kirkuk and Mosul today, feeding speculation that Kurdish forces would be asked to play a significant role in any American effort to open a northern front against the Iraqi Army. The original plan to deploy a large American force was derailed by Turkey's refusal to allow the use of its ports and roads.

headline.main: Iraq Militants Who Killed Kurd Minister Take Hostage

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: The Islamic group Ansar al-Islam, which the United States claims has ties to both Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda, abducted a man from a village in northern Iraq on Sunday, bringing to three the number of hostages it has taken in recent days, Kurdish officials said. The latest kidnapping came the day after the group assassinated a minister of the Kurdish parliament in what the authorities describe as an intricately laid trap.

headline.main: Over 2,000 Syrian Kurds Flee Kobani as Islamic State Advances, Kurdish Official Says
headline.print_headline: Over 2,000 Syrian Kurds Flee Kobani as Islamic State Advances, Kurdish Official Says

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: More than 2,000 Syrian Kurds including women and children are being evacuated from border town of Kobani after Islamic State militants who have besieged the town for nearly three weeks have advanced towards the city center, a translator for the leading Kurdish political group in Syria told Reuters on Monday.

headline.main: As Kurds Protest, Violence Claims 4 More in Turkey

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: The police opened fire to disperse Kurdish demonstrators in southeastern Turkey on Sunday, killing one protester, security officials said. Three more people died when a gasoline bomb that the police said appeared to be linked to the Kurdish protests was thrown into a bus in Istanbul, the officials said. The deaths raised the toll in six days of street violence to 12.

headline.main: Coalition Jets Strike Islamic State Near Turkish Border: Kurdish Sources
headline.print_headline: Coalition Jets Strike Islamic State Near Turkish Border: Kurdish Sources

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: U.S.-led forces launched air strikes on Islamic State fighters who are besieging a Kurdish town near the Syrian border with Turkey on Wednesday, Kurdish sources in the town and a monitoring group said, a rare daylight coalition attack.

headline.main: Kurds and G.I.'s Rout Militants in North
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD -- NORTHERN FRONT

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: A combined American and Kurdish military assault swept through this remote mountain valley in northeastern Iraq today, capturing a series of villages from a militant Islamic group and restoring a swath of border territory to Kurdish control. In a war that has seen early setbacks and unwelcome surprises, this was an operation in which the immediate outcome exceeded expectations.

headline.main: Militants Gone, Caves in North Lie Abandoned
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | THE NORTHERN FRONT

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Some of the cave entrances were slung low and obscured by shadows, waist-high openings in cool, moss-cloaked rock. Others were door-sized slots, tall enough for the passage of upright men. The caves, penetrating the darkness under the ridge at Dari Baramaran, were among warrens of defenses in this remote valley along northern Iraq's border with Iran, which until this weekend had been controlled for nearly two years by Ansar al-Islam, a militant Islamic group.

headline.main: Kurds Face a Second Enemy: Islamic Fighters on Iraq Flank

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Peering down from this snowcapped peak, Khakamend Khakarush Omar, a Kurdish military commander who has spent his life resisting Saddam Hussein, pointed to villages in the valley below. All are under enemy control, ringed by bunkers and armed bearded men. The enemy gunmen on the opposing ridge are not in Mr. Hussein's army. They pay no allegiance to any state. They are fighters for Ansar al Islam, a group of militants who have taken hold of a small corner of Kurdish-controlled Iraq and established harsh Islamic order over a wild, isolated land.

headline.main: NORWAY EXPELS MILITANT LEADER

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Norway said yesterday that it planned to expel the founder of Ansar al-Islam, an Islamic militant group in northern Iraq that is suspected by Washington of having links to Baghdad and Al Qaeda. The founder, known as Mullah Krekar, has had refugee status in Norway since 1991. ''Mullah Krekar will be expelled because of concerns about national security,'' said the local government minister, Erna Solberg. Mullah Krekar said he would appeal the expulsion.

headline.main: Kurdish Struggle Blurs Syria’s Battle Lines
headline.print_headline: Kurdish Struggle Blurs Syria’s Battle Lines

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Kurds are using the chaos in Syria to seek autonomy, but their struggle does not fit neatly into the war between President Bashar al-Assad and the rebels seeking his ouster.

headline.main: Anti-U.S. Kurdish Militants Rebounding, Officials Say

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Ali Hamaamin said he had been whipped with electrical cords, hung by his arms and kicked in the face. Because he was accused of not being religious, he was repeatedly tortured by men from the militant Islamic group Ansar al-Islam. ''They used to come to me at night, wearing masks, and do the most horrible things,'' said Mr. Hamaamin, who lives in Beyara, a village near the Iranian border.

headline.main: Iraq PM Says Kurdish Arbil Becoming a Base for 'Islamic State' Militants
headline.print_headline: Iraq PM Says Kurdish Arbil Becoming a Base for 'Islamic State' Militants

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki said on Wednesday the Kurdish-controlled city of Arbil was becoming an operations base for the Islamic State militant group that seized swathes of northern and western Iraq last month.

headline.main: While Many Islamic Fighters Surrender, Kurds Remain Wary of New Terrorist Attacks
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | NORTHERN IRAQ

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: The voice, hurried and agitated, came loudly over the speakerphone near where a Kurdish commander sat. It was from a member of a group the United States regards as Islamic terrorists. It was asking, almost pleading, for help. ''I am tired,'' the voice said. ''The night is coming. I am very tired.''

headline.main: 5 Killed in Error at a Kurdish Checkpoint

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Five Muslim men, including a leader of a prominent Islamist political party in northern Iraq, were shot and killed today at a highway checkpoint here by Kurdish security officers. Immediately after the killings, Kurdish officials said the action of the officers had thwarted a terrorist squad that has been hunting for American Special Forces teams in the area. But by nightfall, as it became clear the dead were members of a registered political party, the authorities issued statements of regret. It appeared the dead men had been mistaken for terrorists.

headline.main: Kurds Puzzled by Report of Terror Camp

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's assertion today that Islamic extremists were operating a poisons training camp and factory in northern Iraq appeared to surprise Kurdish officials, who greeted the claim with a mix of satisfaction and confusion. The officials were pleased to hear an American effort to discredit their Islamist enemies, and to sense momentum toward war to unseat Saddam Hussein. But some also wondered if the intelligence Mr. Powell presented to the United Nations Security Council was imprecise.

headline.main: With Militant Group Routed, American and Kurdish Forces Hunt for Clues About Al Qaeda
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | SPECIAL FORCES

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: The compound that the United States called a terrorists' poison factory is no more. All that remains are ruined buildings, a flattened fence and a littered yard. Its inhabitants are gone. At least nine precision-guided weapons struck this place, judging by the tightly spaced craters where the weapons hit the earth and exploded, showering the area with cascading bits of building, rock and dirt.

headline.main: Turkish Official Says Iraqi Kurdish Fighters Free to Cross to Kobani
headline.print_headline: Turkish Official Says Iraqi Kurdish Fighters Free to Cross to Kobani

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: A Turkish official said on Monday Iraqi Kurdish peshmerga fighters were free to move through Turkey to Syria "as soon as they are ready" after a Syrian Kurdish leader accused Ankara of stalling on an agreement to allow them passage to the besieged Syrian border town of Kobani.

headline.main: Iran Has Reportedly Pledged Help in Ousting Al Qaeda Militants From Northern Iraq

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: An Iraqi Kurdish leader said today that Iran had promised military help to oust Islamic militants suspected of having ties with Al Qaeda from a swath of northern Iraq. The militants are believed to have carried out raids, assassinations and bombings in the region, including an attack on a Kurdish checkpoint outside Halabja, near the border with Iran, on Monday night.

headline.main: Hundreds Disappear Into the Black Hole of the Kurdish Prison System in Iraq

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: The inmates began their strike with an angry call. ''Allahu akbar!'' they shouted, 120 voices joining in a cadence punctuated by whoops. They thrust their arms between the metal bars and ripped away the curtains and plastic sheets covering the windows facing the prison courtyard. Their squinting faces were exposed to light.

headline.main: Repulsing Attack by Islamic Militants, Iraqi Kurds Tell of Atrocities

Kurdistan - Ansar al-Islam.lead_paragraph: An Islamic militant group with reported links to Al Qaeda has withdrawn today from areas it briefly seized from the Kurdish autonomous government, Kurdish military and government officials said. It left behind stories of battlefield atrocities and grief along the narrow front. The repulsed group, Ansar al-Islam, or Supporters of Islam, operates in a tiny portion of the Kurdish enclave near Iraq's northeastern border with Iran.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Victim's Remains Identified

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Officials have identified the remains of Harry Blanding Jr., a victim of the World Trade Center attack, through DNA testing, the medical examiner's office announced yesterday. Mr. Blanding, 38, of Blakeslee, Pa., was a claims analyst. Officials have identified 1,598 of the 2,749 people who died in the attack, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Three 9/11 Victims Identified

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The city medical examiner's office has made three new identifications based on DNA tests, and another match may be announced within a few days, a spokeswoman, Ellen Borakove, said. The three victims, who were identified on March 11, are a city firefighter, Hector Tirado, who was 31; Luis Manuel Lopez, 39; and George Merino, 39. The medical examiner's office said recently that it was nearing the point where all current means of identifying 9/11 victims would be exhausted, but Ms. Borakove said yesterday that the medical staff had not given up on the use of DNA, which has played a role in most of the identifications at the trade center site. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Increases Access To DNA Labs

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has issued an order to increase the number of laboratories helping with DNA identification of those missing in the World Trade Center attack. At least 50,000 and possibly up to a million samples of DNA taken from various remains will eventually be tested, officials have said. The New York City medical examiner's office, the State Police Forensic Investigation Center in Albany and a state contractor, Myriad Genetics Inc. of Salt Lake City, are working on identifications. The private laboratories appointed under the order were Myriad, Celera in Rockville, Md., and Bode in Virginia. A fourth, in Arizona, is under consideration.

headline.main: Belgian Man Identified in Testing of 9/11 Remains
headline.print_headline: Belgian Man Identified in Testing of 9/11 Remains

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The New York City medical examiner's office says an ongoing retesting of remains recovered from the World Trade Center site has resulted in the identification of 31-year-old Belgian man killed in the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: DNA Samples for 9/11 Inquiry

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the attack on the World Trade Center who submitted toothbrushes, razors, hairbrushes or other items containing DNA material for genetic matching are being asked to call the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner to make sure that enough material was collected for the testing to be completed. Of the 2,870 victims in the Sept. 11 attack, 692 have been identified, 117 of them solely through matching the genetic material in the remains with the items families submitted, said Ellen Borakove, spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office. In some cases, the items did not contain enough genetic material for testing to be completed. All family members who have not submitted material for DNA testing are urged to do so as soon as possible. They are asked to call (212) 447-7884, between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., seven days a week. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: 800 Victims May Not Be Identified, City Says

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Only about 2,000 of the estimated 2,823 people killed in the World Trade Center terrorist attack are likely to be identified through their remains, scientists at the New York City medical examiner's office said yesterday. There will probably not be enough DNA to clearly identify the remaining victims, said Dr. Robert Shaler, the director of forensic biology for the chief medical examiner's office.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Victims' Remains Identified

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The office of the chief medical examiner said yesterday that it had matched the remains of three 9/11 victims with new and additional DNA samples provided by their families. Two were identified as Karen Ann Martin, 40, the head flight attendant on American Airlines Flight 11, which struck the north tower, and Douglas Joel Stone, 54, a passenger on the flight. The name of the third victim was not released, at his family's request. The newly identified remains were not among those discovered recently in a manhole near the World Trade Center site, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. The remains of 1,601 of the 2,749 victims have now been identified. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains -- mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation -- are still being sorted through by the city's medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009. Now, a dispute over what to do with those remains is simmering between some of the victims' families and the officials planning the National September 11 Memorial and Museum underneath where the twin towers stood.

headline.seo: For 9/11 Museum, a Question of How to Handle Remains
headline.main: For 9/11 Museum, Dispute Over Victims’ Remains
headline.print_headline: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Some of the victims’ families are appalled by a plan to place the remains in the new museum behind a wall with a quotation from Virgil about never forgetting.

headline.main: DNA Matches Surge, Aiding in the Identification of Victims

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The number of victims of the World Trade Center attack whose remains have been identified and released to families has increased sharply in the past few days, largely because of a surge in DNA matches confirmed by the New York City medical examiner's office. The daily list of names was 12 on Tuesday, 16 on Wednesday and 8 yesterday, after having trickled in at an average of 2 or 3 a day.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Chief's Remains Identified

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The remains of Deputy Chief Raymond M. Downey, the New York City fire commander who was a nationally known expert on rescue operations, have been identified, eight months after he disappeared in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Chief Downey, a firefighter for 39 years, was identified through DNA analysis, according to the city medical examiner's office. As the head of Special Operations Command, Chief Downey directed rescue operations at collapsed buildings. Asked once why he searched so long for remains of the presumed dead, he cited the families left behind. ''The only way you can relieve some of their sorrow,'' he said, ''is to successfully recover the bodies of the people they loved.'' Kevin Flynn (NYT)

headline.main: Officials Identify Remains of Two Hijackers Through DNA

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The city medical examiner's office has identified the remains of two of the terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center, a spokeswoman said last night. The remains have been removed from Memorial Park, where the 19,935 pieces of unidentified remains have been stored since shortly after the attack. Ellen S. Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office, declined to say where the remains of the hijackers had been taken.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains Found At Ground Zero

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Workers excavating a manhole at ground zero yesterday found human remains, including bones big enough to be arm or leg bones, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. The medical examiner's office is trying to determine whether the remains belong to victims of the World Trade Center attack. Con Edison workers and a private contractor found the remains in abandoned manholes on the north edge of the site, the Port Authority said. Con Edison said that more debris that had been dug up on Tuesday and hauled to a Con Edison property on West 28th Street also turned out to contain human remains, which were turned over to the medical examiner's office. ANDY NEWMAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Help Sought On Remains

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer asked the Defense Department yesterday to assign a specialized military team to assist in identifying human remains found at a building near the site of the World Trade Center. Hundreds of bone fragments have been found at the Deutsche Bank building, which is being prepared for demolition. Many of the fragments are tiny, some as small as one-sixteenth of an inch. In a letter to the defense secretary, Mr. Schumer asked the department to assign one of the teams that specialize in identifying the remains of missing soldiers to assist the city medical examiner's office.

headline.main: Bone Fragments Are Found on Roof

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: More human remains have been found at the former Deutsche Bank building, a skyscraper adjacent to ground zero, authorities said yesterday. Construction workers found the remains on Friday while cleaning the building in preparation for its demolition, the office of the chief medical examiner said. The Deutsche Bank building, at 130 Liberty Street, is just southwest of the World Trade Center site.

headline.main: Forensics Lab Is Prepared For Up to 20,000 DNA Tests
headline.kicker: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MEDICAL EXAMINER

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Faced with the heart-rending but essential task of identifying victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center, the New York City medical examiner's office has made preparations to perform DNA testing on as many as 20,000 tissue samples recovered from the rubble, officials said yesterday. ''We are gearing up to test from 300 to 700 samples a day,'' said Dr. Robert Shaler, who runs the laboratory as director of forensic biology for the medical examiner's office.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Death Toll Declines as 2 People Are Found Alive

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Two more names have been removed from the count of World Trade Center victims after a Florida man and a New York City woman were found alive, discoveries that bring the death toll from the Sept. 11 attack in New York City down to 2,795. Peter Montoulieu of Miami and Tina Spicer of New York are among five people who have been found alive and have been removed from the list of presumed dead since 2,801 names were read at the ground zero ceremony in September, the first anniversary of the attack. One other name was dropped after city officials determined that a female victim had been listed twice, a spokeswoman from the city medical examiner's office said on Friday.

headline.main: Remains Found Near Ground Zero

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The authorities said yesterday that nine pieces of bone and muscle were found on Monday by construction workers at a building near the site of the World Trade Center, and that these may be the remains of a victim of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner, said DNA tests would be used to try to identify the remains. The process, she said, will take at least several days, and it may prove futile because heat, humidity and other factors affecting human tissue decrease the effectiveness of the tests.

headline.main: Now, Doctors Must Identify the Dead

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Doctors are gearing up for the largest effort in the annals of forensic medicine: identifying the dead in the World Trade Center attacks. The scientists always knew the identifications would be an arduous task, but with more than 6,000 people still unaccounted for and relatively few bodies recovered, it is turning out to be a far bigger job than they expected.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Victim Count Drops

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The number of people listed as victims of the World Trade Center attack has dropped below 2,800, after three people were found alive and one duplication was cut from the names read at the anniversary ceremony, a city spokeswoman said yesterday. The count fell to 2,797 after investigators found that Maria Bengochea, 46, of Manhattan, and Germaan Castillo Garcia, 36, of Brooklyn, were erroneously reported missing, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. The name of Nickola Lampley was removed after she was found by The Associated Press the day her name was read at the ceremony.

headline.main: New Test for 9/11 ID's Is Moving Much Slower Than Scientists Hoped

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: After months of rigorous preparation, the New York City medical examiner's office says that a novel genetic testing technique being relied upon to help identify additional victims of the Sept. 11 terror attack has not produced any concrete results because the process has unfolded far more slowly than anticipated. Dr. Robert Shaler, the office's director of forensic biology, said he had hoped that the experimental technique would begin to analyze a huge cache of badly damaged genetic materials from the World Trade Center site in June or July. But because of the magnitude and delicacy of the task, he said, scientists have proceeded cautiously. As a result, the much-awaited results of a pilot test will not be ready until mid-December.

headline.main: At Limits Of Science, 9/11 ID Effort Comes to End

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Again and again, the standard DNA tests came up negative on a three-inch-by-two-inch piece of muscle recovered from the World Trade Center site, and just a year after the 2001 attacks, forensics experts were stymied. Yet now, the scrap has been linked to a firefighter from Midtown Manhattan, allowing his death to be confirmed and giving his wife and two children some sense of finality. Solving brutally difficult cases like that one required an investment of two extra years and millions of dollars by the medical examiner's office in New York, which sought out and used DNA identification technologies that had never been tried.

headline.main: Wider Use of DNA Lists Is Urged in Fighting Crime

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: A team of Harvard scientists is proposing that DNA databases contain enough information to identify many criminals whose DNA has not been catalogued through their kinship to people already listed. They say this could be done by a method developed to identify victims of the World Trade Center attacks and other disasters. The F.B.I.'s DNA database can now be searched only for exact matches to DNA found at crime scenes. But with slight modifications, it could be searched for close relatives of whoever left the DNA.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains At Ground Zero

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: Searchers recovered nine bone fragments that they believe to be human from the World Trade Center haul road along West Street yesterday. Four were found at the site and five others as material was being inspected at a sifting center in Brooklyn, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner. The bones ranged in size from one to four inches. Since September 2005, 990 human remains have been found around ground zero. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Search for Remains Ends With Ceremony

Medical Examiners Office.lead_paragraph: The city will mark the end of its efforts to recover human remains from the rubble of the World Trade Center today with a ceremony at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, where more than a million and a half tons of debris have been sifted for clues. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly are expected to speak at the ceremony, which is scheduled for 9:30 a.m.

headline.main: Developer Secures Funds to Build 3 WTC
headline.print_headline: Developer Secures Funds to Build 3 WTC

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Developer Larry Silverstein has secured the funds to build his long-planned 3 World Trade Center.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arguing Over 9/11 Insurance

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, suffered a legal setback this week in his attempt to recover more than $7 billion in insurance for the Sept. 11 terror attack. Mr. Silverstein has argued that he is entitled to two $3.6 billion payments for two separate attacks on the two buildings; the insurers argue it was one attack. But a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that employees at Willis, Mr. Silverstein's insurance broker, must testify about conversations last fall with Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. The insurers suspect that Mr. Silverstein and the broker initially considered the destruction a single event for insurance purposes. Lawyers for Swiss Re, one of the insurance companies, could start deposing Willis brokers next week. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

headline.main: Insurance Battle Escalates

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The World Trade Center's largest insurer said yesterday that a demand for an immediate payment by the developer who holds the lease to the complex was signaling his decision not to rebuild. Lawyers for the insurer, the SR International Business Insurance Company, an affiliate of the Swiss Reinsurance Company, known as Swiss Re, made that argument in a letter to lawyers for the developer, Larry A. Silverstein.

headline.main: Holder of Trade Center Lease Settles With Two Insurers

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The holder of the lease to the World Trade Center complex, Larry A. Silverstein, announced yesterday that he had settled a dispute with two of the companies insuring the complex. Under the terms of the settlement, one insurer, Ace Bermuda Insurance Ltd., will pay $298 million and the other, XL Insurance Ltd., also of Bermuda, will pay $67 million.

headline.main: Silverstein Properties Places Its Trade Center Losses at $8.2 Billion

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties, the real estate company that controls the lease on the World Trade Center site, said yesterday that its losses related to the Sept. 11 attack on the trade center totaled $8.2 billion. The figures include an estimated cash value of $5.7 billion for the twin towers, buildings 4 and 5 and the retail property at the site. Previously, Silverstein had estimated that the cash value of the properties was $6.5 billion. That amount was corrected to reflect the value of tenant improvements and estimates of depreciation on the destroyed properties.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Loan Is Paid Off

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the developer Larry A. Silverstein used $702 million in insurance proceeds from the World Trade Center complex yesterday to pay off a lender and the company that operated the retail mall at the complex. In what he said was an effort to ease the rebuilding process, Mr. Silverstein paid GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation $562 million to satisfy the loan he took out when he leased the trade center in 2001. The Port Authority simultaneously paid Westfield America $140 million for its retail interest in the trade center. The deal allowed Mr. Silverstein to get back most of the $125 million in equity he and his partners put into the winning bid for the trade center leases. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Settlement In Trade Center Dispute

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties settled a long-running dispute yesterday that had threatened to hold up the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. Under the terms of the agreement, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will spend $563 million to buy out the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation, Silverstein's lender in the company's 2001 winning bid for control of the trade center. In a statement, Larry A. Silverstein, the president and chief executive of Silverstein Properties, said he was ''pleased that we have reached a full agreement with the Port Authority on terms for repaying GMAC.'' The authority will also buy out Westfield America, the Australia-based mall operator that held the retail leases at the trade center, for $140 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mediation Ordered In Trade Center Suit

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A justice in State Supreme Court ordered mediation yesterday in the dispute between Larry A. Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, and Daniel Libeskind, left, the site's master planner, who filed a lawsuit last week claiming that Mr. Silverstein owes him more than $843,000 in architectural fees. Justice Karla Moskowitz issued the order at the request of Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. Edward W. Hayes, a lawyer for Mr. Libeskind, had said that mediation would not be fruitful. Both parties were directed to return to court on Oct. 14.

headline.main: Towers' Insurers Argue Payment to Leaseholder

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The insurance companies that stand to lose the most from the disaster at the World Trade Center are forming a united front in their legal battle over whether the World Trade Center's leaseholder is entitled to payment for one attack or two, one of the biggest insurers said yesterday. The big insurance company, Swiss Re, made its assertions yesterday in a statement about the insurance payout on the trade center. The leaseholder, Larry A. Silverstein, has said repeatedly that the disaster involved two attacks, and that he is therefore owed $7.2 billion in insurance payments. The more than 20 insurance companies involved have said that there was one attack and therefore that they are obligated to pay only half that, or $3.6 billion.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Progress In Rebuilding Dispute

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The Silverstein Organization said yesterday that it was making progress in settling a dispute that had hobbled the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. The developer, which controls the commercial lease at the site, told a state judge that it had reached a tentative agreement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to buy out Silverstein's lender, the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation. GMAC had sued Silverstein over its loan and the developer's handling of the insurance proceeds. To settle the suit, the developer, headed by Larry Silverstein, has sought approval from the Port Authority, which owns the site, for a GMAC buyout, for $570 million. The Port Authority is also buying out Westfield America, the mall operator that had the retail leases at the trade center, for $140 million. Justice Herman Cahn of State Supreme Court ordered Silverstein and GMAC to return to court tomorrow for a hearing. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Owner Settles Suit

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, who controls the lease at the World Trade Center, and Daniel Libeskind, the site's master planner, settled their bitter financial dispute yesterday, with Mr. Silverstein agreeing to pay the architect's firm $370,000 for its work on the Freedom Tower. The long-simmering rift became public in July when Mr. Libeskind filed a lawsuit claiming that he was owed $843,750 in fees. Mr. Silverstein's spokesman said that the architect had already been paid ''many millions of dollars for his work'' and was unable to provide any documentation to justify additional payment. Justice Karla Moskowitz of State Supreme Court then sent the two sides to a mediator. In a statement issued yesterday, Mr. Libeskind and Mr. Silverstein said they expected to cooperate on refining the master plan. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dutch Bank At 7 World Trade

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties announced yesterday that ABN Amro, an international bank based in the Netherlands, had signed a 15-year lease for three and a half floors at Silverstein's 7 World Trade Center tower, opposite ground zero. The bank will move about 500 employees there from Midtown in late 2007 or early 2008. It is the second-largest tenant so far, after Moody's Investors Service, in the 52-story building. The terms were not disclosed. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Leaseholder Loses Court Fight

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: Larry Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, lost his bid to reverse an appeals court ruling that the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the twin towers did not entitle him to a $7 billion insurance payment. The three-judge appellate panel that issued the ruling in September denied his petition for a rehearing. Mr. Silverstein had made the request on the ground that the panel misinterpreted New York law when it found that a policy issued by the Travelers Indemnity Company did not require that the two plane crashes be seen as separate events, each requiring a loss payment of $3.55 billion.

headline.main: First of Two Possible Trials Is Set In Trade Center Insurance Case

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The multibillion-dollar battle over insurance claims at the World Trade Center will be decided during two separate trials, Judge John S. Martin of United States District Court ruled Thursday. First, a jury trial scheduled to begin on Nov. 4 will determine whether the attack on the trade center last September represented two separate occurrences, entitling Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who had leased the huge complex, to a double payment totaling about $7 billion. Mr. Silverstein would get only half that amount if a jury determines that the attack was a single event.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Trade Center Insurers Yield

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The developer Larry A. Silverstein, at left, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey won a victory in their campaign to rebuild ground zero when two insurers effectively agreed to pay more than $100 million for construction at the World Trade Center site. The two companies -- Zurich American Insurance and Wausau -- were among seven insurers sued in June by Mr. Silverstein and the Port Authority after they indicated that they might not pay full coverage because of a new rebuilding plan at ground zero. Zurich and Wausau agreed to withdraw their objections last weekend, after Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Senator Charles E. Schumer and other politicians publicly and privately urged the insurers to pay what they owe and let the rebuilding go forward. The five remaining insurers, including Allianz, are obligated to provide a total of $1.36 billion, according to Silverstein Properties. ''Clearly, the pressure from elected officials is paying off,'' Janno Lieber, the World Trade Center project director for Silverstein Properties, said yesterday. CHARLES V. BAGLI (NYT)

headline.main: Lender Sues Trade Center Leaseholder Over Insurance Money

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: One of the lenders to Larry A. Silverstein, who holds the lease on the World Trade Center site, has filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Silverstein's companies of misallocating insurance money paid out after the Sept. 11 attack. In a complaint filed on Monday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, the lender, GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation, asserts that Mr. Silverstein has used some insurance money to pay lobbyists in Albany and in Washington to try to limit his liability to the victims of the attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Court Upholds Trade Center Insurance Verdicts

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court yesterday upheld jury verdicts requiring insurance companies to pay the developer Larry A. Silverstein an extra $1.1 billion to rebuild the World Trade Center complex. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit said it found no error that would require it to set aside the verdicts. Mr. Silverstein, who had insured the twin towers for $3.5 billion, had sought to recover twice that amount, arguing that there were two attacks. In one trial that ended in April 2004, a federal jury found that most of the insurers, holding more than $1.8 billion of the policy, were bound by a form that defined the destruction of the twin towers as a single event. In a second trial, which ended in December 2004, another jury concluded that nine insurance companies were bound by insurance form language that defined the destruction as two events. That verdict meant that Mr. Silverstein will get $1.1 billion, on top of his $3.5 billion, to rebuild.

headline.main: Trade Towers Leaseholder Sues Insurers
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REAL ESTATE

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The battle over insurance coverage of the World Trade Center took another twist yesterday when Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who won the lease of the trade center in July, sued Ace Bermuda Insurance Ltd. and XL Insurance Ltd., two Bermuda companies that covered the complex. The suit seeks to compel them to litigate any dispute over payments in federal court in Manhattan. According to Mr. Silverstein's suit, filed in federal court in Manhattan, the two companies are trying to have any dispute over the amount they owe decided by a private arbitration panel in London rather than by a United States court. Mr. Silverstein, through his lawyers at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, contends that recently passed federal legislation makes Manhattan's federal courthouse the exclusive forum for resolving claims related to the Sept. 11 attacks, regardless of the language of any contract in particular. The location of legal proceedings is important because Mr. Silverstein may receive a more favorable hearing in New York, and because a decision there would most likely bind several or all the insurance firms involved.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arbitration For Trade Center Dispute

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday ordered the developer Larry A. Silverstein and his insurers to arbitration on Nov. 6 to try to settle their battle over billions of dollars in insurance proceeds for rebuilding at the World Trade Center site. If the process fails, Judge Michael B. Mukasey said, the first of what could be three successive trials will begin in February. Mr. Silverstein's lawyer, Herbert M. Wachtell, expressed reservations about the proposed arbitrator, John S. Martin, a retired federal judge. He said Mr. Martin was a friend of his but had ruled against Mr. Silverstein in earlier stages of the case. But Mr. Wachtell agreed to the choice when Judge Mukasey said that ''you couldn't conceivably have anyone better to mediate this case.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: 9/11 Payment Issues Are Argued in Appeal

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A small army of lawyers took the long-running battle over insurance claims at the World Trade Center to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday as they argued over issues that will determine how much money is available for rebuilding the vast commercial complex. Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who controls the World Trade Center lease, has argued that he is entitled to a double payment of nearly $7 billion because two planes hit two towers in what he describes as two separate ''occurrences'' on Sept. 11.

headline.main: Setback on Insurance for Trade Center Developer

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday rejected a request by Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, to rule immediately on his insurance claim that the destruction of the twin towers amounted to two events, requiring a $7 billion payment. The ruling ensures that unless there is a settlement, the multibillion-dollar battle over the insurance proceeds will go to trial.

headline.seo: Talks Remain Stalled for World Trade Center Redevelopment Plan
headline.main: Ground Zero Talks Still Stalled
headline.print_headline: Ground Zero Talks Still Stalled

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: A deadline passed without an agreement on the construction of office towers at the World Trade Center site. Discussion will continue through the weekend.

headline.main: Trade Center Leaseholder Sues a Big Reinsurer
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FINE PRINT

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The real estate developer who holds the World Trade Center lease fired back at one of the complex's biggest insurers yesterday, filing a lawsuit demanding that the insurer promptly pay its share of the coverage -- even while litigation continues to determine how much the insurers are liable for. A larger dispute turns on the question of whether the attacks on the twin towers were a single event covered for $3.6 billion, as the insurer asserts, or two events representing a claim of $7.2 million.

headline.main: Settlement Offers Are Due on Trade Center Losses

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: In the most significant moment yet in the insurance battle over the World Trade Center, lawyers for Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, and Swiss Re, the lead insurer, are to make settlement offers to a federal judge in Manhattan tomorrow. While they remain as much as $5 billion apart in their assessments of the compensation owed, both parties, in recent days, have proclaimed a desire to settle the dispute. If they agree on an amount, it will determine how much money Mr. Silverstein will have to rebuild the trade center and, more broadly, how much influence he will have over the future of the site and the character of much of Lower Manhattan.

headline.seo: Port Authority Rejects More Public Financing for Silverstein at Trade Center
headline.main: Trade Center Developer and Port Authority at Odds Again
headline.print_headline: Trade Center Developer and Port Authority at Odds Again

Larry Silverstein.lead_paragraph: The agency wants Larry A. Silverstein to find more financing on his own to build skyscrapers at the site of the World Trade Center.

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Journalists Face Fines For Crossings

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Journalists looking to test United States border security are also trying the patience of the Border Patrol. Two television reporters were caught trying to cross into the United States from Canada at East Franklin, Vt., which is not an official crossing point. The authorities say this is the sixth time since Sept. 11 that journalists sneaked across the border to check on security, wasting the time of Border Patrol and Customs agents. The two television reporters face civil fines of $5,000. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

headline.main: Johnson to Visit Border Facilities in Arizona
headline.print_headline: Johnson to Visit Border Facilities in Arizona

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Jeh (Jay) Johnson is traveling to Arizona to tour Border Patrol facilities amid the ongoing crush of immigrant children and families from Central America.

headline.main: Homeland Security Awards Contact for Border Towers
headline.print_headline: Homeland Security Awards Contact for Border Towers

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The Homeland Security Department has awarded a $145 million contract for a series of border security towers to be built along the Mexican border in Arizona.

headline.seo: Immigrants on Trains Near Northern Border Detained
headline.main: Border Sweeps in North Reach Miles Into U.S.
headline.sub: Asks for Citizenship and Immigration Papers
headline.print_headline: Border Sweeps In North Reach Miles Into U.S.

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of passengers are taken into detention each year from domestic trains and buses along the nation’s northern border.

headline.main: Elbit Systems Wins Homeland Security Contract
headline.print_headline: Elbit Systems Wins Homeland Security Contract

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Israeli defense electronics company Elbit Systems said the U.S. Department of Homeland Security Customs and Border Protection (CBP) awarded its subsidiary a contract to deploy border surveillance technology in southern Arizona.

headline.main: DHS Details Aid Being Given to Immigrant Children
headline.print_headline: DHS Details Aid Being Given to Immigrant Children

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Jeh (jay) Johnson says the government is giving humanitarian aid to immigrant children caught trying to cross the Southern border illegally without their parents. But he says it's dangerous for families to send their children unaccompanied to America.

headline.main: Shootings by Agents Increase Border Tensions
headline.print_headline: Shootings by Agents Increase Border Tensions

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The killings of at least 15 people by United States Border Patrol agents have spurred criticism of the agency, which some say lacks oversight and accountability.

headline.main: As Shutdown Looms, Agencies Brace for Its Impact
headline.print_headline: Closing Parks, Feeding Tigers And Deciding Who’s Essential

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: A government shutdown can mean a host of changes for the country, from a shuttered Smithsonian to an Internal Revenue Service that stops issuing refund checks.

headline.main: Gov't Arrests 192 on Immigrant Smuggling Charges
headline.print_headline: Gov't Arrests 192 on Immigrant Smuggling Charges

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The Homeland Security Department said Tuesday it arrested 192 people along the Mexican border in South Texas on immigrant-smuggling charges and seized more than $625,000, part of the Obama administration's efforts to discourage and disrupt the flood of tens of thousands of people crossing the border illegally.

headline.main: Border Agency Replaces Head of Internal Affairs

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The agency replaced James F. Tomsheck, citing an effort to strengthen investigations, particularly into episodes involving shootings and other use of force by border agents.

headline.main: Mexican Helicopter Fired Shots in Arizona Near Border, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: Mexican Helicopter Fired Shots in Arizona Near Border, U.S. Says

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: U.S. authorities are investigating after two shots were fired from a Mexican law enforcement helicopter when it crossed the border into Arizona, although no injuries or damage to U.S. property were reported, the U.S. Border Patrol said on Friday.

headline.main: TIGHTER BORDER DELAYS RE-ENTRY BY U.S. CITIZENS

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: United States border agents have stepped up scrutiny of Americans returning home from Mexico, slowing commerce and creating delays at border crossings not seen since the months after the Sept. 11 attacks. The increased enforcement is in part a dress rehearsal for new rules, scheduled to take effect in January, that will require Americans to show a passport or other proof of citizenship to enter the United States. The requirements were approved by Congress as part of antiterrorism legislation in 2004.

headline.seo: Border Fence Raises Cost Questions
headline.main: Some Cheer Border Fence as Others Ponder the Cost
headline.print_headline: Some Cheer Border Fence As Others Ponder the Cost

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Questions of practicality and effectiveness are raised as Republican candidates call for a longer or higher border fence.

headline.main: U.S. Denies Plan for Civilian Border Patrol

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: One day after its top border enforcement official said he was exploring the idea, the Department of Homeland Security announced Thursday that it had no plans to enlist civilian volunteers to help patrol the nation's borders. On Wednesday, the official, Robert C. Bonner, commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection, told The Associated Press that the agency was considering the training of volunteers to create ''something akin to a Border Patrol auxiliary.''

headline.main: Homeland Security Drones Resume Flying After Crash
headline.print_headline: Homeland Security Drones Resume Flying After Crash

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The Homeland Security Department is back to flying drones along the country's borders more than a week after one crashed into the Pacific Ocean.

headline.main: Guatemala Police Nab 7 Alleged Migrant Smugglers
headline.print_headline: Guatemala Police Nab 7 Alleged Migrant Smugglers

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Guatemalan police have detained seven alleged migrant smugglers who were part of a network that reached to the Mexico-U.S. border.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Fewer Immigrants Captured

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Apprehensions of illegal immigrants crossing the border fell last year by 8 percent, the Department of Homeland Security said. The Border Patrol caught about 1.1 million illegal immigrants in the 2006 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, compared with about 1.2 million in the previous year, the department said. The lower number is a sign that tougher enforcement is deterring people from making the trip, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said.

headline.seo: India’s Industry Helps Open Door to World
