headline.print_headline: India’s Industry Helps Open Door to World

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: A trade foray into Pakistan showed the foreign policy role of India’s private sector, which the government relies on to serve as an intermediary.

headline.main: More Eyes Toward Canada

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The number of federal agents patrolling the northern border of the United States would triple to 7,689 from 2,563 under Attorney General John Ashcroft's antiterrorism legislation, which was drafted after the Sept. 11 attacks and is expected to pass in Congress this week. Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York said the provision would provide $609 million for new Customs, Border Patrol and Immigration and Naturalization Service personnel to patrol along the world's longest nonmilitarized boundary, between the United States and Canada.

headline.main: Border Agents in Texas Warned Not to Talk to Media
headline.print_headline: Border Agents in Texas Warned Not to Talk to Media

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: The surge in immigrant children caught crossing the southern border in Texas that has dominated headlines and risks becoming a political crisis for President Barack Obama and Congress includes a new threat facing Border Patrol agents: reporters.

headline.main: Pakistan Sends Troops to Border to Prevent bin Laden Escape

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers have been deployed on mountain peaks and in hidden valleys along the Afghan border in recent days in a bid to cut off escape routes for Osama bin Laden and his fighters from the remote enclave of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan, Pakistan military officials said today. The terrain in northwestern Pakistan across the border from Tora Bora, where some suspect that Mr. bin Laden is making a last stand, is rugged and inhospitable. Mountains top 15,000 feet and the few trails that exist are little more than ruts and donkey paths through the barren, arid landscape.

headline.main: North Korea Rents Out Its Resources to Stave Off Reform
headline.print_headline: North Korea Rents Out Its Resources to Stave Off Reform

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Pyongyang has leased piers to China and Russia, sold mining rights to the Chinese and built manufacturing outposts along the border, where China can hire cheap North Korean labor.

headline.main: North Korea Rents Out Its Resources to Stave Off Reform

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: SEOUL -- In September, under the flags of North Korea and China, North Korean workers began digging at Haesan, a hilly town near the Chinese border, kicking off one of several joint mining ventures. On Oct. 13, a Russian train chugged across the border to celebrate the restoration of a dilapidated Soviet-era rail link between the Russian city of Khasan and the North Korean town of Rajin. At Haesan, China acquires copper, one of the many abundant mineral reserves lying next door waiting to be exploited. At Rajin, Russia wins access to an ice-free port to export Siberian coal and take in Asian goods it wants to transport to Europe. From both projects, the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, counts cash.

headline.seo: Homeland Security Sending More Agents to Fight Afghan Smuggling
headline.main: U.S. Stepping Up Fight on Afghan Smuggling
headline.print_headline: U.S. Stepping Up Fight on Afghan Smuggling

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said that her department planned to triple the number of agents in Afghanistan to curb smuggling.

headline.main: Delays Are Rare at U.S. Borders

Border Crossings.lead_paragraph: Heightened border security was widely expected to crimp the huge flow of goods back and forth across the United States' borders with Canada and Mexico when the war in Iraq began, just as it caused bottlenecks, delays and headaches after the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. But except for the first day or two, the opposite has happened. If anything, the border crossings are now smoother and more efficient than before the war.

headline.main: DHS Details Aid Being Given to Immigrant Children
headline.print_headline: DHS Details Aid Being Given to Immigrant Children

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Jeh (jay) Johnson says the government is giving humanitarian aid to immigrant children caught trying to cross the Southern border illegally without their parents. But he says it's dangerous for families to send their children unaccompanied to America.

headline.main: 4 Nations With Child Soldiers Keep U.S. Aid
headline.print_headline: 4 Nations With Child Soldiers Keep U.S. Aid

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is allowing military aid to continue to four countries, issuing a waiver of the 2008 law, the Child Soldiers Prevention Act.

headline.main: Travel Advisory; Airlines Impose Curbs On Children Alone

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Children age 11 and younger can no longer fly unaccompanied on most major domestic airline flights that require a connection, even if the connection is on the same carrier. The new rules were adopted by most airlines following the Sept. 11 hijacking and destruction of four jetliners. ''The limitations are a precaution due to the uncertainty of flight schedules,'' said Al Becker, an American Airlines spokesman. ''All other rules and guidelines regarding travel by unaccompanied minors still apply.''

headline.main: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: And now, people must all carry on with jobs that will never be quite the same. Here are first-person accounts of how seven Americans coped in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks. Resilient Children Rise Over Chaos Last spring the school formed a crisis response team and went through training, but nothing prepared us for this.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Ban On Osama and Saddam Names Rejected

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: The Parliament rejected a bill that would have allowed the government to prevent parents from naming their children Osama bin Laden or Saddam Hussein and any other name it deemed ''harmful to public order.'' It was the second time the government had tried to pass the measure. ''Only the parents have the right to name their newborns and nobody else,'' one lawmaker said.

headline.main: Manhattan: Asthma Linked To Trade Center

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Children who inhaled dust from the collapsed World Trade Center may be twice as likely to develop asthma as children who were not exposed, according to preliminary findings released yesterday by the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The department based the observation on self-reported symptoms from the World Trade Center Health Registry's initial survey, which was conducted in 2003 and 2004. Health officials said about 6 percent of the 3,100 children under 18 who are enrolled in the study received a new asthma diagnosis after 9/11. The asthma rate for children under 5 who were directly exposed to the dust cloud was even higher -- possibly three times the rate for the same age group across the Northeast, officials said. But they cautioned that it was too early to tell whether the increase is due to exposure, better detection or the tendency of parents of children with asthma symptoms to join the registry. A follow-up survey is under way.

headline.main: Parents Are Navigating an Emotional Tightrope Over How Much or How Little to Say

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: From New York, where the nightmare of the terrorist attacks was inescapable, to small towns, where the burning buildings and the grim search for bodies could seem so remote as to be unreal, parents have been trying to cope with the question of what, and how much, to tell their children. Should they insist on discussing the events? Should they reassure their children? Should they show their own fears? Some turned to pediatricians, others to psychologists, others to religious leaders or school systems. And others have been trying to muddle through on their own common sense.

headline.seo: Cyberbullying: What Parents Can Do
headline.main: A Range of Options for a Victim’s Parents
headline.print_headline: A Range of Options for a Victim’s Parents

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Suggestions for parents whose child becomes entangled in an online conflict.

headline.main: 100,000 Parents of Citizens Were Deported Over 10 Years

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Of nearly 2.2 million immigrants deported in the decade ended 2007, more than 100,000 were the parents of children who, having been born in the United States, were American citizens, according to a report issued Friday by the Department of Homeland Security. But the department lacks data that might have addressed questions left unanswered by the report, like the number of American children who were left behind in the United States or, alternatively, exited the country with their deported parents. Nor could the report say in how many instances both parents of such children were deported.

headline.main: From an Illness, a Calling

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: MY father practiced law in our hometown, Maplewood, N.J., and my mother took care of our family of six children. I was the fifth child, probably destined to follow my father into the legal profession. But at 13, I found a lump on my neck. At first, the doctors thought it was mumps or maybe a tooth infection , but after a biopsy , Hodgkin's disease was diagnosed.In those days, parents consulted with doctors behind closed doors, and no one told me anything. I could feel the fear around me and thought I was dying. Then, in 1968, as I was being readied for tumor removal surgery, I overheard the nurse say it was Stage 4 Hodgkin's. I had no idea what that meant, but when I returned home from the hospital, I looked it up in our encyclopedia.

headline.main: On the Lookout For High Anxiety

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: THE image is frozen in her mind. A 12-year-old girl who witnessed one of the planes hitting the World Trade Center still sees it as a vivid picture. She can remember the expressions on people's faces, the color of the sky and the sounds of people crying and screaming. The memory replays constantly. An 8-year-old boy who, before Sept. 11, had trouble sleeping in his own room because he feared robbers would come in, now also fears that planes will crash into his bedroom windows. Some nights, he imagines he hears them flying, frighteningly close, toward his house.

headline.main: Parents of Mentally Ill Children Trade Custody for Care

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: For the parents of some severely mentally ill children, it can come to this: pleading with emergency-room psychiatrists who have no good answers. Listening grimly as caseworkers explain their lack of options. Appearing tearfully before family court judges as they take what they regard as a last desperate step in pursuit of medical care. What these mothers and fathers are being urged to do is agonizing: give up custody of their children and turn them over to New York State's child welfare agencies so that they can get the mental health care that they otherwise cannot afford or gain access to.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bikers Raise Money For Charity

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: American flags flying from their motorcycles, more than 1,000 bikers fanned out from Lower Manhattan on Saturday in an unusual memorial for those lost on Sept. 11. The Ground Zero Independence Day Ride, a trek of more than 100 miles to Woodstock, N.Y., raised money for Tuesday's Children, which offers counseling, mentoring and weekly outings to children who lost a parent in the terror attack. Most of the 1,000 registered riders, who contributed more than $50,000 by each paying a $50 entrance fee, were workers who helped in the recovery effort. Jason Begay (NYT)

headline.main: Anguish for Vast Toll of Children Left Behind

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: From the Cantor Fitzgerald bond- trading firm alone, the estimate is staggering: 1,500. Not the number of victims. The children they left behind.

headline.main: Official Says Obama to Seek $2B for Border Control
headline.print_headline: Official Says Obama to Seek $2B for Border Control

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama is seeking more than $2 billion to respond to the flood of immigrants illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border and asking for new powers to deal with returning immigrant children apprehended while traveling without their parents.

headline.main: Thousands Of Orphans? An Urban Myth

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: The calls came in a torrent, from White Bear Lake, Minn., and Castaic, Calif., from Emporia, Kan., and Boucherville, Quebec. There was even an e-mail letter from a family in Argentina. All were eagerly offering to adopt a World Trade Center orphan. For weeks after the terrorist attacks, secretaries at the New York State Office of Children and Family Services and press officers at the city's Administration for Children's Services could hardly answer the telephone without hearing from people who had read news of the ''many,'' ''hundreds,'' even ''thousands'' of orphans left in need of a home by the Sept. 11 disaster.

headline.seo: A 9/11 Widow Balances Her Family, a Job and Islam
headline.main: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
headline.print_headline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Hadidjatou Karamoko Traoré is a 9/11 widow who has had to balance an overnight job, three children and her Muslim faith.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: College Aid Proposed For Terror Victims

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Gov. John G. Rowland proposed yesterday that free college education at a state school be provided to Connecticut children who lost a parent or guardian in last week's terrorist attacks. Details have not been worked out, but Mr. Rowland's aides said the plan was likely to be submitted to the General Assembly in February.

headline.seo: Court’s Leniency Ruling Is Too Late for Deportees
headline.main: For Those Deported, Court Rulings Come Too Late
headline.print_headline: For Those Already Deported, Court Rulings Come Too Late

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: A ruling that the government was wrong to eject legal immigrants for minor offenses probably won’t help those already deported.

headline.main: After the Hurricanes, the Inner Storm for Children

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Once the water recedes, mud is hauled away and families are reunited with those who survived Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, most of the displaced residents will be focused on finding new places to live and work. But it will be equally important to pay attention to the effects of these vast disruptions on the mental health of children whose lives were torn apart. In an almost prophetic coincidence, in the September issue of the journal Pediatrics, experts from the American Academy of Pediatrics published a 10-page report to help pediatricians deal with the psychosocial effects of traumatic events -- natural disasters and acts of terrorism -- on children of all ages.

headline.main: P.S. 234's Reopening Is Shifted to February

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: The Board of Education has pushed back its early January deadline for opening Public School 234, one of the schools near the World Trade Center disaster site, to Feb. 1, parents of children at the school said. The board reached an agreement yesterday with representatives of the parents, who felt that their children needed more time to prepare psychologically for the return to their school. Two spokespeople involved in the decision did not return calls last night.

headline.main: The Sandwich Generation Takes a New Gulp

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: MY generation is one of labels. Around my parents' house, we were called brats, then baby boomers. A few years ago, we became the sandwich generation, because we took care of our young children while assisting our elderly parents. Well, now it's time for another label, because our adult children, out of work and broke, are moving back home. How about the Dagwood sandwich generation?

headline.main: Scientists Square Off on Evolutionary Value of Helping Relatives
headline.print_headline: Scientists Square Off on Evolutionary Value of Helping Relatives

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: A team of prominent evolutionary biologists at Harvard is trying to demolish the theory that helping your relatives can spread your genes faster than having children of your own.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Tuition For Terror Victim Kin

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Children of New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks can attend college tuition-free, under a $500,000 program financed by state and private funds. Gov. James E. McGreevey issued an executive order on Tuesday retroactive to the fall 2001 semester. The order applies to public and private colleges in and outside of New Jersey, and any tuition paid since then will be reimbursed, said Paul Aronsohn, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey. At least 15 children of New Jersey victims are enrolled in college, and the World Trade Center Scholarship Fund is also available to victims' children not yet college age, Mr. Aronsohn said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline.main: Shift of Care For Immigrant Children Alone

Children and Families.lead_paragraph: Tucked into the Homeland Security Department bill that President Bush signed into law on Monday is a measure transferring authority for immigrant children who enter the country without any adult relative or guardian to the Department of Health and Human Services. They had been the responsibility of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Legal groups and immigration advocates have welcomed the shift, saying it will improve services for the children, including their access to the nation's foster care system.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; SECURITY FORCE

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The senior United Nations official for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, added his voice to those of Afghan leaders in appealing for an expanded international security force. The United States and the countries providing the bulk of the force -- Britain, France and Germany -- have all resisted calls to expand the 4,500-member unit beyond Kabul. Instead, they have pressed for an Afghan Army and police force. Serge Schmemann (NYT)

headline.main: KING PLANS TO RETURN

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The former king, Mohammed Zahir Shah, plans to return to Kabul around March 21 and plans to stay in his homeland, said his personal physician, Dr. Zalmai Rasul. Zahir Shah, 87, is seen as a possibly major unifying force in Afghanistan after decades of fighting by rival factions and the overthrow of the Taliban.

headline.print_headline: Assassination In Afghanistan Creates a Void

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: A family associate shot Ahmed Wali Karzai, a provincial council chairman, at close range, friends said.

headline.main: Ex-Afghan King Returning to Kabul This Week

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The chief spokesman for Hamid Karzai, the interim ruler of Afghanistan, said today that Mr. Karzai would travel to Rome on Tuesday to accompany the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, on his return to the country. When the two return, on Wednesday or Thursday, it will be the first time the king has set foot in Afghanistan since 1973, when he was deposed by his cousin. In the years since, Afghanistan has been devastated by foreign invasion, factional fighting, religious fanaticism and, most recently, the war to drive out the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; AFGHAN WARLORD

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The Afghan warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar has left exile in Iran to return home, his spokesman in Pakistan said, raising the likelihood of a new threat to Afghanistan's interim government. Iran told Mr. Hekmatyar to leave after he called the new Afghan government a puppet regime and said he had fighters inside Afghanistan ready to expel foreign troops there.

headline.main: PEACE TALKS FOR CLANS

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The leaders of two Afghan tribal factions battling for control of Gardez, in the east, have gone to Kabul at the request of the government for peace talks. Fifty fighters were killed when forces from the different clans attacked last week, raising questions about the ability of the government to impose its authority. It was not immediately known when their talks in Kabul might begin. For now, a cease-fire is holding.

headline.print_headline: An Inflammatory Video Multiplies American Difficulties in Afghanistan

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: A video of four Marines urinating on dead Taliban fighters is likely to weaken the United States’ position both with the Taliban and with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; THE KING

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: Mohammad Zahir Shah, 87, underwent a medical checkup at a Rome hospital and was pronounced in good health as he prepares to return to Afghanistan next month after nearly 30 years in exile, his family said. Zahir, who was ousted in a coup in 1973, is seen as a unifying figure among the country's various ethnic groups.

headline.main: WORDS FROM EXILED KING

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: Mohammed Zahir Shah, the exiled king of Afghanistan, denounced the American-led military campaign in his country, as ''stupid and useless'' in an interview with the Italian daily La Stampa. King Zahir, 87, who is to return in two weeks for a meeting of tribal elders to decide Afghanistan's future, said the campaign should be called off.

headline.main: FROZEN ASSETS RELEASED

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration authorized the release of $25.5 million to cash-starved Afghanistan in assets frozen while the country was ruled by the Taliban militia. The latest assets ordered unblocked belong to the Afghan Export Promotion Bank, Bank Millie and its subsidiaries, Afghan House and Afghan Trading.

headline.seo: Afghanistan Intensifies Criticism of Pakistan

headline.print_headline: Afghanistan Uses News About Bin Laden to Intensify Its Criticism of Pakistan

headline.main: Troops Kill Man Linked To Al Qaeda And Attacks

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- A combined Afghan and coalition force killed a suspected insurgent leader in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said on Saturday. The man was believed to be a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who at one time was accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape from Tora Bora after the fall of the Taliban. NATO officials could not confirm whether the man who was killed, whom they identified as Sabar Lal, was the same man as Sabar Lal Melma, who was released from Guantánamo in 2007 after five years. But a tribal elder from Kunar Province told CNN that the man who had been killed was the former prisoner.

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: A British Army general said today that he had arrived in Kabul to discuss the size and composition of an international peacekeeping force, even as Afghan leaders have voiced doubts about the need for the troops. Maj. Gen. John McColl arrived at Bagram air base on Saturday night, met today with Hamid Karzai, the provisional leader, and was expected to see the man chosen to be defense minister, Muhammad Fahim, and the one picked for foreign minister, Abdullah Abdullah, on Monday.

headline.main: New Pentagon Chief Says Qaeda Defeat in Reach

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta, who arrived in Kabul on Saturday, said the United States was ''within reach of strategically defeating Al Qaeda'' and that the American focus had narrowed to capturing or killing 10 to 20 crucial leaders of the terrorist group in Pakistan, Somalia and Yemen. Mr. Panetta, who took over as defense secretary from Robert M. Gates on July 1, made his comments aboard his plane before arriving on an unannounced trip to Afghanistan.

headline.main: U.S. Is Gaining In Afghanistan, General Writes In Upbeat Letter

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Just hours before President Obama gave his State of the Union address, his commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David H. Petraeus, offered what amounted to his own ''state of the war'' address, one noticeably more upbeat than a White House assessment issued late last year. The general's assessment, in the form of a letter to troops posted on the NATO Web site, outlined a fight in which troops and the military machine here had gained the edge or was on the cusp of doing so on every front. He described victory as attainable only through a vast, coordinated effort to bring Afghanistan security, good governance and economic development.

headline.main: Quest to Neutralize Afghan Militants Is Showing Glimpses of Success, NATO Says
headline.print_headline: Quest to Neutralize Afghan Militants Is Showing Glimpses of Success, NATO Says

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: About 130 important insurgent figures have been captured or killed in Afghanistan over the past 120 days, according to NATO military statistics.

headline.main: British in Accord With Afghans On Force to Keep Order in Kabul

Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: After a week of intense negotiations, Afghan and British officials agreed that fewer than 100 British marines would be deployed in Kabul before a new interim government took power on Saturday, Western diplomats said tonight. The marines will serve as the vanguard of an international security force that will expand to between 2,000 and 4,000 troops in the next several weeks.

headline.seo: Afghan Peace Talks End With Plea to All Combatants

headline.main: An Olympics Vigil, From 30,000 Feet
headline.kicker: ROYAL AIR FORCE STATION NORTHOLT JOURNAL

Air Force.lead_paragraph: ROYAL AIR FORCE STATION NORTHOLT, England -- More than 70 years after squadrons of Spitfire and Hurricane fighters flew from here into an epic air battle with Hitler's Luftwaffe, pilots flying the fastest fighter interceptors in Britain's modern arsenal have been cast in a similar role. But instead of waves of German bombers in the Battle of Britain, these pilots are guarding against a more elusive enemy: terrorists who might seek to rain destruction on the Olympic Games from the air. While the pilots are loath to talk about the threat, officials acknowledge that they have prepared for a nightmare situation in which terrorists hijack an airliner or executive jet and try to fly it into the 80,000-seat Olympic Stadium or one of the other 30 or more spectator-packed sites around the capital. The specter of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on New York and Washington hangs over the operation, and the lessons learned from those attacks are central to the planning of the mission here.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Lesser Charges In Bombing

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The Air Force dropped manslaughter and assault charges against one of its pilots and said he would face trial at Barksdale Air Force Base on dereliction-of-duty charges for mistakenly bombing Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan last year, killing four. The pilot, Maj. Harry Schmidt, 37, could get six months in prison if convicted. Major Schmidt, left, and a fellow National Guard pilot, Maj. William Umbach, the mission commander, bombed the Canadians on April 17, 2002, from their F-16's, saying they thought they were under attack by Taliban forces. Charges were dropped last week against Major Umbach, 44, a United Airlines pilot.

headline.main: Investigators Named In Canadian Deaths

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Brig. Gen. Stephen T. Sargeant of the Air Force and Brig. Gen. Marc Dumais of Canada will lead an inquiry into why an Air National Guard F-16 pilot who thought he was under attack mistakenly bombed Canadian troops in Afghanistan last week, the Pentagon said today. Four Canadians died. General Sargeant, an experienced F-16 pilot, is commander of the 56th Fighter Wing at Luke Air Force Base, Ariz. The investigation will be conducted in Kuwait.

headline.main: U.S. Air War Chief To Get Pentagon Job

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The Air Force general in charge of the American air war over Afghanistan will be leaving his command within the next few weeks to take up a high-ranking position at the Pentagon, a senior military official said tonight. Lt. Gen. Charles F. Wald, the head of American air forces assigned to the Middle East and Southwest Asia, is being promoted to deputy chief of staff for air and space operations. The position is one of the most coveted billets for a three-star general in the Air Force and has often been a stepping stone to a fourth star.

headline.main: Two Pilots Are Defended For Mistake In Bombing

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Two Air Force pilots whose bomb killed four Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan last spring did not know allied troops were there because of a communication breakdown that also kept their airborne commanders in the dark, defense lawyers said on Thursday. The Air Force has charged the two pilots, Majs. Harry Schmidt and William Umbach of the Illinois National Guard, with involuntary manslaughter, saying they should have known that the Canadians were conducting live-ammunition exercises that night.

headline.seo: U.S. Military Goes Online to Rebut Extremists
headline.main: U.S. Military Goes Online to Rebut Extremists’ Messages
headline.print_headline: U.S. Uses Cyberspace To Rebut Messages Posted by Extremists

Air Force.lead_paragraph: A team at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida is scanning the Web to counter radical ideology and explain American actions in the Middle East and Central Asia.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Arraignment For Translator Accused Of Spying

Air Force.lead_paragraph: An Air Force Arabic translator accused of spying at the Guantánamo Bay military prison camp was arraigned at Travis Air Force Base in a court-martial on espionage and other charges that could send him to prison for life. The translator, Senior Airman Ahmad I. al-Halabi, 24, is accused of trying to deliver messages from detainees at Guantánamo Bay to Syria. The government says he stored the messages on his laptop and planned to carry them overseas.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; U.S. PLANE CRASHES

Air Force.lead_paragraph: An Air Force MC-130 transport plane crashed in Afghanistan on Tuesday but all eight of its crew survived, a spokesman for the Central Command said. Officials said the crash apparently was not caused by enemy fire. Pentagon officials said the plane was on a mission at the time but declined to give details. The MC-130 typically flies night missions and is used to transport Special Operations troops, for search and rescue and to refuel helicopters. Thom Shanker (NYT)

headline.main: Air Force Reprimands General For Numerous Sexual Affairs

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The former chief military lawyer for the Air Force has been formally reprimanded for conduct unbecoming an officer because of improper relationships with more than a dozen women, the Air Force said on Wednesday. The officer, Maj. Gen. Thomas Fiscus, was given a formal reprimand and ordered to forfeit pay for unbecoming conduct, fraternization, obstruction of justice and violating a lawful general regulation, the Air Force said.

headline.main: NATO Planes to End Patrol of U.S. Skies

Air Force.lead_paragraph: NATO airborne-radar planes that have circled American skies since last fall will return to Europe this month, alliance and Pentagon officials said today. The arrival of the surveillance planes last October was the first time NATO forces had crossed the Atlantic to defend the United States. They freed Air Force Awacs for missions elsewhere, including near Afghanistan.

headline.main: New Power To Down Jets Is Last Resort, Rumsfeld Says

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that sufficient safeguards were in place to prevent Air Force fighter jets flying patrols over American cities from mistakenly shooting down a commercial airliner. Mr. Rumsfeld confirmed a report in The New York Times today that President Bush had authorized two midlevel Air Force generals to order hijacked passenger jets that threaten American cities shot down without checking first with him. The authority would be used only as a last resort if there was not enough time to consult with senior military officials or the president.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Suicide Pilot Flew Over Key Base

Air Force.lead_paragraph: A youngster who committed suicide by crashing into a Tampa office building nearly hit the control tower at an Air Force base with a nerve center for the Afghan war, according to the National Transportation Safety Board. The pilot, Charles Bishop, 15, of Palm Harbor, flew his stolen Cessna ''just a few feet'' over the control tower at MacDill Air Force Base on Jan. 5, the report by the board said. It did not speculate whether Mr. Bishop, who left a suicide note expressing admiration for Osama bin Laden, had intended the base as his target. The base is home to the Central Command, which has a crucial role in directing combat in Afghanistan. When a Coast Guard helicopter tried to force Mr. Bishop to land, he flew toward Tampa, the report said. Mr. Bishop slammed the four-seat plane into the 28th floor of the Bank of America Plaza. Nobody else was hurt.

headline.main: When a Plane Is as Good As a Flag

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Moss, which has set a standard for home design since it opened in 1994, is not ordinarily the place to buy conventional Americana. But after Sept. 11, Franklin Getchell, an owner, said he was eager to find something for the ''sophisticated patriot.'' Murray Moss, the other owner, found the 18-inch scale model of Air Force One, and the store has sold more than 40 planes in the last two and a half weeks. The Boeing VC-137, above, was retired in 1998; the new VC-25A Air Force One is also available. $120 at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

headline.main: 3 Counts Against Translator Are Dropped

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The Air Force has dropped three counts in an espionage case against a Syrian-born airman who worked as a translator at the prison camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The lawyer for Senior Airman Ahmad I. al-Halabi, Donald G. Rehkopf Jr., said on Saturday that once those charges were removed, ''simply the gut of the case was gone.''

headline.main: U.S. Is Using More Drones, Despite Concern Over Flaws

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The Air Force is moving rapidly to send more unpiloted surveillance aircraft to Afghanistan, even as the Pentagon's chief tester has raised questions about their ability to operate at night, in bad weather and over long periods of time. The aircraft, known as the RQ-1 Predator, has been widely praised by military commanders as a highly effective, relatively inexpensive and risk-free means of spying on enemies and pinpointing targets. The Air Force maintains that within months, the Predator will be able to replace many of the Special Operations forces that are now helping guide American fighter jets toward targets in Afghanistan.

headline.main: Leadership That Blends Assortment Of Skills

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Lt. Gen. Charles F. Wald is not only a veteran combat pilot with 3,200 flying hours under his belt, but he is also an experienced Pentagon planner who was the military's most visible public spokesman in the Clinton administration air campaign in Kosovo in 1999. As such, General Wald, commander of the Ninth Air Force and Central Command Air Forces at Shaw Air Force Base in Sumter, S.C., brings a combination of practical, political and public relations skills to the job of overseeing the air component of the Bush administration's coming campaign against terrorism.

headline.main: Nation's Memorial to Air Force Stretches Toward Space

Air Force.lead_paragraph: From a promontory high above the Pentagon, three arching spires reach skyward, their elongated tips pointing to the infinity of space. They appear as abstract art forms but only until their symbolism is made clear by their setting: They are the starring elements of a memorial to the United States Air Force, the only branch of the American military that has not had a prominent monument in the Washington area.

headline.main: Enemy's Planes 'in Pieces,' Air Wing Commander Says

Air Force.lead_paragraph: With the American airstrikes against Afghanistan entering a fifth night, most of the early tension on this vessel seems to have lifted, and the air wing commander allowed himself a small moment of bravado tonight. He allowed himself to be identified by name -- Capt. David J. Mercer of the Navy -- something until now taboo aboard this vessel, under a policy set by top officers. And, he said, the only enemy aircraft he had seen in Afghanistan were ''on the ground, and those were mostly in pieces.''

headline.main: The Drone Zone
headline.print_headline: The Drone Zone

Air Force.lead_paragraph: At a desert facility, Air Force pilots are trained to fight America’s remote-controlled wars.

headline.main: The Drone Zone

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Holloman Air Force Base, at the eastern edge of New Mexico's White Sands Missile Range, 200 miles south of Albuquerque, was once famous for the daredevil maneuvers of those who trained there. In 1954, Col. John Paul Stapp rode a rocket-propelled sled across the desert, reaching 632 miles per hour, in an attempt to figure out the maximum speed at which jet pilots could safely eject. He slammed on the brakes and was thrust forward with such force that he had to be hauled away on a stretcher, his eyes bleeding from burst capillaries. Six years later, Capt. Joseph Kittinger Jr., testing the height at which pilots could safely bail out, rode a helium-powered balloon up to 102,800 feet. He muttered, ''Lord, take care of me now,'' dropped for 13 minutes 45 seconds and broke the record for the highest parachute jump. Today many of the pilots at Holloman never get off the ground. The base has been converted into the U.S. Air Force's primary training center for drone operators, where pilots spend their days in sand-colored trailers near a runway from which their planes take off without them. Inside each trailer, a pilot flies his plane from a padded chair, using a joystick and throttle, as his partner, the ''sensor operator,'' focuses on the grainy images moving across a video screen, directing missiles to their targets with a laser.

headline.main: New Incentives for Pilots of Remote Plane

Air Force.lead_paragraph: The new technology of warfare is presenting an unexpected challenge for the Air Force as it expands a fleet of unmanned reconnaissance planes: How to attract -- and satisfy -- pilots who would rather strap into a cockpit and punch holes in the sky at Mach speeds than sit in a trailer watching video to guide a remote-controlled plane. The white-scarf culture of military aviation is resisting this change. But Secretary James G. Roche of the Air Force is trying to ease the transition to the future by ordering a change in regulations so every hour spent guiding an unmanned Predator plane counts as a flight time when calculating pay raises and promotions.

headline.main: Pilots Charged in Attack on Allies Near Kandahar

Air Force.lead_paragraph: Two American F-16 fighter pilots have been charged with manslaughter and assault in the bombing of Canadian troops in Afghanistan, the Air Force said today. Four soldiers were killed in the bombing, on April 18, and eight were wounded. They were members of the Third Battalion of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry.

headline.main: U.S. Would Use Drones To Attack Iraqi Targets

Air Force.lead_paragraph: In a war with Iraq, the Air Force would use the same missile-firing drones that killed one of Al Qaeda's senior leaders in Yemen to attack Iraqi air defense radars, mobile Scud missile launchers and possibly sensitive targets in Baghdad, military officials said today. In Afghanistan, the Air Force flew unarmed Predator planes, mostly for reconnaissance missions or to designate targets for piloted bombers. The Central Intelligence Agency used armed Predators extensively there to attack suspected Qaeda leaders and expanded its killer-drone operations beyond Afghanistan for the first time on Sunday, blasting Qaed Salim Sinan al-Harethi and five associates in Yemen.

headline.main: BOSNIA SUSPECT

NATO.lead_paragraph: NATO peacekeepers in Bosnia handed over to the local police a Muslim man they had detained since October on suspicion of spying on their troops and having links with Al Qaeda. Sabahudin Fiuljanin, who denies the allegations, has not been formally charged with any crime, and the American-led NATO force has come under pressure from human rights organizations to present evidence against him before a court. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

headline.main: A NATO Raid Sets Off a Deadly Afghan Protest
headline.print_headline: A NATO Raid Sets Off A Deadly Afghan Protest

NATO.lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators clashed with security forces in Takhar Province after a NATO night raid that local officials say killed four civilians.

headline.main: NATO Steps Back Into the U.S.S.R.
headline.print_headline: A Mere Blip in the Post-Cold War Order, or an Alliance’s Raison d’Être?

NATO.lead_paragraph: With Libya in chaos and Afghanistan winding down, NATO is having a vivid fight over its future, which is actually a vivid fight about its past.

headline.main: Debate Over Iraq Raises Fears Of a Shrinking Role for NATO

NATO.lead_paragraph: Just two months ago, the 19 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization vowed publicly to streamline the 54-year-old alliance into an institution ready and able to rise to the challenges of fighting terrorism and protecting against weapons of mass destruction. Now, with the military club momentarily paralyzed in a debate about its role in a possible war in Iraq, Europeans are wondering again whether the troubled alliance is destined -- in the post-cold-war world -- to become a second-string institution.

headline.main: Day of Subdued Protests Follows Night of Clashes in Chicago

NATO.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- On the final day of the NATO summit meeting here, Chicago was oddly quiet. Several hundred demonstrators, a far smaller group than had marched through downtown in the days before, staged a ''die in'' on Monday outside the headquarters of Boeing, whose workers, like many Chicagoans, had stayed home to avoid trouble. It was a subdued ending for a city that had, for months, braced for chaos that a global summit meeting might bring and had, for ages, bristled at the images from its 1968 Democratic convention, when the police and protesters battled for days.

headline.main: After NATO's Year of Identity Crisis, a Defining Meeting

NATO.lead_paragraph: Stung by charges of irrelevance after the Sept. 11 attacks, NATO is making a serious effort at transformation to match the needs of a new age and an aggressive United States. It is undertaking a historic enlargement, to 26 members, and making plans to create a strike force able to wage offensive operations alongside the Americans anywhere in the world. But if the alliance fails at this task, senior American and British officials warn, NATO will be increasingly sidelined as a political talking shop, useful in bringing along the nations of the former Soviet Union but no one's first resort in time of crisis.

headline.main: For NATO, Little Is Sure Now but Growth

NATO.lead_paragraph: NATO is getting bigger, but what's it for? This November, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, now an alliance of 19 countries, is likely to expand by another 6 or 7 in what the Bush administration has called ''a robust enlargement.''

headline.main: NATO PLAN OFFERS RUSSIA EQUAL VOICE ON SOME POLICIES

NATO.lead_paragraph: The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, proposed today to give Russia equal status with the alliance's 19 permanent members in devising and executing some policies, a change that probably would bring Moscow into the center of NATO deliberations on terrorism and other issues. The proposal, which Lord Robertson said has the support of President Bush, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and other NATO leaders, implies that Russia would have veto power over certain alliance decisions, he said.

headline.main: NATO Quickly Gives the U.S. All the Help That It Asked

NATO.lead_paragraph: NATO moved swiftly today to back up earlier promises of support for the United States campaign against terrorism with hardware and intelligence, giving the Americans every bit of the help that they asked for in an eight-point shopping list submitted on Wednesday. The allies agreed to unlimited use of their airspace and access to ports, airfields and refueling complexes. They agreed to the use of its early warning aircraft, to replacing any troops that might be moved from peacekeeping missions in the Balkans and to deploy standing naval forces in the Mediterranean, among other measures.

headline.main: Romania and Bulgaria Edge Nearer to NATO Membership

NATO.lead_paragraph: A year ago, the idea that Romania and Bulgaria might join NATO this autumn in the next round of enlargement seemed laughable, and many thought that the aspirations of the Baltic nations for NATO membership might be held hostage again to relations with Moscow. But in the aftermath of Sept. 11 and with the war on terrorism, the southern flank of NATO suddenly seems more important, and the domestic blemishes of candidate countries like Romania less important.

headline.main: Russia Condemns Attack on U.S. And Vows to Aid NATO Actions

NATO.lead_paragraph: President Bush's call for a global coalition against terrorism continued to gain support overseas today as Russia, in a rare joint statement with NATO, expressed its anger over Tuesday's attacks in New York and Washington and called for a worldwide effort to combat such acts. After a special meeting here, the NATO-Russia Permanent Joint Council issued a statement saying that while NATO allies and Russia ''have suffered from terrorist attacks against civilians, the horrific scale of the attacks of 11 September is without precedent in modern history.''

headline.main: NATO Offers Peacekeepers Planning Aid

NATO.lead_paragraph: In a move that would broaden its traditional role, NATO has offered to carry out the planning for a Turkish-led peacekeeping mission in Afghanistan, NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, said today. The NATO offer is intended to encourage Turkey to take over command of the international peacekeeping force in Kabul from the British in June.

headline.main: The Alliance That Refreshes? NATO Hires a Coke Executive to Retool Its Brand

NATO.lead_paragraph: During the cold war, when Western and Warsaw Pact tanks massed on either side of the Iron Curtain, the idea of a brand for NATO would have been ludicrous because everyone knew why it was important. Not anymore.

headline.seo: For Pakistan, No Formal Remorse Yet From Obama
headline.main: Obama Refrains From a Formal ‘I’m Sorry’ to Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Obama Refrains, for Now, From a Formal ‘I’m Sorry’ to Pakistan

NATO.lead_paragraph: The White House has for now overruled State Department officials who favored a show of remorse to help salvage relations after a NATO airstrike killed Pakistani soldiers.

headline.main: NATO Reorganizes Afghan Command Structure
headline.print_headline: NATO Reorganizes Afghan Command Structure

NATO.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, which has moved to sharply increase the American military presence there, sought the change to improve command efficiency over the NATO forces.

headline.main: Putin Says Russia to Study Plan for Broader NATO Role

NATO.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin told NATO's secretary general today that Russia would give urgent attention to a proposal to accord the Kremlin an equal voice with the alliance's 19 members in setting policies on some issues, like terrorism. But in an apparent effort to ease concerns that the plan might give Russia a free hand to block NATO actions, the secretary general, Lord Robertson, stressed that Mr. Putin was not seeking either full NATO membership for Russia or a veto over major decisions.

headline.main: Key Allies Ready to Join U.S. Military Action in Iraq: Obama
headline.print_headline: Key Allies Ready to Join U.S. Military Action in Iraq: Obama

NATO.lead_paragraph: Key NATO allies stand ready to join the United States in military action to defeat Islamic State militants in Iraq, U.S. President Barack Obama said on Friday.

headline.main: Russian Official Cautions U.S. on Use of Central Asian Bases

NATO.lead_paragraph: Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov of Russia said Thursday that his government expected the American military to withdraw from bases in two former Soviet republics in Central Asia once the mission in Afghanistan was completed. On a day spent reassuring NATO defense ministers that Russia seeks broader cooperation with the Atlantic alliance and has no plans to announce a policy of nuclear pre-emption, Mr. Ivanov also said Russia reserved the right to intervene militarily in former Soviet states if the human rights of ethnic Russians were violated. That forceful restatement of Moscow's concern for ethnic Russians in former Soviet republics comes as NATO prepares to expand beyond former Warsaw Pact nations to include three of those former Soviet states: Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.

headline.main: Ghani 'Seen Moving Quickly to Sign Pact on Foreign Forces' in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: Ghani 'Seen Moving Quickly to Sign Pact on Foreign Forces' in Afghanistan

NATO.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan's next president, Ashraf Ghani, is expected to sign legal documents within 24 hours of taking office next week allowing foreign troops to stay in his country beyond 2014, a senior NATO diplomat said on Tuesday.

headline.main: NATO Chief Says Iraq and Afghanistan Are Doomed Without World Cooperation

NATO.lead_paragraph: NATO's top civilian official warned Friday that Afghanistan and Iraq were doomed to be failed states if the United States and the international community did not find a way to work together to save them. Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, NATO's secretary general, also sharply criticized what he described as the Bush administration's abandonment of NATO as an alliance and use of it when it suits Washington's interests.

headline.seo: Spring Offensive to Begin, Taliban Say
headline.main: Taliban Say Offensive Will Begin Sunday
headline.print_headline: Taliban Say Offensive Will Begin Sunday

NATO.lead_paragraph: A U.N. representative warned that expected fighting by both insurgents and the combined NATO and Afghan forces increased the likelihood of civilian casualties.

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; SETBACK ON IRAQ

NATO.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration signaled all week that it was as determined as ever to go to war in Iraq unless Saddam Hussein disarms. But by week's end, the chances of proceeding with the support of allies in the United Nations and NATO seemed to diminish. The chief U.N. weapons inspectors reported some progress, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell faced deep resistance to his call for a Security Council decision to authorize military force. France and Germany, in particular, demanded more time for the inspectors to complete their work, creating the biggest cleavage in the NATO alliance in a generation.

headline.main: At U.S. Urging, NATO Acts to Bolster Afghan Rebuilding Role

NATO.lead_paragraph: NATO defense ministers agreed Friday to take specific steps to strengthen the alliance's reconstruction role in Afghanistan with an eye toward eventually taking over most of the security and rebuilding tasks in the country. At a closed, three-hour meeting here, Britain, Italy, Turkey and Norway committed themselves to leading four of five new NATO teams of soldiers and civilians that will fan out beyond the capital, Kabul, and assist local authorities with security and rebuilding, a senior American official said. The Netherlands, Romania and Lithuania also indicated interest in contributing forces to the new teams, the official said.

headline.main: Questions Focus on Pakistan’s Role in Terror Fight
headline.print_headline: Concerns Come to Fore Globally After Bin Laden Killing

NATO.lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s leader denied Western accusations that his nation lacked “vitality” in combating terrorism.

headline.main: Questions Focus on Pakistan's Role in Terror Fight

NATO.lead_paragraph: The death of Osama bin Laden inspired many questions, but fewer answers on Tuesday: Could it lead to further erosion of support for foreign troops in Afghanistan and, subsequently, a faster withdrawal by NATO? And how should outside powers deal with Pakistan, whose president denied Western accusations that his nuclear-armed nation lacked what he called ''vitality'' in combating terrorism? ''There are lots of questions that need to be asked,'' Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said in a radio interview Tuesday. ''And we should be tough in asking those questions. But we should deal with what we do know. And we do know that the Pakistan political leadership is fighting terrorism. We do know that country has suffered.''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Legal Help For Terror Victims

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: About 200 lawyers are offering free legal advice to families of the Sept. 11 terror attacks in seeking compensation from a special federal assistance fund, the state attorney general's office said yesterday. The 200 volunteers from the Connecticut Trial Lawyers Association will help families legally prove they have suffered economic and non-economic loss. Officials will publicize how to seek compensation by Dec. 21. Victims' families have two years after that date to file claims and are entitled to a decision no more than 120 days after filing.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Decision On 9/11 Suit Is Upheld

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A panel of federal appellate judges upheld a decision to dismiss lawsuits from survivors of victims of the World Trade Center attack who charged that the special master of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund would unfairly limit awards to certain families. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a May decision by the United States District Court for the Southern District, which dismissed three lawsuits on behalf of families of victims who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald. The cases involve victims whose income was in the top 2 percent and whose survivors were considering seeking compensation from the fund for their losses, estimated in one case to be up to $52 million. According to court papers, the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, has spoken about considering awards of up to $7 million. In their decision, the judges wrote that ''any cap on compensation would be a direct violation of the statute'' governing the fund. They also wrote that they saw no evidence that Mr. Feinberg had established a cap. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Special Master Steered a Program Through Its Many Curves

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: No one lived as deeply in the emotional and financial complexities of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund as the person who designed it and became its public face: Kenneth R. Feinberg. At first, Mr. Feinberg, whose official title was special master, was derided as an arrogant Solomon, even though he was working on the fund with no compensation. But he worked tirelessly to sell his program, and began to win converts after the first awards were made in August 2002.

headline.seo: One Family Is Last Holdout on 9/11 Settlements
headline.main: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains
headline.print_headline: Among 9/11 Families, the Final Holdout On a Settlement Wants Its Day in Court

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The family of Mark Bavis, a passenger on United Airlines Flight 175, said its stance was not about money but about proving what it believes was negligence.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Passes Bill To Help Gay Partners

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Seeking to help the families of victims of the Sept. 11 attack, the Legislature gave final approval yesterday to a bill that encourages federal officials to give benefits to same-sex partners of the dead, but stops short of according them the same rights as widows and widowers. Gov. George E. Pataki introduced the bills and has said he will sign them. In September, the governor issued an executive order directing the state crime victim board to give awards to domestic partners. Ken Feinberg, the special master who oversees the distribution of the Federal Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, has said he will follow state laws in deciding who gets benefits. Mr. Feinberg cautioned, however, that he might still be bound by marriage and probate laws, which do not cover same-sex partners. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: Sept. 11 Compensation Fund Pays Out $551 Million
headline.print_headline: Sept. 11 Compensation Fund Pays Out $551 Million

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: An official at the September 11 Victim Compensation Fund say it has paid out $551 million over the last year.

headline.main: 2nd Round of Compensation For Sept. 11 Victims' Families

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The federal government yesterday announced its second batch of awards to compensate the relatives of victims from the Sept. 11 terror attack, offering 18 families awards ranging from a low of $280,000 to a high of $3.7 million. The awards made by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master in charge of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, follow the first group of awards announced Aug. 22, which offered 25 families an average of $1.36 million. In adding the second group, the net average, to date, has now been increased to $1.63 million.

headline.main: Victims' Fund Likely to Pay Average of $1.6 Million Each

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The overseer of the federal fund set up for the families of those killed or injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks estimated today that the fund could cost taxpayers as much as $6 billion and would provide tax-free awards, on average, of approximately $1.65 million for the families of those who died in the attacks. Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, offered the estimates as he unveiled the regulations that would guide the fund's work when it opens for business on Friday. Those rules allow Mr. Feinberg to grant larger awards if evidence shows they are justified by ''extraordinary circumstances.''

headline.main: Defending the Honor of S.I.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A congressman from Staten Island wants the administrator of the federal fund for victims of last year's terror attacks to be fired because he disparaged Staten Island. The congressman, Representative Vito J. Fossella, made the request yesterday in a letter to the Justice Department in response to a comment by the administrator, Kenneth R. Feinberg, in this week's issue of The New Yorker: ''Staten Island, that's a third world country.''

headline.seo: Rethinking the Process for BP Oil Spill Claims
headline.main: Rethinking the Process for BP Spill Claims
headline.sub: Fund Administrator Considering Changes to Speed Up Payments ;
headline.print_headline: Rethinking the Process for BP Spill Claims

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Kenneth R. Feinberg pledged quick payment for claims, but this week he offered more apologies than promises.

headline.main: Seeing Families, Senator Calls For Changes in Sept. 11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton met yesterday with relatives of Sept. 11 terrorist attack victims, and called for changes in the plan to distribute financial compensation from the federal government. The changes Mrs. Clinton suggested included clarifying that same-sex partners of victims would be compensated for their losses and ensuring that the families of illegal immigrants who died would not be deported if they sought awards.

headline.main: Head of Fund Says Families Should State Their Cases

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Faced with widespread protests that he has been stingy, Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master of the federal fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, urged disappointed families yesterday to seek a hearing to argue for larger compensation awards. ''These are only presumptive amounts,'' Mr. Feinberg said. ''I would strongly invite people to come in, make their case and try to raise those amounts even further.''

headline.main: Nov. 25-Dec.1; More Victims, More Funds

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: To help the families of those who died on Flight 587, which crashed on Nov. 12 after takeoff from Kennedy Airport, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that New York City was setting up a new charity, similar to one created for the families of lost rescue personnel after the World Trade Center attacks. The same spirit of inclusion moved in Washington, where a bill was introduced in the House that would open the federal Sept. 11 Victims Compensation Fund to the families of Americans killed or injured in the terrorist bombings of two embassies in Africa in 1998. Diana B. Henriques

headline.main: Many Relatives, Wary and Anguished, Shun Sept. 11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Nearly six months after the federal government opened its checkbook to the relatives of the 3,200 people killed or seriously injured on Sept. 11, fewer than 10 families have filed completed applications, illustrating the complex nature of the process, the anguish or wariness some families still have about settling a victim's financial affairs and lingering concerns about the government fund's fairness. In all, about 500 families have filed partial claims with the government's Victim Compensation Fund, many of which need to be verified or lack crucial information from employers and other sources. But even that figure has been smaller than expected, disappointing some supporters of the fund and surprising detractors, too.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Twin Towers Fund Distribution

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The Twin Towers Fund has begun distributing its third round of benefits totaling more than $103 million. The distribution will go to rescue workers not included in previous distributions. The fund was established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to benefit the families of uniformed rescue workers who perished during the terrorist attacks. It has distributed a total of $155 million to 436 families, including 789 children. The typical distributions are $150,000 to each spouse, $60,000 to each child 23 and younger and $25,000 to children 24 and older. The fund continues to seek donations and hopes to include unmarried domestic partners in the next distribution, Laurence Levy, the president of the fund, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Millions Left In 9/11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A fund established for families of Sept. 11 victims has $7 million in undistributed donations, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. Those who are eligible have until Sept. 30 to submit applications. The remaining money in the New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund is being held for 400 designated families whose members are eligible but have not yet applied for the aid. The fund has distributed slightly more than $63 million to 2,500 families. Notices were mailed yesterday to the 400 families. Those eligible include victims' spouses, domestic partners and fiancées and fiancés, along with children 21 and younger. Parents are eligible if there is no spouse, domestic partner, fiancée or child. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Putting a Price on the Priceless: One Life

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: ASSIGNING a dollar value to a person's life might seem impossible, not to mention unthinkable. But after a wrongful death, the needs of the surviving family - financial, emotional or both - often lead to that grim calculation. Forensic economists advise courts and governments on how to translate lives cut short into money for the living.

headline.main: Judge Dismisses 3 Cases Against 9/11 Fund's Special Master

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday dismissed three lawsuits that claimed the federal fund created to compensate the relatives of Sept. 11 victims was unfair, arbitrary and biased against victims who earned high incomes. In doing so, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District brushed aside what had been the most serious challenge yet to the Victim Compensation Fund, which is expected to cost taxpayers as much as $5 billion. He also vindicated the fund's embattled special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, who had been accused of trying to deprive the families of the victims who died in New York of hundreds of millions of dollars or more.

headline.main: In Last Days For Comment, Victims' Fund Is Under Fire

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: From the day the overseer of a fund to compensate victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks announced a set of draft regulations for distributing the money, there have been those who have criticized his guidelines on various grounds. Now, with a deadline looming for changes to the regulations, which will go into effect Jan. 21, some politicians and victims' relatives are stepping up their opposition to the guidelines set forth by the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg.

headline.main: After Weighing Value of Lives, 9/11 Fund Completes Its Task

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after establishing a fund to compensate the families of Sept. 11 victims, the federal government said yesterday that it had completed the task and that it would end up paying more than 5,000 families almost $7 billion. To mark the end of the program, the fund's administrator, Kenneth R. Feinberg, met with President Bush and Attorney General John Ashcroft yesterday afternoon at the White House. In an interview afterward, Mr. Feinberg said the president praised the program for giving the families the full compensation to which they were legally entitled.

headline.main: Survivors Say Plan For Fund Is Stingy

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Kenneth R. Feinberg has been an extremely popular man for weeks now, much courted by those seeking to influence his decisions about how the federal government will compensate the families of those killed or injured on Sept. 11. But today, Mr. Feinberg's popularity took a pounding, at least from some of those most directly affected by the federal fund he oversees.

headline.main: Final Rules for Federal Victims' Fund Increase Aid to Families of Sept. 11 Dead

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Saying that the complaints from families of those killed or injured on Sept. 11 had not fallen on deaf ears, the official overseeing the federal Victims Compensation Fund announced final regulations today that he said would produce substantially larger awards than his initial rules would have allowed. Under the new rules, average awards -- before any mandated deductions for life insurance, pensions and assorted government benefits -- would increase to $1.85 million from $1.65 million, Kenneth R. Feinberg, special master of the Victims Compensation Fund, said at a news conference here today.

headline.main: Victims' Kin Find Fault With Overseer Of 9/11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: With greater frequency and deepening anger, the relatives of the victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks are growing disenchanted with the man who oversees the federal Victim Compensation Fund. They say he breaks promises, delays decisions repeatedly and provides conflicting guidance for a program that is intended to pay out billions in awards. Family members, along with lawyers and company officials whose colleagues were killed or injured in the attacks, have complained that the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, often promises decisions within a week or two, only to repeat the same promise for weeks, then months, without delivering. They have also accused Mr. Feinberg and his staff of being inconsistent; one relative said that he once got three different responses to the same question on pension benefits.

headline.main: CONCERN GROWING AS FAMILIES BYPASS 9/11 VICTIMS' FUND

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Federal and local officials are growing increasingly concerned that nearly 60 percent of families who lost relatives in the September 2001 terror attacks have not filed claims with the victim compensation fund established by Congress. The most recent statistics show that 3,016 people died in the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and aboard an airliner that crashed in Pennsylvania. But as of Friday, with the Dec. 22 deadline for applications less than four months away, only 1,240 death claims had been filed with the fund. And while no one knows exactly how many people were injured in the attacks, so far only 1,035 of them have sought compensation from the fund, which has no cap.

headline.main: Victims' Families Get Break on Earlier Charity

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from New York's political representatives and leading charity executives, the overseer of a federal compensation fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has decided that the charity the families have received will not count against them in the calculation of awards from the fund, according to people who have been briefed on the fund's new rules. The rules for the multibillion-dollar fund, which is expected to be a principal source of long-term financial support for hundreds of affected families, are scheduled to be announced in Washington today by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the fund's special master.

headline.seo: Admiral Defends Use of Navy Seals Unit in Fatal Raid
headline.main: Admiral Defends Use of Elite Unit in Calamitous Raid
headline.print_headline: Admiral Defends Use of Elite Unit in Calamitous Raid

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Adm. William H. McRaven said “there was nothing unusual” about the Aug. 6 mission in Afghanistan during which an American helicopter was shot down.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.S. Soldiers Kill 2

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: American soldiers shot and killed two men who fired on them while on a patrol on Monday in eastern Afghanistan, said Col. Roger King, an army spokesman. He said about 30 special operations soldiers came under fire from a hilltop north of Asadabad in Kunar Province. No Americans were hurt. In July, the military reported five attacks on Americans hunting for Al Qaeda and Taliban forces. Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline.main: Two G.I.'s Wounded In Attack in Kabul

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Two American Special Forces soldiers and their Afghan translator were injured when an attacker threw a grenade into their jeep at a busy intersection in downtown Kabul this afternoon, American and Afghan military officials said. It was the first direct attack on American soldiers in Kabul since the Taliban fell from power late last year.

headline.main: U.S. Soldier Killed in Afghanistan Skirmish

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: An American soldier was killed in a firefight with enemy forces in eastern Afghanistan today, the United States military said. The soldier's unit came under fire while on patrol in the eastern province of Paktika, the military said in a statement at Bagram Air Base, the headquarters of American forces in Afghanistan.

headline.main: U.S. Soldier Killed in a Firefight in Afghanistan

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: An American Special Forces soldier was killed today in Afghanistan after his unit came under attack while on patrol in the eastern mountains where coalition forces have been operating, military officials said. Late tonight, an American military spokesman identified the soldier who was killed as Sgt. Gene Arden Vance Jr., 38, of Morgantown, W.Va. The official, Maj. Mike Cadle, told the Associated Press that Sergeant Vance was in the 19th Special Forces Unit of the West Virginia National Guard. He had been in the Guard for 10 years and was married and had a daughter, Major Cadle said.

headline.seo: Military Could Be in Afghanistan Past 2014, Allen Says
headline.main: U.S. General in Afghanistan Says Troops May Stay Past 2014
headline.print_headline: U.S. General in Afghanistan Says Troops May Stay Past ’14

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Lt. Gen. John R. Allen’s remarks amounted to the most emphatic signal to date that the United States military intended to secure a presence in the country.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; FIREFIGHT IN KANDAHAR

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: American forces at the Kandahar airport lobbed flares and exchanged machine-gun fire with unknown attackers, Pentagon officials said. No injuries were reported after the 15- to 20-minute firefight, and no enemy forces breached the perimeter. Seven armed men detained after the attack were soon released after it was found that they were security forces loyal to Afghanistan's government. Thom Shanker (NYT)

headline.main: Spike in U.S. Casualties In Iraq Raises Worries

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD -- Two American soldiers were killed Sunday in Iraq, the military command said, making June the worst month in combat-related fatalities for United States forces in Iraq in more than two years. The casualties also reflected the dangers ahead as the United States prepares to withdraw all its troops from Iraq by the end of the year. The June total of so-called hostile-related deaths of American soldiers is now 11, the most since May 2009, when 12 were killed, according to icasualties.org, an online database that tracks the deaths of foreign forces in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; TROOPS TESTED

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Health officials questioned all 1,200 American troops at Khanabad air base in Uzbekistan and found no symptoms of exposure to nerve or other chemical weapons, an Army spokesman said. Traces of the substances were found on base a week ago. Officials will now survey the records of at least 1,800 other troops who passed through the base since American forces were deployed there in October. Officials believe the traces were left by chemical weapons once stored by the Soviet military, which controlled the base until Uzbekistan became independent in 1991.

headline.main: Jump in Elite Forces' Budget Foreseen

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: The budget for the United States Special Operations Command, based in Tampa, Fla., could grow by as much as $1 billion over its current allotment of $4.9 billion, officials said today. The money would provide for more troops and weapons for Special Operations forces to expand their role in the campaign against terrorists, even as they shed some traditional missions, including combat search-and-rescue and counter-drug operations, officials said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills Marine

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: A United States Black Hawk helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan, killing a marine and wounding 14 others, the military announced. The crash was not caused by hostile fire, but occurred in Khost Province where there has been fighting with Taliban and Al Qaeda forces on the border with Pakistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; MINE WOUNDS G.I.

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: An American Army soldier was wounded by a land mine south of Kandahar, but his injuries are not life-threatening, the United States Central Command said. Nineteen American troops and one C.I.A. agent have died in Afghanistan or in the region in support of the war; 76 have been wounded. Only two of the deaths were due to hostile fire.

headline.seo: Lull in U.S. Drone Strikes Aids Pakistan Militants
headline.main: Lull in Strikes by U.S. Drones Aids Militants in Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Lull In Strikes By U.S. Drones Aids Militants

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: A plunge in relations between the United States and Pakistan has led to a pause in American drone strikes and given Al Qaeda and Pakistani factions a chance to regroup.

headline.main: Four U.S. Soldiers Reported Killed in Afghanistan

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Four American soldiers were killed in action on Saturday in southern Afghanistan, Reuters reported, quoting an announcement from the American military. The soldiers died in Zabul Province, which has been the scene of repeated clashes between American and suspected Taliban forces.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; U.S. PLANE CRASHES

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: An Air Force MC-130 transport plane crashed in Afghanistan on Tuesday but all eight of its crew survived, a spokesman for the Central Command said. Officials said the crash apparently was not caused by enemy fire. Pentagon officials said the plane was on a mission at the time but declined to give details. The MC-130 typically flies night missions and is used to transport Special Operations troops, for search and rescue and to refuel helicopters. Thom Shanker (NYT)

headline.main: A Green Beret Dies of Wounds Sustained in Afghanistan in July

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: A Green Beret assigned to Special Operations has died of wounds suffered two weeks ago in a firefight with suspected Qaeda terrorists in eastern Afghanistan, the Pentagon said today. Sgt. First Class Christopher James Speer, 28, of Albuquerque, N.M., was one of five American soldiers wounded on July 27 when a joint reconnaissance patrol was attacked 12 miles east of Khost, in eastern Paktia Province. Two allied Afghan militiamen were killed in the fight.

headline.main: American Planes Foil an Attack on an Airfield in Afghanistan

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: American warplanes bombed a group of suspected Qaeda and Taliban fighters today as they were setting up mortars within striking distance of an airfield in eastern Afghanistan used by allied troops, military officials said. Just before nightfall, the officials said, American reconnaissance aircraft detected 15 to 20 fighters digging four mortar pits several hundred yards from the airfield at Khost. The airfield is a pivotal hub for American Special Operations Forces and other coalition soldiers fighting pockets of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in the rugged mountains near the border with Pakistan.

headline.main: Green Beret Vanguard Arrives In the Former Soviet Georgia
