American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: About 20 American soldiers flew to the former Soviet republic of Georgia today, the first of 150 to 200 Special Forces G.I.'s who will train and equip army, border and security personnel there, the Pentagon said. President Bush ordered the $64 million program to assist Georgia in training that nation's feeble military in counterterrorism tactics. The United States is also sending small arms and ammunition, medical gear and radios, officials said.

headline.main: Canadian-Led Troops Revisit Caves in Eastern Afghanistan

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Canadian-led troops are searching caves in the Tora Bora region of eastern Afghanistan for the first time since the aerial bombardment of that rugged mountain redoubt ended in December, Pentagon officials said today. More than 300 Canadian light-infantry troops, including engineers and explosives experts, are reopening caves sealed by the American bombing, and scouring the region for signs that Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters may have slipped back into the region. About 90 soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division and some allied Afghan troops are also involved in the operation.

headline.seo: For Obama, Health Care Pushes Other Issues to the Margins
headline.main: Health Care Pushes Other Issues to Margins
headline.print_headline: One Subject Pushes Talk of Any Other to the Margins

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: For several weeks the issue of health care has overshadowed every other issue, foreign and domestic, faced by President Obama.

headline.main: PAKISTAN PUSHES FOR DRASTIC CUTS IN C.I.A. ACTIVITY

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Pakistan has demanded that the United States steeply reduce the number of Central Intelligence Agency operatives and Special Operations forces working in Pakistan, and that it halt C.I.A. drone strikes aimed at militants in northwest Pakistan. The request was a sign of the near collapse of cooperation between the two testy allies. Pakistani and American officials said in interviews that the demand that the United States scale back its presence was the immediate fallout from the arrest in Pakistan of Raymond A. Davis, a C.I.A. security officer who killed two men in January during what he said was an attempt to rob him.

headline.main: Troops on Call

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Some nations' military commitments to the international fight against terrorism: BRITAIN: The second-largest contributor of personnel and equipment after the United States. Has deployed a dozen ships, including an aircraft carrier, an assault ship, a frigate, a destroyer and three nuclear submarines. Also, 15 aircraft in the region, for refueling and reconnaissance. There are 150 Royal Marines and British commandos north of Kabul.

headline.main: 1,000 U.S. Troops Raid Afghan Towns

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: About 1,000 American troops launched a raid on villages in southeastern Afghanistan today, hunting for members of Al Qaeda in the biggest United States operation in just over a year, military officials said. Helicopters ferried troops from the Army's 82nd Airborne Division in Kandahar to the remote, mountainous area in the country's southeast, the officials said.

headline.main: Warning in Afghanistan

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: The commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, warned Tuesday of more attacks from Taliban and Al Qaeda guerrillas, but he promised a relentless military response. ''We expect additional attempts by remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda to disrupt the ongoing political process and ongoing reconstruction efforts,'' he said at a news briefing. Afghan security forces, nongovernmental organizations and troops will all be singled out, he said.

headline.seo: Kyrgyzstan Sees Instability After Afghan Withdrawal
headline.main: Kyrgyzstan Sees Instability at End of Afghan Mission
headline.print_headline: Kyrgyzstan Sees Regional Instability at End of NATO’s Afghan Mission

American Military Forces.lead_paragraph: Kyrgyzstan’s departing president expressed deep concern on Wednesday about contagious economic collapse when NATO forces withdraw from Afghanistan.

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; PENTAGON GIVES TRIBUNAL RULES

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon issued final rules for trying terrorist suspects in military tribunals, requiring that defendants who want civilian lawyers must hire Americans. After releasing segments of the rules bit by bit over the last year and half, the Pentagon is now ready to begin the tribunals, except for selecting tribunal members and defendants and arranging travel and security at the trial site, a senior defense official said. Briefing Pentagon reporters on the condition of anonymity, officials said they had some suspects in mind who might be brought before these tribunals but no final decisions had been made.

headline.main: In Letter, 300 Law Professors Oppose Tribunals Plan
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MILITARY TRIBUNALS

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: More than 300 law professors from around the country are protesting President Bush's order to establish military tribunals for foreign terrorist suspects. In a letter that originated at Yale Law School, the lawyers assert that such tribunals are ''legally deficient, unnecessary and unwise.''

headline.main: Bar Group Defies Administration In Voting for Limits on Tribunals

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Defying the Bush administration, the American Bar Association recommended today that Congress have a say in establishing any military tribunals used to try terrorism cases and that defendants in those tribunals be given extensive legal protections. Any such tribunals should follow the settled rules for military courts-martial, including the right to appeal to the Supreme Court, the association said. Defendants should be presumed innocent until proved guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, it said, and a death sentence should require a unanimous verdict.

headline.main: RULES ON TRIBUNAL REQUIRE UNANIMITY ON DEATH PENALTY
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MILITARY TRIBUNALS

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: The military tribunals that may be used to try Al Qaeda members and others accused of terrorism will require a unanimous verdict to impose a death penalty, although a two-thirds vote of the panel of military officers will be enough to find someone guilty, according to rules drafted by senior Bush administration officials. In addition, the draft regulations stipulate that a defendant is presumed innocent and that the military panel may find someone guilty only after deciding that the proof of guilt is beyond a reasonable doubt, the highest standard of proof and the one used in civilian criminal trials, said administration officials involved in producing the regulations.

headline.main: Despite Ruling, Tribunals Continue in Cuba

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Detainees at the Navy base here continued to go before military tribunals Tuesday despite a ruling that could halt the proceedings and future trials. A federal court in Washington ruled Monday that Salim Ahmed Hamdan, the 34-year-old Yemeni driver of Osama bin Laden, should not be tried by a military commission until its rules conform to the established code of military justice. It also said he is entitled to a hearing on whether he is a prisoner of war.

headline.main: BUSH SETS OPTION OF MILITARY TRIALS IN TERRORIST CASES

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: President Bush signed an order today allowing special military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism. A senior administration official said that any such trials would ''not necessarily'' be public and that the American tribunals might operate in Pakistan and Afghanistan. At the same time, the Justice Department has asked law enforcement authorities across the country to pick up and question 5,000 men, most from Middle Eastern countries, who entered the country legally in the last two years.

headline.main: Tribunal v. Court-Martial: Matter of Perception

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Former military lawyers say they are angered by a public perception, fed most recently by the top White House lawyer, that the military tribunals authorized by President Bush are merely wartime versions of American courts-martial, a routine part of military life with a longstanding reputation for openness and procedural fairness. In fact, the proposed tribunals are significantly different from courts-martial, the lawyers say, adding that confusion between the two has distorted the debate over the tribunals and unfairly denigrated military justice.

headline.main: Administration's Position Shifts on Plans for Tribunals

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Despite saying last year that it wanted to move quickly to establish military tribunals for terrorism defendants, the Bush administration is now in no hurry to conduct such proceedings, officials and others say. A principal reason, the officials and analysts say, is that the pressure to bring some prisoners before a tribunal quickly to demonstrate swift retribution for the Sept. 11 attacks has faded.

headline.seo: Guantánamo Defense Lawyers Seek 48-Hour Visits
headline.main: Guantánamo Lawyers Seeking 48-Hour Visits
headline.print_headline: Guantánamo Lawyers Seeking 48-Hour Visits

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: The request for access to five men accused of participating in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, criticized as unreasonable by prosecutors, is part of preparation for possible sentencing.

headline.main: Just Who Would Want to Defend Suspects Before a Tribunal? Probably Plenty

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: As Pentagon officials finish assembling a draft of the rules that will govern military tribunals, there is no shortage of defense lawyers willing, if not eager, to step in on behalf of anyone accused of terrorism who might be tried before them. ''My wife says it would be unacceptable, but I disagree,'' said Charles W. Gittins, a Virginia defense lawyer who specializes in military cases.

headline.main: Review of Guantánamo

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Navy Secretary Gordon R. England is to serve as the senior civilian official with final authority over the status of hundreds of detainees at the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the Pentagon said Wednesday. Mr. England will oversee a review of the status of most of the prisoners. The exceptions are those prisoners who President Bush determines should face military tribunals. Three have been charged with terrorism-related offenses.

headline.main: Draft Rules for Tribunals Ease Worries, but Not All

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Critics of the Bush administration's proposed military tribunals were encouraged today by draft regulations for trying people accused of terrorism, but they remained wary over how appeals would be conducted, the lack of specific Congressional authorization for the tribunals and whether the tribunals were needed at all. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee and one of the chief critics of the tribunals, said the rules suggested that the administration was responding to concerns about due process.

headline.main: Use of Military Court Divides Legal Experts

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Though there is clear legal authority for the government to use military tribunals to try people accused of crimes during war, legal experts were divided yesterday on the merits of allowing such proceedings against foreign terrorists. Some experts questioned the symbolism of President Bush's order to allow the tribunals, saying that the advantages such courts give the government -- like fewer barriers to admission of evidence against a defendant -- could raise questions about the nation's commitment to its basic values.

headline.seo: Pakistan High Court Widens Role and Stirs Fears
headline.main: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears for Stability
headline.print_headline: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s Supreme Court has inserted itself as the third player in a bruising confrontation between military and civilian leaders at a time when Pakistan faces a dizzying array of threats.

headline.main: Bush Defends Wartime Call For Tribunals

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Before a cheering crowd in Florida, President Bush said today that he needed military tribunals and other legal weapons to protect Americans. ''The United States is under attack,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And at war, the president needs to have the capacity to protect the national security interests and the safety of the American people.''

headline.main: U.S. Seeking Guantánamo Defense Staff

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Have a law degree? Willing to work for low pay in an exotic locale? Then Uncle Sam wants you. The Pentagon is trying to recruit civilian lawyers to represent terrorist suspects in its military tribunals at the United States naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. President Bush has yet to single out any prisoner from Afghanistan for a tribunal, but the Pentagon has been preparing for one anyhow. The suspects will be provided military defense lawyers but can also ask for civilian lawyers. So far, no one has applied.

headline.main: GOVERNMENT SETS RULES FOR MILITARY ON WAR TRIBUNALS

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has set the rules for conducting military tribunals for prisoners from the Afghan war, opening the door for the United States to prosecute and possibly execute foreigners by a legal process not used since the Truman presidency after World War II. In establishing the rules, which are widely expected to be made public on Thursday, the administration made concessions to critics who worried that President Bush's original order on Nov. 13 that established such tribunals had codified a secret rigged system that could simply shuttle defendants to hasty deaths.

headline.main: New Charges Filed Against Suspect in U.S.S. Cole Bombing
headline.print_headline: New Charges Filed Against Suspect in U.S.S. Cole Bombing

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Military prosecutors refiled terrorism and murder charges on Wednesday against the suspected mastermind of the 2000 bombing of the American destroyer Cole.

headline.main: Guantánamo Court Choices

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: A retired Army general, John D. Altenburg Jr., will oversee military tribunals for suspected terrorists held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the Pentagon said Tuesday.

headline.main: Supreme Court Is Asked to Block Terror Tribunals

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a Guantánamo detainee asked the Supreme Court on Monday to consider blocking military tribunals for terror suspects, and to overturn what they called an extreme ruling by Judge John G. Roberts Jr., President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court. Judge Roberts was on a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit that ruled last month against the detainee, Salim Ahmed Hamdan, a Yemeni who was Osama bin Laden's driver in Afghanistan.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Detainees Sue Over Tribunal Law

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for dozens of detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a federal appeals court to declare a crucial part of President Bush's new military trials law unconstitutional. The lawyers challenged the military's authority to arrest people overseas and detain them indefinitely without allowing them to use the American courts to contest their detention. Mr. Bush gave the military that authority last month when he signed a law that sets up special commissions to try detainees. In papers, lawyers for the detainees asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to let the detainees keep their legal challenges going in civilian courts. The Justice Department declined to comment.

headline.main: Senior Administration Officials Defend Military Tribunals for Terrorist Suspects
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENTIAL ORDER

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Top administration officials today defended a presidential order allowing military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism as the Pentagon prepared for the potential transfer of immigrants detained by the Justice Department into military custody. A senior administration official said that it was possible that immigrants held in the United States by the Justice Department in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks would be tried by military tribunal. Those trials could take place outside the United States or even on ships, the official said.

headline.seo: One U.S. Prosecutor Behind Many Qaeda Convictions
headline.main: One U.S. Prosecutor in Brooklyn Is Behind Many Terrorism Convictions
headline.print_headline: One U.S. Prosecutor in Brooklyn Is Behind Many Terrorism Convictions

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey H. Knox has supervised nearly all successful recent cases involving post-9/11 activities by core operatives of Al Qaeda.

headline.main: The Untested War Crimes Act of '96

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Pressing their case before Congress last week, Bush administration lawyers warned that granting Geneva Conventions protections to Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners raised an unsavory prospect: that cases of harsh treatment of detainees by American troops and civilian officials could be prosecuted under the War Crimes Act of 1996. The lawyers argued that the vague terms of the conventions opened the door for overzealous prosecutors to bring charges against troops who simply followed current military regulations regarding detainees.

headline.main: Rights Groups Won't Get Seats At Guantánamo Base Tribunals

Military Tribunals.lead_paragraph: Pentagon officials say they do not expect to be able to provide space for representatives of human rights advocacy groups to observe any military tribunals at the naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prompting complaints from those groups that the military is trying to shut out potential critics. In letters last week to Amnesty International, Human Rights First and Human Rights Watch, a senior military official said it was unlikely that they would be allowed to attend any military tribunals at Guantánamo. The official, Brig. Gen. Thomas L. Hemingway, a chief legal adviser in the office of military commissions, wrote that space would be limited if and when tribunals were held at Guantánamo.

headline.main: Sept. 8-14: INTERNATIONAL; THE 20TH HIJACKER

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a Qaeda operative who investigators say was the designated 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and is believed to be one of the few people still alive who know the details of the plot, was captured during a shootout in Karachi, Pakistan in a joint American-Pakistani operation. As many as 10 suspected Islamic militants were captured and two were killed.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Envoy Denies Terror Link

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Iraq's ambassador to Turkey, who has been linked in news reports to contacts between Iraqi intelligence and Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, left Turkey for Baghdad yesterday. The ambassador, Farouk Yahya al-Hijazi, who spent three years in Turkey, said that he had had no contact with Mr. Atta and that he had been recalled ''after the normal period of time,'' not because of the reported links to Mr. Atta.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: A suspected member of the Hamburg terrorist cell behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York and Virginia will go on trial in Hamburg on Thursday. The Moroccan-born defendant, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 30, is charged with 3,066 counts of abetting murder and aiding a terrorist organization. Mr. Mzoudi was a friend of Mohamed Atta, one of the terrorist pilots, and was a witness for his will. Mr. Atta and two other pilots in the attacks were from the Hamburg cell. If found guilty, Mr. Mzoudi faces the same 15-year jail term to which a fellow Moroccan, Mounir el-Motassadeq, was sentenced in February for aiding the hijackers. The trial, with 125 witnesses, could last into early next year. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: Saying U.S. Hinders Its Case, Defense Seeks Halt to German Trial

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Mounir el-Motassadeq, who is being tried in Hamburg for involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, have called on judges to halt the trial and release their client on the ground that the United States is preventing an important witness from testifying in his defense. Last month the Justice Department refused requests for testimony from the witness, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who is believed to have played a direct role in the planning of the attacks. Mr. bin al-Shibh, who once lived in Hamburg with Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the attacks, was arrested in Pakistan in September and is in American military detention at an undisclosed location. Officials say he has been forthcoming with investigators.

headline.main: October 20-26: FRONT LINES; TERRORIST TRIAL BEGINS

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: In Germany, during the opening of the first trial related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Mounir el-Motassadeq, accused of providing support for the Hamburg cell of Mohammed Atta and others, admitted that he attended a training camp in Afghanistan sponsored by Osama bin Laden. He denied knowing that his friends, including three of the Sept. 11 suicide pilots, had intended to commit terrorist acts. Desmond Butler

headline.main: Germans Lose a Bid for Qaeda Suspects

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: The United States Justice Department has denied a German court's request for testimony from two suspected members of Al Qaeda who are in American custody, but will allow court representatives to question Ahmed Ressam, who is accused of trying to bomb the Los Angeles airport in December 1999. The Justice Department will not allow questioning of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who was detained in Pakistan in September, or Zacarias Moussaoui, who is being held in the United States on suspicion he was intended to be the 20th hijacker in the attacks of Sept. 11.

headline.main: Germans Issue First Indictment in the 9/11 Plot

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors brought charges yesterday against a Moroccan man accused of supporting members of the Hamburg cell suspected of helping to plan and carry out the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. The indictment of the man, Mounir el-Motassadeq, 28, was the first formal criminal charge brought by German authorities in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: New Report Details 9/11 Talks in Spain

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: The Spanish authorities have prepared a 700-page report on a meeting, held on the Spanish coast last July, of presumed conspirators in the Sept. 11 attacks, and have forwarded it to the F.B.I., a leading Spanish newspaper reported today. The meeting, which the authorities previously knew about, involved Mohamed Atta, the suspected mastermind of the attacks, and was held in the town of Tarragona, in northeastern Spain. The newspaper El País, citing the report, said that Marwan al-Shehhi, another suspect, may also have been at the meeting.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: A court in Hamburg postponed the verdict in the trial of Abdelghani Mzoudi, accused of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, after prosecutors dramatically announced the emergence of a new witness just one day before the court had scheduled its final decision. The unnamed witness is an Iranian intelligence agent who told investigators that Mr. Mzoudi played a logistical role within the Hamburg cell that planned the attacks, according to a lawyer close to the case. Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline.main: Germans in U.S. With Data On a Top Qaeda Suspect

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German police officials have traveled to Washington to exchange information with American investigators about Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a top suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks who is thought to have inside knowledge of the Hamburg cell of Al Qaeda, according to the German Interior Ministry. The German and American authorities have been working together in Germany since they learned that three of the Sept. 11 hijackers, including Mohamed Atta, who is suspected to have been the leader, lived in Hamburg.

headline.main: Yemeni's Role in Attacks On Sept. 11 Is Stressed

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: In the days after the Sept. 11 attacks, as investigators rushed to piece together details of the plot, they came to the conclusion that Mohamed Atta was the leader of a group of student recruits, that he and two of these recruits planned the attacks while based in Hamburg and went on to pilot three of the four hijacked planes. But though Mr. Atta has become generally regarded as the mastermind of the local cell, German and American investigators have since come to recognize the importance of another onetime student in Hamburg, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who has emerged as the more likely conduit between the cell here and Al Qaeda's leadership in Afghanistan.

headline.main: LOOKING FOR SUSPECT

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the German Foreign Ministry said it had requested information from the State Department about the whereabouts of Mohamed Heidar Zammar, a German citizen under investigation for involvement in the Hamburg plot that led to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The official said the Foreign Ministry was responding to a report in The Washington Post, which quoted an American counterterrorism official who suggested that American officials knew where Zammar was and that he ''is not walking the streets.'' The German Foreign Ministry said there had not yet been a response from the State Department. Mr. Zammar, who was in Germany at the time of the attacks, left in October for Morocco. Though he was under investigation, German police say that there was insufficient evidence to charge him and that he was issued a one-year passport immediately before his departure. His family in Hamburg has reported him missing and requested information from the Foreign Ministry.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Moroccan Linked To 9/11 Hijackers On Trial

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Karim Mehdi, a Moroccan suspected of having links with two men involved in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, went on trial in Paris on a charge of ''criminal association in connection with a terrorist enterprise.'' Arrested in 2003, he is the only person to face charges arising out of a sweeping French investigation into the 2001 attacks. According to documents read in court, he was in contact with Ziad al-Jarrah, the hijacker pilot of United Airlines Flight 93, as well as Ramzi bin al-Shibh, one of the men accused of helping plan the attacks. Mr. Mehdi told the court that he met the two men only once, on a visit to Hamburg, Germany, where a cell of Al Qaeda whose members included the hijackers operated. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bus Hijacking

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: The police seized a 17-year-old Lebanese native who hijacked a bus and held several people hostage for seven hours, demanding the release of four arrested members of Al Qaeda, including one said to be a mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. Nobody was injured in the incident. The police said they did not believe that the youth had any connection to terrorist groups. The hijacking began in the northern city of Bremen when the teenager, a naturalized German citizen, seized a bus and its 14 passengers. He demanded the release of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who was arrested in Pakistan last year. Mr. bin al-Shibh is believed by investigators to have been one of two crucial Qaeda figures behind the Sept. 11 attacks. Richard Bernstein (NYT)

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors indicted Abdelghani Mzoudi, a 30-year-old Moroccan and a suspected member of Al Qaeda who is accused of providing logistical support to the pilots in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. He was charged on 3,066 counts of accessory to murder in connection with the attacks. Mr. Mzoudi, who is in jail in Hamburg, has denied the charges. He is the second suspected member of Al Qaeda to be charged from the small Hamburg-based terrorist cell that played a central role in the Sept. 11 plot. Mounir el-Motassadeq, a former roommate of Mr. Mzoudi, is serving a 15-year sentence on similar charges after his conviction by a Hamburg court in February.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 9/11 Prisoner Seeks Retrial

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Mounir el-Moutassadeq, the only person convicted of involvement in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, asked Germany's highest court to overturn the verdict, and the court said it would decide by March 4 whether to order a retrial. Mr. Motassadeq, a Moroccan, was sentenced to 15 years last February for helping the Qaeda cell in Hamburg that produced three of the Sept. 11 pilots. The trial of a second Moroccan charged as an accessory to the attacks, Abdelghani Mzoudi, is to hear testimony today from a man described as an Iranian defector who has told German investigators he has information incriminating Mr. Mzoudi. Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline.main: Germany Arrests Moroccan Suspected in Sept. 11 Attacks

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German police officials said today that they had arrested a Moroccan man suspected of involvement in the Hamburg cell of Mohamed Atta and others believed to have planned and carried out the Sept. 11 attacks. German federal prosecutors have accused the man, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 22, of having prior knowledge of the cell's terrorist plans and providing its other members with logistical support. He is the third person to be charged with involvement in the attacks.

headline.main: German Police Arrest Associate Of Hijacker Cell

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German police have arrested a Moroccan man who they say had intense contacts with Mohamed Atta and other Sept. 11 suicide hijackers, managing one of their bank accounts and moving money to several of the men while they underwent flight training in the United States a year before the attacks. It was the first time the German authorities had arrested anyone they said was linked to the group of Muslim militants believed to have planned the hijackings from the German port of Hamburg.

headline.main: 3 Fugitives Named as Part of Hamburg Cell

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department today identified three fugitives believed by American investigators to have been part of a terrorist cell based in Hamburg, Germany, that carried out the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States. Attorney General John Ashcroft said the fugitives -- a German, a Moroccan and a Yemeni, all of them previously identified by German authorities as accomplices -- were part of a cell that had existed since at least 1999 in both Germany and the United States.

headline.main: German Police Quiz Roommate Of Top Hijacker

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: The police in Hamburg today questioned an associate of the presumed ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States and five other men because of suspicions that the men were planning unspecified new attacks. One of the detained men, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 29, shared an apartment at 54 Marienstrasse in Hamburg with the ringleader, Mohamed Atta, and other suspects in the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, according to the police and prosecutors.

headline.main: Terror Suspect Tells of His Links to 9/11 Hijackers
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: TRIAL IN GERMANY

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: In a second day of testimony, a suspect on trial for involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks today detailed his relationship with five other men accused of being members of Al Qaeda's Hamburg cell. The suspect, Mounir el-Motassadeq, is accused of providing logistical support for three friends among the Sept. 11 hijackers. Today, he added to a description he made on Tuesday of his friendship with Mohamed Atta and his activities at a Qaeda training camp in Afghanistan from May to August 2000. He also told of varying degrees of contact with five other men accused of being members of the cell: Marwan al-Shehhi, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, Said Behaji, Ziad al-Jarrah and Zakariya Essabar.

headline.main: Germany: Criticism Over Man Suspected as Bin Laden Guard

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: German security officials are coming under fire for allowing a Tunisian man they believe may have served as a bodyguard to Osama bin Laden in 2000 to live in western Germany for years, despite being considered a ''dangerous jihadist'' who they say is spreading extremist views. German authorities insist they have done everything legally possible to curtail the activities of the man, identified only as Sami A., in accordance with privacy laws. He has been under observation since 2004 and is restricted to the city of Bochum, where he lives with his German wife and three children and must check in daily with the police, Birgit Axler, a spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry in North Rhine-Westphalia said Tuesday. Reuters quoted German authorities saying they have had trouble deporting him because of his marriage to a German.MELISSA EDDY

headline.main: U.S. Is Slow to Share Leads On Qaeda Cells, Germans Say

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Hamburg, perhaps more than any city in Europe, has intensified its antiterrorism efforts and direct cooperation with American investigators in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. Now, despite some successful joint efforts that led to searches and arrests, some Hamburg officials say the Americans are still not sharing intelligence gathered overseas. Recently, an official of the Hamburg Interior Ministry, Walter Wellinghausen, flew to Washington to discuss the problems with officials from the C.I.A. and the State Department. ''The main point is to get information flowing both ways,'' he said.

headline.main: Germany Disputes Visit of Qaeda Figure
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE INTELLIGENCE REPORTS

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Intelligence officials in Washington have not responded to requests for information about a visit to Germany by Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, an operative for Al Qaeda who has emerged as a central figure in the Sept. 11 attacks, German officials said today. They added that their own checks had turned up no trace of Mr. Mohammed's ever visiting or living here. The officials said they had first heard from the American press, not American officials, about a possible visit by Mr. Mohammed to Hamburg in 1999.

headline.main: Germans Were Tracking Sept. 11 Conspirators as Early as 1998, Documents Disclose

The Hamburg Terrorist Cell.lead_paragraph: Three years before the Sept. 11 attacks, Germany's domestic intelligence service was tracking prominent members of the Hamburg terrorist cell that planned and executed the aircraft hijackings, according to newly obtained documents. The documents, including intelligence reports, surveillance logs and transcripts of intercepted telephone calls, appear to contradict public claims by the German authorities that they knew little about the members of the Hamburg cell before the attacks.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; FRACTIOUS NATION

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, chairman of the interim government, visited Herat, in western Afghanistan, on his first trip to the countryside since taking office in December. Mr. Karzai was given a warm welcome in the city, which is in one of the country's most troubled regions. But government efforts to end a bloody power struggle in Gardez, in the east, were set back when the ousted governor declined an offer of mediation.

headline.main: Afghans Release Taliban Fighters

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: After nearly three months in prisons here, more than 320 Taliban fighters seized by Northern Alliance forces during the capture of the Afghan capital in mid-November were released tonight by the interim government headed by Hamid Karzai. The prisoners, many of them in light cotton clothing and plastic sandals, waited in 20-degree temperatures for Mr. Karzai to address them, on a lawn inside the old royal palace.

headline.main: Afghan Aid Meeting Ends

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: A two-day international donor conference on rebuilding Afghanistan ended here today with more than $4.5 billion in pledges through 2005. ''We are happy with the result of the conference we had yesterday and today,'' said Hamid Karzai, head of Afghanistan's interim government.

headline.main: AFGHAN LEADER TO SEEK MORE AID

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan will seek further help from foreign countries to quell remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda during his trip to the United States later this month, the foreign ministry said yesterday. Islamic militants remain a threat in Afghanistan, and during his meetings in Washington, Mr. Karzai will stress the need for sustained efforts to defeat them, said Omar Samad, a foreign ministry spokesman. Mr. Karzai will start his foreign tour on Thursday with a visit to Japan, and then will meet in Washington with President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

headline.seo: Gates Visits Afghanistan to Meet With Karzai and NATO Commanders
headline.main: Gates and Afghan Leader Review Plan for a Kandahar Offensive
headline.print_headline: Gates and Afghan Leader Review Plan for a Kandahar Offensive

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said during his unannounced visit that he would review plans for a major American-led offensive into the Taliban heartland.

headline.main: Taliban Chief in Afghanistan, Karzai Says

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: The deposed Taliban militia leader Mullah Mohammad Omar is alive in Afghanistan, hiding near the Pakistani border, the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said here today. Mr. Karzai, speaking at a news conference, also said other members of the ousted Taliban regime remained in Afghanistan. Attempts to arrest Mullah Omar have failed several times, Mr. Karzai said, without elaboration.

headline.seo: Half Brother of Hamid Karzai Is Killed in Kandahar
headline.main: Assassination in Afghanistan Creates a Void
headline.print_headline: Assassination In Afghanistan Creates a Void

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: A family associate shot Ahmed Wali Karzai, a provincial council chairman, at close range, friends said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Prisoners Home From Guantánamo

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Eleven Afghan prisoners held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for up to three years, including one man who is a tribal leader and former Taliban commander, arrived and were released in Kabul. The release, arranged by an aide to President Hamid Karzai and presented at the presidential palace, was interpreted by many Afghans as a vote-seeking attempt to counter criticism of the frequent raids and detention of people by American forces in the country. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline.main: Obama's Growing Trust in Biden Is Reflected in His Call on Troops

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- As President Obama began mulling his next big decision on troop levels in Afghanistan last January, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. quietly flew to Kabul to meet with President Hamid Karzai and tour the battlefield with the top American commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus. At a military base in Wardak Province, where the Taliban continue to pose a security threat, Mr. Biden listened with bewilderment as an American civilian told him about plans to dig a well in a nearby village. ''Why do they need a well?'' he asked, according to a person who was there.

headline.main: Rebel Chief Flees Raid By Taliban

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: An anti-Taliban leader, Hamid Karzai, was said to be alive and well inside Afghanistan today after reports that there had been a fight between his forces and the ruling Taliban militia. Supporters of Mr. Karzai clashed in the district of Derawat in southern Afghanistan on Thursday when Taliban forces came from Kandahar to hunt down the tribal chief.

headline.main: Clan Leader Turned Statesman: Hamid Karzai
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: MAN IN THE NEWS

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, who has been named to lead an interim government in Afghanistan, is at once a traditional tribal chief from the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar and a longtime anti-Taliban leader who became known to policy makers in Washington. Since slipping into southern Afghanistan from here in October, Mr. Karzai has represented the main American hope for a southern resistance, as he traveled from town to town and persuaded fellow Pashtun leaders to turn against the Taliban.

headline.main: Sept. 8-14: INTERNATIONAL; AL QAEDA CREEPS BACK

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after being chased from sanctuaries in Afghanistan, Al Qaeda fighters are beginning to move back into the country, American officials said.

headline.main: August 11-17: INTERNATIONAL; TALKING POINTS

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: The meeting in Kabul between Hamid Karzai and Mohammad Khatami, the Afghan and Iranian presidents, was a case of Central Asia's odd couple: Mr. Karzai the stylishly caped steward of Western hopes for a moderate, democratic Afghanistan; Mr. Khatami the austere Muslim cleric who represents an Islamic theocracy condemned by President Bush as a member of the world's ''axis of evil.''

headline.main: New Leader Urges Foes To Surrender

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: The man appointed today to lead Afghanistan's new interim government, Hamid Karzai, said tonight that he had begun talks with senior Taliban officials over the surrender of Kandahar, the last major stronghold of the Taliban and Arab fighters loyal to Osama bin Laden. ''I have had serious negotiations beginning this morning,'' said Mr. Karzai, the American-backed Pashtun tribal leader who is to take over a provisional government, intended to last six months, on Dec. 22. ''They took a different shape today.''

headline.main: U.S. Plucks Rebel Figure From Afghan Redoubt for 'Consultations,' Then Returns Him

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, the Afghan exile who has emerged as the Bush administration's main hope for forging a southern alliance against the Taliban, was plucked from Afghanistan by American forces early Monday, brought to Pakistan and then ferried back across the border, senior Pentagon officials said today. The operation showed considerable coordination between Mr. Karzai and the Bush administration, which has been criticized for lacking a strategy in the south, where the Taliban are strongest. Until now, the administration has concentrated its political and military support on more organized opposition forces in northern Afghanistan.

headline.main: Afghan President Bringing Bush Gloomy Report on Security

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: On the eve of his Camp David meeting with President Bush, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan painted a bleak picture of life in his country, saying that security had worsened and that the United States and its allies were no closer to catching Osama bin Laden than they were a few years ago. ''The security situation in Afghanistan over the past two years has definitely deteriorated,'' Mr. Karzai said on the CNN program ''Late Edition with Wolf Blitzer,'' in an interview that was taped Saturday in Kabul. It was broadcast Sunday while Mr. Karzai was en route to Camp David for a two-day meeting with President Bush.

headline.main: New Leader Is Assured Of Support

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, who is to become Afghanistan's new leader on Saturday, received the blessing of his country's deposed king today and a pledge of assistance from Italy's prime minister. The former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, who has lived in exile here for nearly three decades, has become an important symbolic figure in the effort to reunite the Afghan nation after more than 20 years of war.

headline.main: In Call, Karzai Tries to Clarify a Diatribe
headline.print_headline: By Phone, Karzai Tries To Clarify A Diatribe

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai said a recent speech was not directed at the U.S. but rather at Western news coverage.

headline.main: An Afghan in New York

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin will meet with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan during the United NationsGeneral Assembly next week, an official at the Afghan Embassy in Washington said. The official said that Ms. Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee who has been governor of Alaska for 20 months, requested the meeting several days ago as part of an effort to become familiar with the leaders of key American allies.

headline.main: Like Politicians Everywhere, Afghans Can Tie New Roads to Votes

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: It was a pre-election scene that has been played out in every country where politicians slap backs and kiss babies. There were the beginnings of new road, a groundbreaking and a bunch of officials promoting the candidate they said deserved full credit. But in this unusual case, the road, still uneven and made of dirt, cuts through a deserted rocky landscape plagued by robbers and Taliban rebels, and the photo opportunity on Thursday was intended for the benefit of President Hamid Karzai as he enters the final month of his country's first presidential campaign.

headline.main: Leading Candidates for the Afghan Presidency
headline.print_headline: Leading Candidates for the Afghan Presidency

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Some of the leading contenders in Afghanistan's presidential election:

headline.main: Afghan Trying to Do 'Big Things' at Big Risk

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: In a mountainous southern region of Afghanistan, far from the round-the-clock pounding by the United States in the north, an Afghan politician-cum-commander, Hamid Karzai, is working to topple the Taliban without the luxury of much backing and with his enemy in hot pursuit. If he survives, his family and supporters say, the prize is big: he could emerge as the hero of the resistance to the Taliban and as the ruler of considerable swaths of liberated Afghan territory. If he does not, he will be remembered as a brave man who took incredible risks for his tribe and country.

headline.main: Peace Talks With Taliban Top Issue in Afghan Vote
headline.print_headline: Afghan Election Debate Centers On Peace Talks With Taliban

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Whether and how to negotiate peace with the Taliban has become the one issue no candidate in the Afghan presidential election can avoid taking a stand on.

headline.main: Afghan Voting Postponed for 3 Months

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan's landmark national elections, which were scheduled for June, will be delayed until September, President Hamid Karzai said Sunday. Mr. Karzai said the delay was needed to allow the United Nations to hold both presidential and parliamentary elections at the same time.

headline.main: Kabul to Send Team to Check on Afghans Held at Guantánamo

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai announced today that he would send a delegation to the American naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to check the conditions under which Afghans are being held there in indefinite detention. Mr. Karzai made the announcement after meeting today with three Afghan men freed from Guantánamo this week, who said they were innocent and had been wrongly detained for months. ''Mr. Karzai decided to send a team to Guantánamo to find out if the rest of the Afghans there are in the same situation,'' said Sayed Fazl Akbar, a presidential spokesman, ''if there are people there who are innocent and should be released.''

headline.main: AIRPORTS

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The National Guard will begin a ''phased withdrawal'' this month from the hundreds of airports the troops have been patrolling for almost six months and are to be completely gone by May 31, the Transportation Department said. At first, the Guard will be replaced mostly by officers supplied by state and local police departments, said Michael P. Jackson, the deputy secretary of transportation; later, more federal police officers will be used. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Algerian Terror Cell Cracked, Police Say

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The police broke up what they said was a cell providing financial and logistic support for an Algerian extremist group with reported ties to Al Qaeda. The police said they arrested four Algerians and a Tunisian near Milan, with a sixth suspect arrested in Switzerland. The suspects, the police said, were members of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, which has been accused of several attacks in Algeria. IAN FISHER (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Dead Man's Identity May Have Been Stolen

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The police are searching for a man who apparently stole the identity of a man who died in the attack on the World Trade Center. The widow of Sean Booker alerted the authorities after a letter addressed to her husband indicated he had received a traffic ticket May 5 in Tarboro, N.C. The police have not been able to find the man, whom they identified as Anthony Andrew Fernandez, also known as Leslie Patrick Cumberbatch. His last known address was in Brooklyn, but the police say he no longer lives there. The police say Mr. Fernandez is in the country illegally, but they do not know when he returned after being deported to his native Guyana in 1998 because of a drug charge.

headline.main: Kenya: Officers Hurt by Grenade

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Seven Kenyan police officers were wounded, some critically, late Wednesday in the second grenade attack in two days in the port city of Mombasa, the police said. The city has been racked with protests by Muslim youths this week over the killing of a radical cleric. A criminal investigations officer, Ambrose Munyasia, said two unidentified attackers had hurled the grenade at the police officers as they prepared to head out on patrol. The cleric, Sheik Aboud Rogo Mohammed, was killed Monday. He had been accused by the United States and the United Nations of fund-raising and helping recruit fighters for the Shabab, the Somali militants linked to Al Qaeda. The police reported earlier Wednesday that two more officers had died from the first grenade attack, on Tuesday, raising the death toll to three.

headline.main: City to Offer Free Trips To Las Vegas for Officers

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A day after two police suicides and the abrupt resignations or desertions of up to 200 police officers, defiant city officials on Sunday began offering five-day vacations -- and even trips to Las Vegas -- to the police, firefighters and city emergency workers and their families. The idea of paid vacations was raised by both Mayor C. Ray Nagin and senior police officials who said that their forces were exhausted and traumatized and that the arrival of the National Guard had made way for the officers to be relieved.

headline.seo: Man Once Believed a Risk to City Is Memorialized
headline.main: A Legacy for a Son Whose Character, After 9/11, Was Misjudged
headline.print_headline: A Legacy for a Son Whose Character, After 9/11, Was Misjudged

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A man who disappeared on 9/11 was mistakenly thought to be a risk to the city. But he had died at ground zero, trying to help.

headline.main: New York City Police Disbands Unit That Watched Muslim Communities
headline.print_headline: New York City Police Disbands Unit That Watched Muslim Communities

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has disbanded a controversial surveillance unit that targeted and monitored Muslim communities after the September 11, 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center, a police statement said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Charges Dropped

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge dismissed charges yesterday that had been filed against 18 firefighters who scuffled with police officers last month. The charges stemmed from the firefighters' Nov. 2 protest march and confrontation with the police after city officials limited the number of the city's firefighters who could search the World Trade Center rubble for bodies. At the request of the district attorney's office, Judge Gregory Carro of Criminal Court dismissed trespass charges against all the firefighters and an assault charge that was filed against one who had been accused of hitting a police officer. ''The interest of justice would not be served by proceeding with the prosecution,'' Assistant District Attorney Kavita Gopwani told the judge.

headline.main: Honoring Cops, Obama Says US Owes Police a Debt
headline.print_headline: Honoring Cops, Obama Says US Owes Police a Debt

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The United States owes a debt to the police officers who put themselves in danger to protect the nation, President Barack Obama said Monday as he honored the nation's top police officers at the White House.

headline.main: Bombers Hit 4 Iraqi Towns in the North
headline.print_headline: Bombers Hit 4 Iraqi Towns In the North

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A suicide bombing inside a Shiite mosque during evening prayers and other attacks north of Baghdad killed 23 people in Iraq on Saturday, officials said.

headline.main: Bombs Explode Outside Homes of Iraqi Police Officers, Killing 4
headline.print_headline: Bombs Explode Outside Homes of Iraqi Police Officers

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The series of bombings signaled a new tactic by insurgents seeking to spread chaos three months after a national election that has not yet delivered a clear winner.

headline.main: SPEED WHILE YOU CAN

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey has signed a bill approving $5 million in state funds to hire state police troopers and to improve the state police emergency communications system.

headline.main: A Reservist at Fort Dix Shoots 4 Before Being Killed by Police

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A military police reservist who was being expelled from the Fort Dix Army Reserve post because of suspected psychological problems shot and wounded two soldiers and two local police officers this afternoon before being fatally shot by the authorities, military officials said today. The gunman, a Pennsylvania man who was a member of the 307th military police unit, had been informed last week that he was being relieved of his duties because of erratic behavior, and was escorted to his locker shortly after noon today by two military police officers to collect his belongings, said Carolee Nisbet, a spokeswoman for Fort Dix.

headline.seo: Repression Tears Apart Bahrain’s Social Fabric
headline.main: Bahrain Boils Under the Lid of Repression
headline.print_headline: Bahrain Boils Under the Lid Of Repression

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Bahrain has become the cornerstone of a counterrevolution to stanch change in the Middle East, but many fear the violence will beget more violence.

headline.seo: 20 Police Officers Killed in Western Iraq
headline.main: Gunmen in Uniforms Kill 20 Police Officers in Iraq
headline.print_headline: Gunmen in Uniforms Kill 20 Police Officers in Iraq

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Gunmen disguised as police SWAT teams entered the town of Haditha, killing three police officers at their homes and more in clashes at checkpoints, security officials said.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; ATTACK ON MOSQUE

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A man who said he hated Muslims drove a truck into a Florida mosque just 30 minutes before evening prayers, the police said. No one was injured on Monday in the Islamic Center of Tallahassee at Florida State University. The driver, Charles Franklin, 41, was arrested later at a campus bar. Investigators said Mr. Franklin told the police that he tried to join the military to kill Muslims but was turned down.

headline.main: Yemen: Suspected Qaeda House Raided

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Two Yemeni police officers were killed and several others were wounded Monday in a gun battle with suspected fighters from Al Qaeda in the eastern province of Hadramawt, Yemeni officials said. The battle, in which five militants were also killed, began when the local police stormed a house in the city of Tarim after getting a tip that militants were there, according to the governor of Hadramawt Province, who was quoted in a statement on the government Web site. The militants threw a grenade at the police, and the two sides exchanged fire, the statement said. The battle was the third recent attack claimed by Al Qaeda's Yemeni branch in Hadramawt, a remote area where the central government's power is weak.

headline.main: Italy: 2 Arrested In Plot For Terrorist Attacks

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The police in Milan arrested two Moroccan-born men on Tuesday on charges of plotting terrorist attacks against Italian targets, including a police barracks and a supermarket. Rachid Ilhami, 31, and Abdelkader Ghafir, 42, have lived in Italy for a decade and in recent weeks acquired materials to make explosives, the police said. They said the two were not tied to international groups but were believed to have admired the work of Al Qaeda. The arrests followed a two-year investigation that relied on surveillance of the men's phones, cars and the Islamic cultural center they frequented outside Milan.

headline.main: Anthrax Scares Are Stretching Thin Blue Line

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: As anthrax and bomb scares continued to jangle nerves around the country, a growing number of police departments said yesterday that their resources were being stretched well beyond normal by the need to respond to calls from jittery residents. In Seattle, Gil Kerlikowske, the police chief, said the demands for a police response to terrorist scares, security needs at the airport and the baseball playoffs involving the Mariners and New York Yankees put such a strain on his department that he intended to ask the state's Congressional delegation to obtain federal financial help.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Muslim Clergyman Attacked

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A Muslim clergyman was attacked Tuesday night in the Bronx by three men who walked into a mosque and, without a word, struck him over the head with a piece of wood, the police said. Details were sketchy yesterday, but the mullah suffered only minor injuries. The police said the assault on the mullah, who is also black, was being investigated as a possible hate crime. The mullah, 35, whose name was not immediately released, was confronted about 8 p.m. by three men inside the Islamic Cultural Center at 371 East 166th Street, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Radiation Detectors

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department installed its first radiation detector outside police headquarters yesterday. The detector, which people must walk through to enter the building, is one of four the department has, a senior police official said. Another will be in the garage of police headquarters, one will be used by the Emergency Services Unit, and another will be given to the bomb squad, the official said. The detector, called a radiation portal monitor, consists of two upright black poles, about three inches in diameter and six to eight feet apart. ''They're easily deployable,'' the official said, calling the detectors a precautionary measure. ''There was no trigger, it's just another counterterrorism response,'' he said. It was unclear last night whether similar measures were being taken at other buildings across the city and how much the devices cost. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Escort Low-Flying Plane

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Two New York City Police Department helicopters escorted a small plane to Essex County Airport in New Jersey on Saturday after the plane flew low over the United Nations complex shortly after 5 p.m., the authorities said. Upon landing, the plane and the two men inside were identified and released, said Officer Jennara Everleth, a police spokeswoman. The pilot was reportedly involved in the preparation of events for the Sept. 11 anniversary.

headline.main: 2 Accused of False Reports

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The police said yesterday that they had arrested two people on charges of falsely reporting relatives among the missing at the World Trade Center. A Toronto woman, Sara Hekriy, 44, went to a center for victims' families and submitted a notarized document saying her husband had been inside one of the towers, the police said. Ms. Hekriy later admitted that she had falsified the document, they said, and was charged with perjury.

headline.main: Collateral Damage in the Chinatown Bus Wars
headline.print_headline: Collateral Damage in the Chinatown Bus Wars

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A 2004 gang killing connected to the bus business also claimed the life of a cocktail waitress. A suspect was arrested this year in Toronto and returned to New York to face federal murder charges.

headline.main: Remembering Help Received After Sept. 11, New York Sends Officers to Louisiana

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Some New York City police officers who arrived here over the last few days were serving on the front lines of a national crisis for a second time. They had been there, too, when the attack on the World Trade Center, a man-made disaster, took the lives of 23 members of their department. The New York police volunteers arrived in caravans only a few days before the fourth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attack and set out, often without sleep, on search-and-rescue, security, evacuation and patrol missions. To exhausted police and emergency crews in Louisiana, they are an army of relief, their numbers and discipline providing steady hands in a challenging situation.

headline.seo: A 9/11 Widow Balances Her Family, a Job and Islam
headline.main: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
headline.print_headline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Hadidjatou Karamoko Traoré is a 9/11 widow who has had to balance an overnight job, three children and her Muslim faith.

headline.main: The Plot Leaders and Lingering Questions

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: A year after Sept. 11 investigators are still struggling to piece together the planning, preparation and connections between the leaders of the attacks. Below, the suspected leaders, some of what the authorities have revealed and questions they continue to try to answer. SARAH SLOBIN

headline.main: No Charge to Fly Sept. 11

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines said today that it would not charge anyone for flying Sept. 11, the first anniversary of deadly terrorist attacks on the United States. The company said the offer was good for those booking flights by Sept. 8 through the airline's Web site or travel agents.

headline.seo: 9/11 Anniversary Books, New and Reissued
headline.main: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea of Others
headline.print_headline: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea Of Others

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: New books are coming out, but is there more for readers to learn about the Sept. 11 attacks on their 10th anniversary?

headline.main: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea Of Others

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Publishers are releasing a new round of books timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks despite lukewarm sales of many books about the events in the past. But the question remains whether people will want to read more about Sept. 11, especially after weeks of magazine covers, newspaper articles and wall-to-wall cable news coverage. W. W. Norton and Company has high hopes for one book it plans to release on Sept. 12: the memoir of Ali H. Soufan, a former F.B.I. agent who played a major role in terrorism investigations between 1997 and 2005. A spokeswoman for Norton said that the book, ''The Black Banners,'' will have close to 150,000 copies in print when it is released, a significant number in these days of e-books and struggling brick-and-mortar bookstores.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Reopening Of Bridge's Walkways

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Bikers and pedestrians returned to San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge as officials reopened the span's walkways for the first time since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. A spokeswoman for the bridge authority, Mary Currie, said the sidewalks would now remain open only during daylight hours as part of increased security.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: European airlines must return to commercial insurers to cover the war and terror risks that have been guaranteed by governments since the Sept. 11 attacks, the European Commission said. A commission spokesman, Gilles Gantelet, said European states would no longer provide insurance guarantees after Oct. 31.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Push For More Workers

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: A group of seasonal Michigan businesses that rely on foreign workers for summer staff is suing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over delays in processing temporary work visas since the Sept. 11 attacks. The 13 companies filing suit are on the shores of the Great Lakes and include hotels and restaurants. John Carpenter (NYT)

headline.main: The Hated and the Hater, Both Touched by Crime
headline.kicker: ASKED AND ANSWERED | MARK ANTHONY STROMAN AND RAIS BHUIYAN

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Mark Anthony Stroman, 41, a stonecutter from Dallas, shot people he believed were Arabs, saying he was enraged by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. He killed at least two: Vasudev Patel, an Indian immigrant who was Hindu, and Waqar Hasan, a Muslim born in Pakistan. A third shooting victim, Rais Bhuiyan, 37, a former Air Force pilot from Bangladesh, survived after Mr. Stroman shot him in the face at close range. Mr. Stroman admitted to the shootings. He is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday.

headline.main: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The White House has issued detailed guidelines to government officials on how to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, with instructions to honor the memory of those who died on American soil but also to recall that Al Qaeda and other extremist groups have since carried out attacks elsewhere in the world, from Mumbai to Manila. The White House in recent days has quietly disseminated two sets of documents. One is framed for overseas allies and their citizens and was sent to American embassies and consulates around the globe. The other includes themes for Americans here and underscores the importance of national service and what the government has done to prevent another major attack in the United States. That single-page document was issued to all federal agencies, officials said.

headline.main: I.N.S. DETAINEES

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Immigration and Naturalization Service changed its policy last week and agreed to allow advocacy groups to visit foreign nationals held in the Hudson and Passaic County jails since Sept. 11. The service will allow such groups as the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee to help detainees with legal questions and to provide representation. There are 460 aliens held nationwide since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the I.N.S., though how many are in New Jersey is not known. John Holl

headline.main: No Profiting Found From 9/11 Attacks

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: After an extensive investigation, the government has found no evidence that terrorists tried to profit from stock and options trading ahead of the Sept. 11 attacks, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday. The S.E.C. was among several federal agencies that investigated possible market manipulation. The agencies, working with stock and options exchanges, reviewed more than 9.5 million transactions that took place during the weeks preceding Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Heightened Security For U.S. Match

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: A huge security operation has been put into effect for Wednesday's international friendly match between Italy and the United States in Catania, Sicily.

headline.main: Onstage in London, Works That Look Back in Time as They Move Forward

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Do some atrocities defy dramatization? That is often thought to be true of the Holocaust, an event all too frequently co-opted for a ready-made, facile emotional ride. And you have to wonder what can be done on stage with the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, that won't descend into glibness, political point-scoring, mawkish appeals to the audience, or worse. One bracing response is on view through Oct. 15 in a space within St. Katharine Docks, East London, in a residential complex minutes from the City financial district. This is where the director Rupert Goold has opened his Headlong Theatre production of ''Decade,'' a mosaic of responses to that September morning that acts as a textual tapestry of grief, rage and compassion -- and as first-rate theater, too.

headline.seo: On the 9/11 Anniversary, Loss and Tension
headline.main: On Sept. 11 Anniversary, Rifts Amid Mourning
headline.sub: Not at War With Islam, President Declares at the Pentagon ;
headline.print_headline: On Anniversary Of Sept. 11, Rifts Amid Mourning

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Thousands of relatives of 9/11 victims gathered as a nation debated whether an Islamic center should be built near ground zero and President Obama pleaded for religious tolerance.

headline.main: 9/11 Case Is Delayed as Defense Voices Fears on Eavesdropping

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Lawyers in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others said they worry that their communications may be subject to government monitoring.

headline.seo: Anwar al-Awlaki: From Condemning Terror to Preaching Jihad
headline.main: Imam’s Path From Condemning Terror to Preaching Jihad
headline.print_headline: From Condemning Terror to Preaching Jihad

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Anwar al-Awlaki, a U.S.-born cleric, has become a central figure in the luring of Western Muslims to violent extremism.

headline.main: 24-Hour Fighter Coverage Is Resumed

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Jet fighters have resumed round-the-clock patrols over New York and Washington as the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks nears. The 24-hour military flights resumed today, a Pentagon spokeswoman, Lt. Col. Cathy Abbott, said.

headline.main: October 20-26: FRONT LINES; TERRORIST TRIAL BEGINS

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: In Germany, during the opening of the first trial related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Mounir el-Motassadeq, accused of providing support for the Hamburg cell of Mohammed Atta and others, admitted that he attended a training camp in Afghanistan sponsored by Osama bin Laden. He denied knowing that his friends, including three of the Sept. 11 suicide pilots, had intended to commit terrorist acts. Desmond Butler

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Capitol Security Relaxes

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: Gov. Judy Martz is scaling back security measures taken at the state Capitol in Helena after the Sept. 11 attacks. Concrete barriers that were installed at the Capitol's driveways will be removed and a requirement that all visitors show identification and sign in when entering the building will be discontinued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

headline.main: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; THREATS IGNORED

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: A 1998 Central Intelligence Agency report, revealed by the joint Congressional panel investigating the intelligence failures of Sept. 11, was the first public evidence that there was specific intelligence about terrorist plans to crash airplanes into the World Trade Center. Officials said, though, that those plans did not appear to be connected to the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.seo: ‘The Flag,’ on CNN, Examines a Lingering Mystery
headline.main: In a Puzzle, a Clearer Look at 9/11
headline.print_headline: In a Puzzle, A Clearer Look at 9/11

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: “The Flag,” a CNN film about Sept. 11, does more than simply retell a familiar story or push the obvious buttons.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middletown: Wesleyan Students Walk Out

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: About 150 students walked out of classes at Wesleyan University yesterday to protest the American and British bombing in Afghanistan. Demonstrators said a violent response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would only provoke more violence. They urged government leaders to develop a peaceful solution. Last month, students formed a coalition against violent retaliation.

headline.main: At Guantánamo, Trial for 9/11 Defendants, and for a Revamped Tribunal

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- As the United States restarts its effort to prosecute -- and ultimately execute -- five detainees accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, it has fallen to Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins both to prove them guilty and to show the world that the tribunal system is now legitimate. ''We're going to have a fair trial,'' General Martins, the chief prosecutor in the military commissions system, said in an interview this week. ''There are a lot of people who come to this with preconceptions about unfairness, and I would just ask people to withhold judgment. The initial version of commissions was flawed, but there has been a lot of work on reforms.''

headline.seo: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field
headline.main: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field
headline.print_headline: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field

The September 11 Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Mets were front and center again on Sunday night as fans stood in unison and began chanting “U.S.A.!” when news of Osama bin Laden’s death began to spread.

headline.main: The Banner Yet Waves

American Flags.lead_paragraph: There was flag-wearing and flag-waving everywhere at last Sunday's marathon. Both runners and spectators were caught up in the current display of patriotism. Many of the nearly 10,000 international runners carried both their own flags and the American flag. Stars and stripes were painted on faces, tattooed on legs and printed on runners' shorts, T-shirts and head wraps. Even the tapes some runners wore on their noses to help them breathe bore the image of the flag. British runners wrapped themselves in their Union Jacks, and French runners often carried the tricolor and the American flag on the same pole.

headline.main: Flying a Flag, if You Can Find One

American Flags.lead_paragraph: The American flag has become a symbol of resolve to carry on after the terrorist attacks, but it is also in short supply in many parts of the country. ''The whole country is out of flags,'' said Ron Dufner, the owner of a hardware store in Bethel, Conn., adding that he has been selling out of flags as soon as supplies come in.

headline.main: Thief Returns 9/11 Firefighter's Flag With Apology
headline.print_headline: Thief Returns 9/11 Firefighter's Flag With Apology

American Flags.lead_paragraph: An American flag stolen from the family of a firefighter killed on Sept. 11 has been returned with a note that says: "I am so sorry, I had no idea."

headline.main: Flag Missing From 9/11 Firefighter's Family's Home
headline.print_headline: Flag Missing From 9/11 Firefighter's Family's Home

American Flags.lead_paragraph: The family of a firefighter killed on Sept. 11 is hoping for the return of an American flag that disappeared from its yard in New York.

headline.main: Thinking About the Flag

American Flags.lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Newark Museum are getting the chance to think about flag and country and write their thoughts in a book. Former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg has lent the museum a 12-foot oil painting of the American flag by Ed Ruscha that hung in his office in Washington and more recently in his current office in Rochelle Park. The painting, which Mr. Lautenberg has called ''an inspiration,'' shows the flag buffeted by winds against a purple background with a black line on the bottom right, somewhat like the signature line on a check.

headline.main: A Wave of Photos Of Faces Still Missed

American Flags.lead_paragraph: THE anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001, will be observed by the unveiling of the Flag of Remembrance, a 20-by-27-foot American flag composed of the names and photographs of World Trade Center victims. The flag was created by Mindy Kombert and Sherry Kronenfeld, Chappaqua residents who suspended their graphic design business after the terrorist attacks to devote time to the project. ''We wanted to shift the focus from the lurid images we were seeing to the beautiful faces of the people who perished,'' Ms. Kombert said.

headline.main: With 9/11 Flag, a Mystery Unfurls

American Flags.lead_paragraph: There it was, one of the enduring symbols of Sept. 11: a simple American flag that became an icon when it was raised by three firefighters over the ruins of the World Trade Center. Evoking comparisons to Iwo Jima, the image of the flag, which came from a luxury charter yacht moored near the site, was captured by a news photographer and has since been seen, and imitated, around the world. There it was, indeed. But where is it now?

headline.main: Seven American Flags Are Set Afire in Brooklyn

American Flags.lead_paragraph: Someone set fire to seven American flags in a Brooklyn neighborhood yesterday, stoking outrage in a place where flags are displayed outside homes all year long. Six of the flags hung at houses in Marine Park, and one was on a car. An investigator speculated that the vandals might be teenagers out of school for the summer. Law enforcement officials said the burnings did not appear to be hate crimes.
