headline.main: Three Firefighters Say Flag Came From Yacht

American Flags.lead_paragraph: So the flag did come from the yacht, after all. Nearly seven months after three firefighters raised an American flag over the ruins of the World Trade Center, the three have signed an affidavit stating that the flag was removed from a charter yacht moored near the trade center at the time of the attack.

headline.main: Flag-Waving: Reading Between The Stripes

American Flags.lead_paragraph: PUT aside the city's current debate about the meaning of patriotism and whether the now ubiquitous American flag stands for militarism or solidarity. Or whether, sadly, wearing or waving a flag is a way for Middle Eastern-looking people to try to inoculate themselves against bias. Consider that for much of New York's history, the American flag was just one of many flags in this city of immigrants and competing political ideologies, said Mike Wallace, a professor of history at John Jay College of Criminal Justice and the director of the Gotham Center for New York History. In the 1860's, the Irish flag flew over City Hall, he said, and the red flag, symbol of international working-class solidarity, was often trotted out by left-leaning New Yorkers starting in the 1870's.

headline.main: Memorial in Space Station

American Flags.lead_paragraph: United States and Russian astronauts aboard the International Space Station held a brief ceremony today commemorating the victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The space shuttle Endeavour, which is docked to the station and took up a new crew, carried thousands of small flags representing families of the victims, badges and patches of the New York City Police and Fire departments, and a Marine flag saved from the Pentagon fire.

headline.main: A Flag, Please, and Make Sure It Flies Proudest

American Flags.lead_paragraph: THE usual group of men gathered outside the Borden Avenue Veterans Residence, a homeless shelter run by the Salvation Army in Hunters Point, Queens. Most of them wore some sort of remnant from military service -- a camouflage hat, a green jacket, lace-up boots -- and somehow they noticed, about 10:30 on a Wednesday morning, that the two flagpoles over the shelter entrance had no flags.

headline.main: 60's Lessons On How Not To Wave Flag

American Flags.lead_paragraph: TODD GITLIN is no flag waver, not by a long shot. Back in the 1960's, he was a leader of Students for a Democratic Society. Let's just say that he spent way too much time with people who spelled America with a K. Never, this sociology professor at New York University says, did he imagine a day when he would drape a large American flag across his balcony. But there, outside his Greenwich Village apartment, the broad stripes and bright stars now hang.

headline.main: For History or Tax Break, Claiming a Sept. 11 Icon

American Flags.lead_paragraph: When three firefighters hoisted an American flag atop the ruins of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, the image became an instant icon, evoking comparisons to Iwo Jima and forming the basis for a proposed memorial statue. So who cares that the flag itself was snatched off a yacht by the firefighters?

headline.main: Burning Flags Is Good Deed For a Scout

American Flags.lead_paragraph: IT will be a little harder to tell it's a patriotic holiday on Thursday. Usually, there's a sudden sprouting of red, white and blue this time of year. But since the flags have been up nonstop for 10 months, it's bound to look more like business as usual. One thing that might be a little out of the ordinary is the old-fashioned bunting that has become popular lately, particularly in quaint Colonial towns like Haddonfield. You can order it from Martha Stewart, who (between taking stock tips) has been busy whipping up lots of fancy flag stuff to drape over your front porch. In fact, she's a good customer of Annin & Company, the Roseland-based flag maker that has, over the years, supplied flags for Mount Everest, the North Pole and the George Washington Bridge.

headline.main: U.S. Binds Wounds in Red, White and Blue

American Flags.lead_paragraph: The signs of the pain inflicted by the terrorists span New York, from the dust cloud over the southern tip of Manhattan to the faces of the missing tacked onto walls in Greenwich Village to the thousands who watch heartbreaking images of the World Trade Center hulk on giant television screens in Times Square. But covering all that hurt, not only in New York but across the nation, are countless bandages in red, white and blue. In this city that is so often slow to show its feelings, the American flag bloomed in Manhattan and the boroughs, waved and worn by countless New Yorkers who wanted to do something, anything, to vent their anger and sorrow.

headline.main: Flag Flying Causes Stir At Palace In Honolulu

American Flags.lead_paragraph: It was meant as a respectful gesture for the victims of Sept. 11: raising the American flag over a historic state building downtown that had not flown the Stars and Stripes since the 1960's. But because the building is Iolani Palace, the 19th-century seat of the Hawaiian monarchy, whose overthrow in 1893 is still mourned by some here, the deed provoked a tempest of hurt feelings, apologies and angry e-mail messages and letters to the editor. It even prompted the governor himself to weigh in -- and then out.

headline.main: Red, White and Blue Highways

American Flags.lead_paragraph: FROM dusty rescue vehicles near Wall Street to gleaming low-riders cruising Los Angeles, the nation's traffic has taken on the star-spangled trappings of a Fourth of July parade. Flags are everywhere, and anywhere: hanging from radio antennas; draped over fenders and tailgates; waved through open windows by passengers and even drivers. Many are affixed to the glass, simultaneously signaling patriotism while posing potential safety hazards -- a Pontiac Firebird parked this week in Kingston, N.Y., had its rear glass and two side windows obscured.

headline.main: Architect Finds Spot for Flag Found in Ruins Of 9/11 Site

American Flags.lead_paragraph: On his way to present a revised design of the World Trade Center PATH terminal and transportation hub to the Port Authority board yesterday, the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava made an unexpected discovery that may add an important memorial symbol to the future train station at ground zero. Outside the boardroom, he spied an 8-by-12-foot American flag in a frame that almost fills an entire wall. The flag had flown over the main plaza of the trade center on Sept. 11, 2001, and survived in tatters. Mr. Calatrava was inspired.

headline.main: Golden Oldies of a Red, White and Blue Stripe

American Flags.lead_paragraph: Shoppers are snatching up the patriotic -- in music as well as clothing. ''God Bless America'' has already won out as anthem of the moment, with everyone from George W. Bush to Diana Ross singing it in public. But there are other favorites. Next month Arista is releasing Whitney Houston's rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' as a single; Warner Brothers is doing likewise with Faith Hill's version. And Oct. 16 is the debut date for an album called ''God Bless America,'' which will include Celine Dion, left, singing the title song; Frank Sinatra's recording of ''America the Beautiful''; Pete Seeger's raspy ''This Land Is Your Land''; and Mahalia Jackson's stirring ''My Country 'Tis of Thee.''

headline.main: Colors

American Flags.lead_paragraph: The diamonds remained mostly in safe-deposit boxes on Monday night, with many women at the season's opening of the Metropolitan Opera trading their usual blaze of jewelry for patriotic loops of red, white and blue ribbon and their elaborate evening gowns for short black dresses and dinner suits. The same style was observed at other evening events last week, which included the opening of Dance Theater of Harlem and the New York Botanical Garden's annual Rose Garden dinner-dance, both on Tuesday. Returning favorites were brocade or black satin dinner suits, popular during and after World War II. Today's version, stripped of the old rhinestone buttons and updated with contrasting color lapels, was revived two years ago by the designer Bill Blass. Many women appeared in these suits last week as they picked up on Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's suggestion to return to normal activities, which for them include benefits to raise money for charity.

headline.main: Pride in a Flag And Outrage Over Its Theft

American Flags.lead_paragraph: A CLOTH flag of the United States draped Joseph V. Daly's coffin when he was returned to the American earth. He was buried in 1999 with military honors, befitting a man of 84 years who had fought in World War II and received a Purple Heart for wounds suffered in the D-Day invasion. ''He loved to tell war stories,'' said a son, Joseph F. Daly, ''but he never talked about that part.'' The good ones, the ones who have seen real action, rarely do.

headline.main: Flag to Carry Sentiments From Ground Zero to Afghanistan

American Flags.lead_paragraph: No one is exactly sure how the flag started, or who wrote what first. But once someone scribbled a tribute to the New York City police officers who died on Sept. 11 -- scribbled it in black marker, on a large American flag that draped one of the surviving buildings near the World Trade Center -- it was hard to stop.

headline.main: Officials Agree on Role For Trade Center Flag

American Flags.lead_paragraph: Softening their stance after negotiations that stretched over two days, international Olympic officials said today that they had reached what they repeatedly called a dignified solution for how best to display a flag that has become a symbol of the victims and heroes of Sept. 11. The flag from the World Trade Center, now tattered from travels to Kandahar, the World Series in New York, and the Super Bowl in New Orleans, will be carried into Rice-Eccles Stadium for the opening ceremony Friday by an honor guard of firefighters, police officers and eight United States athletes. It will arrive before the traditional parade of athletes from each nation and stop in front of the stage where President Bush and other dignitaries will stand. Then the national anthem will be played.

headline.seo: At Empire State, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
headline.main: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
headline.print_headline: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa

American Flags.lead_paragraph: In New York’s latest religious battle, a group protested the Empire State Building’s rejection of a request for blue-and-white lighting in honor of Mother Teresa.

headline.main: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Houston To Test Its Attack Readiness

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Houston will conduct a drill early next month to test its preparedness for an attack involving nuclear, biological or chemical weapons and will conduct similar exercises every three months, city officials said. The drill will test the response of the Houston Medical Strike Team, which includes doctors, nurses, firefighters, police officers and hazardous materials technicians.

headline.main: Bush, in Reversal, Seeks Rules for Enforcing Biological Treaty

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Reversing earlier objections, the Bush administration said today that it would work with the international community to come up with a tough new enforcement plan for the landmark treaty that was to rid the world of biological weapons. President Bush, in a statement issued by the White House, outlined a seven-point proposal that State Department officials said would form the basis of the American negotiating position in Geneva on Nov. 19. There, delegates from the 144 nations that signed a 1972 convention banning biological weapons will discuss how to strengthen the accord.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; TROOPS TESTED

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Health officials questioned all 1,200 American troops at Khanabad air base in Uzbekistan and found no symptoms of exposure to nerve or other chemical weapons, an Army spokesman said. Traces of the substances were found on base a week ago. Officials will now survey the records of at least 1,800 other troops who passed through the base since American forces were deployed there in October. Officials believe the traces were left by chemical weapons once stored by the Soviet military, which controlled the base until Uzbekistan became independent in 1991.

headline.main: U.S. Concludes Al Qaeda Lacked a Chemical or Biological Stockpile

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: After months of searching the bomb-ravaged wreckage of terrorist training camps and other sites in Afghanistan, investigators have concluded that although Al Qaeda researched chemical and biological weapons there is no indication that it acquired or produced them, government officials say. Soil samples, swabs and other chemical tests have so far turned up no evidence of anthrax or other materials that would make chemical or biological weapons, the officials said. Testing is continuing.

headline.main: Panel Warns That Defense Against Germ Attack Is Weak

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Warning that the United States has escaped catastrophic biological attack largely by luck, the presidential commission on intelligence urged the American government on Thursday to intensify its efforts to block any biological assaults by terrorist groups or other countries. The recommendation, which was made in some of the most strident language found in the 601-page report, came even though the commission, like others before it, confirmed that the United States was wrong in its assertion that Saddam Hussein had biological weapons before the start of the war with Iraq in 2003.

headline.main: Defense Secretary Warns Of Unconventional Attacks

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld warned today that he expected the enemies of the United States would eventually help terrorist groups obtain chemical, biological and possibly even nuclear weapons technology. His remarks echoed other administration officials who have stepped up warnings on the spread of chemical and biological weapons, the threat of attacks against Americans overseas and the need for stronger antiterrorism measures at home.

headline.main: How Powell's Evidence Compares to Findings From Prior Intelligence

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The main purpose of the presentation that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell made to the United Nations Security Council was to demonstrate that Iraq was not complying with United Nations demands that it abandon its programs to develop weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Powell sought to explain what intelligence had led the Bush administration to make earlier charges that Iraq was seeking to develop biological, chemical and nuclear weapons, as well the missiles, aircraft and drones to deliver them. In so doing, he offered new information.

headline.seo: In Book, Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria Nuclear Site
headline.main: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in ’07
headline.print_headline: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in ’07

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: In a memoir, former Vice President Dick Cheney expresses little regret about Bush administration decisions.

headline.main: Survey Reveals Scant Backing for Syria Strike
headline.print_headline: Survey Reveals Scant Backing For Syria Strike

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.main: Warning on Qaeda Arms

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has warned law enforcement agencies that Al Qaeda may have shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles, but says it has no information that the organization plans to use the weapons against United States aircraft, a bureau official said today.

headline.main: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy
headline.print_headline: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Aides to President Obama say he will permanently reduce America’s arsenal by thousands of weapons.

headline.main: Talk of Chemical War Grows Louder on TV

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: ''Should you buy a gas mask?'' Diane Sawyer asked her viewers Tuesday on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC. ''Should you get vaccines for your kids?'' It was a startling question, asked in a report on biological weapons. But it was not unique.

headline.main: Money Short For Battle On Chemicals Used in War

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The head of the 143-nation group overseeing the elimination of chemical weapons has warned that it lacks the financial muscle it needs. The group, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, has managed to make less than half the inspections scheduled for this year -- of chemical weapons stocks and of chemical factories -- because the United States and several other countries have been late in paying their dues, the group's director general, José M. Bustani, said in an interview.

headline.main: Chemical Disarmament Hard Even in Peacetime
headline.print_headline:
Chemical Disarmament Tough
Even Without a War Going On

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Large numbers of foreign troops would almost certainly be needed to safeguard inspectors working in the midst of the civil war.

headline.main: Manhattan: Six Convicted In Weapons Plot

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Six men accused of running an international arms smuggling network were found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court of plotting to import weapons -- including antiaircraft missiles and antitank guns -- from Eastern Europe and other locations to the United States. The arms ring was led by Artur Solomonyan, an Armenian, federal prosecutors said, and sold weapons to an informant working with the F.B.I. who told the group he was buying the arms for Al Qaeda. The group delivered a machine gun and seven assault weapons to the informant, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said the dealers were not associated with any terrorist organization but were selling the weapons to make money.

headline.main: The Trouble With Zero

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment the first atomic bomb was detonated in New Mexico in July 1945, the menacing aura of the nuclear age has inspired visions of a world free of nuclear weapons. Never more so than now, with the prospect that the Taliban could someday control Pakistan's nuclear weapons, North Korea might develop nuclear-tipped missiles, Iran may soon become a nuclear power and terrorists could get a bomb. A growing army of nuclear abolitionists, concerned that proliferation could catch fire at any moment, is advancing the cause, led by Barack Obama, the first president to make nuclear disarmament a centerpiece of American defense policy.

headline.main: Bush Team Rejects U.N. Plan To Condemn Anthrax Attacks

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has rejected a proposal by France to win Security Council condemnation of the anthrax attacks in the United States, senior administration and European officials said today. The administration told the French government that a United Nations condemnation would be appropriate only if there was clear proof that the origin of the anthrax or the plot behind the outbreak was foreign, a senior administration official who opposed the move said.

headline.main: U.S. Sees No Conclusive Evidence of Chemical Arms Use by Syria

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The United States is waiting for the results of an exhaustive analysis of soil, hair, and other material to determine whether chemical warfare agents had been used.

headline.main: Remember 'Weapons of Mass Destruction'? For Bush, They Are a Nonissue
headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: WHITE HOUSE MEMO

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: In the debate over the necessity for the war in Iraq, few issues have been more contentious than whether Saddam Hussein possessed arsenals of banned weapons, as the Bush administration repeatedly said, or instead was pursuing weapons programs that might one day constitute a threat. On Tuesday, with Mr. Hussein in American custody and polls showing support for the White House's Iraq policy rebounding, Mr. Bush suggested that he no longer saw much distinction between the possibilities.

headline.main: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, a member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, lashed out at statements in President Bush's State of the Union address that said Iran was violating human rights and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. Ayatollah Yazdi rejected the president's claims and responded with his own: that White House policies after the Sept. 11 terror attacks violated the rights of Muslim immigrants. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline.main: Syria Opposition Claims Has Evidence of Chlorine Gas Attack
headline.print_headline: Syria Opposition Claims Has Evidence of Chlorine Gas Attack

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Syrian opposition activists have posted photographs and video that they say shows an improvised chlorine bomb to back up claims that President Bashar al-Assad's forces used chemical weapons in two attacks last week.

headline.main: Chemical Arms Team to Begin Talks With Syria
headline.print_headline: Chemical Arms Team to Begin Talks With Syria

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons is  tasked with destroying the stockpiles held by Damascus.

headline.main: U.S. Says It Found Qaeda Lab Being Built to Produce Anthrax

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The United States has discovered a laboratory under construction near Kandahar, Afghanistan, where American officials believe Al Qaeda planned to develop biological agents, officials said today. According to a confidential assessment by the United States Central Command, the laboratory was intended to produce anthrax. The assessment was presented to senior American officials in recent days and is based on documents and equipment found at the site.

headline.main: Al Qaeda Sites Point to Tests Of Chemicals

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: The United States has identified sites in Afghanistan that are suspected of involvement in Osama bin Laden's efforts to acquire and produce chemical and biological weapons, but none have been bombed since the military campaign began, according to American military and intelligence officials. The American bombing has spared the sites even though American intelligence officials believe that Al Qaeda may already have produced cyanide gas at one of them, a crude chemical weapons research laboratory in Derunta, a small village near the eastern Afghan city of Jalalabad.

headline.main: Army Reports Iraq Is Moving Toxic Arms To Its Troops
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | INTELLIGENCE

Weapons of Mass Destruction.lead_paragraph: Statements from Iraqi prisoners of war and electronic eavesdropping on Iraqi government communications indicate that Saddam Hussein has moved chemical weapons to the Medina Division, one of three Republican Guard divisions guarding the approaches to Baghdad, Army officials said. The Army officials said they strongly believed that Mr. Hussein would use the weapons as allied troops moved toward Baghdad to oust him and his government.

headline.seo: In Book, Donald Rumsfeld Recalls Bush’s Early Focus on Iraq
headline.main: In Book, Rumsfeld Recalls Bush’s Early Iraq Focus
headline.print_headline: In Book, Rumsfeld Recalls Bush’s Early Iraq Focus

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: “Known and Unknown,” former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld’s memoir of his political career, mixes the policy and the personal.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Recommendation For Navy Secretary

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has recommended that President Bush nominate an oilman, Colin R. McMillan, as Navy secretary, two senior Pentagon officials said. Mr. McMillan, 67, of Roswell, N.M., runs Permian Exploration and was chairman of Mr. Bush's New Mexico presidential campaign in 2000. He served in the Marines from 1957 to 1972 and was an assistant defense secretary 10 years ago, when Vice President Dick Cheney was defense secretary. The Navy has not had a permanent secretary since Gordon R. England left in January to become deputy secretary of the new Homeland Security Department.

headline.main: Medals To Victims

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: All members of the American armed services killed or wounded in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will be awarded the Purple Heart, and the Defense Department has created the Defense of Freedom Medal for all department civilians killed or wounded. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the tributes were appropriate, given the rare nature of the attacks on the Pentagon and the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Rumsfeld Favors Repatriating Detainees

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: The United States would rather have detainees at the Guantánamo Bay prison camp imprisoned by their home countries, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Thursday. American officials are waiting until the Iraqi and Afghan authorities can deal with dangerous prisoners before handing over detainees from those countries, Mr. Rumsfeld said at a news conference during a NATO defense ministers' meeting.

headline.seo: A Free-for-All on a Decade of War
headline.main: A Free-for-All on a Decade of War
headline.print_headline: 'My God, Man!'
headline.content_kicker: A Decade of War: A Round Table

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: From the Times Magazine, a post-9/11 debate on what has been learned and where our conclusions might take us.

headline.main: Reviewing Ideas for Fighting Terrorists

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Top military officials met today to plot better ways of dismantling Al Qaeda, including commando missions to capture and kill its leaders, officials said. In a recent memorandum, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld asked Gen. Charles R. Holland of the Special Operations Command and other senior military leaders to come up with new ideas for tracking down Osama bin Laden's network, two officials said on condition of anonymity.

headline.main: Concerns Led To Revisions, Rumsfeld Says

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said on Tuesday that he rescinded the use of controversial interrogation techniques for detainees at Guantánamo Bay in early 2003 because he had learned that Pentagon lawyers thought some of them were illegal and verged on torture. ''We didn't want to be doing something that people had concerns about in the department,'' Mr. Rumsfeld said at a Pentagon news conference.

headline.main: White House Denies Texas Session Is About Iraq

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: The White House vigorously denied today that President Bush had summoned his senior military advisers to his ranch here to map out a potential effort to topple Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq, declaring that the sole purpose of a meeting to be held here Wednesday was to review military procurement, missile defense and Pentagon spending. ''Look, we've had war councils on Iraq, and we let people know,'' said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman. ''This is the case of the media chasing its own imagination.''

headline.main: Rumsfeld Sees Need to Realign Military Fight Against Terror

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has told military commanders that the Pentagon is ill suited to combat terrorism and suggested that a new, more agile security agency may be needed to overcome the global threat. ''It is not possible to change D.o.D. fast enough to successfully fight the global war on terror,'' Mr. Rumsfeld said in a memo dated Oct. 16, using initials for Department of Defense. ''An alternative might be to try to fashion a new institution, either within D.o.D. or elsewhere -- one that seamlessly focuses the capabilities of several departments and agencies on this key problem.''

headline.main: A 'Damaged' Information Office Is Declared Closed by Rumsfeld
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld disbanded the Pentagon's Office of Strategic Influence today, ending a short-lived plan to provide news items, possibly even false ones, to unwitting foreign journalists to influence public sentiment abroad. Mr. Rumsfeld denied that the new office would have spread misinformation, but he said commentaries and editorial cartoons about the office's proposed activities made it impossible for it to do its job.

headline.main: White House Enacts a Plan To Ease Political Damage

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Under the command of President Bush's two senior political advisers, the White House rolled out a plan this weekend to contain the political damage from the administration's response to Hurricane Katrina. It orchestrated visits by cabinet members to the region, leading up to an extraordinary return visit by Mr. Bush planned for Monday, directed administration officials not to respond to attacks from Democrats on the relief efforts, and sought to move the blame for the slow response to Louisiana state officials, according to Republicans familiar with the White House plan.

headline.main: Rumsfeld Says Airport Should Open

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he hoped Ronald Reagan National Airport could reopen soon, because keeping it closed would be a victory for terrorists. The airport, just south of the Pentagon in Virginia and just across the Potomac River from the heart of Washington, is the only major one that has not reopened since Sept. 11, when a hijacked plane hit the Pentagon and two others hit the World Trade Center towers in New York. Mr. Rumsfeld said on Sept. 16 that the airport would have to be closed indefinitely.

headline.main: Rumsfeld Says He May Drop New Office Of Influence
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon may eliminate a new office intended to influence public opinion and policy makers overseas, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today. Proposals from the new agency, the Office of Strategic Influence, have caused an uproar in Congress and elsewhere in the government. Its director, Brig. Gen. Simon P. Worden of the Air Force, has proposed that the office coordinate activities ranging from public press releases to secret ''information warfare'' in friendly as well as unfriendly countries, military officials said. In the past, such secret operations included the spreading of inaccurate or misleading information.

headline.main: Homeland Security In a Pentagon Post

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld named Army Secretary Thomas E. White today to be the Pentagon's first homeland security coordinator. Mr. White, an Army brigadier general who is retired, will remain Army secretary while he coordinates the Defense Department's efforts with the new Homeland Security Council to be headed by Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, who takes up his new position next week.

headline.main: Navy Secretary Reported in Line To Be Named Rumsfeld Deputy

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said on Tuesday that he had recommended to President Bush a successor to Deputy Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, who has been nominated to head the World Bank. Pentagon officials said all signs pointed to Navy Secretary Gordon R. England as the choice.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: How To Improve The World

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Responding to a remark by President Bush's national security adviser that the world ''will live better without Saddam Hussein in power,'' a government newspaper has said the world would ''definitely be a better place'' without Mr. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld ''and their friends.'' Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, made her comment in an interview published last week by Al Hayat, an Arabic daily newspaper published in London. The Bush administration has considered Iraq as a possible target in its war on terrorism.

headline.main: Rumsfeld to Appeal to Arab Public on Mideast TV Network

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld spoke today on a Middle East television network to assure Arab viewers that the United States was waging war against terrorists in Afghanistan, not the Afghan people. Mr. Rumsfeld became the latest senior Bush administration official to grant an interview to Al Jazeera, the television network in Qatar, which has angered American officials by broadcasting tapes made by Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Guantánamo Detainees' Suit Dismissed

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington has dismissed the main part of a lawsuit brought by four former Guantánamo detainees who were seeking damages from Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other military officials who the suit said were responsible for their mistreatment and wrongful imprisonment. The four former detainees, all British citizens picked up in Pakistan and Afghanistan, charged in their October lawsuit that they had faced repeated beatings, death threats, interrogation at gunpoint, forced nakedness and menacing with unmuzzled dogs. Judge Ricardo M. Urbina on Monday ruled that the defendants had acted in their official government capacity and thus a longstanding legal doctrine made them immune from such a lawsuit. NEIL A. LEWIS (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: High Costs Seen In Trials For Detainees

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon may need hundreds of millions of dollars in additional financing from Congress to build courtrooms, housing and other necessities of running military trials for terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay, officials said. Cully Stimson, the Defense Department's deputy assistant secretary for detainee affairs, said military officials were considering two plans that involve increasing the number of courtrooms at the detention center from one to as many as 10. Brig. Gen. Edward Leacock, deputy commander of the joint task force that runs the facility holding more than 400 terrorism suspects, said the price could run into the ''hundreds of millions.'' Military planners are expected presented their proposals to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld next week, General Leacock said.

headline.main: After the War, New Stature for Rumsfeld
headline.kicker: A NATION AT WAR: THE DEFENSE SECRETARY

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: It was not the heat of war that rattled Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, but the lull beforehand. Meeting with advisers a couple of weeks before fighting began, Mr. Rumsfeld, usually supremely self-assured, suddenly insisted, ''I need help.'' The United Nations would not support the war. Turkey had shut its doors to coalition troops. His desire for quick military action against Iraq was stalled, and Mr. Rumsfeld was looking for ways to move it off the diplomatic dime. He found himself in a rare position -- not in control. ''It was beyond his realm,'' said someone who was present.

headline.main: Bush Seals Fate of Office Of Influence In Pentagon
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: President Bush expressed alarm today over the possible activities of a new Pentagon office intended to influence public sentiment abroad and strongly endorsed efforts to disband or reconfigure the agency. When asked today whether he had ordered Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld to close the office, Mr. Bush said, ''I didn't even need to tell him this; he knows how I feel. I saw it reflected in his comments the other day.''

headline.main: Rumsfeld Asserts Forces Must Take Risks and Think Creatively to Prepare for New Challenges

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today urged ''new ways of thinking and new ways of fighting'' -- and billions of dollars in new spending -- to prepare for enemies he said may attack with weapons far deadlier than hijacked airliners. The challenge in this new century is ''to defend our nation against the unknown, the uncertain and what we have to understand will be the unexpected,'' Mr. Rumsfeld told military and civilian students at the National Defense University. ''We have to put aside the comfortable ways of thinking and planning, take risks and try new things so that we can prepare our forces to deter and defeat adversaries that have not yet emerged to challenge us.''

headline.main: Terrorists Will Fail in Attempt to Disrupt Voting for President in Afghanistan, Rumsfeld Says

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Tuesday that fighters for the Taliban and Al Qaeda remained determined to disrupt the October presidential election in Afghanistan with attacks focused increasingly on civilian targets, but he expressed certainty that their efforts would fail. Mr. Rumsfeld also said that increasing narcotics cultivation and trafficking threatened a stable and democratic Afghanistan but that the solution would require a ''master plan'' involving the Kabul government, coalition forces and the international community.

headline.main: Rumsfeld Seeks Leaner Army, and a Full Term

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: Ask Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld to define his legacy, and he cuts the question short: ''Don't. Hold off on it. There will be plenty of time.'' With a full list of policy initiatives ahead and travel plans penciled in through the Beijing Olympics of 2008, Mr. Rumsfeld gives every indication of serving out the rest of the Bush administration, confounding those who predicted his departure even after President Bush refused, twice, to accept his resignation over the Abu Ghraib prison scandal.

headline.main: Reporters Turn From Deference to Outrage
headline.kicker: STORM AND CRISIS: NEWS COVERAGE -- THE TV WATCH

Donald Rumsfeld.lead_paragraph: When even Fox News will not give Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld more than half the screen for his first appearance in the Hurricane Katrina disaster zone, it is clear that television is having a major mood swing. The last time reporters and anchors were so personally and passionately involved in a story was early in the Iraq war, when journalists who accompanied troops for weeks at a time became bullish supporters of the soldiers and their mission.

headline.main: FEMA Discontinues $2,000-a-Household Benefit
headline.kicker: STORM AND CRISIS: AID TO FAMILIES

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has discontinued its $2,000-per-household emergency assistance program for victims of Hurricane Katrina, switching to a more regimented aid package intended to encourage families to leave shelters. In the aftermath of the storm, FEMA gave displaced families a payment of $2,000, saying they could use the money for clothing, food or rental housing. More than 752,000 households signed up, collecting just over $1.5 billion, officials said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Unreimbursed Police Expenses

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on a resolution calling on the Federal Emergency Management Agency to reimburse nearly $280 million for New York Police Department expenses, including overtime, related to the World Trade Center attack. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7124.

headline.main: Homeland Security Chief Outlines FEMA Overhaul
headline.kicker: STORM AND CRISIS: THE FEDERAL RESPONSE

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff told House investigators on Wednesday that after a ''crash course'' in disaster, he was prepared to rebuild the Federal Emergency Management Agency so that it would never again prove so inadequate in its response to catastrophes like Hurricane Katrina. FEMA, the primary federal agency responsible for disaster response, is stuck in the 20th century when it comes to assembling and distributing emergency supplies like food and water, Mr. Chertoff said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The Jan. 11 deadline for victims of the World Trade Center attack to apply for federal assistance has been extended to March 11, state and federal officials said yesterday. Under the program, disaster victims are eligible for crisis counseling, and those whose homes or belongings were lost or damaged, as well as business owners whose businesses were harmed, are eligible for low-interest loans or grants. Those seeking assistance should call the Federal Emergency Management Agency, (800) 462-9029, or check the Web site at www.fema.gov.

headline.main: AVAILABLE FOR HIRE

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Two months after resigning under fire for his handling of aid efforts after Hurricane Katrina, Michael D. Brown, the ex-chief of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, actually left the agency's payroll last week.

headline.main: Pay for Ex-Head of FEMA

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Michael D. Brown, who resigned as leader of the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Sept. 12 after criticism of his performance in leading the agency's response to Hurricane Katrina, will remain on the government pay roll for yet another month. The Department of Homeland Security, which oversees FEMA, agreed to hire Mr. Brown as a contractor, still at his $148,000 annual salary, first for one month, and now for a second month, said Russ Knocke, a department spokesman.

headline.main: Ex-FEMA Director Says He Issued Early Warnings

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Michael D. Brown, who stepped down as director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency after the government's much-criticized response to Hurricane Katrina, told a Congressional committee on Tuesday that he had warned the White House of impending disaster several days before the storm struck. Asked when the White House became aware that a ''disaster was looming'' in the Gulf Coast region, Mr. Brown said he had warned Andrew H. Card Jr., President Bush's chief of staff, at least three days before the hurricane hit New Orleans on Aug. 28.

headline.main: Attacks Halt Meeting
headline.kicker: A DAY OF TERROR: DISASTER PLANNING

FEMA.lead_paragraph: At the time the Pentagon and World Trade Center were being attacked yesterday, Joe Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and representatives from the 50 state emergency management agencies were attending an annual conference of emergency response officials at a resort in Big Sky, Mont. One of the day's main seminar topics was how to prepare for terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Road Repair

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The city is repaving the streets on roughly 240 city blocks in Lower Manhattan that were damaged by heavy trucks carting away debris from the World Trade Center site, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The project, which is to be completed by June 1, is being paid for by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Officials said that roughly two-thirds of the streets will have to be ripped up again and repaved later, as the supporting infrastructure below them is replaced. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: Hurricane Evacuees Face Eviction Threats at Both Their Old Homes and New

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Warned by angry Texas officials that thousands of Hurricane Katrina evacuees could soon face eviction from their new homes, the Federal Emergency Management Agency is negotiating with officials in Dallas to set up a federally financed housing-voucher program, municipal officials said Thursday. Texas has the largest single concentration of the 500,000 households displaced by the hurricane.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The state and city will receive $250 million from the federal government to help pay the pensions of police officers and firefighters killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki and federal officials said yesterday. The grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency will cover the unforeseen increases in contributions to the pension system. The state and city had to pay the increases to cover benefits for the families of 343 firefighters and 23 police officers who died in the attack. The funds are part of about $8.8 billion in FEMA grants already pledged to the city and state, state officials said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: FEMA Broke Its Promise on Housing, Houston Mayor Says

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill White of Houston accused the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Wednesday of breaking its promise to Hurricane Katrina evacuees by imposing strict limits on a housing relocation program as it stops thousands of hotel subsidies. ''Great nations, like good people, keep their word,'' Mr. White wrote in a letter about Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff and other senior emergency officials.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. To Receive FEMA Aid

FEMA.lead_paragraph: New York University said yesterday that the federal government had agreed to cover some of the expenses incurred from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The decision by the Federal Emergency Management Agency reverses an earlier determination that the university would not qualify for such reimbursement. N.Y.U. said the turnabout was a result of strong support from New York's Congressional delegation and Gov. George E. Pataki. N.Y.U. had submitted a list of about $10 million in expenses, which included the cost of rehousing students and removing debris from dormitories near the World Trade Center. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: State Responsible For Trailer Residents

FEMA.lead_paragraph: State officials must be prepared to help residents evacuate in advance of a major hurricane, even if they live in temporary trailers set up in group sites by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff told Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco in a letter. The letter, one in a series between Mr. Chertoff and Ms. Blanco, responded to the governor's request that the federal government assume responsibility for caring for the 7,100 families in these group sites. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Washington: A Bush Aide Resigns

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Joe M. Allbaugh has resigned as head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, President Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said. Mr. Fleischer said Mr. Allbaugh left ''to pursue other endeavors'' after nine years of working with Mr. Bush. Mr. Allbaugh was the manager of Mr. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign and he, Karl Rove and Karen Hughes were considered Mr. Bush's innermost circle of advisers. Mr. Allbaugh said in a statement that he would help incorporate his agency into the new Department of Homeland Security and would leave the administration in March, to enter the private sector.

headline.main: Government Saw Flood Risk but Not Levee Failure

FEMA.lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Brown, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, returned in January from a tour of the tsunami devastation in Asia, he urgently gathered his aides to prepare for a similar catastrophe at home. ''New Orleans was the No.1 disaster we were talking about,'' recalled Eric L. Tolbert, then a top FEMA official. ''We were obsessed with New Orleans because of the risk.''

headline.main: FEMA Leader Under Clinton Makes It Pay

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Not long before Hurricane Katrina made landfall, James Lee Witt, the former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and his colleagues called officials on the Gulf Coast to offer their help. Soon after the storm hit, the State of Louisiana signed up with Witt Associates, a disaster consulting firm. Within days, Mr. Witt had become a fixture at the state's emergency operations center in Baton Rouge, advising the governor and sleeping in a trailer. He even figured out a way for FEMA to reimburse the state for his firm's fees, which the company estimates at $4 million to $6 million over the next year.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Agency Powers Proposed

FEMA.lead_paragraph: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democratic candidate for mayor, proposed strengthening the city's Office of Emergency Management yesterday and renaming it the Homeland Security Office. Under Mr. Miller's proposal, the office would reassume the authority it once had under Rudolph W. Giuliani to settle jurisdictional disputes between the Police and Fire Departments, and would coordinate the antiterrorism efforts of various agencies. Currently, the emergency management agency can help mediate disagreements, but does not have the power to rule on them. Paul Elliott, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, called the proposed changes unnecessary and ''an added bureaucracy.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

headline.main: In Storm's Ruins, a Rush to Rebuild and Reopen for Business

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Private contractors, guided by two former directors of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and other well-connected lobbyists and consultants, are rushing to cash in on the unprecedented sums to be spent on Hurricane Katrina relief and reconstruction. From global engineering and construction firms like the Fluor Corporation and Halliburton to local trash removal and road-building concerns, the private sector is poised to reap a windfall of business in the largest domestic rebuilding effort ever undertaken.

headline.main: Bush Makes Choice for Domestic Security Position

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Mike Brown, deputy director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, is President Bush's choice to oversee the government's disaster and emergency assistance efforts when the agency becomes part of the new Department of Homeland Security. Mr. Brown had been considered a leading candidate to replace Joe Allbaugh, a longtime Bush aide who announced last month he was stepping down as the emergency agency's chief in March. Mr. Bush nominated Mr. Brown today to be undersecretary for emergency preparedness and response at the Homeland Security Department.

headline.main: Internal Report Urges Changes in Disaster Response

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Widespread criticism of the government's sluggish response to Hurricane Katrina was largely deserved, the Homeland Security Department's internal watchdog concludes in a report faulting the agency for focusing on terrorism at the expense of preparing for natural disasters. The report, by Inspector General Richard L. Skinner and to be released on Friday, includes 38 recommendations for improving disaster response missions by the department and its Federal Emergency Management Agency. The report's executive summary and the recommendations were obtained Thursday by The Associated Press.

headline.main: July 7-13: FRONT LINES; SHAPING SECURITY AGENCY

FEMA.lead_paragraph: There was bipartisan support for a new Department of Homeland Security when President Bush proposed it, but now there is bipartisan support for drastically changing his plan. House committees refused the administration's pleas to include the Coast Guard, the Secret Service and the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the department, and also voted to split up the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The committee recommendations are likely to be changed when the issue reaches the House and Senate floors, but Mr. Bush's plan is unlikely to emerge intact. David Firestone

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Schools To Get More 9/11 Money

FEMA.lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has agreed to give the New York City school system $33 million to counsel students traumatized by the World Trade Center attack. The agency had already awarded the Department of Education $8.9 million for the mental health needs of students who were directly affected by the attack. That money went to schools below 14th Street in Manhattan, as well as districts where dozens of students lost family members. The new funds will be distributed systemwide, based on the findings of a mental-health study of 8,300 city schoolchildren after the attack. The money will come through Project Liberty, a crisis counseling service. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged

FEMA.lead_paragraph: Local elected officials and community groups demanded yesterday that the Federal Emergency Management Agency extend a housing assistance program that is to expire on Friday. The FEMA program, started shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, has paid almost $100 million to nearly 11,000 applicants who lived or worked in Manhattan and have faced eviction or foreclosure. But, the officials said, the deadline should be extended, partly because of New York's continuing economic problems, and partly because the program has not done enough to reach out to potential applicants throughout the metropolitan area. The officials included Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat; William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller; and the Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches. David W. Chen (NYT)

headline.main: FEMA Chief Was Recalled After High-Level Meeting

FEMA.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, at a contentious briefing in the White House press room, President Bush's top spokesman publicly but cautiously praised the work of Michael D. Brown, the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. When pressed, the spokesman, Scott McClellan, said Mr. Bush stood by his previous statement that Mr. Brown had been doing ''a heck of a job.'' But it fact, just hours before, in a meeting in the Oval Office, Mr. Brown's fate had been all but sealed. Michael Chertoff, the onetime judge who has told friends he was shocked by the state of the Department of Homeland Security, which he inherited earlier this year, told Mr. Bush and the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., that he wanted to remove Mr. Brown from the day-to-day management of the Hurricane Katrina relief effort, although he would remain the head of FEMA.

headline.main: U.N. Approves New Sanctions to Deter Iran
headline.print_headline: U.N. APPROVES NEW SANCTIONS TO DETER IRAN

United Nations.lead_paragraph: A new measure takes aim at the military in another attempt to pressure Iran over its nuclear program.

headline.seo: Iran Defends Rights Record Opposition Cancels Rally
headline.main: Iran Defends Rights Record as Opposition Cancels Rally
headline.print_headline: Iran Defends Rights Record As Opposition Cancels Rally

United Nations.lead_paragraph: At the United Nations Human Rights Council, Iran was questioned about its lack of public accounting for the violence and imprisonment protesters faced after the disputed election last year.

headline.main: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; TERROR PENALTIES

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council unanimously voted in favor of a resolution strengthening the enforcement of penalties -- including the freezing of funds, an arms embargo and travel prohibitions -- against Osama bin Laden, Al Qaeda, the Taliban and their associates. It also called on governments to submit updated reports on their efforts.

headline.main: U.S. Walks Out as Iran Leader Speaks
headline.print_headline: Iran Leader Says U.S. Planned 9/11 Attacks

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad made a series of incendiary comments about the Sept. 11 attacks in his U.N. address.

headline.seo: Obama Supports U.N. Seat for India
headline.main: Countering China, Obama Backs India for U.N. Council
headline.print_headline: OBAMA COURTS EMERGENT INDIA AS DEEPER ALLY

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Analysts say that China has been cool to the idea of permanent membership on the U.N. Security Council for rival Asian powers.

headline.main: Afghans Avenge Florida Koran Burning, Killing 12

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters overran the United Nations compound in Mazar-i-Sharif, killing at least 12 people, Afghan and United Nations officials said.

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Tighter Security For Nobel Peace Ceremony

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Security around the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo next month will be heightened as a result of the attacks on the United States and statements by Osama bin Laden, the police say. The winner of the prize is Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, and in a recent videotape Mr. bin Laden called Mr. Annan a ''criminal.''

headline.main: Taliban and Qaeda Sanctions Are Split

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council voted Friday to treat Al Qaeda and the Taliban separately when it comes to sanctions, a move that is aimed at supporting the Afghan government's reconciliation efforts and that could help clear a path for negotiations with the Taliban. The American ambassador, Susan E. Rice, said the vote would send ''a clear message to the Taliban that there is a future for those who separate from Al Qaeda.''

headline.main: Panel To Study Algeria Blasts

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is appointing an independent panel to investigate the car bombing of two United Nations buildings in Algiers last month attributed to a group linked to Al Qaeda that killed 17 staff members and at least 30 other people, the organization announced. The panel is also expected to recommend steps to tighten security at United Nations offices worldwide.

headline.seo: Erdogan Criticizes Israel at U.N. - Ahmadinejad Speaks, Too
headline.main: Harsh Words From Turkey About Israel, and From Iran About United States
headline.print_headline: Harsh Words From Turkey About Israel, and From Iran About United States

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey enumerated a long list of grievances with Israel, and Iran’s president delivered an anti-Western tirade.

headline.main: Morocco: Western Sahara Talks Resuming

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appealed for ''substantive'' results from deadlocked talks brokered by the United Nations between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front over the future of the resource-rich Western Sahara annexed by Morocco in 1975 after the colonial power Spain withdrew. A closed-door round of negotiations, the third in seven months, begin on Tuesday in Manhasset, N.Y., amid fear that failure to settle the dispute in the region, already victimized by violence linked to Al Qaeda, could lead to the resumption of a guerrilla war that lasted until 1991, when the United Nations sent peacekeepers.

headline.main: U.N. Extends Tenure Of Afghan Forces

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The Security Council extended the tenure of international troops in Afghanistan today for another six months but chose not to expand their ranks, as Afghanistan's interim government and some senior United Nations officials had urged. The 15-member body unanimously approved the resolution to maintain the 4,500-member International Security Assistance Force, once its initial mandate expires on June 20.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg To Address U.N.

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will address the United Nations on Friday, his aides said yesterday. The mayor, who earlier this summer took action to crack down on diplomats with outstanding parking tickets, will take a global tone in his speech to the General Assembly. ''He's going to talk about the renewed importance of New York's role as the host city for the United Nations in light of Sept. 11, and thank the freedom-loving countries who have supported New York City,'' said his spokesman, Edward Skyler. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: Somalian Rebels Loot U.N. Posts and Ban 3 Agencies
headline.print_headline: Somalia Rebels Loot U.N. Posts and Ban 3 Agencies

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The Shabab rebels accused the three agencies of working against the establishment of an Islamic state.

headline.main: U.N. Delays General Assembly Session of World Leaders Indefinitely

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations announced today that it was delaying indefinitely the annual speeches by world leaders that traditionally bring platoons of politicians to New York in September because of the strain this would place on the city's security services. The two-week ''general debate'' of the General Assembly had been due to start on Monday with a speech by President Bush.

headline.main: U.N. Security Council Calls for International Help for Iraq
headline.print_headline: U.N. Security Council Calls for International Help for Iraq

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The U.N. Security Council condemned on Thursday recent attacks by Islamic State militants in Iraq and called for international support for the country after the 15-member body held an emergency meeting on the situation.

headline.main: World Briefing | United Nations: Airstrike Report Won't Be Released

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations said it had decided not to publicly release a report written by a fact-finding team sent to the site of an American airstrike that killed dozens of Afghans, but denied that it was doing so because of pressure from the United States. The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan said the report had been submitted to the United States and Afghan governments, which were conducting their own investigations. According to The Times of London, a preliminary report by the team found that the United States might have understated the death toll and covered up evidence related to the attack. The Pentagon denied that any evidence had been secretly removed.

headline.main: U.N. Reviews Plans to Protect Its Offices Around the World

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Reinforced fences. Bulletproof partitions. Electronic monitors and alarms. Sensors to detect gas and chemical attacks. Stockpiles of biohazard gear. Blastproof trash cans. Having provided a public forum for countries uniting to fight terrorism, the United Nations is now looking at ways to make itself more impregnable to terrorists.

headline.main: Effort to Cut Off Qaeda Funds Hits Snags

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The United Nations group formed to stop the flow of funds to Al Qaeda has concluded that serious problems in international efforts to track the terrorist network's finances have left it ''still able to receive money,'' according to a report circulated here today. In the report Michael Chandler, who heads the monitoring group, says a continuing lack of intelligence-sharing and cooperation between governments means that Qaeda operatives can still move across borders and get financial support.

headline.main: U.N. Warns Eritrea on Aiding Islamists
headline.print_headline: U.N. Warns Eritrea on Aiding Islamists

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The U.N. Security Council warned Eritrea that it would consider action against anyone who undermined peace in Somalia.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; AIRLINES' DEBTS

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Airlines are improperly withholding more than $20 million they owe Afghanistan, American officials said. The State Department has urged the International Air Transport Association to turn over the money, which airlines paid to fly over Afghanistan. The funds were collected under a contract with the Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism and delivered to the Taliban until United Nations sanctions were applied in 1999; after that, some payments were made under United Nations supervision, the last in August 2001. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | United Nations: Renewed Call For Syria To Leave Lebanon

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The Security Council called on Syria to withdraw its 14,000 troops from Lebanon and directed Secretary General Kofi Annan to put pressure on Damascus and Beirut by reporting every six months on compliance with a Sept. 2 resolution sponsored by the United States and France that ordered all foreign forces out of Lebanon. ''It will keep Syria's feet to the fire on complying with the requirements of the resolution,'' said Anne Patterson, the deputy United States ambassador. Mr. Annan reported on Oct. 1 that Syria would neither confirm whether it had redeployed any troops nor give any timetable of when it might. Syria's foreign minister, Farouq al-Shara, and the Lebanese Foreign Ministry both dismissed the new Security Council action as illegal intervention in their countries' bilateral relations. Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline.main: The Spirit of the Olympics

United Nations.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee is asking for a halt to violence worldwide during the 2002 Winter Olympics in February in Salt Lake City, the president of committee, Jacques Rogge, said today. ''A resolution supported by the United States will be presented to the General Assembly of the United Nations for a truce, an Olympic truce,'' Mr. Rogge said during a speech at the National Press Club.

headline.main: Peacekeepers and Diplomats, Seeking to End Darfur's Violence, Hit Roadblock

United Nations.lead_paragraph: Sudan has withdrawn its support for a United Nations peacekeeping force to replace African Union troops now in the conflict-ridden Darfur region, and is lobbying other countries to discourage the substitution, Jan Pronk, the United Nations envoy for Sudan, said Tuesday. ''The government is taking a very strong position against a transition to the U.N., and that is new,'' Mr. Pronk said. ''Sudan has sent delegations to many countries in the world in order to plead its case: let the A.U. stay and let the U.N. not come.''

headline.seo: U.N. Report Criticizes American Drone Attacks
headline.main: U.N. Report Highly Critical of U.S. Drone Attacks
headline.print_headline: U.N. Report Highly Critical of American Drone Attacks, Warning of Use by Others

United Nations.lead_paragraph: An official said the use of drones to kill terror suspects undermines global constraints on using military force.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to contribute $3 million to the Tribute Center, the temporary 9/11 memorial that is scheduled to open in the spring at 120 Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center site. The center's Introductory/Orientation Gallery will be named for the Port Authority, and Port Authority employees will lead tours of the site from there. Supporting the center ''is in line with our mission of revitalizing Lower Manhattan and redeveloping the World Trade Center site,'' said James Connors, a Port Authority executive. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

headline.main: $10 Deal for Rights to World Trade Center Name Draws Scrutiny
headline.print_headline: $10 Deal for Rights to ‘World Trade Center,’ Made Years Ago, Draws State Scrutiny

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: New York State is looking into the sale of the rights to the three-word name to a nonprofit, accusing a former Port Authority official of leading the deal without proper approval.

headline.main: Pro Bono Accounts

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: * Port Authority Police Department Patrolman's Benevolent Association, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., to Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee, New York, to create a campaign to help raise money for the families of the 37 Port Authority officers who died in the World Trade Center attacks.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 17 Accused Of Racketeering

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Seventeen men were indicted on racketeering charges of defrauding the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey of as much as $2.5 million, prosecutors said yesterday. District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said that the men overcharged the Port Authority in asbestos contracts and included fake employees in a contract to clean artifacts recovered from the World Trade Center attack. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.seo: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ by Auditors
headline.main: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ as Trade Center Costs Rise
headline.print_headline: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ as Trade Center Costs Rise

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The estimated cost of rebuilding the World Trade Center has grown to at least $14.8 billion, up from $11 billion in 2008, according to an audit commissioned by the bistate agency.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Report Mixed

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Despite the collapse of the World Trade Center, which it owned, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey remains financially strong, according to Standard & Poor's. It affirmed the AA- rating of the authority's bonds and removed it from the CreditWatch warning list; both steps should reassure investors, but Standard & Poor's warned that the outlook for the Port Authority has become negative, because of its plans to increase its debt load and because of weak flight traffic at its airports. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Wants Say Over Airports

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that a potential swap of the World Trade Center site for the land owned by the city at its two airports ''would not just be a land-for-land deal,'' because the city ''has to have a say in how the airports are run.'' City officials said previously that they would seek financial compensation for turning over the land to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center property. But skeptics of a swap have suggested the Port Authority would expand Newark Airport at the expense of La Guardia and Kennedy Airports. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.seo: Port Authority’s Director, Christopher Ward, Is Said to Be Leaving
headline.main: Director Said to Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month
headline.print_headline: Director Said To Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Christopher O. Ward’s departure will add to the list of positions that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo must fill.

headline.main: Director Said To Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Christopher O. Ward, who jump-started development of the stalled World Trade Center site and memorial and oversaw a significant toll increase on the Hudson River crossings, intends to resign as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with his plans. Mr. Ward's departure is planned for the end of October. It will create a formidable challenge for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who must now appoint a new chief for two of the most influential agencies under his purview: the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder, also plans to leave next month, having announced his resignation in July.

headline.seo: In Feud Over Judgeships, Unusual Move by Christie
headline.main: Unusual Move by Christie in Feud Over Judgeships
headline.print_headline: Unusual Move by Christie In Feud Over Judgeships

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, locked in a power struggle with the State Senate, has moved the state’s attorney general into a top job at the Port Authority until she can be confirmed as a judge.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Dykstra, the president and chief executive of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, said after a board meeting yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center land, should ''be delivering to us a buildable site'' for the memorial and memorial museum, meaning the authority alone should pay the cost of the underground infrastructure. At the meeting, Christine A. Ferer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's liaison to the families of 9/11 victims and a Port Authority commissioner, joined the board. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: '93 Bombing Trial Imminent

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: A trial to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should be held liable in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing could begin as early as April, lawyers and a State Supreme Court judge said yesterday. At a meeting with Justice Stanley L. Sklar, lawyers for the Port Authority and for plaintiffs in a lawsuit said they expected the trial to take about three weeks. More than 100 people and companies have filed suit against the authority, claiming it should be liable because it was warned to close its underground parking garage to the public. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.seo: Port Authority Is Sued Over Church Ruined on 9/11
headline.main: Port Authority Is Sued Over Church Destroyed on 9/11
headline.print_headline: Port Authority Is Sued Over Church Destroyed on 9/11

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The Greek Orthodox church says the agency did not hold up its end of a rebuilding agreement.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Sued

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: A group of Sept. 11 victims' family members filed a lawsuit yesterday asking the State Supreme Court in Manhattan to declare the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's real estate in New York subject to New York City's fire and building codes. Thomas D. Shanahan, a lawyer for the group, the Skyscraper Safety Campaign, said the Port Authority claims that because it is a bistate agency, it is not required to comply with city safety codes. A Port Authority spokesman, Greg Trevor, declined to comment on pending litigation. But the agency has said it voluntarily adhered to city codes in constructing the first trade center and intended to do the same with the rebuilding on the site.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Chief Named

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Steven Plate, a 51-year-old engineer, was named yesterday as director of priority programs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He will oversee the World Trade Center redevelopment project for the authority, which owns the site, and the construction of a permanent PATH transportation hub there. In 21 years at the authority, Mr. Plate has managed several projects, including the $1.9 billion AirTrain system at Kennedy International Airport. He was also the mayor of Glen Ridge, N.J., from 2000 to 2003. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Disputed Transcripts Set For Release

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, reversing itself, said it would no longer resist the release of transcripts of more than 200 hours of employee and civilian conversations during the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, 2001. On Friday, responding to a court action by The New York Times, a state judge ruled that an agreement in July, which settled a suit the newspaper filed against the Port Authority to compel the transcripts' release, was valid and enforceable. The authority, which owns the trade center site, had objected to the release, citing privacy concerns and sensitivity to the victims' families. But yesterday, officials said they did not want to prolong the legal process. The authority has until Thursday to release the transcripts. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Port Authority Crime Drops Sharply

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Crime at airports, bus terminals and other sites operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey fell by 8.3 percent last year and has dropped by 44.8 percent since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, officials said. Crime is defined as robbery, larceny, or assault, said Tony Ciavolella, a Port Authority spokesman. He said the decline was attributed largely to the 550 new police officers the authority had hired since the attacks, and to a $300 million security upgrade. The agency now has more than 1,600 officers. The authority, which also operates the PATH commuter trains, has been on a heightened state of alert since 2001. The authority, which lost 37 of its officers in the attack on the World Trade Center, now has 1,600 officers. John Holl (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Backs New Path Cars

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Returning to a project that was suspended because of the Sept. 11 terror attack, the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved spending $809 million to buy new PATH cars and to begin design work on a new signal system for the trans-Hudson tubes. The plan to buy the new cars as well as upgrade the signal system was originally adopted in November 2000 by Port Authority commissioners but temporarily put aside when the attack on the World Trade Center curtailed operations of the line and created new rebuilding priorities. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

headline.main: Role Seen for Newark Airport in Land Swap

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Newark International Airport should be included in a proposal to swap ownership of the World Trade Center property for the land at La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, Gov. James E. McGreevey said in remarks published today. The governor said he was concerned that if Newark is not included in the deal, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will focus its capital investments on the two New York airports. The agency leases all three. Newark's is the busiest.

headline.main: In Attack's Wake, Port Chief Stays On

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority Board of Commissioners for New York and New Jersey, was recently nominated by Acting Governor DiFrancesco as chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. That was Sept. 5. But now, officials in the governor's office said last week, Mr. Eisenberg declined. The Port Authority built and owned the World Trade Center, destroyed by terrorists on Sept. 11, and 2,000 of its 7,500 employees worked there. Seventy-four of them were lost.

headline.main: ANOTHER NOMINEE APPROVED

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved Governor McGreevey's choice of Anthony Coscia to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The governor's first choice, Charles Kushner, quit the agency's board last month amid questions about his campaign contributions.
