Mr. Coscia, 43, would fill his seat and probably assume the leadership in April when the current chairman's term ends. The Port Authority, which governs the area's major airports, bridges, tunnels and ports, is struggling to increase security at a time of tight budgets and will play a key role in redeveloping the World Trade Center site. Mr. Coscia will go before the full Senate next Thursday for confirmation. Michael J. Grabell

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Settlement In Trade Center Dispute

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties settled a long-running dispute yesterday that had threatened to hold up the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. Under the terms of the agreement, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will spend $563 million to buy out the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation, Silverstein's lender in the company's 2001 winning bid for control of the trade center. In a statement, Larry A. Silverstein, the president and chief executive of Silverstein Properties, said he was ''pleased that we have reached a full agreement with the Port Authority on terms for repaying GMAC.'' The authority will also buy out Westfield America, the Australia-based mall operator that held the retail leases at the trade center, for $140 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Refuses To Set Aside Ruling In '93 Bombing Case

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: A judge yesterday refused a request by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to set aside a jury's decision in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center that found the Port Authority responsible for 68 percent of the bombing and the bombers 32 percent liable. Justice Nicholas Figueroa of State Supreme Court in Manhattan rejected the authority's argument that the October 2005 ruling should be set aside because the bombing was an unforeseeable event and because the jury instructions were improper. The decision clears the way for plaintiffs in the case to ask for trials to set damages, but the authority may also choose to appeal further. The 1993 truck bombing of the trade center by Islamic militants killed 6 people and injured 1,000. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated his support yesterday for government financing of the underground infrastructure at ground zero, leaving the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation responsible only for meeting the $500 million budget now assigned to the memorial and museum. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to pay $100 million of the memorial's share of infrastructure costs. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Dispute Over Money Delays 9/11 Museum

Port Authority.lead_paragraph: The scheduled opening next year of the National September 11 Memorial Museum has been delayed because of a $156 million dispute between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the foundation responsible for running the museum, according to people familiar with the discussions. The Port Authority, which is responsible for the construction, has stopped approving new contracts, slowing work on the underground museum, which was to open on Sept. 11. The organizations have been arguing over the money for nearly 18 months, and tensions rose recently as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has sought to exert more control over construction projects in the city. Last month Mr. Cuomo nominated one of his deputies, Patrick Foye, to run the Port Authority and asked the agency to take over the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a joint city and state enterprise that has been working on the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site. The National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center Foundation, whose chairman is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has maintained that poor management and delays by the Port Authority between 2006 and 2008 cost it more than $100 million. The delay in approving construction contracts was reported by The Wall Street Journal on Monday. Michael Frazier, the foundation's communications director, said Monday, ''We are working with the leadership of the Port Authority to come to an immediate resolution that allows this historic project to move forward.'' Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, ''We're working cooperatively with New York City and the memorial foundation'' and that ''work is continuing.''

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bonus For Airport Screeners

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: To keep airport security running through a federal takeover on Nov. 19, the government is offering $500 bonuses to entice privately hired screeners to stay on the job until then. The Transportation Security Administration has to hire 57,500 people to screen passengers and check luggage. Blaine Harden (NYT)

headline.main: 110 Accused of Fraud at Denver Airport

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: One hundred ten people who work at Denver International Airport were indicted today on charges of lying to get airport security badges. The airport was the 19th investigated by a federal government security program begun in response to the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Airport Gets New Federal Screeners

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The first crew of 150 federal X-ray screeners began work yesterday at Newark International Airport, Newark's first wave in a nationwide transition from private sector airport security to federal security personnel. Newark, one of 32 airports that now have federal screeners, is scheduled to add almost 900 more before Nov. 19, the deadline the Transportation Security Administration set to replace all private screeners. Danise Daville, above, and the other screeners were placed in Terminal A, the facility that United Flight 93 left before being hijacked by terrorists on Sept. 11 and then crashing in a Pennsylvania field. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Georgia: $3,300 Fine For Evasive Passenger

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A passenger who ran around a security checkpoint and led officials to close Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta, one of the world's busiest, for three hours was fined the maximum $3,300, regulators said. The Federal Aviation Administration said the passenger, Michael S. Lasseter, 32, of Gainesville, an executive, violated federal rules by entering a secure area without the required screening on Nov. 16.

headline.main: Reagan National Reopens Tomorrow

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: President Bush announced yesterday that Ronald Reagan National Airport would open tomorrow, with service to both New York and Boston on the US Airways and Delta shuttles and to eight other cities. ''I also know full well that the nation is asking this question: Are we taking the necessary safety precautions as we open not only Ronald Reagan Airport, but other airports?'' the president said at the airport yesterday morning. ''The answer is, you bet.'' ELISABETH BUMILLER

headline.main: U.S. Orders Airlines To End V.I.P. Lines

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The government has told airlines to close the V.I.P. lines that allow their most valued customers, mainly business travelers, to avoid long waits for security checks at airports, officials said today. The move was ordered by the Transportation Security Administration, which took over airport passenger and baggage screening from the airlines at more than 420 airports this week.

headline.main: France Tightens Airport Security on U.S.-Bound Flights
headline.print_headline: France Tightens Airport Security on U.S.-Bound Flights

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: France is tightening airport security for U.S. flight destinations for the summer holiday period at the request of U.S. authorities, an official statement said on Friday.

headline.main: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport evacuated for more than an hour yesterday after federal agents found that airport security officers were not making random hand-held metal detector sweeps of passengers. Those random checks, which have been put into place since the Sept. 11 hijackings, are in addition to the metal detectors that passengers must pass through to enter the secure areas in airports.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Airport Staff Cut Criticized

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Anthony R. Coscia, asked the federal Transportation Security Administration yesterday to reconsider its plan to reduce the number of security screeners at Kennedy International and Newark Liberty International Airports. In a letter to Edmund S. Hawley, the assistant secretary of homeland security, Mr. Coscia said that increases in passenger traffic at the two airports last year, and the airports' national significance, appear to recommend an expansion of screeners, not a reduction. A spokeswoman for the administration, speaking generally, said that traffic was not the only factor considered in allocating screeners. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

headline.main: Airport Searches of Women Are Restricted

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: In response to numerous complaints from women, the government has ordered airport security personnel to avoid touching female passengers between the breasts when performing pat-down security searches. Screeners now will keep their hands to the ''chest perimeter'' of women unless detection equipment picks up the possibility of hidden explosives.

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Contracts Awarded For Airport Security Systems

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration, an agency of the Department of Homeland Security, said yesterday that it had selected the Unisys Corporation and Electronic Data Systems for pilot programs operating high-tech security fast lanes for frequent travelers in five airports. The Registered Traveler pilot program will begin later this month at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, the agency said. The program is also scheduled to be rolled out through August at Los Angeles International Airport, George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston, Boston Logan International Airport and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. The contracts, which were awarded by competitive bid, are valued at $2.47 million for Unisys and $1.31 million for Electronic Data Systems. Unisys shares rose 4 cents, to $13.93. Shares of Electronic Data fell 16 cents, to $17.64.

headline.main: Security Company Gets License Back

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts judge has ruled that a security company screening passengers at Logan International Airport should not have its work terminated because the airport revoked its permit illegally. The judge, Allen van Gestel, issued a temporary restraining order on Tuesday, reinstating the license of the company, Argenbright Security.

headline.main: F.A.A. Will Let State Workers Do Airport Screening

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: In a departure from Federal Aviation Administration policy, state employees will start helping airline and federal security workers at Baltimore-Washington International Airport, officials said today. Other states and airports can follow Baltimore's lead if it will reduce lines and delays in air travel, said the aviation agency's administrator, Jane F. Garvey.

headline.main: Concourse Shut In Baltimore After Woman Skips Screening

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Federal aviation authorities evacuated a Southwest Airlines concourse of Baltimore-Washington International Airport this morning after a woman bypassed a security checkpoint, officials said. Three departing Southwest planes were returned to their gates and discharged their passengers, and travelers in the concourse were evacuated while aviation authorities and a police canine unit swept the area, an airport spokesman said. Passengers were re-screened before the concourse was reopened at 9:50 a.m.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Indictment In Bomb Threats

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A Queens man working as an airport cashier has been indicted on charges that he phoned in two false bomb threats to Kennedy Airport, federal prosecutors announced yesterday. The man, Marcelo Almeida, 27, of Richmond Hill, is accused of phoning 911 at 8:34 a.m. and 9:27 a.m. on Monday and saying that a bomb was inside the international arrivals terminal. The calls were traced to a private work area inside the airport for the food-court operator there, Select Service Partner Airport Restaurants, and workers were interrogated by the F.B.I. Mr. Almeida's lawyer did not immediately return phone calls.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kennedy Terminal Evacuated

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A terminal at Kennedy Airport was evacuated after a passenger found a knife past a security checkpoint at 5:45 p.m. yesterday. Flights out of the terminal were grounded, and passengers who had boarded planes had to return to the terminal. Police dogs checked the entire building, Terminal 3, which houses Delta Airlines, and passengers waiting for 11 planes had to be screened again. The rescreening was completed by 10 p.m., said Jim Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The knife, found between the cushions of a seat in one of the boarding areas, had a four-inch serrated blade, an F.A.A. official said. It was not known how long the knife had been there. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Security Lapses Close Terminal

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Federal security agents ordered an American Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport evacuated at 4:30 p.m. today after they decided that passengers were not being screened properly, said Laura J. Brown, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. Seven flights were delayed by more than two hours, Ms. Brown said.

headline.main: Contradictions And Confusion Follow Lapse At Airport

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Somewhere out there, a man in his 40's is walking around with explosives residue on his brown loafers. The one place he is surely not is San Francisco International Airport, where today officials were still trying to explain one of the biggest airport security breaches since Sept. 11. Among the questions they face is how they let the man slip past security Wednesday after his shoes triggered an alarm and why they waited an hour after the breach to shut down the terminal in question.

headline.main: Bullet Found in Airport; Traffic Is Delayed

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A bullet found outside a gate at Fort Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport prompted the authorities to evacuate a busy concourse today, delaying flights up to three hours. A passenger discovered the small-caliber bullet about 7:40 a.m. outside the gate leading to Spirit Airlines Flight 604 to La Guardia Airport in New York, a spokeswoman for the F.B.I., Judy Orihuela, said.

headline.main: Airline Screening Plan Wins Tentative Praise
headline.print_headline: Airline Screening Plan Wins Tentative Praise

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Analysts said the new system promised to improve decisions about who should be prevented from flying.

headline.main: UK Tightens Airport Security After U.S. Warns of Bomb Concerns
headline.print_headline: UK Tightens Airport Security After U.S. Warns of Bomb Concerns

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Britain has stepped up security at airports after U.S. officials said they were concerned that al Qaeda operatives in Syria and Yemen were developing bombs that could be smuggled onto planes.

headline.main: Security Company Faulted Again

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The airport security company that was fined $1.2 million last year for hiring convicted felons to screen passengers at Philadelphia International Airport has committed more violations, a federal task force said tonight. The company, Argenbright, was employing seven screeners at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport who the Immigration and Naturalization Service found were illegally working in the United States, the task force said. At other airports, screeners were found to have criminal records that should have disqualified them, said the task force, which was made up of officials from the Federal Aviation Administration and the inspector general's office of the Department of Transportation.

headline.main: Philadelphia Airport Preparing for Ebola
headline.print_headline: Philadelphia Airport Preparing for Ebola

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Officials at Philadelphia International Airport say they are following guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and federal customs and border protection officials to identify passengers displaying possible symptoms of communicable diseases such as Ebola.

headline.main: U.S. Ponders Easing 9/11 Airport Rule

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Pittsburgh International could become the nation's first major airport allowed to abandon the federal government's post-Sept. 11 rule that lets only ticketed passengers proceed past security checkpoints to the gate. If successful, the test might become a model for other airports. Pittsburgh is a candidate for the experiment for two reasons: It has a centralized security checkpoint, in one terminal, and it has a 100-store shopping mall that has suffered a drop in business because it can be reached only by ticketed passengers.

headline.main: Terminal Evacuated In a False Alarm

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A false alarm attributed to a malfunction by a luggage-screening device led today to the evacuation of 1,500 people from a concourse at Baltimore-Washington International Airport and from five Southwest Airlines jets waiting at the gates. The authorities cleared the planes and Pier B, a concourse used solely by Southwest, after a security worker reported about 11:40 a.m. that the X-ray device had indicated a suspicious item in one passenger's luggage. Officials and bomb-sniffing dogs turned up nothing hazardous in a search of the passenger's bags, Pier B and the planes, and the concourse reopened about 1:15 p.m., said Melanie Miller, a spokeswoman for the airport.

headline.main: Saudi Arabia: Guantánamo Ex-Inmate Is In Custody

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who subsequently joined the Yemeni branch of Al Qaeda returned to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday and was in the custody of the authorities. The Yemeni government said it had returned the former detainee, Muhammad al-Awfi, to Saudi Arabia. But Saudi officials said Mr. Awfi, also known as Abu Hareth, had traveled to the Saudi-Yemeni border and turned himself in. Mr. Awfi was one of 11 Saudis who were believed to have returned to terrorist groups after being released from Guantánamo and passing through a Saudi rehabilitation program for former jihadists. He was on a wanted list of 85 terrorism suspects made public by the Saudi authorities last month.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: 7 Return From Guantánamo

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The Interior Ministry said seven Saudi nationals who had been detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, had been freed and transferred to Saudi custody. A ministry spokesman, quoted by the official Saudi Press Agency, said the men's families would be allowed to visit with them. About 60 Saudis held at Guantánamo have been released; more than 65 are believed to remain. HASSAN M. FATTAH

headline.seo: Political Maneuvering Over Yemen as Saleh Is Reported to Have Severe Burns
headline.main: Yemen Uncertainty Grows; Leader’s Burns Called Severe
headline.print_headline: Yemen Uncertainty Grows; Leader’s Burns Called Severe

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Accounts varied as to the severity of President Ali Abdullah Saleh’s wounds, and leaders in Washington and Riyadh continued in their efforts to stabilize the situation in Yemen.

headline.main: Citing Medical Needs, Yemeni Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
headline.sub: Fears for Stability After President's Sudden Departure
headline.print_headline: HURT IN ATTACK, YEMEN’S LEADER LEAVES COUNTRY

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: President Ali Abdullah Saleh left for treatment a day after being wounded in an attack, Saudi officials said. News reports point to the vice president as Yemen’s acting leader.

headline.main: 2 Hurt by Saudi Bomb Die

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The two guards wounded in an attempted suicide bombing at a Saudi oil and gas plant died Saturday, the Interior Ministry of Saudi Arabia said.

headline.main: Saudi Arabia: Interpol Sends Alert for Terrorist Suspects

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Interpol released an international security alert on Tuesday for 85 terrorist suspects who were identified by Saudi Arabia last week. The international police agency, based in Lyon, France, said it had never issued an alert for so many suspects before. Saudi authorities issued the list last week, asking for Interpol assistance and saying the suspects, all but two of them Saudis, were believed to be plotting attacks against Saudi Arabia. The list includes a man married to Osama bin Laden's daughter and an accused regional al Qaeda leader who is said to be living in Iran.

headline.main: Saudis Freeze Funds Of 66 on U.S. List

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has ordered a freeze on the assets of people and organizations that the United States has identified as sponsors of terrorism, Bush administration officials said today. President Bush has been saying for weeks that Saudi officials were cooperating in the fight against terrorism, and his aides have often repeated a statement that Saudi Arabia has ''done everything we've asked them to do'' to help combat Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: Saudi Militants Are Sentenced In '96 Bombing

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has sentenced some of the people it arrested for the 1996 Khobar Towers bombing that killed 19 American servicemen and injured hundreds of others, the deputy interior minister was quoted as saying today. The official, Prince Ahmed, did not say how many people were sentenced or what the sentences were. The verdicts ''must be announced at the right time,'' the prince said, in an interview with the newspaper al-Jazirah. Prince Ahmed is a brother of King Fahd.

headline.main: Yemen Hands 29 Qaeda Militants to Saudi Arabia: Website
headline.print_headline: Yemen Hands 29 Qaeda Militants to Saudi Arabia: Website

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Yemen has handed to Saudi Arabia 29 al Qaeda militants who were wanted by the Saudi authorities, the Yemeni defense ministry website said on Tuesday, citing informed sources.

headline.seo: Potential New Saudi Crown Prince Is Hard-Line but Pragmatic
headline.main: Potential New Saudi Crown Prince Seen as Hard-Line but Pragmatic
headline.print_headline: Potential New Saudi Crown Prince Seen as Hard-Line but Pragmatic
headline.content_kicker: Man in the News: Prince Nayef Bin Abdul Aziz

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Prince Nayef bin Abdul Aziz, a veteran Saudi interior minister, is expected to be elevated to heir to the crown this week after the death of Prince Sultan.

headline.main: Britain Warns of Attacks in Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Britain's Foreign Office said Friday that it believed that ''terrorists may be in the final phases of planning attacks'' in Saudi Arabia, and that its warning against all but essential travel in the kingdom remained in place. A statement posted on the department's Web site advised travelers to make sure they had confidence in their security arrangements and warned visitors to military buildings to take special care.

headline.main: Saudi Arabia: Diplomat Kidnapped in Yemen

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The Interior Ministry said Tuesday that Al Qaeda had claimed responsibility for kidnapping a Saudi diplomat in southern Yemen last month and was demanding the release of prisoners and a ransom payment. A ministry spokesman, Maj. Gen. Mansour al-Turki, said that a Saudi citizen who is a wanted terrorism suspect relayed called the Saudi embassy in Yemen with the demands, adding a threat to kill the captive, Abdullah al-Khaldi. Mr. Khaldi, the deputy consul at the Saudi consulate in the port city of Aden, was abducted in Aden on March 28.

headline.main: U.S. Intensifies Its Alert on Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The State Department intensified its warnings about terrorism in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, advising Americans not to travel there and giving nonessential diplomatic employees the option to leave. ''The U.S. government continues to receive indications of terrorist threats aimed at American and Western interests, including the targeting of transportation and civil aviation,'' the department said in a statement that superseded an alert of Dec. 8.

headline.main: U.S. Diplomat Meets Saudis Over Accounts

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A senior American diplomat met here today with top Saudi officials, including Crown Prince Abdullah, for talks intended in part to seek further Saudi help in cutting off money to suspected terrorist groups. Before the meeting, senior Saudi officials complained that the United States had not shared the evidence necessary for them to freeze bank accounts permanently and to take other actions it sought.

headline.main: Saudis Are Praised for Fight on Terrorists

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, who met here today with Crown Prince Abdullah, praised Saudi efforts to fight terrorism. Mr. Snow, here as part of a tour through the Middle East and Southwest Asia, said that the crown prince and Saudi Arabia have chosen to be ''firm and merciless'' in the pursuit of terrorists and in efforts to clamp down on Saudi charities and organizations that Western law enforcement officials have said are the world's richest spigots of terrorist financing.

headline.main: Americans Told to Leave Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The United States ordered nonessential diplomats out of Saudi Arabia on Thursday and warned all Americans they should leave, citing fresh signals that attacks had been planned. The decision requires families of diplomats at the embassy in Riyadh and consulates in Jidda and Dhahran to leave the kingdom, which is battling violence believed to be linked to Al Qaeda. On Tuesday, attackers suspected of being Islamic militants killed four Saudi policemen at checkpoints soon after security forces defused two car bombs in Riyadh. Last year, at least 50 people died in bomb attacks on housing compounds used by Americans there.

headline.main: Saudi Tied to bin Laden Turns Himself In Under Amnesty Offer

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Saudi suspected of being a member of Al Qaeda, who had appeared on a videotape with Osama bin Laden, was flown back to the kingdom from Iran after he surrendered under a government amnesty, state television said Tuesday. Khaled al-Harbi, also known as Abu Suleiman al-Makki, had been living in the wild lands along the Iranian-Afghan border and had contacted the Saudi Embassy in Tehran in response to the amnesty offer.

headline.main: Saudis Reject U.S. Accusation They Balked on Terror Money

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Senior Saudi officials rejected today American accusations that the kingdom is not choking off the money supply to Osama bin Laden, accusing Washington of again leveling charges against groups or individuals here without providing any proof. ''We believe firmly that fighting terrorism is done by removing the infrastructure, and one of the main elements of the infrastructure is the financial element,'' said Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister, in an interview. ''So there is absolutely no truth in saying we have not been cooperating in this.''

headline.main: Bush Officials Praise Saudis For Aiding Terror Fight

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Senior Bush administration officials praised the government of Saudi Arabia today for its efforts in tracking down suspected terrorists even as White House officials urged greater Saudi cooperation with investigations into Saudi financiers and charities that may be aiding terror networks. Ari Fleischer, President Bush's press secretary, said, ''I see no reason to believe that Saudi Arabia is not committed to the campaign against terrorism.''

headline.main: Protesters in Yemen Rejoice as Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
headline.print_headline: Joy and Doubts After President Leaves Yemen

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Yemenis celebrated after the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, went to Saudi Arabia for urgent medical treatment.

headline.main: Yemeni Rebels and Saudis Clash at Border
headline.print_headline: Yemeni Rebels and Saudis Clash at Border

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi military and Yemeni rebels both claimed to have inflicted casualties and captured enemy soldiers as border clashes continued.

headline.main: Saudi Denies U.S. Report Of Likely Link To a Suspect

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Saudi Arabian government official said today that a Saudi citizen identified in a recent Congressional report on the September 2001 attacks as a likely intelligence operative was an accountant who never worked as a Saudi government agent. The Saudi official, who is responsible for terrorism investigations, said that Omar al-Bayoumi, who befriended two of the 9/11 hijackers in California more than a year before the attacks, was employed by a contractor for the Saudi civil aviation authority.

headline.main: British Airways Suspends Flights To Saudi Arabia After Threats

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: British Airways today suspended flights to Saudi Arabia because of heightened security concerns, two days after Saudi officials broke up a terror cell that was plotting an attack on a British plane, a senior Saudi official said. Britain's Department for Transport said it had received ''credible intelligence of a serious threat to U.K. aviation interests in Saudi Arabia.'' It did not elaborate.

headline.main: A Top Saudi to Meet With Bush; 9/11 Report Is the Likely Topic

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has sent its foreign minister to Washington to meet with President Bush on Tuesday, an administration official said tonight. The foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, is expected to raise with Mr. Bush and other administration officials his country's concern about reports that classified sections of a Congressional study about the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, found that senior Saudi officials had funneled hundreds of millions of dollars to organizations that might have helped pay for them.

headline.seo: Obama Envoy Meets With President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen
headline.main: Envoy Meets With Leader of Yemen on Accord
headline.print_headline: Envoy Meets With Leader Of Yemen On Accord

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: John Brennan told President Ali Abdullah Saleh that the only way to restart American aid would be to sign an accord to effectively remove himself from power.

headline.main: Task Lighting
headline.print_headline: Sweating the Small Stuff

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Illuminating a task takes beauty and smarts. So says the architect Daniel Libeskind, who is shrinking his projects.

headline.main: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: As an architecture student at Cooper Union three decades ago, Daniel Libeskind watched the World Trade Center being built. ''It was such an inspiring and controversial and wonderful moment,'' Mr. Libeskind said last week -- second only, perhaps, to the moment his design was chosen as the plan to rebuild the trade center. Centered on a recessed memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attack, the plan includes a spiral of buildings rising to a tower standing 1,776 feet -- ''a date or a number,'' he said, ''that will never be surpassed in world history.'' Edward Wyatt

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has reopened the exhibit of design concepts for the World Trade Center site. The exhibit, at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, has been reorganized to display the two designs under consideration: Memory Foundations by Studio Daniel Libeskind and the World Cultural Center by the Think team (Shigeru Ban, Frederic Schwartz, Ken Smith and Rafael Viñoly). The exhibit will continue until the end of this month, when a winner will be chosen and displayed through April. The exhibit is open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily.

headline.main: February 2-8: NATIONAL; REBUILDING PLANS

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center site became more concrete as New York City and state officials chose two finalists to design the future of ground zero. Rebuilding officials will choose by the end of the month between a proposal from Studio Daniel Libeskind, which would set the memorial to victims in a 70-foot pit where most remains were found, and one from a team of architects called Think, which would build two latticework towers, evoking the original ones but including cultural and educational facilities. Each plan includes what would be the world's tallest tower but neither has office space at the top. Edward Wyatt

headline.main: Perfect Complement to a Grand Design

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Daniel Libeskind has already secured what has been called ''the commission of the century.'' He has the plans, the contracts to carry them out and the backing of important patrons, from Gov. George E. Pataki on down. And now, Mr. Libeskind has one more thing that could help him make his vision for the World Trade Center site a reality: an architect's license.

headline.main: Ground Zero Agency Plans To Weigh Libeskind Contract

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: The first contract with Studio Daniel Libeskind for work at the World Trade Center site will be considered for approval this week by the agency that will oversee development of the memorial, officials said yesterday. The agency, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, will discuss a contract at its board meeting tomorrow for Mr. Libeskind to be a consultant on the memorial's development, the officials said.

headline.main: Trade Tower To Reflect Compromise

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Months of architectural wrangling over plans for the tallest building at the World Trade Center site -- and in the world -- have apparently ended in a 1,776-foot compromise that would include an asymmetrical spire favored by Daniel Libeskind rising atop a cable-framed wind farm proposed by David M. Childs. Though the design will not be made public until Friday, an announcement yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation seemed to indicate that agreement had been reached on the broad outlines of the building, called Freedom Tower.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Owner Settles Suit

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, who controls the lease at the World Trade Center, and Daniel Libeskind, the site's master planner, settled their bitter financial dispute yesterday, with Mr. Silverstein agreeing to pay the architect's firm $370,000 for its work on the Freedom Tower. The long-simmering rift became public in July when Mr. Libeskind filed a lawsuit claiming that he was owed $843,750 in fees. Mr. Silverstein's spokesman said that the architect had already been paid ''many millions of dollars for his work'' and was unable to provide any documentation to justify additional payment. Justice Karla Moskowitz of State Supreme Court then sent the two sides to a mediator. In a statement issued yesterday, Mr. Libeskind and Mr. Silverstein said they expected to cooperate on refining the master plan. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Architects Agree to Meet To Work Out Tower Design

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Trying to resolve their differences over the Freedom Tower at the World Trade Center site, the tower's architect and Daniel Libeskind, the site's master planner, agreed yesterday to work together on a design that would more closely follow the Libeskind plan. Mr. Libeskind is expected to meet early next week with David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, who is designing the tower -- the site's skyline emblem -- for the developer Larry A. Silverstein.

headline.main: Two Finalists Are Selected For the Void at Ground Zero

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Two teams of architects, one that sees the foundations of democracy in the concrete walls surrounding ground zero and another that imagines New York's rebirth in soaring towers of culture, have been selected as finalists in the competition to create the design for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday. Each of the designs includes what would be the tallest building in the world, though in both plans, the towers' upper reaches are not occupied by offices. Rather, there is a memorial observation deck in one case, and a hanging garden in the other.

headline.main: Ground Zero Spotlight: Architects Ambivalent

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: While architects have publicly proclaimed the World Trade Center site proposals displayed at the Winter Garden in Lower Manhattan as the greatest architecture show ever, many have privately expressed reservations about the designs' details, the handling of the competition and even the spotlight in which the contestants now stand. ''Architecture is finally having a visible presence, perhaps too visible,'' said Ricardo Scofidio of Diller & Scofidio in Manhattan.

headline.main: One Design for Trade Center Site Is Crossed Off After Firm Leaves

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: One of the seven architectural teams that submitted new designs for the World Trade Center site has been eliminated from further consideration, rebuilding officials said yesterday. The decision followed the withdrawal of the architecture firm that was the lead partner in the effort, they said. The elimination was a disappointing surprise to some members of the team, who thought they might be allowed to continue in the design study even without the architecture firm, Skidmore Owings & Merrill.

headline.main: Libeskind to Oversee Most of Trade Center Development

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Daniel Libeskind, the architect who created the winning design for rebuilding the World Trade Center site, will soon be offered contracts to oversee nearly all of the development projects at the site, rebuilding officials said yesterday. The contracts, to be offered within 30 days by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, are intended to ensure that Mr. Libeskind's plan will guide development at the site, said Kevin M. Rampe, the interim president of the development corporation, and Joseph J. Seymour, executive director of the Port Authority.

headline.main: Support Builds For One Plan For Center Site

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: State and city officials involved in choosing a design for the World Trade Center site have begun lining up in favor of a plan by Studio Daniel Libeskind, which uses the ground zero pit as the setting for a memorial to victims of the terrorist attack, giving that plan important momentum in the week before the final site plan is chosen. Two people close to Gov. George E. Pataki said this week that the governor had not made a final decision, but that he had recently expressed support for the Libeskind design. Reports of his expressions of support follow similar remarks last week by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who said that he personally favored the Libeskind plan.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mediation Ordered In Trade Center Suit

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: A justice in State Supreme Court ordered mediation yesterday in the dispute between Larry A. Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, and Daniel Libeskind, left, the site's master planner, who filed a lawsuit last week claiming that Mr. Silverstein owes him more than $843,000 in architectural fees. Justice Karla Moskowitz issued the order at the request of Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. Edward W. Hayes, a lawyer for Mr. Libeskind, had said that mediation would not be fruitful. Both parties were directed to return to court on Oct. 14.

headline.main: 7 Design Teams Offer New Ideas For Attack Site

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Seven teams of architects from around the world unveiled new designs for the World Trade Center site yesterday, giving a remarkable civic tutorial on architecture and contemporary urban design aimed at mending the hole left in Lower Manhattan by the Sept. 11 attack. The designs, the subject of secrecy and speculation since the teams began work 12 weeks ago, include a broad array of elements: quiet memorial gardens and scenic plazas in the sky, soaring towers of bare scaffolding and sprawling canopies of glass. Four include what would be the tallest building in the world, and all set aside an area for a memorial to the victims of 9/11.

headline.main: The Roster of Ground Zero Architects Grows

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Three celebrated architects -- including Norman Foster, who offered his own vision last year of twin towers rising from ground zero -- were added yesterday to the growing roster of international designers working on the World Trade Center site. Lord Foster, of London, Jean Nouvel of Paris and Fumihiko Maki of Tokyo joined Daniel Libeskind, the master planner, and David M. Childs and T. J. Gottesdiener of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, which will design the first, and tallest, building, Freedom Tower, with Mr. Libeskind. Larry A. Silverstein, who chose all but Mr. Libeskind, said, ''They're the best in the world.''

headline.main: Libeskind Is Chosen For Seoul Project

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Which will get off the ground first? Daniel Libeskind, the architect behind the new World Trade Center site, has been chosen to redesign a major portion of downtown Seoul, South Korea. Studio Daniel Libeskind, based in New York, announced late Tuesday that it had won a competition to spearhead a $20 billion, 34-million-square-foot riverfront project (above) in the Yongsan international business district. The site will include residential, office, retail and cultural areas, built like islands around an urban park along the Han River. ''The idea is to create a 21st-century destination that is at once transformative, vibrant, sustainable and diverse,'' Mr. Libeskind said in a statement. According to The Associated Press, the development is near the current South Korean headquarters for the United States military, which will be turned into a park when the military base moves to an area south of Seoul in 2012. The new Libeskind-designed development is slated to break ground in 2011.

headline.main: Critic of Ideas For Memorial Is New Adviser On Rebuilding

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: An architectural and planning coalition that has criticized the World Trade Center memorial competition was named yesterday to help prepare design guidelines for the overall trade center site. The coalition, New York New Visions, will advise the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The group has argued that planning the memorial and the overall site ''cannot continue as a separate process.''

headline.main: Turning a Competition Into a Public Campaign; Finalists for Ground Zero Design Pull Out the Stops

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: Packed meetings at Town Hall, get-out-the-vote e-mails and head-to-head chats with Charlie Rose may not be as rugged and ritualized as photo-ops in the South Bronx, but in many ways the architects proposing designs for the World Trade Center site have been acting like media-age politicians. The two finalists from an original pack of seven design teams -- Daniel Libeskind from Berlin and Rafael Viñoly and Frederic Schwartz, the two front men on the Think team -- grasped the political nature of the selection process from the start, playing straight to the public as if the citizens of New York City were the clients for the job.

headline.main: 300 Firms Competing to Help Remake Downtown

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: More than 300 architecture and planning firms, including those of the notable architects Philip Johnson and Robert A. M. Stern, have answered the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's call for more innovative concepts for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday. Most of the firms are seeking to be one of five participants in a new, four-week planning and design study, but rebuilding officials said some of the submissions that arrived by the deadline yesterday were answering two calls for consultants, one in urban design and the other in graphic arts. The 300 submissions are from firms on every continent except Antarctica, the officials said.

headline.main: Officials Reach An Agreement On Rebuilding Downtown Site

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: The architect with the winning design for the World Trade Center site and the developer who will rebuild the office space there agreed early this morning to collaborate on the design and construction of the 1,776-foot tower that will anchor the redeveloped site both on the ground and in the Lower Manhattan skyline. The agreement between the architect, Daniel Libeskind, and the developer, Larry A. Silverstein, came during an eight-hour negotiating session that stretched from Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday morning.

headline.main: What's Next

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: TOMORROW A public comment period begins with the opening of a six-week exhibit of plans with videos of architects explaining their work at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center. Open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily, through Feb. 3. Plans are also online at www.LowerManhattan.info and RenewNyc.org. Videos will also be distributed to public libraries in the city.

headline.main: Inside Out and All Around, A Blueprint Goes Digital

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: How many people understand a blueprint? Not many. Enter the architects John Bennett and Gustavo Bonevardi of Proun Space Studio. They have made a video tour of Aqua, a residential project being built in Miami. The design, by the urban planners Duany Plater-Zyberk, combines New Urbanist principles with modern architecture. The five-minute cyberjourney, left, conveys the feeling of visiting the buildings close up. ''We want to capture the spirit of place, to evoke the feeling of Miami,'' Mr. Bonevardi said. The men recently did another slight-of-eye project -- the towers of light, the World Trade Center memorial. The video tour is to be at www.aqua.net this week. DONNA PAUL

headline.main: PRACTICAL ISSUES FOR GROUND ZERO

Daniel Libeskind.lead_paragraph: In the end, it was not so much about architecture, about solemn memorial pits or soaring gardens in the sky. Instead, the decision announced yesterday to choose Daniel Libeskind's design for the World Trade Center site revolved mainly around politics, economics and engineering, people close to the selection process said. Almost immediately after the decision was announced, civic groups, downtown business leaders and others began debating the details that will be needed to put the plan into effect.

headline.main: October 14-20; Embassy Bombers Sentenced

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Four terrorists convicted last spring of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa were sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan to life in prison without any chance of release. Two -- Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24, who assisted in the bombing in Kenya, and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 28, who helped in preparing the attack in Tanzania -- had earlier avoided the death penalty when the jury did not unanimously vote for execution. The two others were Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, 36, and Wadih El-Hage, 41. Benjamin Weiser

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rulings In Embassy Bombing Case

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan has refused to dismiss charges against or grant a new trial for two men convicted in connection with the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, which the authorities say were masterminded by Osama bin Laden. The judge, Leonard B. Sand, said Tuesday that there was no merit to arguments by the two defendants, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, a Saudi man who helped to deliver the bomb in Nairobi; and Wadih El-Hage, who was convicted of terrorism conspiracy. Two other convicted defendants did not file motions; all four men are to be sentenced this month. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Convicted Terrorists Sent to Pennsylvania

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities moved quickly to transfer four convicted followers of Osama bin Laden to a high-security prison in Pennsylvania after they were sentenced last week in the embassy bombings trial. The four terrorists, who received life prison terms last Thursday for conspiring with Mr. bin Laden in global terrorism, arrived Sunday at the federal penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pa., government officials said.

headline.main: Prosecutors Tied Defendants to bin Laden

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The four men who were sentenced yesterday in the embassy bombings conspiracy were all followers of Osama bin Laden. One of the men, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, was also a sworn member of Al Qaeda, Mr. bin Laden's terrorist organization, while another, Wadih El-Hage, was a close aide and former personal secretary. Federal prosecutors have continually asserted that the four men participated in a global conspiracy led by Mr. bin Laden to kill Americans, which included the 1998 bombings of American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. In those attacks, 224 people were killed, including 12 Americans.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prison Transfer For Embassy Bomber

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A man convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania and also accused of assisting in an attack on a Manhattan jail guard has been transferred to a federal prison nicknamed Super Max for its high security, records show. The prison, in Florence, Colo., has held Timothy J. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, and Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber. The embassy bomber, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, above, was one of four men who received life sentences last month for their roles in a conspiracy to kill Americans. Prosecutors said the conspiracy was led by Osama bin Laden. Mr. Mohamed has denied any role in the attack on the guard. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Embassy Bombings Case Goes to New Judge
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TERROR SUSPECTS

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The federal judge who presided in the trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the terrorist convicted in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, has been assigned the future trials in the 1998 embassy bombings conspiracy that prosecutors say was led by Osama bin Laden. Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy of Federal District Court in Manhattan will take over from Judge Leonard B. Sand, according to court officials.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 10 Years For Al Qaeda Operative

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: An operative for Al Qaeda who pleaded guilty last month to conspiring to destroy national defense materials has been sentenced to 10 years in prison, the maximum term. In 2000, the operative, Mohamed Suleiman al Nalfi, was arrested in the case stemming from the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa. He faced life in prison for terrorism conspiracy, but pleaded guilty to a lesser charge, which carried the 10-year penalty. John H. Jacobs, a lawyer for Mr. al Nalfi, said yesterday that he was satisfied with the sentence imposed last Thursday. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Suit Filed Over Bombings

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Attorneys for victims of the 1998 bombings at American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania filed a lawsuit against Osama bin Laden and 164 other named defendants today seeking $100 billion in damages.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Tanzania: Embassy Bomb Suspect Awaits Verdict

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A Tanzanian accused of conspiracy in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Dar es Salaam was found not guilty by a High Court panel of three jurors but must wait for a formal verdict from the judge. The suspect, Rashid Saleh Hemed, remains free on bail, and the judge gave no date for when he would deliver his ruling. American investigators say Al Qaeda carried out the attack on the embassy, which killed 11 Tanzanians, and a another bombing that killed more than 200 at the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya.

headline.main: Tight Security At Sentencing For Bombings

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Security will be heightened at the Old Federal Courthouse in Lower Manhattan tomorrow, with federal marshals carrying 12-gauge shotguns, as the four men convicted this year in the bombings of two American Embassies appear in court to be sentenced. The four men -- Wadih El-Hage, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh and Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali -- were found guilty in May of joining with Osama bin Laden in a global terrorist conspiracy that included the bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania on Aug. 7, 1998. The government is working hard to make sure that when the court imposes punishment on the men tomorrow, no punishment is meted out, in return, by terrorists on the court.

headline.main: Prison Switch For Terrorists In Bombings
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE EMBASSY PLOT

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The four terrorists convicted of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa have been moved to the most secure federal prison in the United States, the so-called Super Max in Florence, Colo., officials said. The prison, officially called the Administrative Maximum Facility, has held, among others, Timothy J. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber; Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber; and Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who bombed the World Trade Center in 1993.

headline.main: 4 Terrorists Ordered to Pay Restitution to Victims

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Four convicted terrorists with ties to Osama bin Laden will be ordered to pay restitution to victims of the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa, a federal judge in Manhattan said yesterday. Lawyers put the figure at roughly $33 million. None of the four terrorists are known to have assets, but prosecutors said in court papers that the order would ensure that if any of the four earned money in the future, such as by writing a book, ''those assets will be applied to mitigate at least some of the harm'' they caused.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Embassy Reopens

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The American Embassy in Nairobi reopened after closing for several days in response to fears of a terrorist attack. The embassy, which replaced one destroyed by Al Qaeda bombers in 1998, is designed to withstand attack. Kenyan soldiers stood guard as diplomats returned to work. Meanwhile, the presidents of Kenya and Tanzania criticized the American and British governments for issuing warnings against travel to east Africa, likening the advisories to economic sanctions. Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Named To Bench

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Kenneth M. Karas, co-chief of the terrorism unit in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, was nominated yesterday by President Bush to be a federal judge in Manhattan. Mr. Karas, 39, a federal prosecutor since 1992, is a member of the team that is prosecuting Zacarias Moussaoui, accused in the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Mr. Karas also helped win the 2001 convictions of four terrorists accused of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa. If confirmed, he would replace Judge Allen G. Schwartz, who died in March. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Named To Terror Unit

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A veteran prosecutor in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan has been appointed co-chief of the office's unit specializing in terrorism cases. The prosecutor, Kenneth M. Karas, replaces Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who was confirmed last week as United States attorney in Chicago. David N. Kelley continues as the other co-chief of the unit. Mr. Karas, 37, joined the prosecutor's office in 1992 and has been assisting in the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. Earlier this year, he helped try four men charged with conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Prosecutors In Bombings Seek Payment

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a judge to order four terrorists convicted in the embassy bombings case to pay $26.3 million in restitution to victims and their families and for the loss of United States property. None of the four terrorists are known to have any personal assets, although one comes from a wealthy Saudi family. But prosecutors said in court papers that such an order was necessary to ensure that if any of the terrorists were to earn money in the future, for example, by writing a book, ''those assets will be applied to mitigate at least some of the harm he has caused.''

headline.main: 3 Seek Retrial In Bombing Of Embassies

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for three terrorists convicted in the 1998 embassy bombings conspiracy case have asked a federal judge in Manhattan for a new trial, citing jury irregularities and other information that they contend could have affected the verdicts. The lawyers cited a newspaper report stating that one juror conducted her own legal research on the Internet, and that two others consulted their pastors about the death penalty. The jurors also learned that the defendants were shackled during the trial, a fact the court tried to conceal with a cloth to preserve the presumption of innocence.

headline.main: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: My opinion is, if the death of 3,000 people isn't sufficient for a death penalty in this country then why do we even have the death penalty? DEBORAH BURLINGAME, whose brother died in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, on the government's decision to seek capital punishment against six Guantánamo Bay detainees. [A18]

headline.seo: Islamist Militants Rally Against Kenya
headline.main: Somali Islamist Militants Rally Against Kenya
headline.print_headline: Somali Islamist Militants Rally Against Kenya

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A rallying call for Islamist militants gathered outside Somalia’s capital was, “We want huge blasts,” in attacks on neighboring Kenya.

headline.main: War vs. Terrorism Debate In Embassy Bomb Appeal

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The national debate over Guantánamo and the way the government has pursued its fight against terrorism since the 9/11 attacks was a presence yesterday as a federal appeals court in Manhattan considered the cases of three operatives of Al Qaeda convicted in the last major terrorism trial in the United States before 9/11. The three terrorists were convicted in a trial that stemmed from the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa in 1998, which killed 224 people and wounded thousands. The trial and two successive death penalty hearings ended in the summer of 2001, just before the attacks.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inmate Criticizes Prison Conditions

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: A man facing trial on charges of taking part in a terror conspiracy with Osama bin Laden is in virtual solitary confinement and almost completely unable to leave his cell after the attack on the World Trade Center, his lawyer told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday. After the court appearance, the lawyer, John Jacobs, also said he was considering asking the judge for a change of venue because he fears his client cannot receive a fair trial in Manhattan. The defendant, Mohamed Suleiman al Nalfi, a native of Sudan, ''has been in basically a total lockdown'' in the Metropolitan Correctional Center since Sept. 11, Mr. Jacobs told the judge. But Mr. Jacobs said prosecutors had indicated that conditions might be relaxed after the sentencing this month of four terrorists convicted in the embassy bombings case. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Jury Behavior Raises Issues In Terror Case

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for four terrorists convicted in the 2001 embassy bombings trial in Manhattan said in court papers yesterday that jury irregularities might have affected the verdicts and could be the basis for granting a new trial. The lawyers say they will ask for a court hearing to examine the effect of the irregularities, in which two jurors sought outside religious guidance from pastors about the death penalty and a third researched a legal concept on the Internet.

headline.main: All in Their Hands

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Mary Jo White, the powerful United States attorney in Manhattan, seemed poised to leave her post after eight years in office and the election of a Republican president. But the deadly attack on the World Trade Center last week seems to have ensured that Ms. White, who was appointed in 1993 by President Bill Clinton, will not be going anywhere soon. Ever since the first trade center bombing in 1993, Ms. White's office has investigated a succession of major acts of terrorism in New York and around the world, including the activities of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile charged with leading the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa.

headline.main: Kenyan Motives in Somalia Predate Recent Abductions
headline.print_headline: Kenyan Motives in Somalia Predate Recent Abductions

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: The Kenyan government revealed that its foray against Islamist militants was not simply a response to a wave of kidnappings, as previously claimed.

headline.main: Heightened Security for a Former Detainee

Embassy Bombings.lead_paragraph: In the end, Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani did not avoid being sent to the so-called Supermax prison in Florence, Colo., after all. Mr. Ghailani, 37, the first former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to be tried in the civilian system, received a life sentence in January for his role in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa, which killed 224 people.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Receive Antiterrorism Training In Israel

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has sent a team of investigators to Israel for training on how to detect suicide bombers and prevent them from carrying out attacks here. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department must be prepared for myriad terrorist threats, including suicide bombings like the one yesterday at an open-air market in Netanya, Israel. The training in Israel, first reoprted yesterday in The Daily News, is the latest effort by the police to prepare for terrorist attacks, and to seek to prevent them. Mr. Kelly announced recently that he would send 30 of his executive staff members to the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., to study mock disasters. Last month, he assigned investigators to work full time at F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. Al Baker (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Counterterrorism Chief

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Richard A. Falkenrath, a former deputy homeland security adviser to President Bush, has been named the Police Department's senior counterterrorism official, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. Dr. Falkenrath, 37, will succeed Michael A. Sheehan, who left last month after three years in the post. Dr. Falkenrath served in the White House from January 2001 to May 2004. After Sept. 11, he was the senior director for policy and plans in the Office of Homeland Security and a special assistant to the president. He will start his new job on July 10, overseeing training and risk assessment and working with federal agents, among other things, Mr. Kelly said. AL BAKER (NYT)

headline.main: More Officers To Shift to Sites Of Rising Crime

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The incoming police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said yesterday that he would continue to scale back the number of officers at strategic posts established after the Sept. 11 terror attack and redeploy them to areas where crime has increased recently. ''The department is certainly looking now at the deployment of the strategic posts that have been developed since 9/11,'' Mr. Kelly said yesterday morning as he left a closed-door briefing on department crime statistics at 1 Police Plaza. ''They're re-examining that, they're having discussions about that now. So, to the extent that there have been extra resources assigned to these strategic posts, you're going to see some shifting of that.''

headline.main: Kelly Says Terror Fight Requires Outside Aid

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that a combination of federal aid, grants and other ''external sources'' of money would be needed to pay for the Police Department's ambitious new counterterrorism program, a series of plans that could cost $700 million in all. The commissioner, speaking to members of the City Council's Public Safety Committee, acknowledged the dire fiscal situation facing the department, which is one factor in the decision to go beyond the city coffers to pay for what has become a core mission of local policing after Sept. 11: fighting terrorism.

headline.main: Kelly Plans to Cut Money For Overtime Police Patrols

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Facing a budget crisis, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he planned to significantly reduce the additional patrols that for two years have been financed by a $172 million overtime program in which officers worked on their days off. The department currently has $24 million to pay for the program from January to March. Mr. Kelly said he planned to stretch that money so that the program, known as Operation Condor, could continue into June, effectively halving the amount available for the patrols over the next six months. At its height, the program paid for an additional 1,000 officers on the street each day.

headline.main: Kelly Is Said to Be Planning Shift of Officers From Security to Crime-Fighting

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has decided to reduce the number of police officers at security checkpoints around the city as part of an effort to raise the number assigned to fighting crime, officials said yesterday. As part of the change in security assignments, Mr. Kelly has shifted some of the officers who had been guarding Gracie Mansion on the Upper East Side. The security needs there have diminished in recent days because Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said that unlike his predecessors, he intends to continue living at his East Side town house.

headline.main: Policewoman's Remains Found at Trade Center

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The remains of the only city policewoman killed at the World Trade Center were found yesterday, along with those of two court officers and two Port Authority police officers. The name tag and shield of the policewoman, Officer Moira Smith, were found near her remains, according to Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. The names of the others were not immediately released.

headline.main: Search for Remains Ends With Ceremony

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The city will mark the end of its efforts to recover human remains from the rubble of the World Trade Center today with a ceremony at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, where more than a million and a half tons of debris have been sifted for clues. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly are expected to speak at the ceremony, which is scheduled for 9:30 a.m.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Barriers In Chinatown

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: A state judge has ruled that the New York Police Department must take the first steps toward removing security barricades that have angered Chinatown residents, but it stopped short of ordering the reopening of the street. The barricades, north on Park Row from Frankfort Street to Chatham Square, helped protect nearby police headquarters after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. But Chinatown residents complained they were not consulted about the street closing and were unable to invite family members or friends to their homes. In a decision Monday, Justice Walter B. Tolub of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered the department to have an independent agency conduct an environmental analysis of traffic congestion and pollution. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department was studying the ruling, but that ''obviously we'll do whatever the court directs us to do.'' Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

headline.main: Kelly Focuses On City Defense And Bolstering Shelters' Safety

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly will create a high-level position within the department to oversee the city's response to threats of terrorism and is creating a policy to make the city's homeless shelters safer, officials said yesterday. The outlines of the Mr. Kelly's first initiatives began to filter out yesterday as he was sworn in for a second turn as commissioner at a crowded ceremony at Gracie Mansion.

headline.main: Without Bloomberg in Charge, Police Commissioner’s Future Is Unclear
headline.print_headline: Without Bloomberg in Charge, Police Commissioner’s Future Is Unclear

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The question hanging over Raymond W. Kelly is this: What comes next for the man whose run as leader of the New York Police Department has made him a nationally recognized figure?

headline.main: Kelly Picks Marine for Counterterrorism Unit

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: All 40,000 officers in the New York Police Department will receive specialized training to help them respond to terrorist acts as part of Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly's broad counterterrorism initiative. Mr. Kelly has chosen a retired Marine lieutenant general to oversee the initiative, which will also include advanced equipment and closer cooperation with federal authorities.

headline.main: Ex-C.I.A. Spy Chief to Run Police Intelligence

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: A former spy master with the Central Intelligence Agency joined the New York Police Department yesterday to serve as its deputy commissioner for intelligence, a new position that was created to help steer the department through the post-Sept. 11 world. The new deputy commissioner, David Cohen, spent 35 years in the C.I.A., including two years, 1995 to 1997, as director of operations, a post in which he oversaw the agency's espionage around the world.

headline.main: Tougher Measures Appear to Be Paying Off

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Captured terrorism suspects questioned by the F.B.I. in Europe and the Middle East have told their interrogators that increased security in New York made the city a more difficult place for terrorists to operate, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. Mr. Kelly, in remarks at a City Council hearing and to reporters afterward, said that several weeks ago, the department learned from the F.B.I. that suspects had said that terrorist operatives now considered New York City ''a much more difficult environment in which to function.'' The commissioner said he believed that the department's counterterrorism program and a wide range of heightened security measures (known as Operation Atlas) put in place when the war began in Iraq were in part responsible for a change of outlook among some terrorist operatives.

headline.main: Under Bloomberg, Kelly Will Guide Police Again

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Raymond W. Kelly, who was New York City's 37th police commissioner, under Mayor David N. Dinkins, has accepted Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's offer to return to 1 Police Plaza as the city's 41st police commissioner, two people familiar with the transition plan said yesterday. The announcement could be made as early as today, they said.

headline.main: Commissioners Seek Closer Ties For Fire Dept. And the Police

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: The commissioners of the New York City Police and Fire Departments said yesterday that for the first time they would exchange liaison officers and carry out specialized training together. The moves, they said, are intended to improve communications between the two agencies, but may also ease the tensions that have long divided some of their members. The effort by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Nicholas Scoppetta, the fire commissioner, was prompted in part by miscues after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, officials said. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce the new arrangement next week.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: General Meets With Police Leaders

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, a retired four-star Army commander, visited about 100 members of the New York Police Department's executive staff yesterday to brief them about his recent travels in Iraq, Afghanistan and Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, said Paul J. Browne, the department's chief spokesman. It was the latest in a series of lectures that Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has set up to keep his senior commanders and aides informed on terrorism-related issues and other international matters in the wake of the 2001 terrorist attacks. Past lecturers have included King Abdullah II of Jordan; Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the emir of Qatar; former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger; and Robert S. Mueller III, the F.B.I. director. AL BAKER (NYT)

headline.main: Kelly Says He's Still Puzzled By Federal Reply to Threat

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly made comments yesterday that appeared to be his most pointed yet regarding the public disagreement earlier this month between city officials and the Department of Homeland Security over a threat to the subway system. Calling the way Homeland Security officials had discounted the threat a ''mystery'' and ''not that logical,'' Mr. Kelly again defended the city's response, and said the dispute was not a result of a miscommunication, as some have suggested. Officials in both the Police Department and Homeland Security, he said, had been talking to each other all along.

headline.main: OTHER SHOE DROPS

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: New York's former police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, became Taser International's most famous former board member last week. He left the company, which makes electric stun guns, three months after he withdrew his nomination to run the Department of Homeland Security, a Taser client. Mark A. Stein

headline.main: Kelly Seeking Federal Money For City Police

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has undertaken an unusual lobbying campaign in Washington, seeking federal money because the New York Police Department has assigned so many officers to counterterrorism duties. The campaign is part of Commissioner Kelly's effort to prevent the city's fiscal woes from significantly reducing the size of the police force. The federal government rarely pays for operating expenses or overtime for municipalities. But aides to Mr. Kelly say he has argued that Washington should bear some of the department's costs because of the number of city officers who have been working since Sept. 11, 2001, to prevent additional attacks. In that way, according to the argument, the officers have been contributing to the national defense, which was previously the sole province of the federal authorities.

headline.main: Battling Crime, and Talk of a Mayoral Run

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has said it again and again: he has no plans to trade his 14th-floor office at 1 Police Plaza for an even more powerful perch across the street at City Hall. He has been unequivocal: he has no plans to make a 2009 run to be New York's mayor. He said it with square-jawed authority on NY1 in August, explaining how happy he is to be police commissioner. He talks of his love of the department he joined as a cadet in 1961, and of the new challenge of fighting terrorism. This summer he told Gabe Pressman of WNBC-TV, ''I'm going to be police commissioner, hopefully, until the end of the term, Mayor Bloomberg's term here.'' That would preclude a run for mayor, since police officials cannot serve and campaign for office at the same time.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Consumer Affairs Commissioner

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Mintz, the acting commissioner of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs since May 2005, has been named the commissioner, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. Previously an assistant and then a deputy commissioner since joining the department in 2002, Mr. Mintz, 42, succeeds Gretchen Dykstra, who resigned to lead the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation. Mr. Mintz, a lawyer, has taught at a private school in Greenwich Village and at law schools in Illinois and Rhode Island. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

headline.main: Police Shift Focus to Terror With Spymaster and a Marine

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: In his first month on the job, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly created two new senior positions in the Police Department and filled them with men who have not a lick of experience policing New York City. But the two new deputy commissioners have a combined 70 years of experience sneaking spies into foreign countries, landing soldiers on foreign shores and navigating the bureaucratic back alleys in Washington where policy and politics intersect. And that, Mr. Kelly has decided, is experience that has become as valuable to the nation's largest police force as are the strategies that brought homicide and robbery rates down or the police management skills now needed in a budget crisis to maintain those declines in crime while holding overtime in check.

headline.main: Kelly Says Analysis Of Security Was Timely

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Raymond W.
