Kelly yesterday defended his department's handling of security issues at ground zero, saying it had provided timely recommendations concerning the planned Freedom Tower. Mr. Kelly did not specify what criticism prompted him to release a statement yesterday about the Police Department's security analysis of the World Trade Center site. But his comments came on the same day a New York Times article quoted people involved in the rebuilding as saying the analysis would require extensive revisions to the design and lead to construction delays of several months to a year.

headline.seo: New York Police Commissioner Takes Al Qaeda Threat Seriously
headline.main: Officials Seek Origin of Threat in Al Qaeda’s Name
headline.print_headline: Officials Seek Origin of Threat in Al Qaeda’s Name

Raymond Kelly - NYPD Commissioner.lead_paragraph: A warning of “Al Qaeda Coming Soon Again in New York” was superimposed on the Manhattan skyline on a Web site.

headline.main: Seeking to Control Borders, Bush Turns to Big Military Contractors

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The quick fix may involve sending in the National Guard. But to really patch up the broken border, President Bush is preparing to turn to a familiar administration partner: the nation's giant military contractors. Lockheed Martin, Raytheon and Northrop Grumman, three of the largest, are among the companies that said they would submit bids within two weeks for a multibillion-dollar federal contract to build what the administration calls a ''virtual fence'' along the nation's land borders.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; PROTEST IN NEW JERSEY

Immigration.lead_paragraph: About half the nearly 100 people jailed in Middlesex County, N.J., on immigration charges are refusing to eat some meals. Among their complaints are the length of their detentions and inadequate medical treatment, several detainees said. Kerry Gill, Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman in Newark, said it was hard to say how many detainees were involved. The warden, Michael T. Abode, said that rather than go hungry, some detainees had bought food at the commissary, which sells candy and instant soup. Immigration and jail officials denied there were serious problems at the jail but said they would look into the complaints. Christopher Drew (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Push For More Workers

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A group of seasonal Michigan businesses that rely on foreign workers for summer staff is suing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over delays in processing temporary work visas since the Sept. 11 attacks. The 13 companies filing suit are on the shores of the Great Lakes and include hotels and restaurants. John Carpenter (NYT)

headline.seo: Immigration Bill Would Aid Security, Napolitano Says
headline.main: Immigration Bill Would Aid Security, Napolitano Says
headline.print_headline: Immigration Bill Would Aid Security, Napolitano Says

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, cited increased financing and manpower and a mandatory electronic employment verification system.

headline.seo: In Test of Deportation Policy, 1 in 6 Offered Reprieve
headline.main: In Deportation Policy Test, 1 in 6 Offered Reprieve
headline.print_headline: In Test of Deportation Policy, 1 in 6 Get a Fresh Look and a Reprieve

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A court review in Denver focused on low-risk immigrants, allowing more than 1,000 to stay without legal status.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Signs Border-Security Measure

Immigration.lead_paragraph: President Bush signed legislation to improve border security and to toughen enforcement of immigration laws. The legislation provides for more immigration investigators, directs colleges and universities to use the Internet to track foreign students and requires foreign visitors to carry visas that include biometric identifiers like fingerprints. Carla Baranauckas (NYT)

headline.main: In Father’s Memory, Fighting to Stay in Britain
headline.print_headline: In Father’s Memory, Fighting to Stay in Britain

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Britain repels illegal immigrants through an enforcement system partly run by private contractors, but it has legitimized treating foreigners as scapegoats.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protesting Treatment Of Immigrants

Immigration.lead_paragraph: More than 100 people gathered in Union Square Park yesterday to protest the government's treatment of immigrants since the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. They chanted, ''I.N.S., F.B.I., no more kidnaps, no more lies,'' and waved signs that read, ''Stop racist attacks on immigrants'' and ''Close the I.N.S. jails, open up the borders.'' Hundreds of immigrants were detained largely on immigration violations in the months after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Diplomats have said they have been provided insufficient information about those behind bars. There were 460 such detainees last month. The State Department has said the government is living up to its obligations to advise detained foreigners of their right to contact their embassy or consulate. Immigration and Naturalization Service officials have said that detainees cannot be released until the F.B.I. completely investigates the leads that brought them to the attention of authorities. The I.N.S. did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment.

headline.main: Scores of Pakistanis Are Deported by U.S.

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department last month quietly deported 131 Pakistani citizens who had been swept up in the post-Sept. 11 crackdown on foreigners in the country illegally, officials said tonight. The department chartered a plane on June 28 to return the Pakistanis, who had received deportation orders from an immigration judge, according to Russell A. Bergeron, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

headline.main: Mexico Worries About Its Own Southern Border

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Quiet as it is kept in political circles, Mexico, so much the focus of the United States' immigration debate, has its own set of immigration problems. And as elected officials from President Vicente Fox on down denounce Washington's plans to deploy troops and build more walls along the United States border, Mexico has begun a re-examination of its own policies and prejudices. Here at Mexico's own southern edge, Guatemalans cross legally and illegally to do jobs that Mexicans departing for the north no longer want. And hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from nearly two dozen other countries, including China, Ecuador, Cuba and Somalia, pass through on their way to the United States.

headline.main: I.N.S. DETAINEES

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The Immigration and Naturalization Service changed its policy last week and agreed to allow advocacy groups to visit foreign nationals held in the Hudson and Passaic County jails since Sept. 11. The service will allow such groups as the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee to help detainees with legal questions and to provide representation. There are 460 aliens held nationwide since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the I.N.S., though how many are in New Jersey is not known. John Holl

headline.seo: Illegal Immigrants May Face New Curbs in Arizona
headline.main: Arizona Endorses Immigration Curbs
headline.print_headline: Immigrants In Arizona May Face New Curbs

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Arizona is moving ahead with legislation widely considered among the most stringent in the states.

headline.main: Judge: Review Immigrant's Residency Application
headline.print_headline: Judge: Review Immigrant's Residency Application

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Kentucky is compelling immigration officials to make a decision about an application for permanent residency brought by an Iranian immigrant who distributed leaflets for a violent organization in his home country 30 years ago.

headline.main: Immigrants Refuse Meals to Protest Treatment

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Seven immigrants detained at a county jail in New Jersey since the Sept. 11 terror attacks are staging a hunger strike to protest their treatment by federal immigration officials, county officials said yesterday. But the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which pays the jail to house the detainees, said it was unaware of any hunger strikers. Nonetheless, the agency said it would take steps to address concerns of detainees at the jail, the Hudson County Correctional Center, including serving halal meals, which adhere to Islamic dietary rules, beginning today.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Reversing itself, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit civil-liberties lawyers to advise hundreds of foreign nationals held since the Sept. 11 attacks. The decision, issued Jan. 11 but not received by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey until Jan. 24, followed two lawsuits accusing the government of illegally withholding the names of detainees and the charges against them. The decision will allow members of the A.C.L.U. to determine whether detainees require legal assistance. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.seo: Senator Hatch Emerges as Key Player on Immigration Reform
headline.main: Veteran Senator Emerges as Player on Immigration Overhaul
headline.print_headline: Veteran Senator Emerges as Player on Immigration Overhaul

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The bipartisan group of eight senators who drafted an immigration overhaul see Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah as a potentially influential partner.

headline.main: Global Seagulls and the New Reality of Immigration
headline.print_headline: Global Seagulls and the New Reality of Immigration

Immigration.lead_paragraph: In the age of the Internet, the jet airplane and the multinational company, the very concepts of immigration, citizenship and even statehood are changing.

headline.main: Global Seagulls and the New Reality of Immigration

Immigration.lead_paragraph: BANFF, ALBERTA -- Immigration is always a hot issue when the economy is weak and jobs are scarce, so it should be no surprise that it has jumped to the top of the political agenda in Europe and the United States. But much of the debate today around these centuries-old themes of us vs. them and newcomer vs. old-timer is missing an essential point: In the age of the Internet, the jet airplane and the multinational company, the very concepts of immigration, citizenship and even statehood are changing. ''This is the new wave, the new trend,'' Wang Huiyao, founder and president of the Beijing-based Center for China and Globalization, told me. ''We had the globalization of trade, we had the globalization of capital, and now we have the globalization of talent.''

headline.main: Report: Gov't Success in Immigration Court Drops
headline.print_headline: Report: Gov't Success in Immigration Court Drops

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Nearly half of immigrants facing deportation are now winning their cases before an immigration judge, their highest success rate in more than 20 years, according to a new analysis of court data published Thursday.

headline.main: Teenage African Immigrant Is Freed After 3 Years in Detention

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A teenage immigrant from Guinea, who had been held in detention centers for three years during a legal struggle for his release and permanent asylum, has been freed, his lawyers announced on Wednesday. The youth, Malik Jarno, now 18, was released by Asa Hutchinson, under secretary of the Department of Homeland Security.

headline.main: I.N.S. Proposes New Limits On the Length Of Visas

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Under intense pressure to regroup after embarrassing lapses involving the Sept. 11 hijackers, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced several steps today to gain greater control over tourists and visiting students and businessmen. The proposed measures would reduce the amount of time granted to most foreign tourists, to 30 days from six months; limit most business travelers to a maximum of six months; and penalize illegal visitors who ignore the agency's orders to turn themselves in within 30 days.

headline.main: WITHHOLDING DETAINEES' NAMES

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A state appellate court ruled last week that the federal government can keep the names of detainees being held in custody a secret. Since Sept. 11 more than 1,100 detainees have been held nationally, many of them in Hudson and Passaic County jails, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The ruling said that the release of detainees' names could compromise investigations and public safety. Civil liberties advocates wanted the names released to monitor detainees' treatment in custody and to ensure adequate legal representation. A representative of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said the group planned to appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. John Holl

headline.main: Effort to Discover Terrorists Among Illegal Aliens Makes Glacial Progress, Critics Say
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE IMMIGRATION AGENCY

Immigration.lead_paragraph: In placing the Justice Department on a wartime footing, Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to lead the charge in ferreting out potential terrorists among the nation's illegal immigrants. But on the ground, the order is being translated into reality at a glacial pace, if that, critics say.

headline.main: U.S. Seeks Employers' Aid On Immigration

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Federal immigration authorities unveiled a program yesterday that is designed to induce employers to stop hiring illegal immigrants and to report those they find on their payrolls. In return, employers would be certified by the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency as having a clean bill of health on hiring.

headline.main: Documents Reveal Pressure to Comply With Program to Deport Immigrants
headline.print_headline: Documents Reveal Pressure to Comply With Program to Deport Immigrants

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Internal documents show that Secure Communities, a program aimed at deporting illegal immigrants with criminal records, aggressively pressured city and county officials to participate.

headline.main: Pearl Prosecutor Quits Post in Pakistan

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The chief prosecutor in the case of the killing of the American reporter Daniel Pearl in Pakistan has resigned as the advocate general of the southern province of Sindh for undisclosed reasons. The prosecutor, Raja Qureshi, submitted a letter on Friday to the government announcing his decision to resign. He denied reports that his resignation had been prompted by written threats against him.

headline.main: Militants Linked to Killing of U.S. Reporter in Pakistan Remain at Large, Report Says

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Nine years after the American reporter Daniel Pearl was captured and killed by operatives of Al Qaeda in Pakistan, more than a dozen of the militants involved in his murder remain at large, a testament to the lack of will by Pakistani authorities to prosecute the cases, according to a report released Thursday. Some of the 14 men who are known to have played a role in the death of Mr. Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, committed other terrorist acts in Pakistan, including an attack on a hotel in Karachi in which 11 French engineers were killed, and the attempted assassination of the former president, Pervez Musharraf, the report says.

headline.main: Suspect in Pearl Case to Face Charges

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: A prime suspect in the kidnapping and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl has been moved to the southern port city of Karachi for prosecution after being arrested last month, Pakistani officials said Tuesday. The suspect, Muhammad Hashim Qadeer, who is about 35, was arrested in the eastern city of Gujranwala, in Punjab Province, and is suspected of having ties with the banned extremist groups Harkat-ul-Mujahedeen and Jaish-e-Muhammad.

headline.main: Pakistan Questions 2 in Daniel Pearl Killing

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Pakistani officials said they were investigating two people arrested Monday in Kashmor, a remote town in the southern province of Sindh, for any links to the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002. Noor Ahmed Paichuho, the Kashmor police chief, said in a telephone interview that the men, Attaur Rehman and Faisal Bhatti, were being interrogated in Kashmor.

headline.main: Mastermind Behind Daniel Pearl's Murder Is Moved to New Prison

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The man convicted of masterminding the kidnapping and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl was transferred Sunday to a prison here, and a leading Pakistani newspaper reported that he had been moved so he could be interrogated about assassination attempts last month on the country's president. Abdur Rauf Chaudhry, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry, said the prisoner, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who has been sentenced to death, had been transferred from a prison in central Pakistan for security reasons. ''Such hardened criminals form groups if they are allowed to stay at one place for a long time,'' he said. ''This is why, because of security concerns, criminals are shifted to various jails.''

headline.main: 2 Qaeda Suspects Are Arrested in Pakistan

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Pakistani police officers and American F.B.I. agents arrested two men suspected of being members of Al Qaeda early today, and a third suspect, who was wounded in a gunfight, may have escaped, officials said. The two men, identified as an Egyptian and a Yemeni, were arrested in a house on the outskirts of Karachi near where the body of Daniel Pearl, the kidnapped Wall Street Journal reporter, was found last year. There was no immediate indication the two men were involved in the abduction of Mr. Pearl.

headline.main: Pakistan Officials Arrest a Key Suspect in Pearl Kidnapping

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The Pakistani authorities today arrested an Islamic militant who has been the main suspect in the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, and said he told them that Mr. Pearl was still alive. The suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, was arrested in the eastern city of Lahore and then taken to Karachi for more questioning. The authorities declined to give further details, but they said that Mr. Sheikh's account might be true, and that Mr. Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, might soon be free.

headline.main: 4 IN PEARL MURDER ARE FOUND GUILTY IN PAKISTAN COURT

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: A British-born Islamic militant was convicted and sentenced to death today for the kidnaping and murder of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter. Ahmed Omar Sheikh was convicted with three other men, Salman Saqib, Fahad Naseem and Shaikh Adil, who were sentenced to life in prison, said Abdul Waheed Katpar, Mr. Sheikh's lawyer. The verdict was handed down this morning by Judge Ali Ashraf Shah.

headline.seo: Lull in U.S. Drone Strikes Aids Pakistan Militants
headline.main: Lull in Strikes by U.S. Drones Aids Militants in Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Lull In Strikes By U.S. Drones Aids Militants

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: A plunge in relations between the United States and Pakistan has led to a pause in American drone strikes and given Al Qaeda and Pakistani factions a chance to regroup.

headline.main: Pakistan Turns Up Heat Under a Prime Suspect in a Reporter's Kidnapping

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The Pakistani authorities have detained several close relatives of the prime suspect in the disappearance of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in hopes that they will help persuade the kidnappers to let Mr. Pearl go, officials here said today. The suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a British-born Muslim militant, has not been found. But Pakistanis who have been watching the case closely say they regard the arrests -- apparently of a grandfather and an uncle of Mr. Sheikh's, among others -- as part of a new hard-line strategy by the government.

headline.main: Wall Street Journal Reporter Missing in Karachi for 2 Days

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter who was in Karachi, Pakistan, reporting on Al Qaeda, has been reported missing. He left the home where he was staying on Tuesday to meet two people who had presented themselves as sources with contacts in the terrorist network, according to a spokesman for Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Journal. Mr. Pearl was reported missing on Wednesday by his wife, who is in Karachi, after he failed to return or make contact with his editors -- a procedure required of reporters in dangerous regions. Karachi, a port city that is home to many Islamic religious schools and was the site of frequent anti-American demonstrations last fall, has a reputation among journalists as a particularly inhospitable place to work.

headline.main: Book Deal For Widow Of Reporter From Journal

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Scribner, part of the Simon & Schuster division of Viacom, has acquired the right to publish a memoir by Mariane Pearl, whose husband, Daniel Pearl of The Wall Street Journal, was kidnapped and killed reporting from Pakistan. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Ms. Pearl, who was born in France, is a journalist and foreign correspondent. She has directed documentary films, had a radio show and written newspaper columns in French.

headline.main: Former Pakistani Navy Commando Arrested in Sweep for Attack Suspects
headline.print_headline: Pakistan: Arrest in Karachi Attack

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The sweep by Pakistani intelligence agents was conducted in connection with the audacious attack last week on the naval base in the southern port city of Karachi.

headline.main: Diplomats Expect Conviction in Pearl Case

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration is confident that Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who is on trial here for the abduction and murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, will be convicted and executed, and is therefore not demanding that he be extradited to the United States, according to Pakistani officials and Western diplomats. ''He will be hung here, as a matter of policy,'' a Western diplomat said about Mr. Sheikh. ''The courts here are not eminently neutral, you know -- that's a reality.'' He added that based on the intelligence he had seen, the case against Mr. Sheik was a strong one, and that the suspect had links to terrorist organizations.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 11 Pakistanis Charged In Terror Plots

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The National Court indicted 11 Pakistani men on charges that they raised money for Al Qaeda sympathizers and conspired to commit terrorist acts in Spain. All were arrested last year on suspicion of forming a terrorist cell in Barcelona. Court documents say the recipients of the group's money included Rabei Osman Sayed Ahmed, known as Muhammad the Egyptian. He is charged with helping to carry out the Madrid train bombings in March 2004 and has boasted that he was their architect. The documents also say the group sent money to the Islamic militants suspected of killing a Wall Street Journal reporter, Daniel Pearl, in 2002 in Pakistan. Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline.main: Video of Death Of Journalist Is Seen in Court In Pakistan

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: A video showing the beheading of the American journalist Daniel Pearl was shown in a Pakistani court today in the trial of four men accused of the murder. The four defendants sat unmoved throughout the screening. A defense lawyer dismissed the videotape as ''very weak evidence,'' and cited the absence of movement from the body during the beheading as proof the video was a fake.

headline.main: Suspect Says Reporter Was Slain In January as Part of Wider Plot

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The chief suspect in the Daniel Pearl case has told investigators that the captive Wall Street Journal reporter was killed in late January as part of a plot that was to have included an attack on the United States Consulate in Karachi, intelligence and law enforcement officials said today. The claims by the suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a British-born militant now in Pakistani custody, are among the clues being weighed by the American and Pakistani authorities still pursuing others thought to have been involved in the killing, a gruesome beheading recorded on a three-minute, 50-second digital videotape made available to American investigators in Karachi late on Thursday.

headline.seo: Pakistan Arrests Militant Suspected in Daniel Pearl Killing
headline.main: Pakistan Arrests Militant Suspected in Daniel Pearl Killing
headline.print_headline: Militant Held Was Sought In ’02 Killing Of Reporter

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The suspect is a senior figure in the Islamist group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, accused in the mass killing of Shiites.

headline.main: Pakistan Holds 2 Ex-Agents in Kidnapping

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The authorities in Pakistan have detained two former members of the country's intelligence service in the hope that they can provide information about the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, Pakistani officials said today. The action represents an unusual assault on the Inter-Services Intelligence agency, the powerful and semiautonomous military institution whose ties to Islamic militants have been a problem and an embarrassment for the current and previous governments of Pakistan. It came as Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was preparing to begin an official visit to Washington.

headline.main: Musharraf Opponents Criticize Handling of Kidnapping

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Opponents of President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan blamed his military government today for failing to prevent the killing of Daniel Pearl, and they warned that the situation could get worse before it got better as General Musharraf tries to make good on a promise to put an end to terrorism. On Friday night, General Musharraf said in a national television address that the killing of Mr. Pearl, an American journalist, apparently by Muslim militants, had doubled his resolve ''to move much more strongly against all such terrorist people and those organizations that perpetrate terrorism, to move against them and liquidate them entirely from our country.''

headline.main: U.S. Indictment In Deadly Plot On Journalist

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: A 28-year-old British-born Muslim militant was indicted today on federal charges that he orchestrated the kidnapping plot that led to the murder of Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. The charges can carry the death penalty. The suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who is now in custody in Pakistan, was indicted by a grand jury in Trenton on charges of hostage-taking and conspiracy to commit hostage-taking resulting in a death. The Journal's corporate home is in South Brunswick, N.J.

headline.main: Prominent Muslim Militant Is Named a Suspect in Pearl Case

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: Pakistani and American officials identified a leader of a Pakistani militant Muslim group today as the chief suspect in the disappearance of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, saying that he came to their attention because of his role in the kidnapping of four Western tourists in India in 1994. The suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a 28-year-old born in Britain, was imprisoned by India in connection with the 1994 case. But he was freed in Afghanistan in 1999 in a prisoner-release deal related to the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet. Pakistani security officials said they lost track of him after his release.

headline.main: 3 Held and Computer Seized In Case of Missing Reporter

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The Pakistani police said today that they had arrested two men suspected of sending e-mail messages with photographs of Daniel Pearl, the American reporter kidnapped in the southern city of Karachi two weeks ago, and a United States law enforcement official confirmed last night that Pakistani police had the computer used to send those messages. A senior Pakistani police official said a third man had also been arrested tonight under suspicion of involvement in Mr. Pearl's abduction.

headline.main: Man Convicted in Murder of Reporter Calls for Retaliation by Other Muslims

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: With security heavy and officials bracing for a retaliatory attack, the man condemned today to death for the kidnapping and murder of the American reporter Daniel Pearl called on fellow Muslims to take revenge for the sentence. ''We shall see who will die first -- either I or the authorities who arranged the death sentence for me,'' the condemned man, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, 28, said in a statement read by one of his lawyers here after the sentence was handed down.

headline.main: Pakistan Arrests at Least 7 Militants, Including Suspect in Bombing

Daniel Pearl and Omar Sheikh.lead_paragraph: The police arrested at least seven Pakistani militants in raids in Karachi this morning, including the suspected mastermind of a car bombing last May that killed 11 French engineers and 3 Pakistanis, officials said in a statement tonight. A police official said militants who had planned to assassinate Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, when he visited Karachi on Tuesday were also arrested.

headline.main: June 16-22; COMING UP

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: On Monday, President Bush will discuss homeland security in Newark, N.J. About half a dozen Congressional committees will be considering the administration's proposal for a new department of homeland security. Making a government conglomerate, Page 3. On Tuesday and Wednesday, the president attends the Group of 8 summit meeting in the Canadian Rockies.

headline.main: November 24-30: NATIONAL; A NEW CABINET MEMBER

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: President Bush named Tom Ridge, who has been the White House's domestic security coordinator, to be the first secretary of homeland security. In his new position, Mr. Ridge, a former Republican governor of Pennsylvania, will oversee creation of the new Department of Homeland Security, a big bureaucratic challenge, while trying to make Americans safer within their own borders. Richard W. Stevenson

headline.main: November 17-23: NATIONAL; 22 AGENCIES, 1 DEPARTMENT

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Moving past months of partisan delays, Congress finally agreed on the new Department of Homeland Security, which will include parts of 22 agencies. After the president signs the legislation later this month, the department will undoubtedly take several years to coalesce and will depend on a much more coordinated intelligence strategy than exists today. David Firestone

headline.main: Sept. 22-28: FRONT LINES; PROTECTING AMERICA

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Democrats gathered enough votes to ensure job protections for workers in a new Homeland Security Department, setting up a battle with the Bush administration, which opposes those civil service protections. Although negotiations continue, creation of the department may be put off until next year. David Firestone

headline.main: Florida: Voter Purge Results In Countersuits

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice said Monday that it will sue Florida to stop its push to remove what it says are ineligible voters from their rolls, while Florida said it was suing the Department of Homeland Security over the purge. Florida says as many as 182,000 registered voters may not be citizens, but the Homeland Security Department has denied its request for access to a federal immigration database to verify the matches. Federal officials say the purge violates voting laws.

headline.main: Homeland Security Deputy To Quit

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The deputy Homeland Security Department secretary, Michael Jackson, who helped set up the Transportation Security Administration shortly after the 2001 terrorist attacks, said he was resigning, effective Oct. 26, and returning to the private sector to earn more money. His name was mentioned as a possible successor to Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff if Mr. Chertoff had been nominated as attorney general.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Department Recommends Asylum For Woman

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security recommended that Attorney General John Ashcroft grant asylum to a Guatemalan woman in a case that may have far-reaching implications for women seeking asylum in the United States on the grounds that they were persecuted because of their sex. The woman, Rodi Alvarado Pena, fled her country to escape an abusive husband. Bill Strassberger, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, said a final decision from Mr. Ashcroft was expected soon. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Security Increased At Research Center

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Plum Island Animal Research Center, which was criticized in the past for security problems, is now being guarded by agents of the Federal Protective Service, who were deployed three weeks ago by the Department of Homeland Security to supplement private security patrols there, Representative Timothy Bishop, above, said yesterday. Homeland Security took over operations on the island off eastern Long Island from the Department of Agriculture in June 2003. Mr. Bishop, a Democrat from Suffolk County, said the addition of the agents, who are guarding the center part time, was ''a good step.'' But he urged 24-hour security ''because the threat to the island is constant.''

headline.main: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: ''After 9/11, we had to show how committed we were by spending hugely greater amounts of money than ever before, as rapidly as possible. That brought us what we might expect, which is some expensive mistakes. This has been the difficult learning curve of the new discipline known as homeland security.'' REP. CHRISTOPHER COX, a California Republican who is the chairman of the Homeland Security Committee. [26]

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Head Of Transportation Security Is Stepping Down

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: David M. Stone, the assistant secretary at the Department of Homeland Security in charge of overseeing airport and other transportation security efforts, will leave his post in June, department officials said. The departure, first reported by The Washington Post, comes as the department's secretary, Michael Chertoff, considers changes in how the department is organized. The Transportation Security Administration, which Mr. Stone has led since December 2003, may lose some components or gain others, the officials said, but will continue to exist even after a department reorganization. Eric Lipton (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Threatens Veto

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The House approved legislation that proposes $39.8 billion for the Homeland Security Department next year. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure over its pro-union provision. The measure, which passed 296 to 126, would strike a provision in the 2002 legislation creating the department that allowed the president to waive collective-bargaining rights for department workers.

headline.main: Deputy Security Official Leaving Post

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The White House announced today that the No. 2 official at the Department of Homeland Security, Deputy Secretary Gordon England, would return to his previous job as Navy secretary, only seven months after he was confirmed to the domestic security post. The move surprised many at the Homeland Security Department, where Mr. England, a former defense industry executive, was responsible for the logistics of the consolidation of 22 agencies. The new department, which has an estimated 170,000 employees, came into being only a week before Mr. England's confirmation by the Senate in January.

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Security Agency Planned

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security says that it has created a national cybersecurity division to prepare for and respond to Internet attacks against government networks and some private-sector networks. The department is expected to name a director for the unit sometime this summer, officials said. The division, which will have 60 employees, will work to identify and reduce potential threats and vulnerabilities to attacks over the Internet. It will also provide technical assistance in planning for a recovery from such attacks and will issue alerts and warnings. ''Cybersecurity cuts across all aspects of critical infrastructure protection,'' said Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security.

headline.main: July 7-13: FRONT LINES; SHAPING SECURITY AGENCY

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: There was bipartisan support for a new Department of Homeland Security when President Bush proposed it, but now there is bipartisan support for drastically changing his plan. House committees refused the administration's pleas to include the Coast Guard, the Secret Service and the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the department, and also voted to split up the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The committee recommendations are likely to be changed when the issue reaches the House and Senate floors, but Mr. Bush's plan is unlikely to emerge intact. David Firestone

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Homeland Security Official To Resign

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Matthew E. Broderick, the senior Department of Homeland Security official who accepted blame for not ensuring that Michael Chertoff and the White House were fully informed about reports of levee breaches on the day Hurricane Katrina hit, has said he will resign at the end of March. Mr. Broderick ran the Homeland Security Operations Center, which received reports of the breaches. Mr. Chertoff said Mr. Broderick, a retired brigadier general in the Marines, ''left an indelible mark on the department.'' Russ Knocke, a department spokesman, said the resignation was not forced. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

headline.main: Technology Briefing | People: White House Names Cybersecurity Chief

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has chosen Amit Yoran, an executive at the Symantec Corporation, to be the nation's cybersecurity chief at the Department of Homeland Security. Mr. Yoran, who will be named to the post today, is a former director of vulnerability assessment at the Defense Department. The White House has said it will seek to improve cybersecurity by encouraging investment in research and standards. It proposes a large role for the domestic security department on numerous fronts: setting up a national cyberspace monitoring system, pushing more secure Internet protocol standards, creating a reliable system for vulnerability disclosure and improving the quality of cybersecurity training.

headline.main: April 27-May 3; More Lobbyists Are Knocking at Ridge's Door

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists are increasingly targeting the Department of Homeland Security, overseen by Secretary Tom Ridge. The agency will be spending billions of dollars.

headline.main: Turning Fear on Its Head With a Soft, Cozy Blanket

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Chrissy Conant, an artist in New York, sometimes lies awake at night worrying about terrorism. To calm her fears by confronting them, she said, she designed the Chrissy Homeland Security Blanket ($750), a soft-napped queen-size blanket bearing the legend of the Homeland Security Advisory System in colors that are ''a little brighter, a little more pleasant'' than those used by the Department of Homeland Security. The blanket, which is made by Pendleton Woolen Mills, comes in a signed, limited edition of 100 from www.chrissyconant.com; the Lyonswiergallery (511 West 25th Street, suite 205); or the gift shop of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum (2 East 91st Street). EVE KAHN

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Fewer Immigrants Captured

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Apprehensions of illegal immigrants crossing the border fell last year by 8 percent, the Department of Homeland Security said. The Border Patrol caught about 1.1 million illegal immigrants in the 2006 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, compared with about 1.2 million in the previous year, the department said. The lower number is a sign that tougher enforcement is deterring people from making the trip, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said.

headline.main: National Report | Washington: New Rail Security Rules

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security said it had developed the first federal procedures to protect rail passengers from terrorism. Asa Hutchinson, the undersecretary for border and transportation security, said rail companies would be required to designate security coordinators, conduct inspections and ask passengers and employees to report unattended property or suspicious behavior. Lawmakers have paid particular attention to the security of railways in the United States since the March bombings in Madrid that killed 201 people. John Files (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Nominee For U.S. Attorney

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: President Bush yesterday nominated Michael J. Garcia, left, an assistant secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, to be the United States attorney in Manhattan. The job is now held by David N. Kelley, who was appointed temporarily in December 2003 when James B. Comey became deputy attorney general. The nomination requires Senate approval, but no great opposition is expected. Mr. Garcia, a New Yorker and a former federal prosecutor, now runs the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency in the Department of Homeland Security. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Homeland Security's Deadline Troubles

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security routinely misses deadlines to document for Congress its progress on tasks as essential as screening air cargo and protecting ports, leaders of the House Committee on Homeland Security said. The accusation came in a letter that two Democratic representatives, Bennie Thompson of Mississippi and Kendrick B. Meek of Florida, sent to the department's secretary, Michael Chertoff, asking him when Congress would be sent the requested information. Department officials did not immediately dispute that they might have missed deadlines for as many as 45 required reports in the last year. Brian Roehrkasse, a department spokesman, said the trouble was that the department was overwhelmed with Congressional requests for information. Eric S. Lipton (NYT)

headline.main: U.S. Security Officials Issue Bulletin on Syria-Based Threat
headline.print_headline: U.S. Security Officials Issue Bulletin on Syria-Based Threat

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: U.S. security agencies issued an intelligence bulletin on Tuesday about threats from Syria-based al Qaeda operatives, a Homeland Security spokeswoman said.

headline.main: Domestic Security Adviser Named

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The White House named Kenneth L. Wainstein, a senior Justice Department official, to be President Bush's homeland security adviser. Mr. Wainstein now heads the National Security Division, which coordinates the Justice Department's counterterrorism, intelligence and counterespionage efforts. He was formerly the top federal prosecutor in Washington and general counsel and chief of staff at the F.B.I.

headline.main: Delaware: Port Security Program

Department of Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Workers at the port of Wilmington will begin being enrolled in a new program and receive identification cards mandated by the federal government in an effort to improve security. The Department of Homeland Security will begin enrollment on Oct. 16 after months of delays in starting the program. Enrollment will continue at 11 other ports through November, and officials hope to have the new IDs for all port workers by September. Congress ordered the administration to develop the card as part of port security legislation passed in late 2002.

headline.main: After Arrests, Taliban Promote a Fighter
headline.print_headline: After Arrests, Taliban Promote a Fighter

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council voted Friday to treat Al Qaeda and the Taliban separately when it comes to sanctions, a move that is aimed at supporting the Afghan government's reconciliation efforts and that could help clear a path for negotiations with the Taliban. The American ambassador, Susan E. Rice, said the vote would send ''a clear message to the Taliban that there is a future for those who separate from Al Qaeda.''

headline.main: C.I.A. Drones Kill Civilians In Pakistan

Taliban.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Several missiles fired from American drone aircraft on Thursday struck a meeting of local people in northwest Pakistan who had gathered with Taliban mediators to settle a dispute over a chromite mine. The attack, a Pakistani intelligence official said, killed 26 of 32 people present, some of them Taliban fighters, but the majority elders and local people not attached to the militants. The civilian death toll appeared to be among the worst in the scores of strikes carried out recently in Pakistan's tribal areas by the C.I.A., which runs the drones. Local residents and media reports said as many as 40 people had been killed in all, though the intelligence official disputed that.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; DISCUSSING SURRENDER

Taliban.lead_paragraph: More than 15 top Taliban leaders, most of them ex-cabinet members, are in contact with Afghan authorities in Kandahar over their possible surrender, according to Khalid Pashtun, a senior aide to Gov. Gul Agha Shirzai. Asked whether the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was among them, he said: ''No. He knows the consequences if he surrenders.'' But security officials said they hoped that the Taliban leaders could provide information to track down Mullah Omar, and even help locate Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Aid workers in Kandahar, Afghanistan, have buried a man originally identified by the Taliban as an American, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today. Citing privacy concerns, Red Cross officials here would not identify the man or release his nationality, saying only that he was not an Afghan or an American.

headline.main: FROZEN ASSETS RELEASED

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration authorized the release of $25.5 million to cash-starved Afghanistan in assets frozen while the country was ruled by the Taliban militia. The latest assets ordered unblocked belong to the Afghan Export Promotion Bank, Bank Millie and its subsidiaries, Afghan House and Afghan Trading.

headline.main: Pakistan Fighting Drives Families Over Border Into Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: Pakistan Fighting Drives Families Over Border Into Afghanistan

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Pakistani families have fled from a surge of fighting between Pakistani government forces and militants into neighboring Afghanistan, an Afghan government official said on Friday.

headline.main: Warning in Afghanistan

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, warned Tuesday of more attacks from Taliban and Al Qaeda guerrillas, but he promised a relentless military response. ''We expect additional attempts by remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda to disrupt the ongoing political process and ongoing reconstruction efforts,'' he said at a news briefing. Afghan security forces, nongovernmental organizations and troops will all be singled out, he said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills Marine

Taliban.lead_paragraph: A United States Black Hawk helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan, killing a marine and wounding 14 others, the military announced. The crash was not caused by hostile fire, but occurred in Khost Province where there has been fighting with Taliban and Al Qaeda forces on the border with Pakistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline.main: Karzai Arrives in Pakistan to Discuss Afghan Peace Talks
headline.print_headline: Karzai arrives in Pakistan to Discuss Afghan Peace Talks

Taliban.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai’s visit on Thursday came just after he announced that his government, with the United States, had begun face-to-face talks with the Taliban.

headline.main: Alliance Strikes Taliban Troops Outside Kabul

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance soldiers attacked a stranded and desperate Taliban force early this morning here, about 12 miles west of Kabul. The Taliban were surrounded, according to alliance commanders. A week of negotiations had foundered before troops began to move toward the forward posts of the trapped militia.

headline.seo: U.N. Mission Head in Afghanistan Met With Taliban Envoys
headline.main: U.N. Mission Head in Afghanistan Met With Taliban Envoys

headline.main: Taliban Say Their Insurgency Is Waiting Out the Bitter Winter

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The harsh Afghan winter has limited Taliban attacks against government and foreign troops, and the militants are regrouping to resume their raids after the weather warms, a Taliban spokesman said on Saturday. The spokesman, Abdul Latif Hakimi, also dismissed reports of Taliban defections to accept amnesty offered by the government of President Hamid Karzai.

headline.main: U.S.-Backed Leader Says He's Talking to Taliban

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, the man the United States has embraced as the best alternative to the Taliban in their stronghold, southern Afghanistan, said this evening that he was in touch with Taliban leaders and was working with them to find a peaceful solution for a new government. Mr. Karzai, a deputy foreign minister in the pre-Taliban era, appealed to the Taliban to take their cars and their weapons and go home quietly. In some towns, Taliban officials who had departed were replaced by administrators from previous governments, but overall, immediate acceptance of Mr. Karzai's gesture of reconciliation seemed unlikely. In an unusual midday broadcast in Kandahar, the political capital of the Taliban, the leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, announced that his forces were retreating to the mountains to fight again.

headline.seo: Taliban Suicide Bomb Attack Kills Key Police Official
headline.main: Taliban Bomber Infiltrates Afghan-NATO Meeting, Killing Police Official and Others
headline.print_headline: Taliban Bomber Infiltrates Afghan-NATO Meeting, Killing Police Official and Others

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The police official’s death raises concerns about stability in the region as NATO begins turning over security to Afghan forces in July.

headline.main: U.S. Denies Taliban Claim That Dead Man Was American

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The American Embassy in Islamabad said today that a man who the Taliban announced had died in a hospital in Afghanistan was not an American citizen, as the Taliban had asserted. The spokesman at the embassy, Mark Wentworth, said the embassy had ''made a determination that he is not an American citizen.'' Mr. Wentworth said he had no information on the nationality of the man whom the Taliban had described as John Bolton of California.

headline.seo: Karzai Says Afghanistan Has Joined Talks With Taliban
headline.main: Karzai Says Afghanistan Has Begun Taliban Talks
headline.print_headline: Karzai Says Afghanistan Has Begun Taliban Talks

Taliban.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai said talks between Afghanistan, the Taliban and the United States were underway, signaling the end of a longstanding objection to face-to-face discussions.

headline.print_headline: Pakistan: Government Suspends Talks With Taliban

Taliban.lead_paragraph: The government refused to meet with Taliban representatives after the reported killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers in militant captivity.

headline.main: U.N. Envoy Met Taliban To Discuss Peace Talks

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Members of the Taliban leadership met with a United Nations official this month to discuss the possibility of face-to-face peace talks with the Afghan government, American and United Nations officials said Friday. The official, Kai Eide, the United Nations' special representative in Afghanistan, met with a group of Taliban leaders in the days before this week's international conference in London, where President Hamid Karzai invited the Taliban to take part in peace talks.

headline.main: Spike in U.S. Casualties In Iraq Raises Worries

Iraq - Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD -- Two American soldiers were killed Sunday in Iraq, the military command said, making June the worst month in combat-related fatalities for United States forces in Iraq in more than two years. The casualties also reflected the dangers ahead as the United States prepares to withdraw all its troops from Iraq by the end of the year. The June total of so-called hostile-related deaths of American soldiers is now 11, the most since May 2009, when 12 were killed, according to icasualties.org, an online database that tracks the deaths of foreign forces in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.

headline.main: Obama: 300 Military Advisers Available for Iraq
headline.print_headline: Obama: 300 Military Advisers Available for Iraq

headline.main: Bush, Conceding Problems, Defends Iraq War

Yet Mr. Bush acknowledged that the conflict that began three years ago next week, when he ordered the start of an invasion to topple Saddam Hussein, had taken on a different complexion with the recent acceleration of sectarian violence. Twice he used the words ''civil war'' in his speech, but only to describe the objectives of Sunnis, Saddamists and members of Al Qaeda seeking to keep a new government from forming, rather than to characterize the current state of events.

The report, by the Institute for Defense Analyses, a federally financed research institution, found ''no smoking gun'' after a review of more than 600,000 Iraqi documents that have come into American hands since the March 2003 invasion. Senior administration officials cited the existence of ties between Mr. Hussein and the terrorist network run by Osama bin Laden as a rationale for the invasion of Iraq.
