headline.main: Russia Says Unrest Threatens Iraq's Territorial Integrity
headline.print_headline: Russia Says Unrest Threatens Iraq's Territorial Integrity

Iraq - Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: Russia is concerned about unrest in Iraq which threatens the country's territorial integrity, Russian news agencies quoted Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov as saying on Thursday.

headline.seo: The Sunni Awakening Braces for an Iraq Without U.S.
headline.main: U.S. Leaving Iraqi Comrades-in-Arms in Limbo
headline.print_headline: U.S. Leaving Iraqi Comrades-in-Arms in Limbo

Iraq - Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: As the Sunni Awakening, former insurgents helped swing the war. Now they face the rule of a Shiite-run government.

headline.main: Hussein Aide Denounces Powell's Case as Full of Baseless 'Stunts'

Iraq - Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: Iraq tonight denounced as ''manufactured'' and ''baseless'' the arguments made to the United Nations Security Council by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. ''This was a typical American show, complete with stunts and special effects,'' Gen. Amir al-Saadi, the top science adviser to President Saddam Hussein, told reporters. ''What we heard today was for the general public and mainly the uninformed in order to influence their opinion and to commit the aggression on Iraq.''

headline.main: Spain: 3 Suspected Qaeda Recruiters Arrested

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The police arrested three Moroccan men in Barcelona on suspicion that they had links to the North African terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, and belonged to a terrorist cell that recruits and equips militants. They were detained at the request of the Moroccan authorities.

headline.main: Homeland Security Chief Says ISIL Not Only Threat
headline.print_headline: Homeland Security Chief Says ISIL Not Only Threat

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The head of the Homeland Security Department says that while the surging Islamic State group is taking most U.S. attention now, officials must stay on top of other terrorist threats as well.

headline.main: FBI: No Credible Threats to US From Islamic State
headline.print_headline: FBI: No Credible Threats to US From Islamic State

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The FBI and Homeland Security Department say there are no specific or credible terror threats to the U.S. homeland from the Islamic State militant group.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Terror Suspect Killed In Riyadh Shootout

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: A former teacher of Islamic law who issued religious decrees for a terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda was killed in a shootout with the police in Riyadh that also killed a policeman, security officials said. The suspect was identified as Abdullah Muhammad Rashid al-Roshoud, a former high school teacher of Islamic studies known for writing statements on Islamic Internet sites and for issuing edicts justifying terrorist attacks against the Saudi government and foreigners in the kingdom.

headline.main: Gaza: Israeli Airstrike Kills Three Militants

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip late Wednesday and seriously wounded a fourth, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials. Israel said the militants had been preparing to launch a rocket to attack Israel. The raid came days after Palestinian militants fired about a dozen rockets into southern Israel from Gaza, the coastal enclave controlled by Hamas. Groups affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for those attacks and criticized Hamas this week for cracking down on them. The names of the three people killed Wednesday were released, but no militant group officially claimed them as members. That fueled speculation that the militants had been working with the Qaeda-linked groups. Those groups are made up mainly of former members of Islamic factions, including Hamas, Islamic Jihad and the Popular Resistance Committees. The Hamas fighters who join the groups are often dissatisfied with the cease-fire that Hamas observes with Israel.

headline.main: Egyptian Police Arrest Militants Accused of Recruiting for Islamic State
headline.print_headline: Egyptian Police Arrest Militants Accused of Recruiting for Islamic State

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Egyptian police have arrested four Islamic militants accused of recruiting youths to fight for Islamic State, the Mena state news agency said.

headline.main: Somali Backlash May Be Militants’ Worst Foe
headline.print_headline: Somali Backlash May Be Militants’ Worst Foe

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: As Somalia’s government gears up for an offensive, the population is turning against the Islamist militants.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Niger: Army Claims Deaths Of Algerian Militants

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The army in Niger has killed at least four members of an Islamic militant group linked to Al Qaeda, military officials said. The officials said the clash, in the Sahara earlier in April, involved members of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat. The United States says the group has begun using old trade routes in the Sahara to recruit and rearm after being mostly chased out of its home bases in Algeria.

headline.main: France Convicts 19 Islamic Militants

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: A Paris court convicted 19 Islamic militants today for their roles in a network that channeled arms and false identity papers to insurgents who have been fighting a nine-year-old war to topple the government in Algeria. Five other defendants were acquitted at the two-month trial of supposed supporters of the Armed Islamic Group, a leading force in the civil war in Algeria, a former French colony.

headline.main: Tajikistan: 34 Jailed on Terror Charges

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: A court in Tajikistan has convicted 34 people on charges of involvement in a terrorist group and sentenced them to prison terms of 8 to 28 years. The court said they belonged to the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, a group linked to Al Qaeda, and were trying to overthrow the government. Officials in Tajikistan insist that radical Islamism is a genuine threat to stability, but some analysts say the crackdown is an effort to eliminate dissent.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: 17 Islamic Rebels Reported Killed

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Security forces, on heightened alert before presidential elections next month, have killed 17 Islamic rebels in separate attacks over the past week, the Interior Ministry said. Seven militants belonged to the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, which is fighting for a Taliban-style state and has declared its allegiance to Al Qaeda. Algerians vote April 8, and the authorities have warned that Islamic rebels may try to disrupt the election.

headline.main: Iraqi Foreign Minister Calls for Global Support Against Islamic State
headline.print_headline: Iraqi Foreign Minister Calls for Global Support Against Islamic State

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Iraqi Foreign Minister Hoshiyar Zebari urged the world on Wednesday to back his country against Islamic State militants after the al Qaeda offshoot released a video purportedly showing the beheading of a U.S. journalist kidnapped in Syria.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Trial Of Militants Opens

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Uzbekistan put on trial a group they described as foreign-trained Islamic militants accused of trying to topple the ex-Soviet state's government with explosions, suicide bombings and shootouts in March and April that killed 47 people. The trial of a first group of 15, said to be followers of Al Qaeda, opened amid tight security and concerns by human rights groups that a new clampdown on dissent might follow. The accused, 13 men and 2 women, face up to 20 years in jail or the death penalty.

headline.seo: Unrest Continues to Shake Yemen, Especially in South
headline.main: In Yemen, One Islamist Is Dead, but the Battle Goes On
headline.print_headline: In Yemen, Unrest Is Persistent Despite Death of a Top Militant

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Despite the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, the infamous Yemeni-American cleric and propagandist for aspiring jihadists, Yemen’s battle against Al Qaeda is far from complete.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 4 Years For Qaeda Suspect

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Shahdi Abdellah, a Jordanian of Palestinian origin convicted of helping to plan attacks against Jewish targets in Germany, received a lenient four-year prison sentence after providing information into his radical Islamic group and its links to Al Qaeda. Mr. Abdellah, 27, who has said that he was once was a bodyguard for Osama bin Laden, told the authorities that Islamic extremists in a group called Al Tawhid were planning attacks on Jewish targets in Düsseldorf and on the Jewish Museum in Berlin.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: 16 Terror Arrests

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The authorities arrested 16 people suspected of being terrorists and seized a cache of bomb-making material, foiling a number of plots to attack ''vital installations,'' the Interior Ministry said. The arrest sweep appeared to be one of the largest since Saudi Arabia began a crackdown on Islamic militants after the deadly suicide bombings in the capital, Riyadh, on May 12.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Islamic Terrorists Held

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Five suspected Islamic terrorists have been detained in Russia in recent months, an Interior Ministry official said. The official, Yury Demidov, said one of the detained men is a member of Hizb ut-Tahrir and has lived illegally in Russia since 2000 and established secret cells, according to the Interfax news agency. Hizb ut-Tahrir aims to put Islamic leaders into power in Arab countries, but says it pursues peaceful methods. Three others are accused of being members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, a group that fought alongside Al Qaeda and the Taliban. The fifth is a Tajik accused of organizing bombings in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. Russia is considering extraditing the Uzbeks and Tajik to their home nations. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

headline.main: Al Qaeda Warns U.S. on Fighting In Muslim Lands

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Ayman al-Zawahri, Al Qaeda's second in command, has threatened the United States with more attacks if it does not end its military activity in Muslim countries. He spoke on a videotape broadcast Wednesday on Al Jazeera's news channel. ''If we are attacked in our countries, then we will not stop attacking you in your countries,'' he said.

headline.main: Egypt Army Kills Militant Commander in Sinai: Security Sources
headline.print_headline: Egypt Army Kills Militant Commander in Sinai: Security Sources

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Egypt's army killed a field commander in Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis, the country's most dangerous Islamist militant group, during clashes on Thursday in the lawless north of the Sinai Peninsula, security sources said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Arrests Linked To Qaeda Aid

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The police arrested 10 people on charges of providing financial and logistical aid to an Islamic radical group in Algeria suspected of having connections to Al Qaeda, the interior minister, José Antonio Alonso, said. He said the suspects were part of a cell in southern Spain that raised money by drug trafficking, document fraud and robbery to support the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, which he called a ''notorious member of Al Qaeda's international network.'' Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline.seo: Indonesia Sentences Radical Cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, to 15 Years
headline.main: Indonesia Sentences a Radical Cleric to 15 Years
headline.print_headline: Indonesia Sentences a Radical Cleric to 15 Years

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The United States had pressed Indonesia to prosecute Abu Bakar Bashir, who was convicted on Thursday of supporting a jihadi training camp.

headline.main: U.S. Blacklists Islamist Militants in Iraq, Syria
headline.print_headline: U.S. Blacklists Islamist Militants in Iraq, Syria

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The United States on Monday targeted two Islamist militants in Iraq and Syria, including the Islamic State spokesman, following similar actions by the U.N. Security Council last week.

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; KURDISH LEADER KILLED

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: Gunmen from the militant group Ansar al-Islam assassinated a Kurdish minister of Parliament and two security officials in northern Iraq. The gunmen posed as peace negotiators in sessions with the minister, finally luring him away from his security. He was killed while refining terms for a possible peace settlement between the secular government and a faction of the Islamic group, which the U.S. says is supported by both Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. C.J. Chivers

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Terror Cell Broken Up

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The government announced that it had disrupted a terror cell that was training women to be suicide bombers and committing robberies to underwrite its activities and was affiliated with Al Qaeda. The group, the Central Asia Mujahedeen Jamaat, was led by former members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which the United States has classified as a terror organization, the government said, and its members, many of whom have been arrested, possessed literature inciting religious war, as well as weapons, faked passports and bomb-making gear. A security official said that the group operated in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan and Russia and participated in attacks this year in Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, according to Interfax. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

headline.main: Spain Arrests Man Suspected as Militant Chief

Jihadist Groups.lead_paragraph: The Interior Ministry announced Thursday that the police had arrested the man suspected of leading an Islamic militant group accused of running a recruiting network for the insurgency in Iraq. The arrest on Wednesday of the suspect, Omar Nakhcha, after the arrests on Tuesday of 20 people suspected of being his subordinates, provides another illustration of how Islamic radicals have established elaborate networks in Spain. They are most likely lured by its growing population of Muslim immigrants and its proximity to North Africa.

headline.seo: John Brennan, C.I.A. Nominee, Clears Committee Vote
headline.main: Nominee to Lead C.I.A. Clears Hurdle After Release of Drone Data
headline.print_headline: Nominee to Lead C.I.A. Clears Hurdle After Release of Drone Data

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Senators of both parties have used John O. Brennan’s nomination to try to pressure the White House into disclosing information it has previously withheld.

headline.main: Intelligence Turf: A Guide

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The ''intelligence community,'' with its estimated 100,000 employees, has always been a confederacy of warring states, battling for money, power and influence. A presidential commission last year called it ''fragmented, loosely managed and poorly coordinated.'' The director of central intelligence had always been chairman of American intelligence and chief executive of the C.I.A.; he was responsible. Last year, his chairmanship was abolished and given to the new director of national intelligence, as the 9/11 commission recommended. So far, the change has not brought calm or order. TIM WEINER

headline.seo: Panetta Warns Pakistani Intelligence Officials on Collusion With Militants
headline.main: C.I.A. Director Warns Pakistan on Collusion With Militants
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Director Warns Pakistan on Collusion With Militants

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Leon E. Panetta, the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, traveled to Pakistan with what the C.I.A. believed to be proof that Pakistani officials had tipped off militants about a raid.

headline.main: Pakistani Role Is Suspected in Revealing U.S. Spy’s Name
headline.print_headline: Cover Blown, C.I.A. Chief Has to Quit Pakistan

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. station chief in Islamabad left after his identity was exposed. Some American officials suspect that Pakistan’s military intelligence agency deliberately blew his cover.

headline.main: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; THREATS IGNORED

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: A 1998 Central Intelligence Agency report, revealed by the joint Congressional panel investigating the intelligence failures of Sept. 11, was the first public evidence that there was specific intelligence about terrorist plans to crash airplanes into the World Trade Center. Officials said, though, that those plans did not appear to be connected to the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.main: Obama’s Pentagon and C.I.A. Picks Show Shift in How U.S. Fights
headline.sub: New Battle Missions Are Blurring the Roles of Spies and Soldiers;
headline.print_headline: Obama to Name Pentagon Chief And C.I.A. Head

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The latest evidence of a 10-year shift in American missions is seen with Leon E. Panetta, the intelligence chief, going to the Pentagon, and Gen. David H. Petraeus going to the C.I.A.

headline.main: Page Two: April 11-17; Intelligence Takes A Beating

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: THE question in Washington is not whether the intelligence community will be overhauled, but how, after fresh evidence last week that the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. had missed major warning signs about the Sept. 11 attacks. The commission investigating the attacks disclosed that intelligence officials were warned in the summer of 2001 that Osama bin Laden was ''planning high-profile attacks'' and that George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, had received a briefing that August titled ''Islamic Extremist Learns to Fly,'' about the arrest days earlier of Zacarias Moussaoui. Attorney General John Ashcroft was also portrayed as being inattentive to terrorism before the attacks -- a charge he heatedly denied.

headline.main: Obama Thanks the C.I.A. for Hunting Down Bin Laden
headline.print_headline: Obama Thanks the C.I.A. for Hunting Down Bin Laden

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: President Obama told a jubilant crowd at the Central Intelligence Agency that the tracking and killing of Osama bin Laden was a crucial milestone in the larger war to “defeat al Qaeda.”

headline.main: Officer Failed to Warn C.I.A. Before Attack
headline.print_headline: Officer Failed To Warn C.I.A. Before Attack

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Before a Jordanian doctor bombed an Afghanistan base last December, a C.I.A. officer was told he might work for Al Qaeda, an investigation revealed.

headline.main: Bin Laden Memorabilia a Big Presence in Panetta’s Office
headline.print_headline: Bin Laden Memorabilia a Big Presence in Panetta’s Office

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta’s office is filled with pictures and other mementoes of the operation that killed Osama bin Laden, a raid he oversaw as director of the C.I.A.

headline.main: Senator Says New Agency Needs Greater Access

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The ranking Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee has termed ''unacceptable'' President Bush's proposal that the new Homeland Security Department receive only completed intelligence reports from the C.I.A. and F.B.I. The senator. Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, joined the growing debate over how the department should interact with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency, and he sought ways to bolster the department for what he saw as a likely struggle with the nation's existing intelligence bureaucracy.

headline.seo: Petraeus Appointment Could Inflame Relations With Pakistan
headline.main: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus in Conflict With Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus In Conflict With Pakistan

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Pakistani and American officials said Gen. David H. Petraeus’s selection as C.I.A. director could further inflame relations between the two nations.

headline.main: Files Note Close C.I.A. Ties to Qaddafi Spy Unit
headline.print_headline: Files Note Close C.I.A. Ties to Qaddafi Spy Unit

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Documents at an abandoned office in Tripoli show that Libya’s cooperation with the C.I.A. and its British equivalent, MI-6, was much more extensive than generally known.

headline.main: PAKISTAN PUSHES FOR DRASTIC CUTS IN C.I.A. ACTIVITY

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Pakistan has demanded that the United States steeply reduce the number of Central Intelligence Agency operatives and Special Operations forces working in Pakistan, and that it halt C.I.A. drone strikes aimed at militants in northwest Pakistan. The request was a sign of the near collapse of cooperation between the two testy allies. Pakistani and American officials said in interviews that the demand that the United States scale back its presence was the immediate fallout from the arrest in Pakistan of Raymond A. Davis, a C.I.A. security officer who killed two men in January during what he said was an attempt to rob him.

headline.seo: C.I.A. Names Chief for Intelligence Network
headline.main: C.I.A. Names Spy Chief
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Names Spy Chief

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The agency brought John D. Bennett, one of its most experienced officers, out of retirement to run the National Clandestine Service.

headline.main: Intelligence Spending Rises, but Restraint Is in the Air

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The steep buildup in government spending on intelligence programs continued over the past year, according to figures made public on Tuesday, but American intelligence agencies are also bracing for a new era of austerity. Spending on intelligence operations increased by some 9 percent last year, to $47.5 billion, Mike McConnell, the director of national intelligence, said Tuesday. That figure includes most intelligence spending, including the budget for the National Security Agency, the Central Intelligence Agency and the operation of spy satellites, but it does not include several billions that the military services spend annually on intelligence operations.

headline.main: Page Two: July 4-10; The Buck Reaches The C.I.A. and Stops

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: FOR nearly a year, it has been apparent that the stocks of illicit weapons the Bush administration expected to unearth in Iraq were not there. Now the Senate Intelligence Committee has concluded that the intelligence agencies that said two years ago that the weapons existed did so on the flimsiest of evidence. The committee report served as a devastating indictment of the agencies and their departing leader, George J. Tenet. Never, the report said, did the Central Intelligence Agency question its conviction that Iraq possessed illicit weapons. Almost always, the report said, did it make too much out of too little -- transforming what should have been cast as many shades of gray into the black-and-white assertions used by the Bush administration as a rationale for going to war.

headline.main: Leak of C.I.A. Officer Name Is Sign of Rift With Pakistan
headline.print_headline: As Pakistan Digs In, C.I.A. Chief Is Exposed

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The publication of the name of the C.I.A. station chief in Islamabad seemed a deliberate effort after the Osama bin Laden raid.

headline.main: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- At some point in coming days, a shadowy group of Al Qaeda operatives in Pakistan who make up the network's ''General Command'' is likely to announce a replacement for Atiyah abd al-Rahman, the Libyan chief of operations who was killed last week in a drone strike launched by the Central Intelligence Agency. But as the 10th anniversary of the group's most successful strike approaches, the key question is: Does it matter?

headline.main: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent
headline.print_headline: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda is expected to announce a successor to its slain operations chief soon, just as its affiliates are growing more independent.

headline.main: C.I.A. Chief Defends Handling of Hijacker Data

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The director of central intelligence on Tuesday defended his agency's handling of information it received about one of the Sept. 11 hijackers some two and a half years before the attacks, saying, ''We didn't sit on our hands.'' German intelligence officials gave the C.I.A. the first name of the hijacker, Marwan al-Shehhi, and his phone number in early 1999 after monitoring conversations of a well-known Islamic extremist in Hamburg. The commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks said it was trying to determine what American intelligence officials did with that information.

headline.main: Spymaster Tells Secret of Size Of Spy Force

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: John D. Negroponte, the director of national intelligence, said Thursday that the United States' global spying apparatus now numbered nearly 100,000 people assigned to stealing secrets and analyzing information to help protect national security. The total number of personnel who report to the 16 disparate intelligence agencies and departments has until now remained secret, an effort by the government to mask the size of its spying operations. Mr. Negroponte disclosed the figure at a lunchtime speech here, calling those who serve in the intelligence field ''patriotic, talented and hard-working Americans.''

headline.main: Afghanistan War ‘Fragile’ but Doable, General Says
headline.print_headline: Afghanistan War 'Fragile' but Doable, General Says

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: David H. Petraeus said the focus should now be on rekindling a relationship with Pakistan.

headline.main: Both Parties Call on C.I.A. To Issue Report on Agency

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The Republican and Democratic leaders of the House Intelligence Committee have called on the Central Intelligence Agency to release an internal report examining the agency's performance in the run-up to the Sept. 11 attacks, Congressional officials said on Wednesday. The leaders, Representatives Peter Hoekstra, Republican of Michigan, and Jane Harman, Democrat of California, have not made the letter public, and their offices declined to comment on any request.

headline.main: A Little Light Is Shed on Intelligence Digests

CIA - Intelligence.lead_paragraph: In Washington-speak, it is the P.D.B. or President's Daily Brief. An intelligence digest prepared six mornings a week, by the Central Intelligence Agency, it is one of the most highly classified documents prepared by the government, its distribution limited under President Bush to fewer than a dozen senior administration officials. Compiled in a loose-leaf notebook, and consisting of about a dozen items a day, the P.D.B. in some ways serves as a kind of newspaper, with reports on current developments around the world and on broader trends. On Aug. 6, 2001, the digest presented to Mr. Bush in Crawford, Tex., included a memorandum titled ''Bin Laden Determined to Attack Inside the U.S.'' Until Thursday, when it was publicly disclosed by Condoleezza Rice in her testimony before the special commission looking in the Sept. 11 attacks, even that title was classified.

headline.main: The Trouble With Zero

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment the first atomic bomb was detonated in New Mexico in July 1945, the menacing aura of the nuclear age has inspired visions of a world free of nuclear weapons. Never more so than now, with the prospect that the Taliban could someday control Pakistan's nuclear weapons, North Korea might develop nuclear-tipped missiles, Iran may soon become a nuclear power and terrorists could get a bomb. A growing army of nuclear abolitionists, concerned that proliferation could catch fire at any moment, is advancing the cause, led by Barack Obama, the first president to make nuclear disarmament a centerpiece of American defense policy.

headline.main: Leaders Gather for Nuclear Talks as New Threat Is Seen
headline.sub: Growing Arsenals in Pakistan and India Show Limits of Negotiations ;
headline.print_headline: Agenda of Nuclear Talks Leaves Out a New Threat

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: A nuclear arms race may be escalating in South Asia, but the problem is not set to be discussed when President Obama’s nuclear security summit meeting opens Monday in Washington.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: India: A Rare Nod To Pakistan

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Defense Minister George Fernandes is not known for kind comments about Pakistan, India's nuclear-armed neighbor, but he said at a seminar on terrorism that he believed that Pakistan's nuclear arsenal was safe and that those in charge of its nuclear program were responsible. ''Politics apart, I must give them credit that they are responsible people and will not allow people to walk away with nuclear weapons,'' he said. Some American officials fear that Pakistan's nuclear materials could wind up in terrorists' hands. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline.seo: Japan Backs Off Goal to Phase Out Nuclear Power by 2040
headline.main: Japan, Under Pressure, Backs Off Goal to Phase Out Nuclear Power by 2040
headline.print_headline: Japan, Under Pressure, Backs Off Goal to Phase Out Nuclear Power by 2040

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Japan’s reversal on a plan to eliminate its use of nuclear power came after intense opposition from business groups and communities that host the country’s nuclear plants.

headline.seo: Safety Becomes Victim in Japan’s Nuclear Collusion

headline.print_headline: Culture of Complicity Tied To Stricken Nuclear Plant

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The ties binding power companies, utilities, regulators and politicians underlie the nation’s push to increase nuclear power at all costs.

headline.main: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy
headline.print_headline: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Aides to President Obama say he will permanently reduce America’s arsenal by thousands of weapons.

headline.main: U.N. Approves New Sanctions to Deter Iran
headline.print_headline: U.N. APPROVES NEW SANCTIONS TO DETER IRAN

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: A new measure takes aim at the military in another attempt to pressure Iran over its nuclear program.

headline.main: Threat of Nuclear Terror Has Increased, Official Says

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 attacks on the United States have increased the chances that terrorists might try to use nuclear weapons or materials, or attack nuclear power plants, the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency warned today. He spoke after Pakistan said it had detained three of the country's leading nuclear scientists for questioning in connection with concerns in the United States that nuclear weapons technology could have found its way into the hands of Osama bin Laden and the Taliban.

headline.main: Ban on Shipping Nuclear Waste Is Lifted

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The Energy Department said today that the moratorium on the shipment of low-level nuclear waste, put in place on the day of the terrorist attacks, was lifted earlier this week, sending truckloads of material to disposal and storage sites around the country. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham had suspended the transport in an effort to ensure that terrorists would not attack the nuclear material. Typically, shipments move along highways to storage plants in Utah, New Mexico, Nevada and elsewhere.

headline.main: Japan Public Still Divided As 2 Reactors To Be Opened

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: TOKYO -- Brushing aside widespread public opposition to avoid feared electric power shortages, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda ordered the reactivation of two nuclear reactors at a plant in western Japan on Saturday, making it the nation's first plant to go back online since the crisis last year in Fukushima. The decision to restart the Ohi nuclear plant ends the temporary freeze of Japan's nuclear power industry, when all 50 of the country's functional reactors were idled after the triple meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi plant. Despite the prime minister's vows to strengthen the Ohi plant against the same sort of huge earthquake and tsunami that knocked out the Fukushima plant in March 2011, the Japanese people have remained deeply divided on the safety of nuclear power.

headline.main: Report Says Plan to Safeguard Nuclear Material Is Lacking

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The United States lacks a comprehensive plan for protecting the world's supply of nuclear material from terrorists, according to a report issued today by Harvard University researchers. The report, titled ''Controlling Nuclear Warheads and Materials,'' is part of a three-year research project commissioned by the Nuclear Threat Initiative, a Washington foundation, to create a report card on nuclear security around the world.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Clinton Urges Air Patrols

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton urged the federal government yesterday to consider flying air patrols over New York State's nuclear power plants. In a letter to Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, Senator Clinton urged patrols over the Indian Point, Nine Mile and Gina nuclear power plants. The letter, also sent to the Department of Homeland Security, noted federal warnings this week that operatives of Al Qaeda might try to hijack cargo jets from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean and fly them into nuclear plants. The Sept. 11 hijackers, Senator Clinton wrote, ''were believed to have flown over or nearby the Indian Point reactors on their way down the Hudson River.'' Stacey Stowe (NYT)

headline.main: Europe Tightens Security at Nuclear and Other Sensitive Sites

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: France is positioning surface-to-air missiles at two sensitive military and nuclear-processing sites as a precaution against airborne suicide attacks, military officials said today. Antiaircraft missile-defense systems were being placed to protect Île Longue, a nuclear submarine base off Brittany, and La Hague, the site of Europe's largest plant to reprocess nuclear waste, a spokesman for the air force, Frédéric Solano, said today.

headline.main: Missing Radioactive Material May Pose 'Dirty Bomb' Threat: IAEA
headline.print_headline: Missing Radioactive Material May Pose 'Dirty Bomb' Threat: IAEA

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: About 140 cases of missing or unauthorized use of nuclear and radioactive material were reported to the U.N. atomic agency in 2013, highlighting the challenges facing world leaders at a nuclear security summit next week.

headline.seo: Spent Reactor Fuel Risk Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says
headline.main: Risk From Spent Nuclear Reactor Fuel Is Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Risk From Spent Nuclear Reactor Fuel Is Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Pools that hold spent nuclear fuel at American plants typically contain far more radioactive material than the spent fuel pool at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant, a new report says.

headline.main: Risk From Spent Nuclear Reactor Fuel Is Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The threat of a catastrophic release of radioactive materials from a spent fuel pool at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi plant is dwarfed by the risk posed by such pools in the United States, which are typically filled with far more radioactive material, according to a study released on Tuesday by a nonprofit institute. The report, from the Institute for Policy Studies, recommends that the United States transfer most of the nation's spent nuclear fuel from pools filled with cooling water to dry sealed steel casks to limit the risk of an accident resulting from an earthquake, terrorism or other event.

headline.main: U.S. Debates Deterrence For Terrorist Nuclear Threat

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Every week, a group of experts from agencies around the government -- including the C.I.A., the Pentagon, the F.B.I. and the Energy Department -- meet to assess Washington's progress toward solving a grim problem: if a terrorist set off a nuclear bomb in an American city, could the United States determine who detonated it and who provided the nuclear material? So far, the answer is maybe.

headline.main: The Week Ahead; BUSH AND MUSHARRAF

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, President Bush meets in Washington with President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, a critical ally in efforts to root out Qaeda remnants along the Afghan-Pakistani border. It is also a nuclear power whose confrontation over Kashmir with India, another nuclear power, makes the Indian subcontinent a terrifying flashpoint. The two presidents met last week in New York, where a senior administration official said they talked about the American-led war on terrorism, and specifically about cross-border terrorism in Kashmir. Marc D. Charney

headline.main: China Promotes Another Boom: Nuclear Power

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The view from this remote point by the sea, with lines of misty mountains stretching into the distance, is worthy of a classical Chinese painting. In the foreground, though, sits a less obvious attraction: one of China's first nuclear power reactors, and just behind it, another being rushed toward completion. There are countless ways to show how China is climbing the world's economic ladder, hurdling developed countries in its path, but few are more pronounced than the country's rush into nuclear energy -- a technology that for environmental, safety and economic reasons most of the world has put on hold.

headline.main: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Bite-Size Nukes

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: For 50 years the United States has maintained nuclear weapons with the express intention of not using them. Nukes keep the peace, the thinking goes; they are more about threatened payback than military utility. But there's a new school of thought among military thinkers: maybe we should all learn to stop worrying and love the Bomb -- at least in miniature. With America battling new enemies, some Pentagon hawks want to reimagine the nation's nuclear arsenal on a smaller and more usable scale, building more precise ''low yield'' nuclear weapons with payloads a fraction of the 15 kilotons of explosive force that erased Hiroshima. And these hawks have influence. At the Bush administration's urging, Congress not only voted this year to lift a 10-year U.S. ban on research and development of new forms of nuclear weapons; it also approved financing for the research.

headline.main: Fearing Theft, U.S. Plans To Relocate Nuclear Fuel

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The United States is moving rapidly toward shipping tons of bomb-grade plutonium and uranium out of a vulnerable laboratory in New Mexico, according to Energy Department officials and internal documents. Experts said it would be the first time the government has moved nuclear weapons fuel to reduce the risk of terrorists stealing it. The plutonium and uranium would be shipped to a complex at the Nevada Test Site, about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas, that was formerly used to assemble nuclear devices for detonation. It would be taken from a place called Technical Area 18, or T.A.-18, at Los Alamos Nuclear Laboratory.

headline.main: House Approves Nuclear Deal With India

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday night to approve a nuclear deal with India that would for the first time allow the United States to ship nuclear fuel and technology to a country that has refused to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The accord's passage, by a vote of 359 to 68, is a quick, major victory for the Bush administration, which argued that nurturing India as an ally outweighed concerns that the agreement would free more nuclear material for India to use for the manufacture of nuclear weapons.

headline.main: Attack in Pakistani Garrison City Raises Anxiety About Safety of Nuclear Labs and Staff
headline.print_headline: Attack in Pakistani Garrison City Raises Anxiety About Safety of Nuclear Labs and Staff

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: A suicide attack in Rawalpindi on Thursday was the first singling out workers of Pakistan’s prized nuclear labs, military analysts and newspapers said.

headline.main: Nuclear Weapons Comment Puts Obama on the Defensive

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama found himself on the defensive again yesterday about his views on foreign policy, this time over a comment he made about the use of nuclear weapons in Afghanistan or Pakistan. During an interview with The Associated Press, Mr. Obama, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, initially ruled out using nuclear weapons in the region as part of the effort to defeat terrorism and root out Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: Pakistan Releases 3 Scientists Questioned on Ties to Taliban

Nuclear Energy and Weapons.lead_paragraph: Pakistan said today that three nuclear scientists arrested 10 days ago for questioning about their relationship to the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan were released on Thursday night. Two scientists had been ''looking into land research'' on trips to Afghanistan in the last three years, and not passing along nuclear secrets or matériel to the Taliban or Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda, an aide to President Pervez Musharraf said at a briefing. The aide, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi, identified the two scientists as Sultan Bashiruddin Mahmood and Chaudry Abdul Masheed. General Qureshi said nothing more about the third scientist, Mirza Yusuf Baig.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Training Grant

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: New York City will expand its hazardous-materials training for firefighters with a $3.2 million federal grant, fire officials said yesterday. The Fire Department, which is facing budget cuts, lost nearly a quarter of the firefighters it had certified to handle hazardous materials on Sept. 11. The training will be done by the International Association of Firefighters, a labor organization that sought the funds on behalf of city firefighter unions. ''We are especially pleased it covers 100 percent of the costs to the department,'' said Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Sets New Rules On Recovery

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The Fire Department has banned fire companies from rushing to ground zero when a firefighter's remains are found. Firefighters had developed an informal policy of going to the site in keeping with the tradition in which firefighters carry their fallen brethren from the scene of a disaster. In explaining the new policy, reported yesterday in The Daily News, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said the department was seeking to maintain order. ''We are trying to keep an official notification process, where a body is removed respectfully by those who are at the site,'' he said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Firefighters Union Sues

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A city firefighters union has sued the Fire Department to stop it from reducing engine staffing in the face of budget shortfalls. The Uniformed Firefighters Association contends that the plan to reduce the size of crews on dozens of fire engines would endanger lives and violate a collective bargaining agreement. The department responded yesterday that the plan was legal and that firefighters would be able to work safely. ''This is a contractual provision that the union agreed to,'' said Francis X. Gribbon, a Fire Department spokesman. The department plans to reduce crew sizes to four from five on more than 50 engines under an agreement allowing it to do so if firefighters' sick leave climbs above a preset level. The firefighters' union claims that the sick leave rate has been artificially inflated by staff reductions and illnesses caused by the World Trade Center attack.

headline.main: Pressed Back Into Service

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: For decades, the remains of firefighters who died in the line of duty were carried to funerals on a fire engine that had been dedicated to that solemn purpose and no other. But the caisson, as the Fire Department calls the equipment, was not used at the burials last weekend of Chief Peter Ganci, First Deputy Commissioner William Feehan, or Chaplain Mychael Judge. Nor was it to be used at the four funerals for firefighters today.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: F.D.N.Y. Logo Unchanged

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Like many official logos of city departments, the emblem of the Fire Department of New York includes an image of the World Trade Center. Although many organizations like movie studios and television production companies have deleted the towers from films and other images as a too-raw reminder of the Sept. 11 attack, the Fire Department has decided to keep the towers. ''There are absolutely no plans to change the emblem of the Fire Department,'' Nicholas Scoppetta, the new fire commissioner, said yesterday. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: The Last Dispatch

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: For New York's firefighters the call to the World Trade Center came during the change of tours. Men on their way home turned around. Veterans and rookies alike headed out. And while much is unknown about the final minutes of the collapse, here is a hard truth: 343 men from New York City's fire department are missing or dead. Below, a map of firehouses and battalions -- and a look at loss. SARAH SLOBIN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Testing Begins On New Fire Radios

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, the Fire Department will be testing new hand-held radios designed to penetrate deep into high-rise buildings like the World Trade Center. The city had pulled the radios from service in March 2001 and resumed using older equipment after a firefighter's call for help during a Queens fire went unheard. But the performance of the older radios on Sept. 11 has been criticized by some fire officers who say communication problems contributed to the deaths of 343 firefighters. Tests began in the Bronx on Saturday, and firefighters in Staten Island will get the radios on Aug. 26 during an eight-week pilot program. If all goes well, the radios will be distributed citywide in the fall. Alan Feuer (NYT)

headline.main: Fire Chief's Remains Are Among 13 Found

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The remains of one of the highest ranking Fire Department officers killed on Sept. 11 were found yesterday at ground zero, along with those of 10 other firefighters and two civilians, fire officials said. The officer, Assistant Chief Donald J. Burns, 61, was a citywide tour commander who received five citations for valor during his 39-year career, fire officials said. He was a resident of Nissequogue in Suffolk County, where he volunteered with the local Fire Department. He is survived by his wife, a daughter and two sons, one of whom is a city firefighter.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threw out a lawsuit against New York City by eight firefighters who claimed that their constitutional rights were violated when they were arrested at a protest at ground zero on Nov. 2, 2001. The firefighters, including Michael Carter, a vice president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, joined a march that day to protest orders from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cut back on police officers and firefighters searching for victims' remains in the ruins of the World Trade Center. All charges against people arrested at the protest were dropped a month later. Judge Richard J. Holwell ruled that the firefighters' arrests were not malicious because it was clear they were not authorized to march to the trade center site. Julia Preston (NYT)

headline.main: Thousands Will Honor Fire Department's Dead

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of firefighters, some traveling from as far away as Ireland and Japan, are expected to fill Madison Square Garden and the surrounding blocks on Saturday as the Fire Department holds an official memorial service for members who died in the attack on the World Trade Center. City and fire union officials have made elaborate preparations for the event, which they view as a cathartic final farewell to the 343 firefighters whose deaths overwhelmed the Fire Department's previous calculus for loss. Before Sept. 11, the entire nation had seldom lost more than 100 firefighters in a year.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Remains Found

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The remains of 3 firefighters were uncovered at the World Trade Center site yesterday, a day after the remains of at least 11 were unearthed in the biggest find in weeks. Firefighter Louis Giaconelli, a department spokesman, said that none of those discovered yesterday had been identified. He said two of the firefighters uncovered on Tuesday were identified as Michael F. Lynch and John Tipping II, both 33. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: 4-Alarm Fire Destroys Queens Warehouse

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A furniture warehouse in Astoria, Queens, was destroyed yesterday in a four-alarm fire, one of the first major blazes that city firefighters have battled since the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, the Fire Department said. The fire at Gothic Cabinet Craft, at 2750 First Street, whose cause is under investigation, drew 168 firefighters from 33 units and took 15 hours to bring under control. Two firefighters were treated for minor injuries.

headline.main: Firefighters Retiring at Triple the Usual Rate

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: New York City firefighters are retiring at more than triple the usual rate this year, according to fire officials who say the surge in departures is another lingering impact from the collapse of the World Trade Center. Since January, 343 firefighters have filed their retirement papers, compared with 93 who had retired by this time last year. The Fire Department usually loses no more than 500 firefighters a year to retirement.

headline.main: At Least a Quarter of Ground Zero Firefighters Ill

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A quarter of the 6,500 firefighters who have worked at ground zero after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center have respiratory ailments, and 100 to 200 are exhibiting serious symptoms that may allow them to retire on a disability pension, Fire Department officials said yesterday. Representatives of the firefighters' union gave even higher estimates of the number who are ill. Thomas Manley, sergeant-at-arms and health and safety officer for the Uniformed Firefighters Association, which represents 9,100 firefighters, estimated that 4,000 firefighters are suffering from a persistent cough and that 400 to 500 may end up being forced to retire. Between 300 and 400 are on medical leave because they have a chronic cough, get winded very easily or are coughing up a lot of phlegm or a chalky substance, he said. None are hospitalized, though one or two were in September, he said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters Criticize Emergency Rules

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The union leaders representing city firefighters and fire officers sent a letter yesterday to Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge criticizing the city's new emergency protocol, saying it does not meet federal requirements, and asking for a meeting to discuss their concerns. The union leaders, Stephen J. Cassidy of the Uniformed Firefighters Association and Peter L. Gorman of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, called the protocol misguided because it makes the Police Department the primary agency at events involving dangerous materials, a departure from the rest of the nation, while giving the Fire Department the responsibility for saving lives and decontamination. ''It is impossible to be responsible for life safety and not be in command of the emergency from the outset,'' they wrote. Jarrod N. Bernstein, a spokesman for the city's Office of Emergency Management, which drew up the protocol, said it was in the best interest of the city and complied ''fully with the federal mandate.'' William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

headline.main: 9/11 Inspires Call to Review Response Plan For Crises

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: At the time the World Trade Center towers collapsed, the New York Fire Department had little idea how many firefighters were inside and could not communicate with a Police Department helicopter flying overhead, a fire official said yesterday. These and other shortcomings expose the need to re-examine emergency response policies, Deputy Chief Charles R. Blaich told emergency management professionals gathered yesterday at John Jay College of Criminal Justice for a forum on urban hazards.

headline.main: Union Asks Better Cleaning of Fire Trucks

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Officials of the union that represents New York City firefighters said yesterday that the Fire Department has done an inadequate job of cleaning trucks that might have been exposed to toxic substances when the World Trade Center collapsed. Five of the 200 fire trucks that were present when the buildings fell have tested positive for the presence of asbestos and either have, or will be, decontaminated, fire officials said.

headline.main: More Firefighters Added to Crew To Calm Dispute at Trade Center

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday doubled the number of firefighters -- to 50 -- assigned to dig for their colleagues' remains in the World Trade Center rubble, in an apparent effort to calm a rancorous dispute that has pitted firefighters against the police and the city. The city has said that the cut in manpower was based on safety considerations and a sense that the prospects of recovering remains at the site have begun to diminish, both positions many firefighters dispute. The firefighters have said that the city should not be reducing the size of rescue teams while the bodies of more than 200 firefighters and thousands of civilians remain unaccounted for.

headline.main: Fire Union Says Training Is Inadequate

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: New York City fire union officials charged yesterday that the Fire Department had failed to train and equip its ranks properly, and that the department was placing in peril firefighters who would be the first to respond to the next chemical, biological or radiological attack. In a 119-page report, the union listed complaints ranging from lack of terrorism training, to improper decontamination of fire equipment, to what it called the department's general lack of responsiveness after months of complaints.

headline.main: Postscript

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: An Our Towns column last Thursday described Michael Bellone, a former nightclub bouncer who worked as a volunteer with firefighters and the police at ground zero in Lower Manhattan for months after Sept. 11, 2001. He helped recover the remains of victims and, as part of an effort to keep alive the memory, now has a fire truck that bears the names of all 343 members of the Fire Department who died that day. The column omitted one pertinent element of Mr. Bellone's relationship with the Fire Department. As other news organizations reported at the time, he was briefly arrested in 2005 and accused of misrepresenting himself and using official equipment illegally as part of presentations on the disaster to school children and others. The Manhattan District Attorney's office decided on the day of his arrest not to prosecute him, and the equipment was returned to the Fire Department.

headline.main: Firefighters Block a Plan for Statue in Brooklyn

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Plans to honor firefighters with a bronze statue depicting a black, a white and a Hispanic firefighter raising an American flag at ground zero were abandoned yesterday in response to complaints by firefighters. The statue was to have been placed outside Fire Department Headquarters in Brooklyn and was based on a newspaper photograph that showed three white firefighters raising the flag in the World Trade Center debris.

headline.main: Tribute for Firefighters Will Have a Global Reach

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday that the city and the International Association of Firefighters would stage a memorial service on Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden for the 343 firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. At a news conference with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Von Essen said the city hoped to accommodate ''most of our firefighters'' and families of the firefighters who were lost.

headline.main: Facing Criticism, the City Again Adds Firefighters to the Search

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The number of city firefighters assigned to search for bodies at the World Trade Center site has been increased yet again, as the Giuliani administration moves to answer criticism that it was failing to prevent human remains from being disposed of, accidentally, along with debris. Already this week, 15 firefighters were added to each 12-hour shift, bringing the total assigned to look for human remains to 65, city records show. That is about the same number as last month, before the city cut back the staff, drawing angry protest from city firefighters.

headline.main: Citing Safety, City Will Cut Work Force For Recovery

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: City officials have ordered the Police and Fire Departments to reduce the number of officers and firefighters recovering remains at ground zero, a decision announced amid new concerns about polluted air at the site. The number will be dropped to 24 officers and 24 firefighters at any one time, spokesmen for the Uniformed Firefighters Association said.

headline.main: 2 More Firefighters Arrested In Dispute on Search for Bodies

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Two more officials of the firefighters' union were charged with criminal trespass yesterday in connection with a scuffle on Friday in which firefighters pushed through barricades and police lines during a protest march to ground zero and tangled with police officers. The arrests brought to 15 the number of firefighters and fire officers who have been charged criminally in connection with the march, which was held to demonstrate their anger over the reduction of the number of rescue workers at the site.

headline.seo: U.S. Raises Pressure on Pakistan in Raid’s Wake
headline.main: U.S. Raises Pressure on Pakistan in Raid’s Wake
headline.print_headline: U.S. Raises Pressure on Pakistan in Raid’s Wake

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The U.S. government wants to control the investigation to determine whether Pakistani government, intelligence or military officials were complicit in hiding Osama bin Laden.

headline.seo: Vaccination Ruse Used In Pursuit of Bin Laden
headline.main: Vaccination Ruse Used in Pursuit of Bin Laden
headline.print_headline: Vaccination Ruse Used In Pursuit of Bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency ran a phony program in Pakistan to obtain DNA from the Bin Laden family.

headline.main: How to Keep an Ex-Terrorist Talking

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The informer was growing terrified about the prospect of testifying against Al Qaeda. Osama bin Laden, he feared, would get to him or his family. Allah, he suspected, was already punishing him; his father was sick and his infant child had died. ''Anything I touch, I don't feel happy,'' he said. But the United States prosecutors and F.B.I. agents who had been hiding him in witness protection since his defection from Al Qaeda reassured him over and over: Think positive. He was probably the safest man in America. Allah would surely support his decision to turn on his fellow terrorists.

headline.main: Qaeda Official Speaks About Bin Laden's Death

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Ayman al-Zawahri, long the second in command of Al Qaeda, delivered his first public comments on the killing of his boss Osama bin Laden in an American raid last month, saying in a video eulogy posted by Al Qaeda's media arm on Wednesday that Bin Laden had ''terrified America in his life'' and ''will continue to terrify it after his death.'' The 28-minute video, titled ''The Noble Knight Dismounted,'' begins with old footage of Mr. Zawahri and Bin Laden seated together in a mountainous setting before cutting to Mr. Zawahri alone, dressed in white and seated with a rifle in front of a black background. He alternates between poetry and verse eulogizing Bin Laden, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which tracks jihadist communications and translated the video.

headline.seo: Videos From Bin Laden’s Hide-Out Are Released
headline.main: Videos From Bin Laden’s Hide-Out Released
headline.print_headline: Videos Reveal Bin Laden’s Concern for His Image

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Five videos show Osama bin Laden threatening the United States, condemning capitalism and watching news coverage of himself on television.

headline.main: Christmas Bombing Try Is Hailed by bin Laden
headline.sub: Qaeda Leader Does Not Take Credit for It;
headline.print_headline: Christmas Bombing Try Is Hailed by bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Osama bin Laden spoke publicly for the first time about the botched airliner bombing, praising the attempt — but not explicitly taking credit for it — in an audiotape aimed at President Obama.

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Tighter Security For Nobel Peace Ceremony

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Security around the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo next month will be heightened as a result of the attacks on the United States and statements by Osama bin Laden, the police say. The winner of the prize is Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, and in a recent videotape Mr. bin Laden called Mr. Annan a ''criminal.''

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; NEW BIN LADEN TAPE

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Threatening attacks against the United States and urging Muslims to defend Iraq against an American-led invasion, the latest tape attributed to Osama bin Laden and broadcast by Al Jazeera television jangled the frayed nerves of Americans already fearful that a terror attack might be imminent. Senior Bush administration officials like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the tape buttressed the case for military action against Saddam Hussein, saying it showed Mr. bin Laden was ''in partnership with Iraq.'' David Johnston

headline.main: Bin Laden Criticizes Councils

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: In an audiotape released Saturday, Osama bin Laden urged Iraq's Sunni Arabs not to join the Awakening Councils. ''Our duty is to foil these dangerous schemes, which try to prevent the establishment of an Islamic state in Iraq, which would be a wall of resistance against American schemes to divide Iraq,'' Mr. bin Laden said in the 56-minute tape, which was posted on a militant Web site used by Al Qaeda's media arm, The Associated Press said.

headline.main: Bin Laden's Sons Assail U.S. for Its Deadly Raid

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The adult sons of Osama bin Laden have lashed out at President Obama in their first public reaction to their father's death, accusing the United States of violating its basic legal principles by killing an unarmed man, shooting his family members and disposing of his body in the sea. The statement, provided to The New York Times on Tuesday, said the family was asking why Bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, ''was not arrested and tried in a court of law so that truth is revealed to the people of the world.''

headline.main: November 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; BIN LADEN ON TAPE

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: After months of debate among counterterrorism experts about whether he had died in the war in Afghanistan, Osama bin Laden has sudden resurfaced. American intelligence officials concluded last week that a recently recorded audiotape that was broadcast on an Arab television network is genuine and contains the voice of the terrorist leader. On the tape, the voice said to be that of Osama bin Laden refers to several recent terrorist attacks, offering proof that he is alive, or at least was alive in recent weeks. James Risen

headline.main: Presidential Spotlight Shines on the Commandos Who Work in the Shadows

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. -- They are the shadowy warriors of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden: two dozen members of the Navy Seals who stormed the fortified compound in Pakistan where Bin Laden was hiding. Their identities will probably never be known; their faces will most likely never appear in photographs at the White House, on magazine covers or on television talk shows. But on Friday, President Obama flew to this Army air base to thank them, behind closed doors, for what he called a ''job well done,'' describing it as one of the greatest military and intelligence operations in American history.

headline.main: U.S. Seeks Source for Some bin Laden DNA

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The United States is trying indirectly to obtain samples of DNA from relatives of Osama bin Laden for possible future use in identifying his remains, American officials said today. Government officials say that they have not yet been able to obtain the samples and that there are no plans to ask the bin Laden family for the DNA directly.

headline.main: Bin Laden as Patriarch

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- When a man stalks the world as a mass killer, it distracts from the ordinary interest we might otherwise take in the mundane details of his life. And so it was with Osama bin Laden. But after he was cornered and killed on May 2 in an upstairs bedroom of his house in Pakistan, Bin Laden the terrorist and Bin Laden the family man came together. At home with him were three of his wives, the youngest of whom was shot in the leg; a son, who was killed; a daughter, who witnessed her father's death; and other children, some of whom may be Bin Laden's.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Heroin Named After Bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: First, the police in Brooklyn discovered that drug dealers were peddling a brand of heroin called Twin Towers, which officials said appeared soon after Sept. 11. Now authorities in Queens say they have found a brand of the drug called bin Laden, as in Osama. Yesterday, four women were arrested and charged with drug possession after police in Hollis discovered they were carrying cocaine, marijuana and the bin Laden heroin. It was in glassine envelopes with bin Laden in red letters on the front and the image of an airplane heading toward the World Trade Center on the back. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Politics: New Hampshire: Punishing Bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Howard Dean, responding in an interview published in The Concord Monitor about whether Osama bin Laden should be put to death, said, ''I still have this old-fashioned notion that even with people like Osama, who is very likely to be found guilty, we should do our best not to, in positions of executive power, not to prejudge jury trials.'' Dr. Dean, a Democratic presidential contender, later released a statement saying that the bin Laden case was ''exactly the kind of case that the death penalty is meant for.''

headline.main: Spain Expels Son of bin Laden Who Sought Asylum

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: A son of Osama bin Laden who was seeking asylum in Spain has been deported after his final appeal failed, the Spanish authorities and one of his lawyers said Saturday. Omar Osama bin Laden, 27, one of 19 children of Osama bin Laden, the founder of Al Qaeda, applied for asylum last week after arriving at Barajas International Airport in Madrid on a flight from Cairo. Mr. bin Laden argued that his life was in danger, his lawyer in Spain, Bianca Sharma, said Saturday.

headline.main: Denying Links to Militants, Pakistan's Spy Chief Denounces U.S. Before Parliament

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- In an unusual, and apparently heated, closed-door session of Parliament, Pakistan's spy chief issued a rousing denunciation of the United States on Friday for its raid that killed Osama bin Laden and denied that Pakistan maintained any links with militant groups, according to lawmakers. Rather, the spy chief, Lt. Gen. Ahmed Shuja Pasha, blamed an intelligence failure for the presence of Bin Laden in the city of Abbottabad, where a top military academy is located and where the leader of Al Qaeda was killed in an American raid on May 2.

headline.seo: Al Qaeda Leadership Void Seen
headline.main: Signs of Leadership Void as Al Qaeda Pushes On
headline.print_headline: Signs of Leadership Void As Al Qaeda Pushes On

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of Osama bin Laden’s death, flawed or little-known candidates are on the list of possible replacements.

headline.main: March 2-8: INTERNATIONAL; THE BIN LADEN HUNT HEATS UP

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: American and Pakistani intelligence units have begun an operation in the northernmost district of the Pakistan, along the border with Afghanistan, in hopes of capturing Osama bin Laden. Further south, the police in Baluchistan have also been told to prepare for a possible operation. The activity follows the arrest of one of Mr. Bin Laden's top deputies, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, on March. 1.

headline.seo: In Bin Laden’s Compound, Seals’ All-Star Team
headline.main: In Bin Laden’s Compound, Seals’ All-Star Team
headline.print_headline: In Bin Laden’s Compound, Seals’ All-Star Team

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Members of Team 6, a secretive unit of men who endured years of brutal preparation, are the elite of the elite.

headline.main: Pornography Is Found in Bin Laden Compound Files, U.S. Officials Say

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The enormous cache of computer files taken from Osama bin Laden's compound contained a considerable quantity of pornographic videos, American officials said on Friday, adding a discordant note to the public image of the Islamist militant who long denounced the West for its lax sexual mores. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity about classified material, would not say whether there was evidence that Bin Laden or the other men living in the house had acquired or viewed the material.

headline.seo: Pornography Is Found on Bin Laden’s Computers
headline.main: Pornography Is Found in Bin Laden Compound Files, U.S. Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Pornography Is Found in Bin Laden Compound Files, U.S. Officials Say

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Officials would not say whether there was evidence that Bin Laden or the other men living in the Abbottabad compound had acquired or viewed the material.

headline.main: Pentagon Breaks Silence on Pakistani Role
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Breaks Silence on Pakistani Role

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: A top Pentagon official said Thursday that Obama administration officials “do not have any definitive evidence at this point” that Pakistan knew where Osama bin Laden was living.

headline.main: Pentagon Breaks Silence on Pakistani Role

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A top Pentagon official said Thursday that Obama administration officials ''do not have any definitive evidence at this point'' that Pakistan knew that Osama bin Laden was living in a compound in a garrison city only 35 miles from Islamabad, but she said that Pakistan would have to work hard to rebuild relations with the United States Congress. In the public comments by a Pentagon official on the raid and its aftermath, Michele A. Flournoy, the undersecretary of defense for policy, said that she had ''a very candid conversation'' with top Pakistani military officials at the Pentagon on Monday during a previously scheduled meeting. She said she had urged them to take clear steps to show Congress that they were committed to fighting terrorism and working with the United States.

headline.main: CANTOR FITZGERALD TO DONATE $4 MILLION TO RELIEF FUND

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald , the bond and equity broker that lost 658 employees last year in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, expects to give yesterday's trading profits of $4 million to its family-relief fund. The firm will make the ''charity day'' an annual event, it said. ''We are particularly grateful to our customers from throughout the world who today went above and beyond to help us fulfill our mission to support the families of our lost colleagues,'' said Howard W. Lutnick, chairman and chief executive of Cantor and eSpeed, its electronic brokerage unit.

headline.main: CANTOR FITZGERALD ADDS 15 TO BOND TRADING STAFF

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the stock and bond trading firm that lost 60 percent of its employees in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, hired 15 people from the Advest Group to expand its trading and sales of corporate bonds and mortgage securities. Cantor also hired Jeffrey Kidwell, 43, from Morgan Stanley as managing director to lead its funding and repurchase agreement business, Tom Ryan, a spokesman for Cantor Fitzgerald, said. The company is building its bond trading business to complement the more than 125-employee equity unit in place since the 1960's, Mr. Ryan said.

headline.main: Cantor Chief Expands Role

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Howard W. Lutnick, would be taking over the firm's fixed-income trading and sales business, succeeding Irvin Goldman, who left the closely held firm Monday after four years. A Cantor spokesman declined to comment further on Mr. Goldman.

headline.main: Cantor Details Aid to Survivors

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the trading firm that lost 700 employees in the World Trade Center attack, said the victims' families would receive health insurance for 10 years and a share of the partnership's profits for five years. The company said 25 percent of the money that would have been distributed to partners would be given to families of employees killed in the attacks over five years, or until they receive $100,000 each. Each will get a life insurance payment of double the victim's salary up to a maximum $100,000.

headline.main: Dow Jones Fights Cantor in Court

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had sued the Cantor Fitzgerald Securities Corporation, the bond brokerage firm, to end liability for annual payments of $48 million to Cantor for its bond market data. Cantor, which occupied floors near the top of the World Trade Center and lost 657 employees in the Sept. 11 attacks on New York, was under contract to provide market data through the Telerate system, which Dow Jones owned until 1998. Telerate is now defunct.

headline.main: Brokerage Firm Sells Loan Unit

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Metropolitan West Securities L.L.C. said today that it would buy the securities lending operations of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. The firm will share profits from the acquired operations with Cantor Fitzgerald for two years. The price of the deal, which is expected to close this week, was not disclosed.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cantor Adds To Network For Its Data On Prices

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the dominant broker in the United States Treasury market, began yesterday to distribute its price data through several sources, including Bloomberg terminals. For the last 20 years, the data had been disseminated exclusively through Telerate, which is being sold as part of a bankruptcy reorganization. A Cantor Fitzgerald executive said that the Treasury price data could eventually be distributed through Reuters as well.

headline.main: Chief's Book to Tell Story Of Cantor's Efforts to Heal
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BOND FIRM

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Howard W. Lutnick, chairman of the bond-trading firm Cantor Fitzgerald, is writing a book about his company's struggle through the deaths of more than 600 of its 1,000 employees in the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. The HarperCollins division of the News Corporation has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum for the right to publish the book.

headline.main: Firm That Was Hit Hard on 9/11 Grows Anew

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Howard W. Lutnick, the chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald, has defied the skeptics. Three years after 658 of his co-workers died in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, Cantor is alive. As if that were not enough for the company that lost by far the most employees that day, it is on track to achieve double-digit earnings growth again this year.

headline.main: From Devastation to Determination
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE BOND TRADER

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: ''New employees come up to me and say, 'You know, people here have issues,' '' says Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, reflecting on life today inside Cantor, the bond trading firm that lost more people in the Sept. 11 attacks than any other American company. ''And I say, 'I know. Me, too.' '' An instant later, his rueful smile is gone: ''We've been through the worst of circumstances, the worst of circumstances,'' he said in an interview last week. ''But we're still here.''

headline.main: The Survivor Who Saw the Future

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: TEN years and a lifetime ago, Howard W. Lutnick was a prince of Wall Street. Forty years old, and already the head of a powerful financial house, he could peer down on rivals from his office on the 105th floor of One World Trade Center. Then - you know the rest.

headline.main: Tower's Leaseholder Is Suing Cantor Fitzgerald for Rent

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: The company that held the lease on 1 World Trade Center before terrorists destroyed the building on Sept. 11, 2001, is suing a former tenant, Cantor Fitzgerald Securities, for more than $1 million in back rent. The leaseholder, 1 World Trade Center L.L.C., a company controlled by the real estate developer Larry A.
