Silverstein, says in court papers that Cantor Fitzgerald, which occupied floors near the top of 1 World Trade Center, owes $1,027,685.96 in rent from Aug. 1 through Sept. 10, 2001.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Financing For Ground Zero Center

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: New York State will contribute $80 million to build a visitors' center at ground zero, designed by the firm Snohetta, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. Also yesterday, the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation added new board members: Howard W. Lutnick, chairman and chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald; Julie Menin, chairwoman of Community Board 1; and Savita Bhan Wakhlu, managing director of Jagriti Communications. Michael D. Eisner, former chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, resigned from the board, citing unexpected commitments. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: British Judge Splits Ruling On Suit by Cantor Fitzgerald

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: A British High Court judge handed down a split ruling today in a bitter dispute of the rival bond brokerage firms Cantor Fitzgerald and Icap, backing Cantor's accusations that Icap unlawfully poached one broker after the firm lost 658 employees in the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. But the judge, Richard McCombe, dismissed complaints by Cantor that Icap, which is based in London, illicitly lured two other brokers from Cantor's London offices. Mr. McCombe also cast doubt on suggestions that Icap's activities represented part of a deliberate attempt to weaken its rival after Sept. 11, as Cantor had initially argued. All three of the traders hired away from Cantor by Icap were London interest rates swaps traders.

headline.main: Flinty Bond Trader Leads His Firm Out of the Rubble
headline.kicker: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE TRADING FIRM

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Brass-knuckled deals and stiletto insults are prized in normal times on Wall Street. And by all accounts, Howard W. Lutnick of Cantor Fitzgerald fit that world perfectly, edging out his rivals at other bond trading firms and grabbing profits with the best of them. But since Tuesday morning, Mr. Lutnick's open affection and tears have softened his flinty edge, made him a television icon and shown how a leader can find a new voice to get his firm and the nation's markets up and running again.

headline.main: Horrible Year Ends on Up Note At Cantor; Financial Health for the Firm And More Smiles for the Staff

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: As Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, headed to Florida last weekend to see out the worst year of his life, he found himself, beyond all expectations, with good news to share. ''I have told my families'' -- as Mr. Lutnick affectionately calls the survivors of the colleagues he lost on Sept. 11 -- ''that Cantor will be profitable in the fourth quarter,'' he said. With a faint trace of his old swagger, he added: ''We will be highly profitable -- not barely profitable, but highly profitable.''

headline.main: Cantor Sues Rival Firm In London

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Not long after Sept. 11, Michael Spencer, chief executive of the brokerage firm Icap, paid a sympathy visit to Lee Amaitis, chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald's London operations. He offered three things: His condolences for the devastation Cantor suffered in the attack on the World Trade Center; a $500,000 gift to the fund for Cantor families; and a promise not to poach members of Cantor's staff, provided Cantor made the same promise in return. Cantor declined the deal.

headline.main: Some Families Doubt Sincerity of Cantor
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TRADING FIRM

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the finality of it. On Sept. 15, the bond trading firm of Cantor Fitzgerald dropped its missing employees from the payroll. Whether that was prudent or crass depends in large part on one's view of Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of the firm, which lost almost 70 percent of its New York staff in the attacks on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Cantor Seeks To Relocate To Union Sq.

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond broker that lost 658 employees in the attack on the World Trade Center, is negotiating to build a $100 million headquarters in a former department store in Union Square, an area that has not traditionally drawn financial services firms. Howard Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, has long vowed to rebuild his company and has pressed his case everywhere from City Hall to Albany and Washington. According to city and state officials and real estate executives, he has focused on Union Square, an area 2.5 miles north of Wall Street and one that is more known for its high-end restaurants and residential buildings.

headline.main: $4.9 Million Of Cantor Net To Be Shared By Survivors

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 people in the Sept. 11 attacks , reported unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday for eSpeed, its publicly traded electronic trading unit, and announced that it would share $4.9 million of its own fourth-quarter profits with the families of the employees killed in the attacks. The payment is the first installment in Cantor's previously announced plan to give the families 25 percent of its profits over the next five years, or $100,000 for each family, whichever is greater.

headline.main: Firm That Lost 658 in the Towers Finds a New Home on 59th St.

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after 658 Cantor Fitgerald employees were killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, the stock and bond trading company has found a new home five miles from ground zero, on the East Side of Manhattan. Cantor signed a lease last week to move into space now occupied by Bloomberg L.P., the business information company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, at Park Avenue and 59th Street, where Cantor plans to erect a monument to the co-workers who died in the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.main: Judge Approves American Air-Cantor Fitzgerald Sept 11 Settlement
headline.print_headline: Judge Approves American Air-Cantor Fitzgerald Sept 11 Settlement

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday approved a $135 million settlement between American Airlines Group Inc and Cantor Fitzgerald over business and property losses suffered by the financial services company in the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, in which 658 of Cantor's employees were killed.

headline.main: For the Families, a Chance to Share Tears and Love

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Since Sept. 11, the name of the bond trading firm Cantor Fitzgerald has become synonymous with loss. By now, the numbers are only too familiar: more than 600 of 1,000 employees gone, leaving behind 1,500 children. And so yesterday, at a memorial service held in a sunless Central Park, statistics went unmentioned while individuals were remembered. A letter of sympathy from President Bush, as well as irises and lilies by the bucket, greeted some 2,500 people who made their way through the park in black-clad clusters, showing identification before they entered a colony of white tents near the bandshell.

headline.main: Cantor Survivors on a Mission; Rebuilding the Firm, and Remembering Those Lost

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Almost every day, Chris Crosby turns in his chair at Cantor Fitzgerald's technical center in Rochelle Park, N.J., to ask his buddy for help -- for one sweet instant forgetting his friend is dead. Philip Marber, a Cantor division president in Manhattan, still wakes up at 3 most mornings, worrying about how to turn his new stock trading desk into the ''well-oiled machine'' he once ran.

headline.main: Gwen Leifer, Justin Levinson

Cantor Fitzgerald.lead_paragraph: Wendy Leifer, the daughter of Vicki and Lane Leifer of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., is to be married today to Justin A. Levinson, a son of Rhoda and Steven Levinson of New York. Rabbi Abner L. Bergman will officiate at Temple Judea of Manhasset, N.Y. Cantor Richard Berman is to take part in the ceremony. The bride, 35, is known as Gwen. She is an assistant chief counsel in the New York office of the Department of Homeland Security. She graduated from Brandeis and received a law degree from New York University.

headline.seo: Pakistani and NATO Forces Clash Near Afghan Border
headline.main: Pakistan and NATO Trade Fire Near Afghan Border
headline.print_headline: Pakistanis Exchange Fire With NATO Helicopters

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: A clash between Pakistani ground troops and NATO helicopters added another irritant to the already sour relationship between the United States and Pakistan.

headline.main: Musharraf, Vowing Return, Announces New Party
headline.print_headline: Musharraf, Vowing Return, Announces New Political Party

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: The former leader also defended military rule as a hedge against corruption and violence.

headline.seo: Decision to Investigate Anti-Army Memo Is Delayed in Pakistan
headline.main: Decision to Investigate Anti-Army Memo Is Delayed in Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Pakistan’s Top Court Delays Decision on Memo That Sought to Constrain the Army

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court called on the government to provide more details in the case in which a Pakistani diplomat purportedly sought American help to constrain the military.

headline.seo: Petraeus Appointment Could Inflame Relations With Pakistan
headline.main: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus in Conflict With Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus In Conflict With Pakistan

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Pakistani and American officials said Gen. David H. Petraeus’s selection as C.I.A. director could further inflame relations between the two nations.

headline.main: PAKISTAN PUSHES FOR DRASTIC CUTS IN C.I.A. ACTIVITY

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Pakistan has demanded that the United States steeply reduce the number of Central Intelligence Agency operatives and Special Operations forces working in Pakistan, and that it halt C.I.A. drone strikes aimed at militants in northwest Pakistan. The request was a sign of the near collapse of cooperation between the two testy allies. Pakistani and American officials said in interviews that the demand that the United States scale back its presence was the immediate fallout from the arrest in Pakistan of Raymond A. Davis, a C.I.A. security officer who killed two men in January during what he said was an attempt to rob him.

headline.seo: Pakistan Military Tries to Quash Rumors of a Coup
headline.main: Rumors Buzz, but Pakistan’s Military Denies Talk of Coup
headline.print_headline: As Rumors Buzz, Pakistan’s Military Denies Talk of a Coup

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Pakistan lurched between crises, with its military chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, dismissing talk of an attempt to seize power and canceling a visit from a top American general.

headline.main: Pakistani Details Narrow U.S. Role

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: President Pervez Musharraf said today that Americans were helping to provide communications support for Pakistani forces tracking down Al Qaeda and Taliban militants in Pakistan. ''There are some officials inside Pakistan for communication purposes but they are not fighting,'' General Musharraf told reporters. ''Americans not even in double figures are with us. They are communication experts.''

headline.main: Denying Links to Militants, Pakistan's Spy Chief Denounces U.S. Before Parliament

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- In an unusual, and apparently heated, closed-door session of Parliament, Pakistan's spy chief issued a rousing denunciation of the United States on Friday for its raid that killed Osama bin Laden and denied that Pakistan maintained any links with militant groups, according to lawmakers. Rather, the spy chief, Lt. Gen. Ahmed Shuja Pasha, blamed an intelligence failure for the presence of Bin Laden in the city of Abbottabad, where a top military academy is located and where the leader of Al Qaeda was killed in an American raid on May 2.

headline.main: Pakistani Role Is Suspected in Revealing U.S. Spy’s Name
headline.print_headline: Cover Blown, C.I.A. Chief Has to Quit Pakistan

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. station chief in Islamabad left after his identity was exposed. Some American officials suspect that Pakistan’s military intelligence agency deliberately blew his cover.

headline.seo: Tensions High After NATO Air Strikes Kill Pakistani Soldiers
headline.main: Tensions Flare Between U.S. and Pakistan After Strike
headline.print_headline: NATO Strikes Kill Pakistani Forces, Raising Tensions

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Saying at least 25 of its soldiers were killed by NATO aircraft, Pakistan closed the alliance’s two main supply routes into Afghanistan and ordered the C.I.A. to vacate drone operations at an air base.

headline.seo: General Kayani Is Said to Cling to Job in Pakistan
headline.main: Pakistan’s Chief of Army Fights to Keep His Job
headline.sub: Seething Anger Is Seen Among Officers Over Ties With U.S.;
headline.print_headline: PAKISTAN’S CHIEF OF ARMY FIGHTS TO KEEP HIS JOB

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is facing seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline.seo: Lull in U.S. Drone Strikes Aids Pakistan Militants
headline.main: Lull in Strikes by U.S. Drones Aids Militants in Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Lull In Strikes By U.S. Drones Aids Militants

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: A plunge in relations between the United States and Pakistan has led to a pause in American drone strikes and given Al Qaeda and Pakistani factions a chance to regroup.

headline.main: Page Two: June 15-21 -- The Week Ahead; TALK WITH MUSHARRAF

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: President Bush has invited the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to Camp David on Tuesday at a moment when many in the administration worry that the country is a half-ally -- helpful in the war against Al Qaeda but perhaps a nuclear-proliferation risk. In public, Mr. Bush is sure to commend Mr. Musharraf for helping hunt down Osama bin Laden's lieutenants. In private, he will urge him to do far more, and to make sure that North Korea gets no more help from Pakistani nuclear scientists or laboratories (something Mr. Musharraf says has never happened). This is a rare moment: India and Pakistan appear to be talking to each other, but their nuclear rivalry is certain to be discussed Tuesday. David E. Sanger

headline.seo: Pakistan High Court Widens Role and Stirs Fears
headline.main: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears for Stability
headline.print_headline: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s Supreme Court has inserted itself as the third player in a bruising confrontation between military and civilian leaders at a time when Pakistan faces a dizzying array of threats.

headline.main: Former Pakistani Navy Commando Arrested in Sweep for Attack Suspects
headline.print_headline: Pakistan: Arrest in Karachi Attack

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: The sweep by Pakistani intelligence agents was conducted in connection with the audacious attack last week on the naval base in the southern port city of Karachi.

headline.seo: Pakistani Leader Faces Pressure Over Memo
headline.main: Pakistani Leader Faces Pressure Over Memo
headline.print_headline: Pakistan’s Opposition Demands Action on Memo

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: President Asif Ali Zardari met briefly with his ambassador to the United States, who has been blamed for a memo asking Washington to help rein in the military.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; CROSSING THE BORDER

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Pakistan said yesterday that the United States had not consulted it about the possibility of American-led forces crossing into Pakistan to hunt down Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters. Maj. Gen. Frank Hagenbeck told reporters in Afghanistan last week that United States forces might cross into Pakistan to snuff out the extremists' havens. But a Pakistani military spokesman, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi, insisted there had been no such request from the United States-led forces. General Qureshi said Pakistan's policy was clear: ''All actions that are to be taken inside Pakistan are taken by Pakistani forces and Pakistani personnel.''

headline.main: American Terror Suspect Traveled Unimpeded
headline.print_headline: American Terror Suspect Traveled Unimpeded

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: David C. Headley scouted targets in India and met with a senior Al Qaeda operative in Pakistan.

headline.seo: President Back in Pakistan as Tensions With Army Rise
headline.main: Pakistani Crisis Prompts Leader to Race Home
headline.print_headline: Pakistani Strains Prompt Leader to Race Home

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: A tense showdown between Pakistan’s powerful army and its besieged civilian government brought President Asif Ali Zardari hurrying back from Dubai early on Monday.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Reputed Qaeda No.3 Handed Over To U.S.

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: A Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed that Pakistan had handed over Abu Faraj al-Libbi, the Libyan described as the third most senior leader of Al Qaeda, to the United States. Earlier, President Pervez Musharraf had told Al Ittihad, a newspaper in the United Arab Emirates, that Mr. Libbi had been deported. ''We don't want people like him in our country,'' the newspaper quoted General Musharraf as saying. The whereabouts of Mr. Libbi -- arrested in northwestern Pakistan last month and wanted in two failed assassination attempts on Mr. Musharraf in 2003 -- was not disclosed. President Bush had called his arrest a ''critical victory in the war on terror,'' but it is unclear what charges, if any, he might face in the United States. Salman Masood (NYT)

headline.seo: India’s Industry Helps Open Door to World
headline.main: Industry in India Helps Open a Door to the World
headline.print_headline: India’s Industry Helps Open Door to World

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: A trade foray into Pakistan showed the foreign policy role of India’s private sector, which the government relies on to serve as an intermediary.

headline.seo: Kerry Seeks to Soothe Pakistani Anger Over Bin Laden Raid
headline.main: Meeting With Pakistani Leaders, Kerry Seeks to Ease Anger Over Bin Laden Raid
headline.print_headline: Meeting With Pakistani Leaders, Kerry Seeks to Ease Anger Over Bin Laden Raid

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry said that the two sides should work together despite the anti-American clamor by the Pakistani government in the past two weeks.

headline.main: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group's Foreign Staff

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children , apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year. In a statement issued from its London office early Thursday, Save the Children said the Pakistani Interior Ministry had ordered that ''visas for our six international staff in Pakistan may not be renewed.'' A senior aid official in Pakistan, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the staff members had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country.

headline.seo: Clinton Meets With Less Hostility in a Pakistan Trip
headline.main: In a Visit to Pakistan, Clinton Encounters a Less Hostile Reception
headline.print_headline: In a Visit to Pakistan, Clinton Encounters a Less Hostile Reception

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: The mood was noticeably less toxic on Monday than it was a year ago, perhaps in part because Mrs. Clinton showed up with more than $500 million in economic aid.

headline.main: Militants Linked to Killing of U.S. Reporter in Pakistan Remain at Large, Report Says

Pervez Musharraf.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- Nine years after the American reporter Daniel Pearl was captured and killed by operatives of Al Qaeda in Pakistan, more than a dozen of the militants involved in his murder remain at large, a testament to the lack of will by Pakistani authorities to prosecute the cases, according to a report released Thursday. Some of the 14 men who are known to have played a role in the death of Mr. Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, committed other terrorist acts in Pakistan, including an attack on a hotel in Karachi in which 11 French engineers were killed, and the attempted assassination of the former president, Pervez Musharraf, the report says.

headline.main: BIN LADEN INTERVIEW

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The Arab television station Al Jazeera said in a statement that it never aired an October interview with Osama bin Laden because it was conducted under duress and the questions were dictated to its correspondent. The statement was the latest Al Jazeera said CNN, which aired the interview on Thursday, had obtained the tape illegally. A CNN official denied that and said Al Jazeera should explain why it had never made the tape public.

headline.main: Voice of bin Laden?

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera, the Qatar-based Arabic-language television channel, broadcast today what it said was the voice of Osama bin Laden threatening new attacks on the United States. Al Jazeera said the audiotape was dropped off at one of its offices but did not say where or by whom. It was not clear when the tape was made.

headline.main: Tape Goads Pakistanis

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Two Arabic satellite television channels today broadcast an audiotape said to be from one of the senior leaders of Al Qaeda, Dr. Ayman al-Zawahiri, in which he urged Pakistanis to overthrow President Pervez Musharraf for ''betraying'' Islam. The speaker on the tape, which was shown by the Al Jazeera and Al Arabiya channels, also urged Muslims to fight what was described as the Christian-Zionist crusade ''aimed at eradicating Islam and Muslims.''

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; NEW BIN LADEN TAPE

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Threatening attacks against the United States and urging Muslims to defend Iraq against an American-led invasion, the latest tape attributed to Osama bin Laden and broadcast by Al Jazeera television jangled the frayed nerves of Americans already fearful that a terror attack might be imminent. Senior Bush administration officials like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the tape buttressed the case for military action against Saddam Hussein, saying it showed Mr. bin Laden was ''in partnership with Iraq.'' David Johnston

headline.main: Qaeda Deputy Says Iran Collaborated With U.S.

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The second in command of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, accused Iran of collaborating with the United States in Afghanistan and Iraq in a video broadcast on Monday on the Al Jazeera cable channel. Al Jazeera, which broadcast excerpts from the videotape, said it was more than 90 minutes long and was titled ''Seven Years of Crusades.'' Its release was intended to mark the seventh anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States, according to the station.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Al Jazeera Reporter Arrested

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The police arrested a reporter for the Arabic television station Al Jazeera on suspicion of having links to the terror network Al Qaeda. The suspect, Tayseer Allouni, of Syrian origin, was accused of assisting the leader of the network's Spanish cell, who was arrested in November of 2001, and of transferring money to Al Qaeda operatives in Afghanistan, the news agency EFE reported. Mr. Allouni's wife disputed the accusations, as did the director of Al Jazeera. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

headline.main: A 'New' Tape Of bin Laden

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A British-based Islamic news agency released a videotape today of Osama bin Laden that it said was filmed just two months ago. But the independent Arab satellite news network Al Jazeera said it had seen the tape three or four months ago and believed it was recorded in October. The 100-second clip showed Mr. bin Laden seated outside a stone building as he spoke to unseen supporters, extolling the merits of martyrdom.

headline.main: Al Jazeera Reporter Jailed

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A Spanish judge jailed a correspondent for Al Jazeera today after he was accused of being a member of Al Qaeda. The judge, Baltasar Garzón, accused the journalist, Tayssir Alouni, of transferring money to Qaeda operatives, recruiting new members for terrorist training camps and sharing information with leaders of the network's Spanish cell, which was rounded up in November 2001.

headline.main: Little Airplay for Al Qaeda Rebuttal to Bush

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Establishing what could become a pattern of direct response by videotape to statements by President Bush, Osama bin Laden's chief lieutenant said yesterday that the president had lied in a speech on Thursday night when he said the United States was destroying Al Qaeda and the Taliban forces. A videotape of the the man, Ayman al-Zawahiri, was delivered to the Arabic-language network Al Jazeera just 20 hours after President Bush's speech in Atlanta. On Nov. 3, American officials rushed to condemn a taped message from Osama bin Laden broadcast on Al Jazeera.

headline.main: New Group Says It Strikes G.I.'s

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A group claiming to be linked to the terrorist network Al Qaeda said in an audiotape broadcast on an Arab television station today that it, and not followers of Saddam Hussein, was behind attacks on United States forces in Iraq. ''I swear by God no one from his followers carried out any jihad operations as he claims,'' said the unidentified male voice on the tape, which was broadcast by Al Arabiya television, based in Dubai. The voice said the attacks were ''a result of our brothers in jihad'' and warned of a new strike in the days to come that would ''break the back of America completely.''

headline.main: Tape Opposing Vote Attributed to bin Laden

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: An audiotape message said to be made by the terrorist leader Osama bin Laden called for Muslims to boycott elections there next month and endorsed the Jordanian militant Abu Musab al-Zarqawi as Mr. bin Laden's deputy in Iraq. The tape, broadcast Monday by the Arab news network Al Jazeera, condemned the American-backed Iraqi elections for a constitutional assembly, scheduled for Jan. 30, saying, ''In the balance of Islam, this constitution is infidel and therefore everyone who participates in this election will be considered infidels.''

headline.main: Qaeda Figure May Be on Tape

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera broadcast what may be a new audiotape of the senior Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri on Thursday, in which he called on Pakistanis to overthrow their government. ''I call on Muslims in Pakistan to get rid of their government, which is working for Americans,'' said the voice on the tape, which sounded like previous recordings of Dr. Zawahiri, the right-hand man of Osama bin Laden. Americans believe Dr. Zawahiri played a major role in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline.main: Americans Being Chased Even in U.S., Qaeda Says

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The Arabic television channel Al Jazeera broadcast an audiotape on Friday said to be from Dr. Ayman al-Zawahiri, a senior figure in the terrorist network Al Qaeda, saying his group was chasing Americans everywhere, including the United States. ''With God's help, we are still chasing Americans and their allies everywhere, including their homeland,'' the speaker said on the tape. Dr. Zawahiri is the right-hand man to Osama bin Laden, the Qaeda leader.

headline.main: Unraveling Duct Tape, Warts and All

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: AS you might imagine, these are heady days at the Pressure Sensitive Tape Council in Northbrook, Ill. As hardware stores around the country experienced runs on duct tape, Glen Anderson, the council's executive vice president, voiced mixed feelings about the tape's sudden summons to national security. With due respect for the Department of Homeland Security, he said, duct might not be the best tape for the job. ''Polypropylene tape would be most acceptable,'' Mr. Anderson said. ''Duct tape will leave a residue, whereas polypropylene will not.''

headline.main: Interview With bin Laden Makes the Rounds

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera, the Persian Gulf television network, obtained an exclusive interview with Osama bin Laden in October, the only television interview the terrorist leader has given since the war in Afghanistan began. But the network never broadcast the interview, partly because it revealed how much Mr. bin Laden had intimidated the network's correspondent, according to American and Middle Eastern government officials. Later, however, Britain and the United States secretly obtained copies of the interview, and on Nov. 14, British Prime Minister Tony Blair used it to buttress the West's public case that Mr. bin Laden was responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Duct Tape: The Cure for All Ills

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: LIKE we need another excuse to buy duct tape. What's it been, maybe just a few months since duct tape was last flying off store shelves? In October, the tape had a bigger comeback than Ozzy Osbourne when a Cincinnati doctor announced it was a better and less painful remedy than liquid nitrogen for wart removal. The head of the wart study said he didn't know for sure why it worked, but thought it may have something to do with irritation of the immune system.

headline.main: Big Networks Clear the Decks For Coverage And Comment

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: All three major television networks as well as the three all-news cable channels gave blanket coverage to the release of the Osama bin Laden tape yesterday, the first time in two months that all of them agreed that a development in the terrorism story merited such across-the-board, live coverage. Network executives said that the images of Mr. bin Laden rejoicing in the devastation of the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks justified such extraordinary coverage.

headline.main: C.I.A. Says bin Laden Tape Is Likely Authentic

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: An audiotaped message broadcast earlier this week that was said to be the voice of Osama bin Laden is ''probably'' authentic, an official at the Central Intelligence Agency said today. The conclusion was reached after sophisticated voice analysis, but did not determine when the message was recorded, the official said.

headline.main: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A reporter for the Arab satellite station Al Jazeera is being held at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, suspected of having links with the terror network of Al Qaeda, according to a statement issued by the station. Al Jazeera identified the reporter as Sami al-Hajj, a Sudanese, who it said was arrested in southern Afghanistan on Dec. 15.

headline.main: Qaeda Deputy Says Attacks Won't Stop

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda's deputy leader said in a videotape broadcast that governments could not stop its attacks and that the security of the West depended on respect for Islam and an end to aggression against Muslims. The leader, Ayman al-Zawahiri, also said that the ''new crusader campaign'' would end in defeat.

headline.main: Al Jazeera Says U.N. Peacekeepers Released in Golan
headline.print_headline: Al Jazeera Says U.N. Peacekeepers Released in Golan

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera television said on Thursday the al Qaeda-backed Nusra Front group released U.N. peacekeepers it seized two weeks ago on the Golan Heights.

headline.main: November 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; BIN LADEN ON TAPE

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: After months of debate among counterterrorism experts about whether he had died in the war in Afghanistan, Osama bin Laden has sudden resurfaced. American intelligence officials concluded last week that a recently recorded audiotape that was broadcast on an Arab television network is genuine and contains the voice of the terrorist leader. On the tape, the voice said to be that of Osama bin Laden refers to several recent terrorist attacks, offering proof that he is alive, or at least was alive in recent weeks. James Risen

headline.main: A Gaunt bin Laden on New Tape

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A new videotaped statement from Osama bin Laden that purports to have been made sometime in late November or early December shows the terrorist leader looking tired and gaunt but alive some three months after the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Excerpts from the latest tape were broadcast today on Al Jazeera television, the Arab network that has served as an outlet for Mr. bin Laden in the past. The full statement, which is supposedly about 30 minutes long, is to be broadcast by the network on Thursday and rebroadcast in the United States.

headline.main: Networks Find Tape Provides Little News

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The major TV news networks gave Osama bin Laden's latest message significant weight yesterday, even though most of what he said was not really new. All stayed true to promises made to the White House in October that they would handle Al Qaeda videotapes carefully lest they contain hidden messages to terrorist operatives. None showed the tape in its entirety.

headline.main: Another Tape Ties bin Laden To Hijackings

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A tape of Osama bin Laden found recently in Afghanistan shows him recounting how he listened to news reports on the radio of the first plane crashing into the World Trade Center three months ago and quickly told others around him ''there will be more'' as he awaited the second attack. Administration officials say they have read transcripts of the amateur videotape, which the White House is debating whether to make public, and that Mr. bin Laden seemed amused that many of the hijackers in the attacks apparently had not known they were on suicide missions.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Emergency Food Aid

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: People who get food stamps but whose food was lost through power failures or other events after the attacks on the World Trade Center can get replacement food stamps quickly, state officials said yesterday. But the deadline is midnight tonight to report the losses at (877) 472-8411 (for those who speak English and Spanish) and (718) 557-1015 (for those who speak other languages). As many as 10,000 households in Lower Manhattan receive food stamps. Separately, residents who do not currently qualify for food stamps may be eligible for emergency benefits and can call the same numbers. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

headline.main: U.N. Plans Relief Airlifts

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: United Nations officials said today that they were planning airlifts of food and medicine to Afghans who, because of their remote locations, could no longer be supplied by road. Relief officials said those plans were at the preliminary stage. They emphasized, however, that the bombing campaign and banditry continued to hinder relief efforts. ''If we don't get the food into those remote areas, the people will come to us -- if they are physically able,'' said Oliver Ulich of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.

headline.main: Demand at Food Pantries Rises, but Donations Drop

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The slow economy and the loss of thousands of jobs after the World Trade Center attack have heightened demand at food pantries, but the supply of donations is decreasing, according to a study released yesterday by the city's largest food bank. The food bank, Food for Survival, took a survey of the soup kitchens they serve in the days after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and found that 64 percent of the people receiving free food in New York were taking donations for the first time. Most of these first-time clients were single mothers who needed emergency food because they had lost their jobs in the attack, said Lucy Cabrera, the president of the food bank.

headline.main: Two Roles for Military: Supplying Guns and Butter

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon plans to continue airdropping packets of food into Afghanistan, military officials said this week, even though the United States plans to rebuild Afghan airbases and open roads that would allow much larger deliveries into needy areas. With the deep snows of winter piling up in the mountain passes, the officials said some regions of northern Afghanistan would remain inaccessible to supply trucks even after Taliban forces have retreated, leaving American cargo planes as the only means for getting food to some isolated villages.

headline.main: U.S. Will Buy Asian Wheat to Give Afghans

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said today that it would spend $11.2 million on wheat and other food supplies from Central Asian countries for immediate shipment to Afghanistan to avert a worsening hunger crisis there. With more than seven million people at risk of starvation, the United States Agency for International Development said it would buy $6 million in wheat from Kazakhstan through the United Nations' World Food Program rather than shipping wheat from the United States, which would take longer.

headline.main: Aid Warehouse Looted

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: As Afghanistan's interim leaders basked in the pledges of aid in Tokyo today, events at home underscored how shaky this country remains. The United Nations said a warehouse belonging to one of its affiliates was looted and robbed of 40 tons of food last Thursday. It was the second attack in a week on relief efforts operated by the World Food Program, said a United Nations spokesman, Jordan Dey.

headline.seo: Yemen in Crisis as Global Food Prices Rise
headline.main: Millions Are Facing Food Crisis in Yemen, U.N. Agency Says
headline.print_headline: Millions Are Facing Food Crisis in Yemen as Global Prices Rise, U.N. Agency Says

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: More than 5 million cannot afford food, and another 5 million are on the edge as political instability has compounded a surge in global food and fuel prices.

headline.main: Food Drops Go Awry, Damaging Several Homes

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The planes would bring gifts from the sky, 2-year-old Mohebrahman Sedigh kept saying when American planes began bombing near here. He meant food. The gifts finally came early this morning, in the form of Pop-Tarts, peanut butter and other food rations. But they also inadvertently brought more hardship.

headline.main: Asia's Challenge to Europe
headline.print_headline: Asia's Challenge to Europe

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The economies of China and India could scarcely be more different, yet each will test the Continent's ability to adapt to more difficult environment.

headline.main: U.S. Orders New Aid to Help Avert Famine in Afghanistan

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said today that it was spending $8.2 million in emergency aid for Afghanistan, most of which would be used to buy trucks to transport 30,000 tons of wheat immediately to northern Afghanistan. It was the second emergency purchase this week intended to avert what the administration is now calling famine conditions. With only days before the first snows fall in Afghanistan's central mountains, Andrew S. Natsios, the administrator for the Agency for International Development, said relief officials were buying the trucks in central Asia this week and would begin using them immediately to deliver the food.

headline.main: Rising Demand Squeezes Food Banks

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: EVERY day, tractor-trailer rigs pull up to the loading dock of an old paper warehouse on the bank of the Genesee River here and unload donated food. The sturdy concrete warehouse was a donation itself, to Foodlink, a nonprofit wholesaler that distributes about six million pounds of food each year to soup kitchens, food pantries and meals-on-wheels programs in the Finger Lakes region of western New York. In the last decade, government has shifted onto charities the job of making food available to the poor, unemployed, disabled and housebound. Foodlink is one of 230 nonprofit food banks that are vital to a large portion of Americans who might otherwise go hungry.

headline.main: Nearly 3 Million Syrian Children Not in School
headline.print_headline: Nearly 3 Million Syrian Children Not in School

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: Nearly three million Syrian children are not attending school due to the civil war raging in their homeland, an international charity group said Thursday, as the country's intractable conflict threatens to deny an entire a generation of education.

headline.seo: World Food Program to Resume in Pakistan’s Tribal Region
headline.main: Pakistan Food Program Set to Resume
headline.print_headline: Food Aid Program to Resume After Bombing in Pakistan

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The World Food Program had ceased operations in the tribal region of Bajaur following an attack that killed 46 people over the weekend.

headline.main: Provision Could Limit U.S. Food Aid
headline.print_headline: Provision Could Limit U.S. Food Aid

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: A new law would require that three-quarters of United States food aid, instead of one-half, be sent on American vessels, potentially preventing nations in need from receiving it.

headline.main: The World; The Danger Of Doing Good Deeds

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: DURING the Afghanistan air war, the top military officer of the United States regularly briefed reporters not only on the areas bombed overnight, but also on the number of individual food packets dropped by military cargo planes. In a typical briefing on Oct. 22, 2001, Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that ''U.S. forces struck in six planned target areas that included airfields and air defenses, command and control facilities, and terrorist forces and camps.'' Then, barely missing a beat, he added, ''We continued our humanitarian airdrop mission Saturday, with four C-17s delivering approximately 52,000 rations.''

headline.main: A Rise in Hunger Pangs in an Unexpected Place
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STATEN ISLAND UP CLOSE

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: Armed against the snow with bright winter jackets, young women with baby carriages and old men with carts stood on line and waited for food. Except for the snow, it was an average Thursday in front of Wendy De Shong-Neuhalfen's house on Post Avenue in Staten Island. Ms. Neuhalfen, executive director of New Direction Services, a food pantry, has been handing out food from her basement in Port Richmond since 1995. On this December day, 104 families trudged through nearly impassable streets to get 260 bags full of apples, rice, canned chili and other foodstuffs. Last month, Ms. Neuhalfen ran out of food and had to close for three weeks.

headline.main: Bridge Into Afghan North Is Officially Open but Little Food Aid Gets Through

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: This border town, where the only bridge linking Afghanistan to its northern neighbor, Uzbekistan, was opened with fanfare on Saturday, lay desolate and inactive today, a junkyard of discarded Soviet military armor and decaying concrete buildings. The so-called Friendship Bridge that spans the ancient River Oxus, known today as the Amu Darya, remains off limits to the public, and on the Afghan side, Northern Alliance soldiers barred access to the customs area. ''The border is open,'' one said, but he refused access all the same. Very little seemed to be moving in either direction.

headline.seo: World Food Program Suspends Aid to Southern Somalia
headline.main: Threats Lead Food Agency to Curtail Aid in Somalia
headline.print_headline: Threats Lead Food Agency To Curtail Aid In Somalia

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The World Food Program said the suspension of food deliveries to a million people was due to threats as well as “unacceptable demands by armed groups.”

headline.main: The Iranians Seek to Stem Refugee Flow

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: Fearful that famine and war will force hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees to pour into the country, Iran has set up a corridor in the northeast to send aid into Afghanistan. Since the American-led airstrikes against Afghanistan began on Sunday, tons of food and relief items have gone through Khorasan Province to be distributed in Afghanistan. Much of the work is being supervised by foreign relief networks whose distribution of food and medicine in Afghanistan has been disrupted.

headline.main: Napolitano Aims to Grow UC Role in Fighting Hunger
headline.print_headline: Napolitano Aims to Grow UC Role in Fighting Hunger

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: University of California President Janet Napolitano said Tuesday that she plans to leverage the state's role in agriculture and research to tackle one of the world's most pressing problems: food.

headline.main: U.N. Watches Refugee Effort For Afghans

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: About 223,000 Afghan refugees have returned home since a United Nations program to help them return began six weeks ago, but there is concern over whether conditions are adequate for them to stay, the United Nations refugee agency said on Friday. Ruud Lubbers, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, is to visit Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan to see the project firsthand and to emphasize the need for long-term rehabilitation and development.

headline.main: Food Industry's Resistance Stalls Bill to Protect Food

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: Rushed through both houses of Congress last fall in response to the threat of bioterrorism, legislation to improve food safety has stalled on Capitol Hill because of resistance from the food industry. The bill, passed with overwhelming bipartisan support, was written by senior members of both parties, after suggestions from the White House and the Food and Drug Administration. But like many other initiatives begun after the Sept. 11 attacks, it appears to have lost its urgency.

headline.main: Individual Meals From the Sky

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: American troops aboard two C-17 cargo jets were dropping about 37,000 individually wrapped food packages into some of the most remote areas of Afghanistan today in an effort to show the Islamic world that the United States wanted to help the Afghan people at the same time that it was punishing their Taliban rulers. The areas singled out for the drops were in the central highlands, where some of the poorest people in Afghanistan, the Hazara ethnic group, live in inaccessible valleys and mountains, a senior administration official said.

headline.main: Can-Do Architects

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: The publicity material is full of puns, for example, calling the event ''The Uncanniest Show On Earth.'' But the proceedings are no joke; organizers expect that the so-called Canstruction competition will raise 20,000 pounds of food for the Community Food Bank of New Jersey in Hillside, a group especially in need because of its participation in World Trade Center relief efforts. At the Newark Museum on Wednesday, from 5 p.m. to midnight, teams from eight New Jersey architecture firms will build elaborate structures from canned and boxed food. Winners will be selected in four categories -- best meal, best use of labels, structural integrity and jurors' favorite -- and will compete nationally with winners from 50 cities nationwide.

headline.main: Even With Roads Still Open, Security Fears Are Choking the Flow of Food Aid

Humanitarian Aid.lead_paragraph: When allied forces routed the Taliban from Kabul and most of northern Afghanistan, international aid organizations predicted that the roads would soon be filled with truck convoys bearing food and supplies to the millions of Afghans thought to be at risk of starvation. Three weeks later that optimism is fading. A crucial bridge into northern Afghanistan from Uzbekistan remains closed, cutting off the most promising avenue for shipping in supplies.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; DISCUSSING SURRENDER

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: More than 15 top Taliban leaders, most of them ex-cabinet members, are in contact with Afghan authorities in Kandahar over their possible surrender, according to Khalid Pashtun, a senior aide to Gov. Gul Agha Shirzai. Asked whether the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was among them, he said: ''No. He knows the consequences if he surrenders.'' But security officials said they hoped that the Taliban leaders could provide information to track down Mullah Omar, and even help locate Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: Taliban Chief in Afghanistan, Karzai Says

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: The deposed Taliban militia leader Mullah Mohammad Omar is alive in Afghanistan, hiding near the Pakistani border, the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said here today. Mr. Karzai, speaking at a news conference, also said other members of the ousted Taliban regime remained in Afghanistan. Attempts to arrest Mullah Omar have failed several times, Mr. Karzai said, without elaboration.

headline.main: Against Odds, Path Opens for U.S.-Taliban Talks

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Over the last year, Marc Grossman, a veteran but low-key diplomat, led a small team of American officials who met secretly from Doha, Qatar, to Munich with a shadowy representative of Afghanistan's Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, in hopes of starting peace talks. The Obama administration's efforts to negotiate an end to the war, initially brokered by Germany's spy service, showed promise but have been scuttled more than once by rumors, deliberate leaks in Kabul, Islamabad and Washington and the assassination of the top Afghan negotiator in September by a supposed envoy wearing a bomb in his turban, Afghan and Western officials said.

headline.main: Threat Attributed to Taliban Leader

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: A statement attributed to Mullah Muhammad Omar, the ousted leader of the Taliban, says the United States will face more ''hostility, chaos and destruction'' if it attacks Iraq, an Arab television station reported today. The station, Al Jazeera, said it was faxed a one-page statement from Mullah Omar. It provided no other details.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: General Vows Bin Laden Capture

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: The American commander of the combined forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David Barno, said he hoped to capture Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, this year. ''Their day has ended, and this year will decisively sound the death knell of their movements in Afghanistan,'' he said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline.main: Taliban Leader Said to Be Yielding Grip on Stronghold to 2 Once-Powerful Supporters

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: The Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, a main target of the American war in Afghanistan, has decided to cede control of his political stronghold in Kandahar to two commanders from the Pashtun ethnic group, the Afghan Islamic Press reported tonight. The retreat would end the seven-year reign of the extremist Islamic group, which gave safe harbor to Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Taliban Leader Is Hiding in Mountain Province Near Kandahar, Afghan Official Says
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MISSING MULLAH

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's paramount leader, is hiding in a mountainous region not far from his former headquarters here, the region's intelligence director said today. After the surrender of Kandahar more than a week ago, Mullah Omar retreated into the mountains near Baghran, about 100 miles northwest of here, in neighboring Helmand Province, said Hajji Gullalai, the newly appointed director of intelligence for four provinces in southern Afghanistan.

headline.main: NORWAY EXPELS MILITANT LEADER

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Norway said yesterday that it planned to expel the founder of Ansar al-Islam, an Islamic militant group in northern Iraq that is suspected by Washington of having links to Baghdad and Al Qaeda. The founder, known as Mullah Krekar, has had refugee status in Norway since 1991. ''Mullah Krekar will be expelled because of concerns about national security,'' said the local government minister, Erna Solberg. Mullah Krekar said he would appeal the expulsion.

headline.main: Taliban's Founder Still Eludes Search

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the mountain fastness north of here, in tribal lands beyond the reach of Afghanistan's central government, Mullah Omar Mohammed is believed to be hiding. The police say that one year after the beginning of the end of the Taliban government, its founder, Mullah Omar -- a secretive, one-eyed cleric -- has returned to his conservative, rural roots. Here in the harsh heartland of the Taliban movement, clan loyalties carry more weight than the $10 million bounty offered for him since January by American soldiers, most recently by Special Forces troops in a new post here.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Muslim Clergyman Attacked

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: A Muslim clergyman was attacked Tuesday night in the Bronx by three men who walked into a mosque and, without a word, struck him over the head with a piece of wood, the police said. Details were sketchy yesterday, but the mullah suffered only minor injuries. The police said the assault on the mullah, who is also black, was being investigated as a possible hate crime. The mullah, 35, whose name was not immediately released, was confronted about 8 p.m. by three men inside the Islamic Cultural Center at 371 East 166th Street, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

headline.main: Afghans Plan Drive to Seize Taliban Leader

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Officials in southern Afghanistan said today that they were planning a military campaign to capture Mullah Muhammad Omar, the former Taliban leader they believe is hiding in a mountainous region about 100 miles northwest of here. Mullah Omar, who escaped from Kandahar before it fell to United States-backed forces in mid-December, is being protected by 2,500 to 3,000 loyal soldiers who control Baghran district, in Helmand Province, according to the officials, who work under Gul Agha Shirzai. Mr. Shirzai is the American-backed warlord who controls four southern provinces, including Kandahar and Helmand.

headline.main: U.S. Airstrike Kills Close Ally Of bin Laden, Pentagon Says

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: A leading Taliban military commander described as a close associate of Osama bin Laden and the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar was killed in an airstrike this week close to the border with Pakistan, the United States military said Saturday. A man identifying himself as a Taliban spokesman denied the report. The commander, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Osmani, , was killed Tuesday by an American airstrike as he traveled by vehicle in a deserted area in Helmand Province in the south, the United States military said. Two of his associates were also killed, it said.

headline.main: OFFER IS MADE TO SURRENDER TALIBAN'S LAST STRONGHOLD; DEAL MAY HINGE ON AMNESTY

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Surrounded by opposition forces and harried by weeks of American bombing, the Taliban agreed today to surrender the southern city of Kandahar, their last stronghold and the birthplace of their radical Islamic movement. But tonight negotiators had yet to resolve two critical issues that could affect the surrender: the fate of Mullah Muhammad Omar and of thousands of Arab fighters, who are loyal to Osama bin Laden and believed to be in Kandahar.

headline.seo: Captured Leader Offers Insight Into the Taliban
headline.main: Captured Leader Offers Insight Into the Taliban
headline.print_headline: Questioning of Captured Taliban Leader Offers Insight Into How the Group Works

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: U.S. officials say that Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar is not revealing details about combat operations, but information from him could prove useful in future talks.

headline.main: The 5 Detainees Swapped for US Soldier
headline.print_headline: The 5 Detainees Swapped for US Soldier

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Snapshots of the five people released from the Guantanamo Bay detention center in a swap for Taliban-held U.S. Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl:

headline.main: Taliban Ex-Envoy Detained And Questioned in Pakistan

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Pakistani officials said today that they had arrested the former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan, Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, and that he was being questioned by Pakistani and American intelligence officials seeking information on the whereabouts of Osama bin Laden as well as Mullah Muhammad Omar, the former Taliban leader. The arrest of Mullah Zaeef, who was taken to Peshawar, on Pakistan's frontier with Afghanistan, came nearly two months after he ceased to be an ambassador when Pakistan decided to shut his embassy. The Pakistani officials who spoke about the matter declined to say why the decision to pick him up had been delayed so long, beyond confirming that they had acted at the request of the United States, which has made the capture of Mr. bin Laden and Mullah Omar a prime objective of American military operations in Afghanistan.

headline.main: Fearful City Wonders Whether Taliban Will Leave Quietly or Fight

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: An atmosphere of fear and suspense hangs over Kandahar, the birthplace of the Taliban in southern Afghanistan, as the leader of the movement, Mullah Muhammad Omar, appears to be maneuvering toward his exit, travelers from the city said today. The dwindling number of civilians left there are rattled by the American bombs, these travelers to Pakistan said, but even more by the uncertainty of what is about to unfold. The city is not sure whether the Taliban will leave quietly, slipping out at night while unfurling their turbans and shaving off their beards, as they did in Kabul, or whether there will be door-to-door fighting as new authorities move in and seal the fate of the extremist Islamic group.

headline.main: Taliban Leader, In a Comeback, Is Vexing U.S.

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: In late 2001, Mullah Muhammad Omar's prospects seemed utterly bleak. The ill-educated, one-eyed leader of the Taliban had fled on a motorbike after his fighters were swiftly routed by the Americans invading Afghanistan. Much of the world celebrated his ouster, and Afghans cheered the return of girls' education, music and ordinary pleasures outlawed by the grim fundamentalist government.

headline.main: A Dogged Taliban Chief Rebounds, Vexing U.S.
headline.print_headline: Taliban Leader, In a Comeback, Is Vexing U.S.

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Mullah Muhammad Omar’s prospects seemed bleak in 2001. Now, he leads an insurgency that has gained ground in much of Afghanistan.

headline.main: Taliban Remain in Kandahar, Their Southern Citadel, and Say They'll Fight to the Last

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: As much of Afghanistan began to cast off the effects of seven years of Taliban rule, the southern city of Kandahar, the Taliban's citadel, remained in the movement's hands today, a stubborn refuge for hard-liners. After a report on Friday that the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, planned to relinquish power to two commanders, Taliban officials said today that little had changed and that the movement would fight to the last.

headline.main: Seeking Mullah Omar in a Land of Secrets

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Black-turbaned men stare out at a stranger's car from the teahouses and shops in the shabby bazaar here in the southern province of Oruzgan. This is where the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was raised and, by some reports, where he has returned to hide. Mullah Omar, Afghanistan's former leader, is one of the world's most wanted men, since he gave sanctuary to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network in 1996 and allowed him to operate and acquire enormous power and influence in the country. Mullah Omar is widely reported to be hiding in his home province since fleeing Kandahar, the Taliban's spiritual center, in December.

headline.main: Don't Doubt Steadfastness Of Taliban, Envoy Insists

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: When the man who has become the Taliban's last remaining voice outside Afghanistan returned here today after a week traveling at home, his message to the United States seemed more than just defiant. In fact, he sounded positively smug: bomb us as you will, he seemed to say, and we will still be there to thwart you. Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, the Taliban ambassador to Pakistan, resurfaced on his embassy's veranda for an evening news conference.

headline.main: TALIBAN ABANDON LAST STRONGHOLD; OMAR IS NOT FOUND

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: Two months after the American bombardment of Afghanistan began, Taliban forces today abandoned their last stronghold in Kandahar. The surrender, reported by anti-Taliban leaders entering the city, appeared to complete the collapse of the radical Islamic group that had ruled Afghanistan. But confusion was widespread in the streets of Kandahar, with rival warlords competing for control, some Taliban fighters still defiant, and the fate of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, unclear.

headline.main: UZBEKS TO ALLOW OPENING OF BRIDGE ON AFGHAN BORDER

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: After weeks of diplomatic pressure from the United States, the president of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, agreed on Saturday to open a crucial bridge that could help speed urgently needed food and medical supplies from this Central Asian country to war-ravaged Afghanistan. The announcement to open the Friendship Bridge came in a news conference here with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is visiting partners in the United States-led coalition against terrorism. The decision would free international relief organizations to move millions of tons of food and other aid into northern Afghanistan, where wintry weather has already complicated the plight of millions of Afghan civilians threatened by drought and the war.

headline.main: Pakistan Says an Ex-Envoy and Spokesman for the Taliban Is Seeking Asylum

Muhammad Omar.lead_paragraph: The Foreign Ministry confirmed today that it had received an application for political asylum from Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, the former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan who became the most visible face of the Taliban to the outside world, with the feisty news conferences he held here in the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks. ''We have received an application from Mullah Zaeef for asylum, and we will process it,'' a foreign ministry official said.

headline.main: TRACKING TERRORISTS

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Al Qaeda followers in the United States and abroad remained committed to participating in terror attacks in the United States. Mr. Mueller, speaking at a hearing of the House Appropriations Committee on his bureau's budget, said counterterrorism officials had thwarted some attempted terrorist plots. ''But,'' he warned, ''the mere fact that there have been successes does not in any way, shape or form mean that we are confident that there will not be another attack.'' David Johnston (NYT)

headline.seo: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Material Witness Law
headline.main: Supreme Court to Hear Material Witness Case
headline.print_headline: Jailed as a Material Witness but Treated Like a Terrorist, a Lawsuit Says

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The case of Abdullah al-Kidd raises questions about when the government may detain citizens it is unable to charge with a crime for fear they may engage in terrorism.

headline.main: LINK TO MALAYSIA DENIED

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Malaysia was not a ''launching pad'' for the Sept. 11 attacks, an assertion that had been attributed to anonymous bureau officials in the past. Mr. Mueller made his comments in Malaysia during an Asia-Pacific tour that will take him to Singapore, the Philippines and Indonesia, all countries where Al Qaeda cells have been operating. Malaysian authorities are holding 49 suspected Islamic militants without trial after arrests dating to before Sept. 11, saying they belong to a regional network seeking a conservative Muslim state. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

headline.main: F.B.I. Agent Who Wrote Critical Memo Retires at 50

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: A career F.B.I. agent who wrote a blistering memo to the agency's director alleging missteps by the bureau before the Sept. 11 attacks retired from the agency on Friday. The agent, Coleen Rowley, retired 11 days after turning 50, when she became eligible for a full pension, The Star Tribune reported.

headline.seo: Obama to Pick James B. Comey to Lead F.B.I.
headline.main: Former Bush Official Said to Be Obama Pick to Lead F.B.I.
headline.print_headline: Ex-Bush Official Said To Be Choice For Chief Of F.B.I.

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: James B. Comey earned a reputation for independence after leading an internal revolt in the administration of George W. Bush over the legality of its warrantless wiretapping program.

headline.main: Feb.23-March 1; COMING UP

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: President Bush plans to speak at an American Medical Association conference in Washington on Tuesday and will meet with the president of Rwanda. Congress will hear testimony from Attorney General John Ashcroft, Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge and Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I., regarding the war on terrorism.

headline.main: Agent's Role In Inquiries Is Questioned

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators has demanded that the Federal Bureau of Investigation explain why a senior agent who had access to two important strands of counterterrorism information never put the information together in a way that might have helped thwart the Sept. 11 attacks. According to the three senators, a warning last summer from a Phoenix F.B.I. agent about terrorists using American flight schools was sent to the same unit of the bureau that was dealing with the Minnesota field office and its suspicions about Zacarias Moussaoui, a flight student there who officials now say was supposed to be the 20th hijacker.

headline.main: An Expert on Counterterrorism Will Head the F.B.I. in New York

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: A veteran F.B.I. agent who helped lead investigations of the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, the East Africa embassy bombings in 1998 and the attack on the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen in 2000 was named today by Robert S. Mueller III, the bureau's director, to head its New York office. The agent, Pasquale J. D'Amuro, is currently assigned to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters as a senior official in charge of counterterrorism and counterintelligence, areas that are a primary responsibility of the bureau's New York office, which is regarded by agents as the most important of the 56 field offices.

headline.seo: Review Faults F.B.I.’s Scientific Work in Anthrax Investigation
headline.main: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters
headline.print_headline: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: A review of the F.B.I.’s scientific work on the investigation of the anthrax letters of 2001 concludes that the bureau overstated the strength of genetic analysis linking them to an Army scientist.

headline.main: F.B.I. Whistle-Blower Is Criticized in Report

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. agent who blew the whistle on the bureau's failings in its investigation of Zacarias Moussaoui before Sept. 11, 2001, was criticized on Monday in a government report for her own actions in the case. The whistle-blower, Coleen Rowley, a former lawyer in the F.B.I.'s Minneapolis field office who is now running for Congress as a Democrat, received praise and criticism in the report, prepared by the Justice Department's inspector general.

headline.main: Wary of Risk, Slow to Adapt, F.B.I. Stumbles in Terror War

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: When the director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged on Wednesday that the agency had missed warning signals on terrorism, he stunned many Americans. But his statement was not news to some veterans of the agency -- or lawmakers who now say they treated the F.B.I. with too much deference for too many years. These officials say the F.B.I., despite efforts to strengthen its counterterrorism programs over the last decade, and despite hefty increases in its budget, never developed a nimble enough structure, analytic capability or sense of mission to foil terrorist plots before they were carried out.

headline.main: Lawyers in 9/11 at Gitmo Case Seek to Question FBI
headline.print_headline: Lawyers in 9/11 at Gitmo Case Seek to Question FBI

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for five men charged in the Sept. 11 attack are seeking to question the FBI about an apparent investigation of defense team personnel in the case.

headline.main: F.B.I. Says Pre-Sept. 11 Call For Inquiry Got Little Notice

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today at a Senate hearing that his agency had paid too little attention to a July 2001 memorandum written by an F.B.I. agent in Phoenix who detected a disturbing pattern of Middle Eastern men attending American flight training schools. ''Should we have done more in terms of the Phoenix E.C.?'' Mr. Mueller said of the memorandum, referring to it as an electronic communication. ''Yes.''

headline.main: Agent Who Saw 9/11 Lapses Still Faults F.B.I. on Terror

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The veteran F.B.I. agent who exposed the bureau's failure to heed evidence of terrorist plots before the Sept. 11 attacks is now warning her superiors that the bureau is not prepared to deal with new terrorist strikes that she and many colleagues fear would result from an American war with Iraq. The agent, Coleen Rowley of the bureau's Minneapolis field office, is not a counterterrorism specialist and does not have access to detailed intelligence about Al Qaeda and its planning. But she is a 22-year F.B.I. veteran who is intimately acquainted with the bureau's inner workings and with the thinking of fellow agents, including agents who specialize in counterterrorism.

headline.main: Bush Addresses Misuse of F.B.I. Subpoenas

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: President Bush acknowledged on Saturday ''F.B.I. shortfallings'' in the disclosure that the bureau improperly used the USA Patriot Act to obtain thousands of business, financial and other records in the United States. But at a news briefing in Uruguay, part of a weeklong trip to Latin America, Mr. Bush said the provision that was misused remained an important tool against terrorism.

headline.main: F.B.I. Chief Admits 9/11 Might Have Been Detectable

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged today for the first time that the attacks of Sept. 11 might have been preventable if officials in his agency had responded differently to all the pieces of information that were available. As a result, Mr. Mueller said he was beginning an overhaul of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to aim more resources toward what he asserted is now its fundamental mission: the prevention of new terrorist operations. The changes, he said, are designed to bolster the bureau's capability to analyze information about terrorist threats and anticipate possible attacks.

headline.main: Whistle-Blower Recounts Faults Inside the F.B.I.
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE CONGRESSIONAL HEARINGS

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. agent whose impassioned protest letter ignited a storm of criticism of the bureau's management told a Senate committee today that the F.B.I.'s bureaucracy discouraged innovation, drowned investigators in paperwork and punished agents who sought to cut through the many layers of gatekeepers at the bureau's headquarters. The agent, Coleen Rowley, a lawyer in the bureau's Minneapolis office, gave the Senate Judiciary Committee a rare glimpse into life in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's field offices, where most of the investigative work is done, but where she said agents operated under risk-averse superiors in Washington.

headline.main: F.B.I. Said to Find It Could Not Have Averted Boston Attack
headline.print_headline: F.B.I. Said to Find It Could Not Have Averted Boston Attack

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The conclusion, based on several internal reviews, rejects criticism that the bureau could have better monitored one of the suspects before the attack.

headline.main: City's F.B.I. Chief Will Retire To Lead a Giuliani Company

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: Pasquale J. D'Amuro, head of the F.B.I.'s New York office and one of the bureau's leading terrorism experts, has announced that he is retiring to become chief executive of a security consulting company that is a division of Giuliani Partners L.L.C., the consulting company headed by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. D'Amuro, 49, will become the top official at Giuliani Security and Safety L.L.C., on April 1.

headline.main: National Briefing | Domestic Security: F.B.I. Warns Of Suspicious Almanacs

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is warning the police nationwide to be alert for people carrying almanacs, saying the books could be used for planning terrorist attacks. In a bulletin sent to about 18,000 police organizations, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said terrorists might use almanacs ''to assist with target selection and pre-operational planning.'' It urged officers to watch during searches, traffic stops and other investigations for almanacs, especially ones annotated in suspicious ways. ''The practice of researching potential targets is consistent with known methods of Al Qaeda and other terrorist organizations that seek to maximize the likelihood of operational success through careful planning,'' the F.B.I. wrote.

headline.main: F.B.I. Creates New Management Structure for Better Oversight
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL AGENTS

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I., said today that he was reorganizing the bureau in an effort to fix embarrassing administrative problems and strengthen its ability to deter terrorist attacks. In one significant change, Mr. Mueller has decided not to name a deputy director to replace Thomas J. Pickard, who until his retirement last week had been the most senior career official at the F.B.I. Instead, Mr. Mueller has appointed four executive assistant directors to manage the agency on a daily basis.

headline.main: F.B.I. Agent Tells of Ground Zero Crystal Theft

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department's inspector general is investigating an F.B.I. agent's complaint that an F.B.I. evidence recovery team stole a Tiffany crystal globe paperweight from the rubble of the World Trade Center, government officials said today. The agent, from the bureau's Minneapolis office, wrote in a Sept. 25 letter to two senators on the Judiciary Committee that the slightly damaged paperweight turned up last month on the desk of an F.B.I. secretary, who said it had been found by agents working at the trade center.

headline.main: Lawmakers Say Misstatements Cloud F.B.I. Chief's Credibility
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE INTELLIGENCE REPORTS

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: With admissions this week that the F.B.I. might have been able to foil the Sept. 11 attacks and that it had bungled additional clues, Robert S. Mueller III has contradicted much of his past public defense of the bureau, raising new concern today on Capitol Hill about his leadership of the embattled agency. Lawmakers said in interviews that the F.B.I. director was secure in his job for now and that they welcomed the plans he announced on Wednesday to change and enlarge the bureau's counterterrorism program.

headline.main: AGENT COMPLAINTS LEAD F.B.I. DIRECTOR TO ASK FOR INQUIRY
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE INTELLIGENCE REPORTS

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said today that he was ordering an internal inquiry into complaints by a senior agent in Minneapolis that officials at headquarters repeatedly held back agents in Minneapolis who sought to investigate Zacarias Moussaoui aggressively in the days before the Sept. 11 hijackings. The agent, Coleen Rowley, general counsel in the Minneapolis office, also said in a detailed 13-page letter to the Congressional committee that is investigating the government's preparedness for the Sept. 11 attacks that Mr. Mueller had misrepresented the bureau's handling of Mr. Moussaoui's case after his arrest on immigration charges three weeks before the hijackings, according to officials who have reviewed her letter.

headline.main: F.B.I.'s Counterterrorism Chief Is Leaving After Three Months

Robert Mueller III - FBI Director.lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief point man in the campaign against terrorism is leaving to join a Las Vegas gambling empire, less than three months after he became the third-ranking official at the bureau, officials said on Wednesday. The F.B.I. official, Larry Mefford, who is head of the bureau's counterterrorism and counterintelligence operation, becomes the third person to leave that post in the last 14 months. No immediate successor was named. The bureau made counterterrorism its top priority after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: WITHHOLDING DETAINEES' NAMES

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: A state appellate court ruled last week that the federal government can keep the names of detainees being held in custody a secret. Since Sept. 11 more than 1,100 detainees have been held nationally, many of them in Hudson and Passaic County jails, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The ruling said that the release of detainees' names could compromise investigations and public safety. Civil liberties advocates wanted the names released to monitor detainees' treatment in custody and to ensure adequate legal representation.
