A representative of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said the group planned to appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. John Holl

headline.main: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Because of Secrecy
headline.print_headline: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Due to Secrecy

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Leaders in Congress and the intelligence committees strongly support the National Security Agency programs, and use national security arguments to trump privacy concerns.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: A.C.L.U. Sues Over Airport Search

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois filed suit against a National Guardsman and three security guards at O'Hare International Airport for making Samar Kaukab, an American of Pakistani descent, remove her traditional Muslim head covering in a search last November in which her pants and sweater were also opened. The A.C.L.U. said Ms. Kaukab, 22, had been singled out because of her religious attire for a search that violated her constitutional rights to equal protection and religious freedom. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: High Court Won't Hear Detainee Case

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union lost a round yesterday in its effort to learn the names of foreigners who were arrested after Sept. 11 and detained in New Jersey jails. The New Jersey Supreme Court denied the group's appeal of a June appellate court ruling that said the federal government could pre-empt the state's right-to-know laws in the interest of national security. A.C.L.U. officials said they were considering an appeal to the United States Supreme Court. The Justice Department issued a statement saying that disclosing the detainees' names ''could provide terrorists a road map of the department's investigations.'' Susan Sachs (NYT)

headline.main: I.N.S. DETAINEES

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The Immigration and Naturalization Service changed its policy last week and agreed to allow advocacy groups to visit foreign nationals held in the Hudson and Passaic County jails since Sept. 11. The service will allow such groups as the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee to help detainees with legal questions and to provide representation. There are 460 aliens held nationwide since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the I.N.S., though how many are in New Jersey is not known. John Holl

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Reversing itself, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit civil-liberties lawyers to advise hundreds of foreign nationals held since the Sept. 11 attacks. The decision, issued Jan. 11 but not received by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey until Jan. 24, followed two lawsuits accusing the government of illegally withholding the names of detainees and the charges against them. The decision will allow members of the A.C.L.U. to determine whether detainees require legal assistance. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: SUIT ON DETAINEES

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey filed a lawsuit against Hudson and Passaic Counties last week requesting the names of all Immigration and Naturalization detainees held in both counties' jails after the Sept. 11 attacks. The suit was prompted by the jails' refusal to disclose the names after several A.C.L.U. requests. Deborah Jacobs, executive director of the state A.C.L.U., said her organization's offer to legally represent detainees was being thwarted by the refusal. About half the Muslim men held since the Sept. 11 attacks are believed to be in county jails in New Jersey. Jo Piazza

headline.main: Complaint Seeks Data on Prisoners

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union, the Center for Constitutional Rights and three other organizations filed a federal civil complaint yesterday against the Pentagon and other government agencies, alleging that they illegally withheld information about the condition of prisoners in Iraq and Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The complaint, filed in federal court in Manhattan, claims the agencies violated the Freedom of Information Act by failing to respond to a request for documents that the groups filed in October. They sought information about the treatment of prisoners in military custody and reports of prisoners' deaths in Iraq.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; RULING ON DETAINEES

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge ruled yesterday that the Hudson and Passaic County jails should turn over the names and incarceration dates of immigration detainees held there under contract with the federal government in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The ruling, which the government plans to appeal, stems from a lawsuit filed in January by the American Civil Liberties of New Jersey in State Superior Court, after the government began detaining immigrants anonymously. A similar suit against the government is pending in federal court, but the New Jersey group sued the jails directly under state laws. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Rights Group Criticizes Terror Laws

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Amnesty International accused governments of violating civil liberties in the name of combating terrorism since the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. ''The United Nations member states, individually and collectively, have failed to uphold human rights,'' Colm O'Cuanachain, head of the group's international executive, said at a meeting of winners of the Nobel Peace Prize, which was awarded to Amnesty International in 1977. ''In response to the horrific human rights abuses of Sept. 11, governments are moving to restrict civil liberties and human rights, ostensibly to promote security,'' he said.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Groups Urge Delay On 'Charitable Choice'

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Forty-four religious, civil liberties, labor and education groups have sent a letter to President Bush urging him to postpone action on his ''charitable choice'' proposal to give government money to religious charities. The letter is a response to statements from White House advisers that the proposal has a better chance in the wake of the terrorist attacks. The groups, most of which already opposed the proposal, said, ''This is no time to divide us along religious lines.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: A.C.L.U. Intervenes For Muslim Scholar

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union asked a federal court in New York for a preliminary order to stop the administration from banning a prominent Swiss Muslim scholar from speaking in the United States. The scholar, Tariq Ramadan, has been barred from this country since his visa was revoked in July 2004, a week before he was scheduled to begin a job at the University of Notre Dame. Administration officials explained the action by citing a USA Patriot Act ban of foreigners who ''espouse terrorist activity.'' Mr. Ramadan has been invited to address a writers' conference in New York on April 25. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Panel To Debate Changes To Antiterror Law

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The Senate Intelligence Committee has scheduled a closed hearing on Thursday to begin debating possible changes to the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act. One item under consideration, officials said, is a long-sought expansion of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's ability to issue subpoenas demanding records in intelligence investigations without getting approval from a judge. Committee officials said that the debate would be held in closed session because lawmakers planned to discuss classified intelligence operations and that the committee would issue a public report on the session. The American Civil Liberties Union protested the process, saying legislative debate should not ''be kept secret from the public.'' Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

headline.main: Detainee Files Sought

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union and its New York branch returned to federal court yesterday in a new effort to force the Bush administration to release documents about the detention of prisoners at Abu Ghraib in Iraq, Guantánamo Bay in Cuba and other military-run facilities. The motion, in the Southern District in Manhattan, asked the court to order the prompt release of the documents. It came eight months after the groups first filed a Freedom of Information Act request for the documents. In May the groups filed a new request, but the Defense Department and other agencies said they would not speed up their processing.

headline.main: Illinois: Ruling On Watch Lists

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: A federal magistrate judge in Chicago has ruled that protecting state secrets is not a valid argument for the government to refuse to tell American citizens whether they are on the terrorism watch list, the Terrorist Screening Database. The ruling, signed on April 16 but made public by the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois on Wednesday, ordered the Department of Homeland Security and the F.B.I. to give the court the files regarding the 10 Muslim or Arab-American plaintiffs who filed a lawsuit starting in 2005, seeking court protection from what they contend is unwarranted harassment at the border. The magistrate judge, Sidney I. Schenkier of Federal District Court, said the court could review the information to decide whether it should remain classified. The F.B.I. said it had no comment.

headline.main: Some Foresee A Sea Change In Attitudes On Freedoms

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The political pressure to do something anything -- to ensure that there is never a repeat of this week's terrorist attacks is immense on Capitol Hill. And civil liberties advocates are watching with quiet concern. Across the political spectrum, lawmakers are arguing that the United States has entered a new and more dangerous era that demands heightened security measures, including armed guards on commercial airliners and greater surveillance powers for federal agents.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Group Sues Over Security Records

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union's New Jersey office filed a public records lawsuit yesterday to discover how municipalities determined potential threats in their applications for federal Homeland Security Department grants. The A.C.L.U. wants to know whether anyone was singled out because of legitimate political activity. The group also accuses former state Attorney General Peter C. Harvey of misleading them in his response to an earlier lawsuit seeking the information. He called the accusation ''as frivolous as it is silly.'' RONALD SMOTHERS (NYT)

headline.main: Suit Takes Aim at Rules On Immigrant Workers

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Central Labor Council of Alameda County in California, the American Civil Liberties Union and other legal groups filed a lawsuit challenging new rules from the Department of Homeland Security that would force employers to fire illegal immigrant workers. The rules, announced Aug. 10, give employers 90 days to dismiss workers whose Social Security numbers do not match the records of the Social Security Administration. The suit charges that because there are inaccuracies in the agency's records, the rules would threaten jobs of American citizens and legal immigrants. It seeks to stop the agency from sending out a round of letters to employers starting next Tuesday that would include a notice about the new rules.

headline.main: ACLU Asks Appeals Court to Undo Phone Data Ruling
headline.print_headline: ACLU Asks Appeals Court to Undo Phone Data Ruling

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court should outlaw the National Security Agency's collection of millions of Americans' telephone records, concentrating searches instead on terror suspects, civil liberties lawyers said in papers filed seeking a reversal of a lower-court judge who ruled the program was legal and necessary to fight terrorism.

headline.main: A Familiar Battle Fought and Won
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURITY AND LIBERTY

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers today hailed the antiterrorism legislation passed by Congress as an appropriate balance between civil liberties and the heightened security needs of a nation at risk. But civil liberties advocates asserted that the new law jeopardized fundamental rights and would require vigilant oversight to keep the authorities in line. Law enforcement authorities said they would move quickly to capitalize on new powers for the investigation, surveillance and detention of suspected terrorists.

headline.main: Judge Delays Order to Identify Detainees Until Appeals Ruling

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after a federal judge ordered the Justice Department to reveal the names of hundreds of people detained in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the same judge ruled today that the names did not have to be made public immediately. In a victory for the Bush administration's effort to keep the names secret, the judge, Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington, issued a stay of her original order and said the names need not be disclosed before an appeals court ruled on the issue, which could take weeks or months.

headline.main: F.B.I. Leader Wins a Few At Meeting Of A.C.L.U.

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation wandered into a lion's den of critics today and emerged, for the most part, unscathed. In a speech before more than 1,400 avowed ''card carrying'' members of the American Civil Liberties Union, the director, Robert S. Mueller III, declared that the F.B.I. and the A.C.L.U. -- though often at odds -- shared a common bond of respect for the Constitution and for civil liberties. He even co-opted one of the group's slogans, saying that in the fight against terrorism, the nation must be ''both safe and free.''

headline.main: A.C.L.U. Gains in Its Quest for C.I.A. Documents on Detainees

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: A federal district judge in Manhattan told the Central Intelligence Agency yesterday that it could not invoke any blanket exemption from requirements to disclose internal documents under the Freedom of Information Act. He ordered the agency to move toward releasing documents about its interrogation of prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan and at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The judge, Alvin K. Hellerstein, was impatient with the C.I.A.'s contention that it enjoyed such protections from the act, known as FOIA. Judge Hellerstein also rejected the agency's argument that it could not handle the administrative burden of searching for prisoner documents.

headline.main: A Frustrated A.C.L.U. Tries to Guide Consulates Through a Thicket

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: When it arrived at Pakistan's consulate in New York recently, the letter offered welcome help to officials worn out by desperate calls from Pakistanis in detention. It said it was ''to offer our assistance'' to people who have been held by the American government since Sept. 11. ''We are particularly interested,'' the letter continued, ''in highlighting instances of abuse by our government and in developing systematic litigation to challenge its unconstitutional practices.''

headline.main: Senate Bill Would End NSA Phone Records Collection
headline.print_headline: Senate Bill Would End NSA Phone Records Collection

Civil Liberties.lead_paragraph: Sen. Patrick Leahy on Tuesday introduced a bill to end the National Security Agency's bulk collection of phone records, a proposal that goes further than a similar House measure and has drawn support from civil liberties groups, the White House and Republicans.

headline.main: POET LAUREATE CONTROVERSY

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, spent much of his week defending a poem he wrote about the Sept. 11 attacks, a poem that had Governor McGreevey calling for his resignation. The work, ''Somebody Blew Up America,'' implies that Israel knew about the attacks in advance. Mr. Baraka said that he would not resign and that the facts in his poem can be verified. There is no state law that can remove Mr. Baraka, 67, from the post but aides to Governor McGreevey said they would continue to urge him to resign. John Holl

headline.main: LAUREATE HAS ANOTHER JOB

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka, the New Jersey poet laureate, is still under fire for a poem he wrote about the terrorist attacks, but the Newark Public School Board has hired him as the district's poet laureate, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported last week. Mr. Baraka's poem ''Somebody Blew Up America'' implies that Israel knew about the attacks in advance. Many Newark officials praised the appointment and Mr. Baraka continued to say that he would not resign from the state post. But aides to Governor McGreevey said they would continue to urge him to quit. John Holl

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Bill Seeks End Of Poet Post

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year since outrage over a Sept. 11 poem prompted calls to remove the state's poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, the Assembly will consider a bill this week to abolish the position. Under state law, Mr. Baraka, left, cannot be dismissed. Because he has refused to step down, lawmakers want to eliminate the post. The Senate has already approved a bill to dissolve the position, but both houses must agree on the legislation. A spokesman for Gov. James E. McGreevey said the governor supported the concept but wanted to see the final version of the bill before agreeing to sign it. In his poem ''Somebody Blew Up America,'' Mr. Baraka implied that some Israelis had advance knowledge of the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: McGreevey Seeks Power To Dismiss State Poet

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey will seek authorization from the New Jersey Legislature to fire the state's poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, over a poem about the attack on the World Trade Center that has been widely criticized as anti-Semitic, a spokesman for the governor said yesterday. The spokesman, Kevin Davitt, said the governor's staff was working last night with legislators to draft a bill that may be introduced as early as today. Although the precise language remained undetermined, Mr. Davitt said, ''It would give the governor power to terminate the reign of the current poet laureate.''

headline.main: NJ Wake Set for Activist Poet-Writer Amiri Baraka
headline.print_headline: NJ Wake Set for Activist Poet-Writer Amiri Baraka

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will be among those honoring activist poet-playwright Amiri Baraka at a wake in New Jersey.

headline.main: Senate Panel Moves to Abolish State Poet Laureate Position

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey appointed Amiri Baraka as New Jersey's poet laureate without much of a hubbub in the fall. But the task of removing Mr. Baraka, now that he stands accused of reciting an anti-Semitic poem, has proved to be a great deal more difficult and time-consuming. Faced with the judgment of government lawyers that Mr. Baraka could be fired, a State Senate committee took the first step today toward abolishing the position of poet laureate outright, with the idea that New Jersey should be supporting the arts in general, not individual artists.

headline.main: New Jersey Assembly Votes To Cut Embattled Poet's Job

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey General Assembly approved a measure today to eliminate the post of state poet laureate. The legislation would effectively remove the poet, Amiri Baraka, who had caused a furor with his poem referring to the 9/11 attacks. The 69-to-2 vote sends the bill to Gov. James E. McGreevey, who has vigorously denounced Mr. Baraka for the poem, which suggests that Israelis knew about the terrorist plot in advance.

headline.main: Poet Laureate Returns Critics' Rage

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The revolutionaries, with a little more gray in the hair and a little less grip in the fist, had come down to the Bowery to support the poet. They believed the man had him up against the wall. ''They have slandered me,'' said Amiri Baraka, 68, the poet laureate of New Jersey. ''They have created a situation where I will be known and characterized this way for the rest of my life.''

headline.main: McGreevey Could Fire Poet Under Proposed Legislation

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of legislators said today that they would introduce measures that would give Gov. James E. McGreevey the power to strip Amiri Baraka of his position as New Jersey's poet laureate. Mr. McGreevey, among others, has called for Mr. Baraka's resignation because of a poem he wrote after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The poem repeated a rumor that Israel knew in advance of the attacks and warned its citizens to stay away from the World Trade Center.

headline.main: New Jersey Laureate Refuses to Resign Over Poem

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: A month after Amiri Baraka became the poet laureate of New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey asked the writer and political activist to resign yesterday because a poem he read at a recent poetry festival implies that Israel knew about the Sept. 11 attack in advance. But Mr. Baraka said he would not resign, creating an unusual political quandary. Aides to the governor said he did not have the power to remove Mr. Baraka because Mr. McGreevey had not directly selected him. And a member of the committee of poets and cultural officials who chose Mr. Baraka said that group had no power to remove him either.

headline.main: Poet Laureate Stands By Words Against Israel and Won't Step Down

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka, the state's poet laureate, stood on the podium at a literary festival here today to say that he would not heed Gov. James E. McGreevey's demand that he step down for writing a poem that implied that Israel knew in advance about the attack on the World Trade Center. Before a mostly supportive crowd of about 200 in a stately hall of the Newark Public Library, Mr. Baraka said his critics were attempting to ''repress and stigmatize independent thinkers everywhere.''

headline.main: Criticized Poet Is Named Laureate of Newark Schools

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: In an act of defiance aimed at the state's political establishment, the school board here has anointed Amiri Baraka the district's poet laureate at a time the state is trying to take the same designation away from him. The unanimous vote by the nine-member advisory board comes as Mr. Baraka, the poet laureate of New Jersey, is under fire for a poem he wrote last year suggesting that Israel had advance knowledge of the plot to attack the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Our Towns; New Jersey's Unrepentant Poet of Outrage and Indignation

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: JUST before Gov. James E. McGreevey introduced Amiri Baraka last month as New Jersey's new poet laureate, the celebrated and controversial activist writer said he warned the governor this might happen. ''I said, 'Governor, you're going to catch a lot of hell for this,' '' Mr. Baraka said. ''He said, 'I don't care.' I said, 'If you don't care, I don't care.' ''

headline.main: When Poetry Seems to Matter

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: FROM a large brown house with bars on the lower windows, Amiri Baraka sends forth a stream of poems, statements and broadsides to the world. As usual, Mr. Baraka, the state's outspoken poet laureate, is busy. When not writing and publishing, he is often traveling or talking -- about racism, injustice and the political feuds in which he has grappled firsthand over the past four decades.

headline.main: Politics and Poetry Are Volatile Mix in New Jersey

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: If poetry is the art of finding the transcendent in everyday experience, then Amiri Baraka, New Jersey's poet laureate, has given the state more than it ever bargained for. Nearly a year ago, Mr. Baraka set off a furor by reading a poem suggesting that Israelis had been warned about the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Now, as the New Jersey Legislature works to cobble together the matter of a $24 billion budget, lawmakers are also trying to delicately maneuver through another political thicket: what to do about the state's embattled poet laureate.

headline.main: Daughter of Controversial Poet Is Killed at Her Sister's Home

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The 31-year-old daughter of Amiri Baraka, the poet, playwright and civil rights activist, and a friend were found murdered late Tuesday night in the home of another of Mr. Baraka's children in Piscataway, N.J., the authorities said yesterday. The victims, Shani Baraka, and Rayshon Holmes, 30, were shot several times and were found in the family room of the house owned by Ms. Baraka's older sister, Wanda Pasha, the Middlesex County prosecutor, Bruce Kaplan, said.

headline.main: I'll Never Forget 2002, a Laugh a Minute

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: PERHAPS the now-departed 2002 has already faded from your memory. (''2002 -- wasn't that the year the Devils, or maybe it was the Nets, almost won something?'') If so, you are doing 2002 a grave disservice, because careful journalistic analysis shows that it was in fact the year we New Jerseyans showed the world that anything is possible. It was, for instance, the year we demonstrated that poetry can actually be interesting. Newsworthy, even.

headline.main: Activist Poet-Playwright Amiri Baraka Dies at 79
headline.print_headline: Activist Poet-Playwright Amiri Baraka Dies at 79

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka, the militant man of letters and tireless agitator whose blues-based, fist-shaking poems, plays and criticism made him a provocative and groundbreaking force in American culture, has died. He was 79.

headline.main: A Return to Rage, Played Out in Black and White

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: HISTORY seemed summoned to one of its spotlight moments on March 24, 1964, when Amiri Baraka's ''Dutchman'' had its premiere at the Cherry Lane Theater in New York. He was little known outside the studied bohemian precincts of the Greenwich Village poetry scene; but this short, brutal play about the fatal confrontation between a black man and a white woman on a subway made him famous, respected and despised. Edward Albee was among the three producers. It won an Obie. He was called ''King of the East Village'' by The New York Herald Tribune Sunday magazine. At the time, though, he hadn't yet changed his name to Amiri Baraka from LeRoi Jones. The actress Cicely Tyson was in the audience on opening night. ''I remember her yelling, 'Yeah, yeah,' '' said Mr. Baraka's former wife, the poet and writer Hettie Jones.

headline.main: Activist Poet-Playwright Amiri Baraka Dies at 79
headline.print_headline: Activist Poet-Playwright Amiri Baraka Dies at 79

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka, the militant man of letters and tireless agitator whose blues-based, fist-shaking poems, plays and criticism made him a provocative and groundbreaking force in American culture, has died. He was 79.

headline.main: Verses From bin Laden's War: Wielding the Pen as a Sword of the Jihad

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: The poem is a tale of betrayal, exile and siege, cast as a mournful conversation between father and son. ''Why, father, have they sent these missiles, thick as rain,'' the child asks, ''showing mercy neither to a child, nor to a man shattered by old age?'' ''It is a world of criminality, my son,'' the father laments, ''where children are, like cattle, slaughtered.''

headline.main: In Shelley or Auden, in the Sonnet or Free Verse, The Eerily Intimate Power of Poetry to Console

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Bits of famous poems, original poems, snatches of verse pinned alongside photos of the victims. In the weeks since the terrorist attacks, people have been consoling themselves -- and one another -- with poetry in an almost unprecedented way. Almost immediately after the event, improvised memorials often conceived around poems sprang up all over the city, in store windows, at bus stops, in Washington Square Park, Brooklyn Heights and elsewhere. And poems flew through cyberspace across the country in e-mails from friend to friend. On the day of the disaster, someone sent a copy of Shelley's ''Ozymandias'' to a circle of friends and suggested that if the World Trade Center were ever to be rebuilt, it should bear a plaque with the inscription ''My name is Ozymandias, king of kings:/ Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!''

headline.main: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW -- Amid the escalating violence in Syria and a diplomatic outcry over Russia's actions blocking intervention by the United Nations, President Dmitri A. Medvedev bestowed a prestigious cultural award on a Syrian writer and poet who has publicly applauded the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and expressed strong anti-Semitic views. The writer, Ali Ukla Ursan, also known for close ties to Russia, was one of 11 foreign honorees to receive prestigious awards for their close ties to Russia at a ceremony last week at Mr. Medvedev's presidential residence.

headline.seo: Medvedev Honors Ali Ukla Ursan, a Controversial Syrian Writer
headline.main: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian
headline.print_headline: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: Ali Ukla Ursan, who received the Pushkin Medal, has publicly applauded the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and expressed strong anti-Semitic views.

headline.main: Poetry of Praise for New York City

Amiri Baraka.lead_paragraph: In his poem ''Mannahatta,'' Walt Whitman characterized that aboriginal name for New York City as ''liquid, sane, unruly, self-sufficient.'' Taking its title from another line in that Whitman poem, the Poetry Society of America on Tuesday presented ''The Words of My City,'' an anthology of New Yorkers reading New York poems. Whitman's seemingly contradictory words echoed through the evening. The event, organized by Alice Quinn, executive director of the Poetry Society and the poetry editor of The New Yorker, took place in the Great Hall at Cooper Union and, she said, was intended ''as an evening of many arts centered around poetry of the city.'' The readers included poets (Richard Howard, Sapphire, Willie Perdomo) as well as the choreographer Mark Morris (reading Frank O'Hara) and the actress Maria Tucci. Stephin Merritt played the ukulele and sang songs of the city.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Limited Insurance For Golden Gate

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Annual insurance premiums for San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge will double, to $1.1 million, and coverage for terrorist attacks will end when its policy is renewed on Monday. Of more than 20 insurers approached, only two offered limited terrorism coverage, and at high rates, so the bridge's board opted to keep the current insurer, ACE USA. Catherine Billey (NYT)

headline.main: MARSH & MCLENNAN, INSURANCE BROKER, FORMS NEW FIRM

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, said yesterday that it was forming a new company to deal with industry cutbacks in coverage that have occurred since the Sept. 11 attacks. The new firm, to be called Axis Specialty Ltd., is being created to capitalize on the shortage of services as insurance companies are hit by losses stemming from the attacks, Marsh & McLennan said. The attacks are expected to be the most expensive disaster for the insurance industry, with costs expected to exceed the record $20 billion payout from Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arguing Over 9/11 Insurance

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, suffered a legal setback this week in his attempt to recover more than $7 billion in insurance for the Sept. 11 terror attack. Mr. Silverstein has argued that he is entitled to two $3.6 billion payments for two separate attacks on the two buildings; the insurers argue it was one attack. But a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that employees at Willis, Mr. Silverstein's insurance broker, must testify about conversations last fall with Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. The insurers suspect that Mr. Silverstein and the broker initially considered the destruction a single event for insurance purposes. Lawyers for Swiss Re, one of the insurance companies, could start deposing Willis brokers next week. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

headline.main: Sales Are Resumed for Coverage of Airlines for Terror Damage

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Aviation insurers resumed selling war and terrorism coverage to airlines around the world yesterday, four days after governments stepped in to provide temporary coverage to prevent a shutdown of flights worldwide. The new coverage is expected to cost the airlines an extra $1.5 billion to $3 billion a year, depending on their passenger loads, insurance industry executives said.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: European airlines must return to commercial insurers to cover the war and terror risks that have been guaranteed by governments since the Sept. 11 attacks, the European Commission said. A commission spokesman, Gilles Gantelet, said European states would no longer provide insurance guarantees after Oct. 31.

headline.main: Insurers Are Ready to Fight to Keep Federal Backing of Terrorism Coverage

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Insurance and business groups are gearing up for a battle to preserve a government program that would cover most of the losses from another major terrorist attack. After Sept. 11, 2001, President Bush campaigned for the program to shield insurers from the bulk of the cost of an attack up to $100 billion. Without such backing, few insurers were willing to sell the coverage.

headline.main: Former U.S. Security Chief Launches Cyber Crime Insurance
headline.print_headline: Former U.S. Security Chief Launches Cyber Crime Insurance

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Former U.S. Homeland Security secretary Tom Ridge has launched a cyber crime insurance product in collaboration with syndicates operating at the Lloyd's of London insurance market, Ridge's new insurance firm said on Monday.

headline.main: Insurers Are Taking Advantage Of New York, City Official Says

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., confirmed yesterday what New York businesspeople have been saying for more than a year: insurance prices are soaring. But Mr. Thompson said a survey he conducted shows that insurance prices have risen more in New York than elsewhere in the country, and he asserted that insurers were taking advantage of the city.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurer Files For Bankruptcy

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The Taisei Fire and Marine Insurance Company, Japan's 12th-largest casualty insurer, filed for bankruptcy yesterday because of claims stemming from the terrorist attacks in the United States. The insurer, which planned to merge with Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance and Nissan Fire and Marine Insurance next April, said its liabilities exceeded assets by 40 billion yen ($325 million). The company held 74 billion yen ($602 million) in claims related to the attacks in September, analysts estimated. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline.main: U.S. Is Urged to Be Selective on Terrorism Insurance

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: An executive of a leading consumer advocacy group called yesterday for the government to take a highly selective approach to protecting businesses against big losses from terrorist attacks, saying that terrorism insurance was widely available from commercial carriers. Only in cases of prominent buildings in New York and other large cities should the government back terrorism insurance policies, J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said in an interview.

headline.main: For Insurers, Some Failures And Rate Jumps

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center will cause the cost of commercial coverage to rise by at least 20 percent as insurers struggle to recoup losses in the worst insurance disaster in history, insurers and analysts said yesterday. Even then, they said, some insurance companies are certain to fail under the burden of claims that may run as high as $30 billion to $40 billion.

headline.main: Airlines May Create Own Insurance Plan

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: With the market for war liability insurance for airlines all but dried up since Sept. 11, the nation's major carriers are discussing the creation of their own insurance company. Working with an insurance unit of Marsh & McLennan Companies, the Air Transport Association, an industry group based in Washington, has developed a proposal that would provide airlines with as much as $1.5 billion in third-party war liability coverage. The industry-run policy could go into effect as early as next month.

headline.main: A Proposal for Federal Protection From Catastrophe Divides Insurers

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Even as profits on home insurance are soaring, some of the nation's big insurers are turning to Washington in a bid to gain protection against future catastrophic losses. The two biggest companies, Allstate and State Farm, which provide nearly 35 percent of the insurance on American homes, are seeking legislation that would offer the same kind of program for hurricanes and other natural disasters as the government now promises to provide to commercial insurers in a future terrorism attack.

headline.main: Consumer Group Has Plan For Managing Insurers' Loss

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: With skepticism in Congress deepening over proposals that the government pay a major share of insurance costs from future terrorist attacks, a new proposal from a consumer group would help insurers manage their losses with long-term federal loans. After an early widespread sentiment that the insurance industry, which lost about $40 billion in the World Trade Center attack, needed help, many in Congress are now beginning to wonder why insurers cannot, indeed, cover the costs of future attacks. They have an estimated $300 billion in capital. If help is provided, sentiment is growing for the insurers to pay for a substantial amount of the losses from the start.

headline.main: Holder of Trade Center Lease Settles With Two Insurers

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The holder of the lease to the World Trade Center complex, Larry A. Silverstein, announced yesterday that he had settled a dispute with two of the companies insuring the complex. Under the terms of the settlement, one insurer, Ace Bermuda Insurance Ltd., will pay $298 million and the other, XL Insurance Ltd., also of Bermuda, will pay $67 million.

headline.main: Insurers Say 2001 Brought First Overall Loss

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Car, home and business insurers -- battered by poor investment returns and claims from the World Trade Center attacks -- suffered their first annual overall loss last year, according to a report released yesterday by two industry groups. Property-casualty insurers, including State Farm, Allstate, the American International Group and Travelers Property Casualty, lost $7.9 billion over all in 2001, compared with a $20.6 billion profit in 2000.

headline.main: Terror Attacks Often Covered By Insurance, A Report Says

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Insurance coverage for a terrorist attack like the one in New York on 9/11 has expanded significantly in the last five years as a result of a government program that pays for the bulk of the damage, a Bush administration report said yesterday. But the report said there was virtually no coverage available for most of the damage that would come from a nuclear attack or one carried out with chemical or biological weapons.

headline.main: Consumer Groups Unite To Track Insurance Prices

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: With premiums soaring for almost every kind of insurance, more than 60 consumer organizations around the country have banded together to mount a campaign against what they regard as price gouging. The consumer groups have named their organization Americans for Insurance Reform and say that by uniting they expect to have a stronger voice and to be more quickly able to gather information on developments in insurance, which is regulated state by state.

headline.main: Another Blow to Airlines and Their Insurers

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: The crash of the American Airlines passenger jet in New York yesterday is expected to further increase the cost of insurance for the airlines, which were already facing steep increases as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, industry experts said. The experts estimated that the crash yesterday would cost insurers at least $1 billion, bringing their losses to about $7 billion since Sept. 11, when four passenger jets were hijacked and crashed.

headline.main: Industries Welcome U.S. Aid on Terror Insurance

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Deborah Beck sighed with relief yesterday. For 14 months Ms. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a powerful trade group, had been spearheading a campaign on behalf of the great buildings of New York -- places like the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building -- as well as scores of huge but less-distinguished buildings. The buildings' owners and lenders all wanted terrorism insurance, she said, but they could not get enough -- or, in some cases, any at all.

headline.main: Senate Acts To Provide Coverage To Airlines

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Congress overwhelmingly acted yesterday to insure the nation's airlines against war and terrorism for 180 days, averting a threatened halt to all flights. Private insurers refused to sell the airlines sufficient coverage to continue flying after last week's terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Lost-Income Claims May Exceed $10 Billion

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Claims by businesses for lost income and relocation expenses may run to more than $10 billion, insurance industry analysts say, possibly exceeding the direct costs of the damage to destroyed buildings and the hundreds of offices inside. These extraordinary expenses are expected to significantly raise business insurance rates around the nation. Because of the high stakes, lawyers are already collecting evidence for their clients' claims in anticipation of long battles with insurers. But at least so far, both lawyers and insurers have promised to curb some of their most contentious tactics.

headline.main: Moody's Sees Risks in Threats to Landmarks

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: In another indication of financial concerns about the threat of terrorist attacks in New York and other cities, a leading bond-rating agency said yesterday that it was reviewing its ratings on $5 billion in loans on about a dozen big commercial buildings and groups of buildings, including the Rockefeller Center complex. Most of the buildings are in Manhattan, like the Condé Nast building at 4 Times Square. But also among them are the Columbia Center, the tallest building in Seattle, and the Sun America tower in Los Angeles.

headline.main: Compromise May Extend Terrorism Insurance Aid

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: A compromise appears to be taking shape to extend a federal program that would pay most of the commercial insurance losses in a major terrorist attack, easing months of uncertainty about the program's future. A proposal outlined by Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, and backed by Republican leaders in Congress, would increase costs for insurance companies and reduce the range of coverage. But the insurers are willing to consider those changes as a trade-off for achieving their main goal: the extension of the program that requires the government to pay the bulk of insurance losses in a terrorist attack up to $100 billion.

headline.main: Europeans Consider Terror Insurance Venture

Insurance Losses.lead_paragraph: Three of Europe's biggest insurance companies are in talks to set up a Luxembourg-based joint venture that would provide partial insurance coverage for terror-attack risks in Europe, perhaps with government backing. Allianz of Germany, Swiss Re and Zurich Financial Services are involved in the talks.

headline.main: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; DOCUMENTS CLASSIFIED

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Richard C. Reid, the man who admitted trying to sabotage a transatlantic flight by igniting explosives hidden in his shoes, will not be allowed access to classified documents in his case, a federal judge in Boston has ruled. A lawyer for Mr. Reid argued that by allowing him access to the documents and presenting them at his sentencing hearing the public would ''hear the other side of the story.'' Only lawyers and the judge, William Young, have seen the documents, the details of which have not been disclosed. Mr. Reid, who pleaded guilty in October, will be sentenced Jan. 30. The government has recommended that Mr. Reid, who has admitted to being a member of Al Qaeda, receive life in prison. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

headline.main: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; SHOE-BOMBER PLEA

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The man accused of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives hidden in his shoes pleaded guilty to all eight charges against him, including attempted murder. Richard Colvin Reid, a British citizen, admitted to prosecutors that he was a member of Al Qaeda. Officials called it the first successful prosecution of a Qaeda member in the U.S. Pam Belluck

headline.main: Camera Captures Crisis on Flight 63

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Joly was sitting a few rows behind Richard C. Reid on American Airlines flight 63 from Paris to Miami on Dec. 22 when the plane erupted in confusion after Mr. Reid tried to light a fuse coming out of his sneaker. Mr. Joly, 62, the owner of a technology company in Toulouse, grabbed his digital camera and captured the scene in these photos, which he made available to The New York Times on Friday. First, above, about eight passengers used belts and earphone wires to tie up Mr. Reid as other passengers watched. They would later say they thought he was drunk.

headline.main: Suicide Watch for Man Found to Have Explosives in Shoe on Jet

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The man who is thought to have tried to blow up a jetliner with explosives hidden in his shoes was under suicide watch today, and British officials said they believe he was born in England. The man, identified as Richard C. Reid, remained under the suicide watch at the Plymouth County House of Correction pending a psychological examination, said Timothy Bane, chief deputy of the United States marshal's office.

headline.main: Prosecutors See Plot in Attempted Bombing
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE SHOE BOMB CASE

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: There is evidence that the man accused of trying to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight with bombs hidden in his sneakers did not act alone, according to court documents filed today. A memorandum by federal prosecutors in the case of the man, Richard C. Reid, stated that ''an examination of one of the explosive devices in Reid's shoes disclosed evidence of a confederate (or confederates).''

headline.main: Qaeda Man Pleads Guilty To Flying With Shoe Bomb
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE SHOE BOMB CASE

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Admitting membership in Al Qaeda, Richard C. Reid pleaded guilty today to charges of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight in December with explosives hidden in his shoes. Mr. Reid's statement delighted federal officials, who said it represented the first successful prosecution in the United States of a member of the terrorist group. But his exact role was unclear.

headline.main: Man Accused of Shoe-Bomb Plot Says He Intends to Plead Guilty
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE SHOE-BOMB SUSPECT

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The man accused of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives hidden in his shoes filed a motion today saying he intended to plead guilty to all the charges against him. The man, Richard Colvin Reid, had been scheduled to go on trial on Nov. 4 to face eight counts, including attempted murder and attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction, and prosecutors were caught by surprise by the move. Justice Department officials said Mr. Reid's motion did not involve any plea deal, meaning that he still faces a potential sentence of life in prison for his role in the harrowing incident on Dec. 22.

headline.main: Officials Remain Uncertain On Identity of Suspect on Jet

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said today that the man who tried to ignite explosives in his shoes on a flight from Paris to Miami on Saturday had no known address, and investigators in the United States and Europe struggled to determine his identity, nationality and motive. In Paris today, the French border police were at pains to explain how they let the man onto American Airlines Flight 63, after they detained him for questioning on Friday because he tried to board the same flight without baggage. They finally decided to let him fly, but since the delay made him miss his flight, he stayed at a hotel near the airport and caught the same flight on Saturday without hindrance.

headline.main: Man Charged As Accomplice In 'Shoe' Case

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: A British man arrested last week in southwestern England was charged Wednesday with conspiring with the convicted ''shoe bomber,'' Richard C. Reid, in an explosives plot, the police said. The suspect, Sajid Badat, was charged with three offenses, including that from Sept. 1, 2001, to Nov. 28, 2003, he ''unlawfully and maliciously conspired with Richard Reid and others unknown'' to cause an explosion ''likely to endanger life or cause serious injury'' in Britain or elsewhere.

headline.main: Reports Narrow Down Movements Of Man With the Plastic Explosives

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Investigators in Europe and the United States were trying today to establish the movements of Richard C. Reid, a 28-year-old Briton, in the days and weeks before he was suspected of having tried to blow up a trans-Atlantic airliner with explosives hidden in his shoes. In Washington, federal law-enforcement officials said today that the material found in Mr. Reid's black suede basketball sneakers appeared to contain PETN, or pentaerythritol tetranitrate, a chemical ingredient in plastic explosives. They said its use suggested fairly sophisticated knowledge of such materials by Mr. Reid or any accomplices.

headline.main: Unrepentant Shoe Bomber Is Given a Life Sentence For Trying to Blow Up Jet
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE BOMB PLOT

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Richard C. Reid, who said he was a member of Al Qaeda and pleaded guilty to trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives concealed in his shoes, was sentenced today to life in prison. Mr. Reid was unrepentant and confrontational, telling Judge William G. Young of Federal District Court, ''I am at war with your country'' and saying, ''I further admit my allegiance to Sheik Osama bin Laden, to Islam and to the religion of Allah.''

headline.main: AL QAEDA TRAINED BOMBING SUSPECT, INDICTMENT SAYS
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BOMBING SUSPECT

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Richard Reid, who was overpowered on a Paris-to-Miami flight last month as he tried to light explosives in his shoes, was a Qaeda-trained terrorist who tried to bring down an airliner carrying nearly 200 people, according to a federal grand jury indictment filed in Boston today. The nine-count indictment, which includes charges of attempted murder and attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction, said Mr. Reid, a 28-year-old British citizen, was trained at ''various times'' in Afghanistan. The indictment provided no other details about Mr. Reid's ties to Osama bin Laden's Qaeda network but made it clear that prosecutors regarded him as a terrorist.

headline.main: Crew Criticizes Airline's Training on Bomb Threats
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: SHOE BOMB CASE

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Crew members aboard the Paris-to-Miami jet that stopped a man accused of carrying a bomb in his shoes admitted they made mistakes, including carrying the shoes into the cockpit. One crew member said that yanking the shoes off the feet of the suspect, Richard C. Reid, and bringing them into the American Airlines cockpit ''was the dumbest thing I ever did.''

headline.main: Shoes Were a 'Homemade Bomb,' F.B.I. Agent Says

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: A federal investigator testified today that Richard C. Reid's sneakers, which he is suspected of trying to ignite on a trans-Atlantic jetliner last Saturday, were a ''homemade bomb'' containing a highly unstable explosive powerful enough to have blown a hole in the plane. The explosive, triacetone triperoxide, or TATP, is used almost exclusively by terrorists and favored by Palestinian bomb makers, experts say. But it is so volatile that several bomb makers have been killed by accidental explosions of their own creations.

headline.main: U.S. Charges British Suspect In Bomb Plot

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: American law enforcement officials filed charges on Monday against a British man, saying he plotted to blow up airliners in concert with Richard C. Reid, a fellow Briton caught aboard a trans-Atlantic flight with bombs inside his shoes in late 2001. The suspect, Sajid Mohammed Badat, 25, was charged with conspiracy to destroy an aircraft and other charges in a seven-count federal indictment that was unsealed Monday. He would face life in prison if convicted in an American court.

headline.main: Faintly Connected Dots Portray a Qaeda Man

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: As investigators retrace the movements of Richard C. Reid, the drifter who is accused of trying to blow up an American Airlines plane last month with an explosive in his sneakers, they are becoming increasingly convinced that he carried cash and messages for Al Qaeda across Europe and the Middle East. Senior French intelligence officials said the pattern of Mr. Reid's travels to more than half a dozen countries during the past year, his habit of paying for tickets and hotels in cash and his stint at a training camp in Afghanistan strongly suggested that he was a low-level courier for Osama bin Laden's terrorist network.

headline.main: The Shadowy Trail And Shift to Islam Of a Bomb Suspect

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: He is a gangling giant of a man with immigrant roots in Jamaica, a record of crime and a sense that his Christian upbringing was not enough to shield him from the violence, poverty and racial bias of south London. The profile fits Richard C. Reid, 28, the man accused of trying to ignite explosives-packed sneakers on American Airlines flight 63 from Paris to Miami on Dec. 22. It also fits his father, Robin C. Reid, 51, a man with whom he had little contact growing up but whose life seemed to be a model for the son's -- until last week.

headline.main: Shoe-Bomb Suspect Linked With E-Mail Across Europe

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The shoe-bomber suspect Richard C. Reid was in e-mail contact with supporters across Europe in the days before he flew to the United States, a person close to the investigation said today. The disclosure came as the newspaper La Provence reported that Mr. Reid, who has been indicted in federal court in Boston, might have left a note claiming responsibility for a planned attack on his flight from Paris to Miami on Dec. 22, to be published in the event he did blow up the plane and died in the process.

headline.main: Prosecutors Concede Doubts About Moussaoui's Story

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The prosecution acknowledged on Thursday that even the government's chief investigators did not believe the claim of Zacarias Moussaoui that Richard C. Reid, known as the shoe bomber, was to help him fly a jetliner into the White House on Sept. 11, 2001. The jury, which is considering whether to order either the death penalty or life imprisonment for Mr. Moussaoui, was presented with a document saying Federal Bureau of Investigation analysts had agreed that Mr. Reid was never meant to be part of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: G.O.P. Attacks Reid Over Comments
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Attacks Reid Over Comments

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Republicans sought to compare racially charged remarks attributed to Harry Reid as similar to those made in 2002 by Trent Lott, the G.O.P. leader who was forced to resign.

headline.main: Terrorism Warning for Airlines Focuses on Shoes and Clothing

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: The Homeland Security Department has issued a new terrorism warning to airlines and state and local law enforcement agencies after a police raid in Britain last week turned up evidence suggesting that Al Qaeda might try again to place explosives in shoes or clothing, law enforcement officials said on Friday. They said the British police had found residue of explosives in socks belonging to a 24-year-old British man who was arrested on charges of conspiring with Richard C. Reid, the Qaeda member who tried to blow up a passenger plane over the Atlantic in December 2001 with explosives in his shoes.

headline.main: U.S. Issues Warning About Shoe Bombs on Airplanes Bound for U.S.
headline.print_headline: U.S. Issues Warning About Shoe Bombs on Airplanes Bound for U.S.

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: U.S. authorities issued a warning on Wednesday to airlines flying to the United States to watch out for militants who may have hidden bombs in their shoes, U.S. government sources said.

headline.main: G.O.P. Eyes Tough Task: Winning Reid's Seat

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, has emerged as a tempting target for Republicans as he prepares for re-election next year: unpopular at home, identified with partisan battles in Washington and shadowed by the memory of the election defeat suffered by the last Democrat who held his job, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. ''We view this race as highly competitive, if not the most highly competitive race for a seat held by a Democratic incumbent today,'' said Randy Bumps, political director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

headline.seo: At Adis Medunjanin’s Terror Trial, 2nd Would-Be Shoe Bomber Testifies
headline.main: A Would-Be Shoe Bomber Testifies in a Terror Trial
headline.print_headline: A Would-Be Shoe Bomber Testifies in a Terror Trial

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: Saajid Badat was heard via video in the case against Adis Medunjanin, a Queens man accused in a plot to blow up New York subways.

headline.main: Fears of a Shoe Bomb

Richard Reid.lead_paragraph: A man was detained briefly today at the airport here after batteries and wires were spotted in his shoes. The shoes were blown up by the police, even after it was determined that they were not dangerous. They were apparently designed to heat up to keep the wearer's feet warm, said an airport spokesman, Ron Wilson.

headline.seo: Ex-Spy Is Long Shot to Defeat Schumer
headline.main: Ex-Spy Is a Long Shot to Oust Schumer
headline.print_headline: Mission Impossible? Ex-Spy Is Long Shot to Oust Schumer

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: “I’m a professional insurgent,” says Gary Berntsen about his effort to unseat New York’s senior senator.

headline.seo: Man Thought to Be Insurgent Sabar Lal Melma Is Killed
headline.main: Troops Kill Man Linked to Al Qaeda and Attacks
headline.print_headline: Troops Kill Man Linked To Al Qaeda And Attacks

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: The man was believed to be a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who at one time was accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape after the Taliban’s fall.

headline.main: Troops Kill Man Linked To Al Qaeda And Attacks

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- A combined Afghan and coalition force killed a suspected insurgent leader in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said on Saturday. The man was believed to be a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who at one time was accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape from Tora Bora after the fall of the Taliban. NATO officials could not confirm whether the man who was killed, whom they identified as Sabar Lal, was the same man as Sabar Lal Melma, who was released from Guantánamo in 2007 after five years. But a tribal elder from Kunar Province told CNN that the man who had been killed was the former prisoner.

headline.main: Rumsfeld Defends Strategy Used in Tora Bora Last Year

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld reaffirmed his support today for the battle plan used to flush Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters last year from the mountains of Tora Bora in Afghanistan, and denied reports that the administration had concluded that Osama bin Laden was there but was able to escape. ''We have seen repeated speculation about his possible location,'' Mr. Rumsfeld said during a news briefing at the Pentagon, referring to Mr. bin Laden. ''But it has obviously not been verifiable. Had it been verifiable, one would have thought that someone might have done something about it.''

headline.main: Bin Laden Reported Spotted in Fortified Camp in Afghan East

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Osama bin Laden was seen this week at a large and well-fortified encampment 35 miles southwest of this city, a minister of the self-proclaimed government here said tonight. The official, Hazarat Ali, the law and order minister for the Eastern Shura, which claims dominion over three major provinces in eastern Afghanistan, said trusted informants had told him that Mr. bin Laden was spotted near Tora Bora, a village where two valleys meet in deep mountains in Nangarhar Province.

headline.main: Canadian-Led Troops Revisit Caves in Eastern Afghanistan

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Canadian-led troops are searching caves in the Tora Bora region of eastern Afghanistan for the first time since the aerial bombardment of that rugged mountain redoubt ended in December, Pentagon officials said today. More than 300 Canadian light-infantry troops, including engineers and explosives experts, are reopening caves sealed by the American bombing, and scouring the region for signs that Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters may have slipped back into the region. About 90 soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division and some allied Afghan troops are also involved in the operation.

headline.main: Looking for bin Laden: Reading the Signs

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: In reaching their assessment that Osama bin Laden is probably still in the mountains of Afghanistan near Tora Bora, American commanders are relying on high-tech surveillance equipment, but also on surmise and on reports from local Afghan fighters who are helping in the fight against his forces there. ''Obviously we use all sorts of technical means to gain insights into where he may be,'' said Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of American forces in the region.

headline.main: As Criticism of Failure to Capture bin Laden Mounts, a Reassessment of the Manhunt

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: The broadcast of a new videotape from Osama bin Laden prompted Senator John Kerry on Friday to renew his criticism that President Bush had the leader of Al Qaeda cornered in the rugged mountains of Tora Bora, Afghanistan, in December 2001, but ''outsourced'' the job of killing or capturing him to unreliable Afghan warlords. Mr. Kerry's accusation has elements of truth, but is also somewhat exaggerated, military commanders and Pentagon officials say. Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan at the time, said this month that Mr. Kerry's ''understanding of events doesn't square with reality.''

headline.main: Sept. 8-14: INTERNATIONAL; AL QAEDA CREEPS BACK

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after being chased from sanctuaries in Afghanistan, Al Qaeda fighters are beginning to move back into the country, American officials said.

headline.main: Pakistan Sends Troops to Border to Prevent bin Laden Escape

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers have been deployed on mountain peaks and in hidden valleys along the Afghan border in recent days in a bid to cut off escape routes for Osama bin Laden and his fighters from the remote enclave of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan, Pakistan military officials said today. The terrain in northwestern Pakistan across the border from Tora Bora, where some suspect that Mr. bin Laden is making a last stand, is rugged and inhospitable. Mountains top 15,000 feet and the few trails that exist are little more than ruts and donkey paths through the barren, arid landscape.

headline.main: Afghans Say Civilians Are Imperiled by U.S.
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DEATH TOLL

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: According to Afghan commanders here in the far eastern part of the country, civilians are being killed in the American hunt for Osama bin Laden. The commanders, who are pro-American, said that bad intelligence has caused mistakes in American bombing, and some say they sense an American indifference.

headline.main: TORA BORA ATTACK ADVANCES SLOWLY IN TOUGH FIGHTING

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Even as American forces and their Afghan allies close in on Al Qaeda fighters in the mountains here, the forbidding terrain and the stubbornness of some of the foreign followers of Osama bin Laden are making the struggle for Tora Bora the most complex battle of the war. Unlike the earlier string of victories, the goal is not to capture a city. It is to capture or kill up to 1,000 hardened fighters in one of the country's most rugged regions. Ultimately, it is also to apprehend or kill one of the most elusive of quarries, Mr. bin Laden and his top Al Qaeda lieutenants.

headline.main: MARINES AND ARMY MAY SCOUR CAVES, U.S. GENERAL SAYS

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by the failure to capture Osama bin Laden, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan has proposed that United States marines or Army troops be deployed to comb the wild terrain of Tora Bora to try to determine the fate of Al Qaeda leaders, American officials said today. The proposal, presented to the Pentagon by Gen. Tommy R. Franks, head of the United States Central Command, stems from the recognition that the Afghan allies may not have the ability or the will to establish control over Tora Bora, an untamed and dangerous region that borders Pakistan.

headline.main: Hunt for bin Laden Loses Steam As Winter Grips Afghan Caves

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: The American-backed effort to comb the caves of Tora Bora for signs of Osama bin Laden, his fighters and intelligence on terrorist attacks that might be in the works has made little progress and seems to be fading as a top priority, American and Afghan officials said today. More than 50 American Special Operations troops remain in the region, but they are not searching any caves themselves, military officials said. The Afghan militia members carrying out that task are relatively few in number, poorly clothed for scouring the rugged terrain in increasingly harsh winter weather and unenthusiastic about the mission.

headline.main: On Tora Bora, Horror Rained On Al Qaeda

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Tora Bora seemed to be an impregnable fortress when Osama bin Laden controlled the high ground. For a group of patients in the public hospital here it was a frigid, barren zone where they said they were terrorized by American airstrikes. Eighteen wounded Arab members of Al Qaeda were taken to the hospital as the fighting intensified. In their first interviews since their capture, several described what it was like to be on the receiving end of the American-led offensive to take Tora Bora.

headline.main: Tora Bora: Deep Ravines Hide Many Enemies

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: The sun so pulsed off the great gorges here that the walls of rock seemed adorned with spangles. Below, at the floor of the canyon, a shallow river, barely inches deep, rushed across a bed of stones. The water was glassy clear. Into beauty this pristine, the sight of an ugly blue-and-green truck coming around the curve today was startling. Armed soldiers sat atop the sides of the truck as it splashed over the riverbed. A cargo of bodies was at their feet. The dead were Al Qaeda fighters, hauled down from elevated caves and tunnels where they had put up their fatal resistance.

headline.main: AL QAEDA BALKS AT SURRENDER; BIN LADEN IS IN 'SHRINKING AREA'

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: American bombers laid a heavy barrage across the snowcapped mountains here early this morning as efforts to arrange a surrender of embattled Osama bin Laden fighters broke down. In Washington, a senior military officer said on Tuesday that United States intelligence had intercepted radio communications among Al Qaeda forces talking about Mr. bin Laden's location in the Tora Bora area.

headline.main: AL QAEDA FLEEING TOWARD PAKISTAN, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have fled from the caves of Tora Bora into the snow-capped mountains that mark the Pakistan border, and Osama bin Laden may be among them, according to United States intelligence officials, who acknowledged today that they had lost track of him. American officials thought they had a bead on his location until about 48 hours ago, when radio traffic and other communications they had been intercepting between Al Qaeda leaders largely dried up.

headline.main: 10-Month Afghan Mystery: Is bin Laden Dead or Alive?

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: This is where the trail ran cold. With the uncertainties surrounding Osama bin Laden since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States -- whether he is alive or dead, in Afghanistan or Pakistan, or perhaps in some hide-out much farther afield -- this much is known: The last sightings of the leader of Al Qaeda of which pursuers can be reasonably certain were here in the White Mountains of southeastern Afghanistan.

headline.main: An Anti-Taliban Commander Says bin Laden's Top Aide Is Dead
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: TORA BORA BATTLE

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: A front-line anti-Taliban commander said today that Osama bin Laden's top aide, Ayman al-Zawahiri, had been killed during fierce fighting here. ''This morning I got the news from my commanders in the mountains,'' said the Afghan commander, Aleem Shah. ''Zawahiri is dead.'' There was no independent means to verify this assertion, and military officials in Washington said they had no confirmation of his death.

headline.main: Al QAEDA ROUTED FROM AFGHANISTAN, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: American officials said today that Al Qaeda had been effectively destroyed in Afghanistan, and Afghan commanders here declared victory in the fierce battle for the mountain stronghold of Osama bin Laden's organization. But neither Americans nor Afghans said they knew where Mr. bin Laden was. Asked where he could be, Commander Muhammed Zaman, one of the main tribal leaders, shrugged and said: ''God knows. I don't.''

headline.main: New Deadline Set for Qaeda After Deal on Surrender Fails

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Afghan fighters set a new deadline of Thursday for Al Qaeda fighters bottled up in mountain canyons and caves to give up, after an agreement for a surrender this morning collapsed in confusion amid continued American bombing. The commanders of the Afghan tribal forces -- spurred by American pressure and the possibility of a $25 million reward -- are now demanding that Al Qaeda forces turn over their leader, Osama bin Laden, although his presence in these eastern Afghan mountains could not be confirmed.

headline.main: Afghan Says Fighters Are Ready to Attack Cave Complex

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: An Afghan commander said tonight that 1,500 Pashtun fighters, accompanied by American Special Operations soldiers, were prepared to attack Tora Bora, the mountain cave complex where Osama bin Laden and 2,000 Al Qaeda fighters are believed to be hiding. Early this morning and on Sunday, helicopters were seen and heard coming into the Jalalabad airport. A guard at the airport named Thezab said they were American helicopters, including a helicopter gunship and two light helicopters. The United States has helicopters, used by Special Forces, based in both Pakistan and Tajikistan.

headline.main: Uphill Battle to Take Caves And Maybe bin Laden, Too
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: IN THE MOUNTAINS

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Anti-Taliban Afghan fighters appeared stalled today in their drive to capture a complex of mountain caves held by Osama bin Laden loyalists and then begin a full-scale search for him there. On Thursday, anti-Taliban commanders said, the fighters moved about two miles forward in a series of fierce skirmishes, capturing several caves just above the valley floor and seizing ammunition and at least half a dozen Toyota and Datsun pickup trucks, the favored transport of all Afghan fighters.

headline.main: U.S. PUTTING OFF PLAN TO USE G.I.'S IN AFGHAN CAVES

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: The United States military is revising a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take the lead, American officials said today. Just last Friday, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he was ordering hundreds more troops to join Afghan militia in the hunt for Mr. bin Laden and other Qaeda leaders, in the hope of uncovering intelligence on terror attacks in the works. Officials said then that the plan was to send in about 500 marines and possibly Army troops, and the units began to prepare for the mission.

headline.main: Review of Guantánamo

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Navy Secretary Gordon R. England is to serve as the senior civilian official with final authority over the status of hundreds of detainees at the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the Pentagon said Wednesday. Mr. England will oversee a review of the status of most of the prisoners. The exceptions are those prisoners who President Bush determines should face military tribunals. Three have been charged with terrorism-related offenses.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; GUANTÁNAMO PRISON FILLS UP

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The makeshift prison at the naval base at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba that is holding suspected terrorists officially hit full capacity on Saturday. A dozen more prisoners were processed, bringing the number of detainees to 300, said Brig. Gen. Michael Lehnert, commander of the task force operating the site. The camp has 320 cells, but officials want to keep 20 units available for temporary use if needed.

headline.main: CONCERNS OVER DETAINEES

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The European Parliament called on the United States to immediately clarify the status of detainees at the American naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The parliament also urged the United States authorities ''to release prisoners against whom there are no retainable charges.'' More than 600 detainees of around 40 nationalities are being held on the base, following American intervention in Afghanistan and its offensives against members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

headline.main: At Guantánamo, Trial for 9/11 Defendants, and for a Revamped Tribunal

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- As the United States restarts its effort to prosecute -- and ultimately execute -- five detainees accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, it has fallen to Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins both to prove them guilty and to show the world that the tribunal system is now legitimate. ''We're going to have a fair trial,'' General Martins, the chief prosecutor in the military commissions system, said in an interview this week. ''There are a lot of people who come to this with preconceptions about unfairness, and I would just ask people to withhold judgment. The initial version of commissions was flawed, but there has been a lot of work on reforms.''

headline.main: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantánamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer. Since the spring, Mr. Ghailani has also been a defendant in federal court in Manhattan, the first Guantánamo detainee to be moved to the civilian courts.

headline.seo: Ghailani’s New York Trial Is Key Test for Other Terror Cases
headline.main: Terrorism Trial May Point Way for 9/11 Cases
headline.print_headline: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani’s case in Manhattan could be important in a future trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, accused of planning 9/11.

headline.seo: Vexed by Terrorism, Trials and Guantánamo, and Bearing Witness
headline.main: Bearing Witness at Terrorism Trials
headline.print_headline: Vexed by Terrorism, Trials and Guantánamo, and Bearing Witness

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The director of the Center on National Security at Fordham has made herself an expert on matters of torture, terrorism trials and the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GUANTÁNAMO: 30 COME, 13 GO

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: About 30 new prisoners have been flown to the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, after the United States released 13 others, bringing the total number being held at the high-security facility to about 680, military officials said. Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind, a Navy spokeswoman, said the Pentagon would not provide the identities or nationalities of the new prisoners, nor of those who were released.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Reporters Must Leave Guantánamo

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon ordered three reporters at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to leave, officials and the reporters said. The reporters, from The Miami Herald, The Los Angeles Times and The Charlotte Observer, had been reporting on the suicides of three detainees last weekend. Lt. Cmdr. J. D. Gordon, a Pentagon spokesman, said other news organizations had threatened to sue if they were not given similar access or if the other reporters at Guantánamo did not leave. NEIL A. LEWIS (NYT)

headline.main: Rumsfeld Favors Repatriating Detainees
