Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The United States would rather have detainees at the Guantánamo Bay prison camp imprisoned by their home countries, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Thursday. American officials are waiting until the Iraqi and Afghan authorities can deal with dangerous prisoners before handing over detainees from those countries, Mr. Rumsfeld said at a news conference during a NATO defense ministers' meeting.

headline.main: In Dossier, Portrait of Push for Post-9/11 Attacks

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- He peers out from the photo in the classified file through heavy-framed spectacles, an owlish face with a graying beard and a half-smile. Saifullah Paracha, a successful businessman and for years a New York travel agent, appears to be the oldest of the 172 prisoners still held at the Guantánamo Bay prison. His dossier is among the most chilling. In the months after the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Paracha, 63, was one of a small circle of Al Qaeda operatives who explored ways to follow up on the hijackings with new attacks, according to the classified Guantánamo files made available to The New York Times.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Arraignment For Translator Accused Of Spying

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: An Air Force Arabic translator accused of spying at the Guantánamo Bay military prison camp was arraigned at Travis Air Force Base in a court-martial on espionage and other charges that could send him to prison for life. The translator, Senior Airman Ahmad I. al-Halabi, 24, is accused of trying to deliver messages from detainees at Guantánamo Bay to Syria. The government says he stored the messages on his laptop and planned to carry them overseas.

headline.main: UNITED STATES: SUICIDE ATTEMPTS

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon reported two new suicide attempts by prisoners held at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, bringing the total number to 27. Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind of the Navy, a Pentagon spokeswoman, said that in the last 10 days one detainee had tried to kill himself for the first time, while another had made a repeated attempt. Neither was injured and both received medical and mental evaluation, she said. Commander Burfeind said that 18 detainees had tried to kill themselves and that there were 27 total attempts since the Guantánamo facility was opened in January 2002.

headline.seo: Clues About Jurors Emerge at Ex-Detainee’s Trial
headline.main: Glimpse at Jurors in Ex-Guantánamo Detainee’s Trial
headline.print_headline: Some Clues About Jurors In Trial of Former Detainee

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Details about the anonymous jury in the first civil trial of a former Guantánamo Bay detainee came from disclosures about the jury selection process.

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Army Chaplain Quits

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A Muslim chaplain cleared of espionage charges after being imprisoned for 76 days resigned from the Army, saying officials never apologized or allowed him to retrieve his belongings from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The chaplain, Capt. James J. Yee, 35, most recently based at Fort Lewis, ministered to prisoners at the Guantánamo naval base. Captain Yee, left, was taken into custody last September after the military linked him to a possible espionage ring. In March, the Army dismissed criminal charges against him.

headline.main: Justices Decline to Hear Appeal From Chinese Detainees
headline.print_headline: Justices Decline to Hear Appeal From Chinese Detainees

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Five Chinese Muslims who are detained at Guantánamo Bay were refused an appeal by the Supreme Court for a hearing about the possibility of their release into the United States.

headline.main: U.S. Plans to Transfer Afghan Prisoners

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The United States will return about 110 Afghan prisoners now at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to Afghanistan, where the Afghan government will decide whether to detain or release them, American and Afghan officials said Thursday. The Pentagon said an additional 350 Afghans detained by the American military at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan would be handed over to the Afghan government after other facilities were built and guards trained.

headline.main: 9/11 Defendants Were Protesting 'Unjust System' at Hearing, Their Lawyers Say

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- Lawyers for five men charged before a military commission with conspiring in the attacks of Sept. 11 complained on Sunday that the process was rigged to lead to the execution of their clients, and they offered new details and explanations for a sometimes chaotic daylong arraignment on Saturday. Throughout the arraignment, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and the other four defendants refused to talk to, or even listen to, the judge. Several delayed the hearing by praying, and one shouted to the judge that guards at the prison might kill them. Another was brought to the court in restraints and later took off his shirt, before insisting that the full charges be read aloud, which lasted into the night.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 7 From Guantánamo Charged

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The authorities have charged seven Russian citizens who were prisoners of the United States military at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and were transported to Moscow over the weekend, with illegally crossing borders, mercenary activity and participating in a criminal group, according to the Interfax new agency. They were captured in Afghanistan and were accused of fighting with the Taliban. The federal prosecutor's office has said the detainees were from the Muslim-majority republics of Tatarstan and Bashkortostan, the city of Chelyabinsk in the Urals, western Siberia and the Caucasus Mountain region.

headline.main: Judge Won't Step Down In Case of Cole Attack

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The military judge presiding over the war crimes trial of a Guantánamo Bay prisoner charged in the attack on the Navy destroyer Cole rejected a defense motion Tuesday that he remove himself from the case. Lawyers for Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri said Col. James Pohl of the Army could not be impartial because he had a financial incentive to side with the Pentagon, which paid his salary, and he was serving as the judge in other Guantánamo cases. But Colonel Pohl said at a hearing that the defense had offered scant evidence to support its argument. Mr. Al-Nashiri, a Saudi, is charged with orchestrating the 2000 attack on the Cole, which killed 17 sailors. He has been held at the United States Naval Base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since 2006.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Morocco: U.S. Hands Over 5 Guantánamo Suspects

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Five Moroccans held at the American prison camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for more than two years have been handed to Moroccan authorities for investigation, the MAP state news agency said. The men, captured in Afghanistan and Pakistan on suspicion of serving as fighters for the Taliban, arrived in Morocco on Sunday. One, Abdallah Tabarak, has been described as a former bodyguard for Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: GUANTÁNAMO SUICIDE ATTEMPTS

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Suicide attempts among terrorism suspects held at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba are on the rise, the Pentagon said yesterday. At least 5 of the more than 600 detainees at the naval base have tried to hang themselves in the past three weeks, said a Pentagon spokeswoman, Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind. Amnesty International urged the United States authorities to investigate the suicide attempts to determine whether the manner in which interrogations are conducted may have contributed.

headline.main: More Prisoners to Be Released From Guantánamo, Officials Say

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Bush administration officials said today that they would soon release an additional group of prisoners, about a dozen, from the detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Officials said that the prisoners, captured in the war in Afghanistan, had been determined to have no further intelligence value and that there was no evidence they had been involved in any crimes.

headline.main: Guantánamo Detention Challenge Is Rejected

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court today blocked a challenge to the detention of the 600 Afghan war prisoners held at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base, ruling that a group of clergy members and professors had no legal standing to represent them. The group, the Coalition of Clergy, Lawyers and Professors, sued on behalf of the prisoners, who they said had been deprived of their liberty without lawyers and had not been informed of the accusations against them.

headline.seo: Man Thought to Be Insurgent Sabar Lal Melma Is Killed
headline.main: Troops Kill Man Linked to Al Qaeda and Attacks
headline.print_headline: Troops Kill Man Linked To Al Qaeda And Attacks

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The man was believed to be a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who at one time was accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape after the Taliban’s fall.

headline.main: In Latest Phase of Ground Zero Building Dispute, a New Call for Oversight

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The financial dispute that has hobbled construction of the museum at ground zero for eight months entered a new stage this week with a struggle over who will control the overall memorial and the eight-acre site. The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement. The foundation, which has raised $430 million in private donations, has also controlled the site and overseen annual events commemorating the deaths of nearly 3,000 people in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Trade Center Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a memorial for the victims of the World Trade Center attack yesterday at the New York State Museum. The exhibits will open to the public on Nov. 23. Tiny aluminum tiles suspended from the ceiling in the shape of the towers will each represent one of the victims. The memorial will also include a plaque and artifacts from the scene.

headline.main: Joining a Grim Roster
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Dykstra, the president and chief executive of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, said after a board meeting yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center land, should ''be delivering to us a buildable site'' for the memorial and memorial museum, meaning the authority alone should pay the cost of the underground infrastructure. At the meeting, Christine A. Ferer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's liaison to the families of 9/11 victims and a Port Authority commissioner, joined the board. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: No Buildings Where Towers Once Stood, Pataki Vows

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki vowed yesterday at a memorial ceremony for Sept. 11 victims that there would be no commercial development on the land where the twin towers stood. ''Where the towers stood is hallowed ground,'' said Governor Pataki, who received a standing ovation from about 400 family members at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for the memorial service.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

Memorials.lead_paragraph: A section of steel girder from the World Trade Center given to the British will be buried rather than displayed in a planned memorial garden in London, to prevent distress to victims' relatives, officials said yesterday. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport is overseeing the memorial's construction. The blackened, twisted piece of metal from the north tower was given to Britain by the mayor's office in New York for a memorial in Grosvenor Square, opposite the United States Embassy. Sixty-seven Britons were killed in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated his support yesterday for government financing of the underground infrastructure at ground zero, leaving the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation responsible only for meeting the $500 million budget now assigned to the memorial and museum. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to pay $100 million of the memorial's share of infrastructure costs. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Floodwater Pours Into 9/11 Museum, Hampering Further Work on the Site
headline.print_headline: Floodwater Pours Into 9/11 Museum, Hampering Further Work on the Site

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The main floor of the National September 11 Memorial Museum, still under construction nearly 70 feet below the memorial plaza at the World Trade Center, filled with at least seven feet of water.

headline.main: 9/11 Memorial Access Will Be Limited

Memorials.lead_paragraph: For years after the Sept. 11 memorial opens this fall, access will be limited, the president of the memorial foundation said on Monday. Ultimately, visitors will be able to approach the memorial and its green spaces and cobblestone plazas from all sides. But for years, said Joe Daniels, the president of the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, the memorial will be surrounded by the construction sites of skyscrapers and a transit hub, and visitors will be able to use only one entrance.

headline.seo: 9/11 Memorial Access Will Be Limited
headline.main: 9/11 Memorial Access Will Be Limited
headline.print_headline: 9/11 Memorial Access Will Be Limited

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Because of construction nearby, only one entrance will be available for several years, limiting access to 1,500 visitors at a time, who will have to sign up online.

headline.main: Six Finalists Are Selected for Design at Pentagon

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The competition to design a memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon has been narrowed to six finalists, officials of the Army Corps of Engineers said today. The director of the Pentagon memorial project said none of the designs by the finalists made reference to the attack on the World Trade Center or to the hijacked jet that crashed in Shanksville, Pa. That has dismayed some family members of victims of the trade center attack who traveled to Washington today to discuss memorial plans with Pentagon officials.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Piscataway: Hearing On Trade Center Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: About 100 people attended a public hearing at Rutgers University here to discuss new designs and guidelines for a memorial at the World Trade Center, and many complained that organizers had not planned more hearings in New Jersey, which lost hundreds of people on Sept. 11. Many of the speakers made emotional pleas to the planners of the memorial to include the remains of unidentified victims that now lie in a landfill in Staten Island. ''Where do I go to see my son,'' said Krystynacq Boryczewskicq, 63, of Parsipanny, whose son Martin, 29, was died on 9/11. Maria Newman (NYT)

headline.main: Memorial Jury to Decide How to List 9/11 Rescuers

Memorials.lead_paragraph: A top rebuilding official said yesterday that the guidelines for the World Trade Center memorial were flexible enough to allow the professional affiliations of firefighters and other rescue workers to be listed on it with their names, if the memorial jury chose a design that did so. The issue has been the subject of aggressive lobbying and demonstrations by firefighters and other rescue workers in recent weeks. While some firefighters have campaigned for a separate memorial for rescue workers, a larger number have asked that ''F.D.N.Y.'' or other such affiliations be listed with the names of rescue workers who were killed at the trade center.

headline.main: Remembering the Little Things; Older Monuments Guide Planners of Sept. 11 Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Shoes. Abandoned haphazardly in the middle of the street, buried in ash along curbsides, dug from the mountains of rubble formed by the collapse of the World Trade Center. For many who think back to Sept. 11, the shoes are the most vivid reminders of the terror and the hope of survival, of the panic and the uniquely individual scale of that monumental tragedy.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have prohibited admission or other fees at the World Trade Center memorial, museum or visitor center, his office said yesterday. Mr. Pataki said the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation could not rule out charging the public, given what he estimated would be the $50 million annual cost of operating a memorial and museum at ground zero. State Senator Martin J. Golden, the Brooklyn Republican who introduced the bill, had said ''there should be no barriers,'' including fees, that would prevent people from paying their respects. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

headline.main: MEMORIAL IN WEST ORANGE

Memorials.lead_paragraph: ''Remembrance and Rebirth,'' a $1.3 million bronze memorial to people killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was unveiled last week at the Eagle Rock Reservation in West Orange. Patrick Morelli of Cedar Grove designed and built the memorial, which depicts a girl clutching a teddy bear and standing before an open book inscribed with the names of the names, ages and hometowns of Essex County residents who died in the attacks. Behind the book, a bald eagle with an eight-foot wingspan perches atop a tree. A teenage boy holding a lantern and facing New York stands next to the book. The names of all those who died in the attacks are inscribed on granite walls next to the memorial. John Holl

New York City is the most popular tourist destination in the country, and the National September 11th Memorial at the World Trade Center plaza is becoming one of its most popular sites. Though the memorial has been open for under nine months, 2.7 million people -- averaging 10,000 a day -- have already visited it. Not as many as the Metropolitan Museum of Art attracts, but then again, that spot doesn't require reservations or a photo ID.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Entries Received For 9/11 Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The state has received 688 entries in a competition to find a design for a memorial to the nearly 700 New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, officials announced yesterday. A professional advisory committee will narrow the field of contestants to several finalists, said an administration spokeswoman, Ellen Mellody. A panel of family members of victims and survivors will choose a winning design by July. The memorial will be installed in Liberty State Park, in Jersey City, across from the World Trade Center site.

headline.main: Changed Plans

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Until Sept. 11, the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders had planned to create a memorial at Cooper River Park in Pennsauken honoring residents of New Jersey who perished in the explosion of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. John Giannotti, above, a sculptor and professor emeritus at Rutgers University, had already designed the memorial. ''But everything changed after Sept. 11,'' Mr. Giannotti said.

headline.main: Photos, Flags and Other Mementos Stolen From a 9/11 Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Thirty photographs, four flags and other mementos have been stolen from a sidewalk memorial to three officers at State Supreme Court in Manhattan who died in the attack on the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday. Laura Loud, a senior court officer who maintains the 25-foot-long display, said that she first noticed on Monday that some items -- including nearly half the pictures -- were missing from the memorial, which was put together just after 9/11 in tribute to the fallen officers, Thomas Jurgens, Mitchel Wallace and Capt. William Harry Thompson.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but ''would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Officials Plan New Memorial To Victims Of '93 Attack

Memorials.lead_paragraph: State officials said yesterday that they would erect a temporary memorial to the victims of the 1993 terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center and that it would include a fragment of the original memorial, which was destroyed in the collapse of the twin towers in 2001. The announcement came two days before the 10th anniversary of the bombing, which killed six people.

headline.main: Less Is More, Mayor Suggests On World Trade Center Site

Memorials.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he believes the development of the World Trade Center site must balance the commercial and residential needs of the neighborhood with the need for a memorial, and should not turn the site into ''a cemetery.'' After a speech yesterday morning to the United States Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Bloomberg was asked whether he thought the memorial should occupy the entire 16-acre site. ''I don't know how big it will be,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. ''There's a cry for making it bigger, and I would argue sometimes less is more, and that we run the risk of making something much too big.''

headline.main: 9/11 Flag Is Destroyed in Fire at Memorial
headline.print_headline: 9/11 Flag Is Destroyed in Fire at Memorial

Memorials.lead_paragraph: The flag that flew over the United States Capitol on Sept. 11, 2001, was among several artifacts destroyed in a fire at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Shanksville, Pa.

headline.main: Powell Says Obama Sought Policy Advice

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Sunday that Senator Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential candidate, had sought him out for advice on foreign policy matters. Mr. Powell said he had met twice with Mr. Obama. ''I've been around this town a long time and I know everybody who is running for office,'' Mr. Powell said in an interview on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC. ''And I make myself available to talk about foreign policy matters and military matters with whoever wishes to chat with me.''

headline.main: Supporters: Praise, Yes. Endorsement, No.

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy Colin Powell thinks President Obama fixed the auto industry.

headline.main: Powell, in Mexico, Pledges Migrant Reform

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security, assured Mexican officials on Tuesday that President Bush would pursue a temporary worker program that could free millions of migrants living illegally in the United States from legal limbo. But they injected a note of caution, saying that Congress must be persuaded to move forward with the issue, which is politically volatile.

headline.main: Powell Poised To Announce New Strategy In Middle East

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is poised to unveil a new American strategy to end the violence between Israelis and Palestinians and restart talks aimed at creating a Palestinian state, senior administration officials said today. In a long-awaited speech that could be delivered as early as Monday during a scheduled visit to the University of Louisville in Kentucky, Secretary Powell will signal that the Bush administration will take a more active diplomatic role in bringing peace to the region, the officials said.

headline.main: AFGHAN LEADER TO SEEK MORE AID

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan will seek further help from foreign countries to quell remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda during his trip to the United States later this month, the foreign ministry said yesterday. Islamic militants remain a threat in Afghanistan, and during his meetings in Washington, Mr. Karzai will stress the need for sustained efforts to defeat them, said Omar Samad, a foreign ministry spokesman. Mr. Karzai will start his foreign tour on Thursday with a visit to Japan, and then will meet in Washington with President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

headline.main: March 31-April 6; COMING UP

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell leaves today for meetings in Morocco, Egypt, Jordan, Israel and Spain. President Bush repeats calls for community service in Knoxville, Tenn., on Monday and in Bridgeport, Conn., on Tuesday. He meets with NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, on Tuesday, and comments on human cloning on Wednesday.

headline.main: U.S. Weighs Tackling Iraq On Its Own, Powell Says

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: In his sharpest comments yet on the next phase of the war on terrorism, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told Congress today that President Bush was set on a ''regime change'' in Iraq and warned that it was something the United States ''might have to do alone.'' Testifying before the House International Relations Committee, Secretary Powell, who has been chief among President Bush's advisers in urging caution on Iraq, declined to outline ''any of the details'' under consideration. But in somber tones he described them as ''the most serious assessment of options that one might imagine,'' and said that Mr. Bush was ''leaving no stone unturned as to what we might do.''

headline.main: Powell Hails Man Who Cited Pressure on Iraq Data

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has offered public support for the department expert who told Congress that he felt pressured to make his intelligence reports on Iraq and other matters conform to administration policy. Mr. Powell told reporters on Thursday night that he had sent word to the expert, Christian Westermann, a specialist on chemical and biological weapons, that he was ''pleased'' that Mr. Westermann had ''honestly answered'' when asked in closed-door hearings whether he had perceived such influence.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cuomo Goes To Israel

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: As he left yesterday on a trip to Israel, Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, released a letter he sent to Secretary of State Colin Powell recommending that he add the Palestinian Authority to the United States list of terrorist groups. Mr. Cuomo applauded the Bush administration's insistence that Yasir Arafat leave office. Mr. Cuomo denied that his trip was intended to counter the expected boost in Jewish support that his opponent, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, will receive from a recent endorsement by Senator Charles Schumer. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

headline.main: 10 Asian Nations Join With U.S. in Pledge to Fight Terrorism

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Ten Southeast Asian nations joined the United States today in pledging to ''prevent, disrupt and combat'' global terrorism through increased sharing of information and intelligence, winding up a regional conference in Brunei at which North Korea and Washington took a first step toward renewed dialogue. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell signed the agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations before flying here for meetings with top Indonesian leaders on terrorism and military cooperation on Friday. The declaration commits a region that is battling extremist groups, including some with links to Al Qaeda, to strengthening counterterrorism training, exchanging financial and immigration data and working to create joint programs with the United States. ''It's not a project; it's a base for projects,'' one senior American official said.

headline.main: Embattled, Scrutinized, Powell Soldiers On

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: After a recent meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was kidding around with the secretaries in the national security adviser's White House office, complaining that their pretzel jar was empty. Then he said: ''Okay, that's enough. I've got to get back to work now -- and by the way, I'm not resigning.'' The staff ''all took a slight, shallow breath and then broke up,'' a senior administration official recalled. But the question of Secretary Powell's tenure is no laughing matter in Washington these days.

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; NEW BIN LADEN TAPE

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Threatening attacks against the United States and urging Muslims to defend Iraq against an American-led invasion, the latest tape attributed to Osama bin Laden and broadcast by Al Jazeera television jangled the frayed nerves of Americans already fearful that a terror attack might be imminent. Senior Bush administration officials like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the tape buttressed the case for military action against Saddam Hussein, saying it showed Mr. bin Laden was ''in partnership with Iraq.'' David Johnston

headline.main: U.S., Citing Antiterror Gains in Sudan, Seeks More

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that despite progress toward peace in the southern Sudan, the government in Khartoum had ''a way to go'' before Washington removes it from its list of ''state sponsors of terrorism.'' Secretary Powell was speaking in an interview with CNN after talks in Khartoum between President Omar Hassan Bashir and an Assistant Secretary of State, Walter Kansteiner.

headline.main: With Candor, Powell Charms Global MTV Audience

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Daniella Satori, who described herself as a ''young Catholic woman,'' had a question from Milan: What about her church's ban on condoms in an age of AIDS? Secretary of State Colin L. Powell pursed his lips as if to stifle the rueful smile of trepidation he knew was coming, then he let loose. ''I certainly respect the judgment of the Holy Father and the Catholic Church,'' he began, before going on to say that condoms were a vital defense against disease and adding, ''I not only support their use, I encourage their use among people who are sexually active and need to protect themselves.''

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Recommendation For Navy Secretary

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has recommended that President Bush nominate an oilman, Colin R. McMillan, as Navy secretary, two senior Pentagon officials said. Mr. McMillan, 67, of Roswell, N.M., runs Permian Exploration and was chairman of Mr. Bush's New Mexico presidential campaign in 2000. He served in the Marines from 1957 to 1972 and was an assistant defense secretary 10 years ago, when Vice President Dick Cheney was defense secretary. The Navy has not had a permanent secretary since Gordon R. England left in January to become deputy secretary of the new Homeland Security Department.

headline.main: Powell Tries to Allay Worry Of Senators on Muslim Rage

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell took the unusual step of inviting the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to lunch today. His guests emerged satisfied, they said, that the Bush administration would try to alleviate a major concern: that military action against Osama bin Laden would inflame the Muslim world. The session at the State Department was organized by Secretary Powell as a way to avoid a public Congressional hearing while the administration was still trying to solve some of the problems in its international anti-terror coalition.

headline.main: Powell Treading a Thin Line In Rallying Antiterror Support

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here tonight for meetings with fellow foreign ministers aimed at solidifying a second front, in Southeast Asia, in the campaign against global terrorism. But he has had to balance that goal with longstanding concerns about human rights abuses in the region. In meetings today in Malaysia and Singapore before touching down in this oil-producing sultanate for two days of talks with members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, Secretary Powell said, he repeatedly raised the issue. ''We still believe strongly in human rights, and that everything we do has to be consistent with universal standards of human rights,'' he said.

headline.main: Powell Will Visit India and Pakistan

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Seeking to contain tensions between India and Pakistan, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he would visit both countries next week, and possibly others in the region, on his way to an international conference on the reconstruction of Afghanistan. After a meeting at the State Department today with India's home minister, Lal Krishna Advani, to discuss the administration's campaign against international terrorism, Secretary Powell said he would visit South Asia ''to see if I can make a further contribution, by my presence, toward resolving the situation that currently exists, the crisis that currently exists, in a peaceful manner.''

headline.main: Powell's Message: America's Courting of Pakistan Will Not Come at India's Expense

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration sought to reassure India today that America's intensifying alliance with Pakistan would not come at the expense of India, its rival. But the response from India, which regards Pakistan as a sponsor of terrorism in the disputed territory of Kashmir, was guarded. ''We don't necessarily need to be disagreeable about the disagreement,'' the Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, said, ''and we can work together.''

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; SETBACK ON IRAQ

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration signaled all week that it was as determined as ever to go to war in Iraq unless Saddam Hussein disarms. But by week's end, the chances of proceeding with the support of allies in the United Nations and NATO seemed to diminish. The chief U.N. weapons inspectors reported some progress, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell faced deep resistance to his call for a Security Council decision to authorize military force. France and Germany, in particular, demanded more time for the inspectors to complete their work, creating the biggest cleavage in the NATO alliance in a generation.

headline.main: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; SWEDEN: GUANTÁNAMO PRESSURE

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Anna Lindh of Sweden said Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had promised to look into the case of a Swedish man held since January 2002 at the United States prison camp at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba. Sweden has urged the United States to release or press charges against the man, Mehdi Muhammad Ghezali. He is being held among the 600 prisoners suspected of links to Al Qaeda, the Taliban or other militant or terrorist groups. Mr. Ghezali's father, a Muslim of Algerian origin, has said his son had been studying in Pakistan and had nothing to do with Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Powell Says U.S. Had Signs, But Not Clear Ones, of a Plot

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration had received a ''lot of signs'' that terrorists were planning attacks against the United States but extensive efforts by intelligence agencies failed to pick up enough information to stop the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. Early this summer ''there were a lot of signs that there was something going on,'' Secretary Powell said. ''But we never got the fidelity and the information that we would have liked to, some warning of what did actually happen.''

headline.main: Talks on Kashmir Urged by Powell

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in India today at the start of a weeklong Asian trip to shore up support for the campaign against terrorism, with his first issue the flare-up over Kashmir that has threatened war between India and Pakistan, two nations critical to the campaign. As Secretary Powell landed, for his third visit to India and Pakistan since October, Indian officials promptly raised complaints about what they say is continued cross-border infiltration from Pakistan into Kashmir.

headline.main: In Shattered Kabul, Powell Vows Long-Term Support for Afghans

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: In a whirlwind visit to this war-ravaged capital, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell announced today that the United States had restored its crumbling, long-shuttered embassy to full diplomatic status, and he assured Afghanistan's interim leader, ''We will be with you in this current crisis and for the future.'' Under heavy security, Secretary Powell swept into Kabul from the nearby Bagram air base this morning in a low-flying Army Chinook helicopter with machine gunners at front and rear, becoming not only the most senior American official to arrive here since the fall of the Taliban government but also the first secretary of state to visit since Henry A. Kissinger in 1976.

headline.main: Powell Tried to Warn Bush on Iraq, Book Says

Colin Powell.lead_paragraph: Colin L. Powell, in his last face-to-face meeting with President Bush before stepping down as secretary of state in January 2005, tried to impress upon him one last time the dangers he saw the United States facing in Iraq, according to a new Powell biography. The insurgency was growing and the country was spiraling into sectarian bloodshed, Mr. Powell warned. Elections in Iraq would not solve the problems, and the president's ability to act decisively was being crippled by divisions within his own administration, according to the account in ''Soldier: The Life of Colin Powell'' (Knopf, 2006) by Karen DeYoung, an associate editor at The Washington Post. Mr. Bush appeared disengaged, the book says, and brushed off Mr. Powell's complaints about dysfunction in his government.

headline.main: Marines Move To Kandahar And Secure An Airport

Marines.lead_paragraph: A vanguard of marines in armored vehicles rolled into the airport outside of Kandahar early today, consolidating control over a scene of intense fighting against the Taliban and clearing the way for deliveries of supplies and aid. It was the most significant military maneuver known to have been undertaken by hundreds of marines since they arrived in southern Afghanistan on Nov. 25.

headline.main: Elite Troops Patrolling Desolate Swaths of No Man's Land

Marines.lead_paragraph: Having established significant firepower on the ground here, American marines are now probing deeper toward the chaotic swaths of territory still under control of the Taliban, spokesmen here said today. The force reconnaissance platoon of the 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit has begun widening its patrols across an arc of desolate territory that is essentially no man's land, focusing particularly on an area between here and Kandahar, the Taliban's last bastion.

headline.main: With All Clear, Marines Dig In And Scout Area

Marines.lead_paragraph: From a dry, isolated lake bed here in the high Afghan desert, American helicopter gunships and armored vehicles are probing the last military strongholds of Afghanistan's crumbling Taliban government. But the Americans have encountered no enemy resistance since attacking a convoy of military vehicles four days ago, officers said tonight.

headline.main: Vanguard of Marines Digs In and Directs Air Attacks

Marines.lead_paragraph: Just hours after establishing a base in Afghanistan, American marines helped direct air attacks today on an armored column, inaugurating a new phase in the war that will deploy 1,000 American ground troops, Pentagon officials said. About 500 marines dug in today at a primitive desert airstrip less than 80 miles southwest of Kandahar, the Taliban stronghold, but still within easy helicopter striking distance of the city. Officials said the Marine vanguard, along with another 500 marines who were expected to land Tuesday, will intercept military traffic, cut off escape routes for enemy fighters and, given credible intelligence, strike at leaders of the Taliban and at Osama bin Laden's organization, Al Qaeda.

headline.main: The Marines' 21st-Century Beachhead Is Far Inland

Marines.lead_paragraph: Just past 2 a.m. on Dec. 7, a company of marines -- scouts, snipers and troops in armored vehicles -- stretched a roadblock across the main road out of Kandahar, Route 1, and ambushed a sport utility vehicle of the kind favored by the Taliban. As the vehicle bolted to a stop, its axle entangled in concertina wire, a Force Reconnaissance squad -- some of the Marines' most elite fighters -- crested the road and fired when the men inside brandished AK-47's.

headline.main: 3 Marines Wounded by Land Mine at Kandahar Airport

Marines.lead_paragraph: Three marines were wounded by a land mine today, one of them seriously, at the airport outside Kandahar as they worked to clear an airport building of mines, booby traps and unexploded ordnance, Marine spokesmen said. The men were quickly evacuated to the field hospital at Camp Rhino, the original Marine outpost in southern Afghanistan, officials at that base said. One of them, who lost his leg below the knee when he stepped on the mine, was evacuated from Afghanistan to an Air Force hospital in the Persian Gulf area.

headline.seo: Westchester/In the Region - Welcome-Home Houses
headline.main: Welcome-Home Houses
headline.print_headline: Welcome-Home Houses

Marines.lead_paragraph: The Westchester affiliate of Habitat for Humanity is helping veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan to become homeowners.

headline.main: At Afghan Base, Marines Dig Foxholes and Spoil for a Fight
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: AT U.S. BASE

Marines.lead_paragraph: The days are dry and hot, the nights near freezing. The first few inches of sand are loose, then there is rock. It is here, more than a mile northeast of the main American base in Afghanistan, that Charlie Company has dug foxhole after foxhole into a rough, barren ridge facing in the direction of Kandahar, watching for an enemy who is not likely to come. With Cobra helicopter gunships on the ground here and American fighter jets controlling the skies, the chances of a significant Taliban force reaching this dusty base are negligible, the marines here said. Even so, commanders fear that small bands of fighters -- on foot, perhaps, and at night -- might try to infiltrate the perimeter of the base, the largest concentration of American forces on the ground here.

headline.main: Marines Build Firepower in the South, Bolstering Their Patrols and Readiness
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: AT U.S. BASE

Marines.lead_paragraph: The Marines nearly doubled the number of combat helicopters at an ever-sprawling desert airstrip here Sunday, sharply increasing their firepower as opposition forces, supported by American bombing raids, mounted a final drive on the Taliban's last stronghold, Kandahar. Early today, still more troops and weapons arrived on cargo aircraft that flew through the night from the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit based at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Those included additional armored fighting vehicles and antitank Humvees.

headline.main: Growing Marine Force Turns Desolate Airstrip Into a High-Tech Base

Marines.lead_paragraph: No one at the Pentagon likes to say the Marines own this piece of Afghanistan, but they are clearly making it their own. After seizing what appears to have been a primitive military compound eight days ago, the expanding American force here has gradually turned the dry, desolate airstrip into a heavily fortified, highly technological base of operations to support the final assault on the Taliban's last stronghold, Kandahar.

headline.seo: U.S. Deplores Video of Marines Urinating on Taliban
headline.main: Video Inflames a Delicate Moment for U.S. in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: An Inflammatory Video Multiplies American Difficulties in Afghanistan

Marines.lead_paragraph: A video of four Marines urinating on dead Taliban fighters is likely to weaken the United States’ position both with the Taliban and with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.

headline.main: Up to 2,000 Marines to Go To Afghanistan From Gulf

Marines.lead_paragraph: As many as 2,000 marines now aboard ships in the Persian Gulf will be sent to Afghanistan in the coming weeks to reinforce the American-led operation there to combat fighters of Al Qaeda and the Taliban, Pentagon officials said Thursday. American commanders have not yet decided how many marines from the 22nd Marine Expeditionary Unit from Camp Lejeuene, N.C., will ultimately be deployed to Afghanistan. A senior Pentagon official said ''it will be most of them,'' while a defense official said that ''some of the marines'' would be sent but that conditions in the field would dictate the number.

headline.main: Anticipating Many Captives, U.S. Marines Build a Prison Camp at Kandahar Airport
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: IN THE SOUTH

Marines.lead_paragraph: Marines reinforcing a new forward base at Kandahar's airport are building a prison camp for as many as 300 Al Qaeda fighters in anticipation of the fall of Tora Bora, officers here said today. As the war in Afghanistan reaches its climax, the marine-led force here has rapidly shifted its objective from putting pressure on the last bastion of Taliban control to preparing for the complex and potentially disorderly aftermath.

headline.main: Kuwaiti Youth Arrested With Firebombs

Marines.lead_paragraph: Kuwaiti police officials said they arrested a teenager today as he drove a cargo of gasoline bombs near a housing complex where some American military officers live. ''The man gave himself up and nothing happened,'' a senior Kuwaiti security source told Reuters.

headline.main: Troops of U.S. And Kenya Plan Exercise

Marines.lead_paragraph: Fresh from the battlefields of Afghanistan, more than 2,000 American marines are to begin a three-week exercise off the coast of Kenya on Sunday, military officials said today. Pentagon officials said the exercise with Kenyan forces had been planned for about a year, and did not foreshadow any imminent military operations in neighboring Somalia, where American officials say Al Qaeda fighters may have fled from Afghanistan.

headline.main: Marines Land in Afghanistan With Panache, Semper Fi and Press Tagging Along

Marines.lead_paragraph: When the few and the proud landed in Afghanistan on Monday, they took some of the ink-stained with them. The decision by the United States Marine Corps to take three print reporters, a television cameraman and a photographer into combat so early in their mission was a welcome surprise to many news organizations. It was not quite as startling to military men and women familiar with the Marine Corps's panache for public relations.

headline.main: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; KUWAIT KILLING

Marines.lead_paragraph: A U. S. marine was killed and another was wounded after two Kuwaiti gunmen sneaked into a military training exercise on Failaka Island in the Persian Gulf. American officials called the shooting a terrorist act. Pentagon officials said the gunmen, who were shot dead, may have trained in Afghanistan at Al Qaeda camps. Eric Schmitt

headline.main: In Raid on Hospital, a Fighter Is Captured

Marines.lead_paragraph: American soldiers, evidently Special Operations troops, arrested an Arab fighter at the hospital here Sunday night after a chaotic raid by local Afghan security forces that included a brief firefight. No one was injured in the raid and the fighter was spirited to the Marines' temporary prison camp at Kandahar International Airport, 12 miles southeast of here, according to information supplied by a witness and military spokesmen.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills Marine

Marines.lead_paragraph: A United States Black Hawk helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan, killing a marine and wounding 14 others, the military announced. The crash was not caused by hostile fire, but occurred in Khost Province where there has been fighting with Taliban and Al Qaeda forces on the border with Pakistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline.main: Warning in Afghanistan

Marines.lead_paragraph: The commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, warned Tuesday of more attacks from Taliban and Al Qaeda guerrillas, but he promised a relentless military response. ''We expect additional attempts by remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda to disrupt the ongoing political process and ongoing reconstruction efforts,'' he said at a news briefing. Afghan security forces, nongovernmental organizations and troops will all be singled out, he said.

headline.main: 2 Marines Killed and 5 Injured As Helicopter Crashes Near Base

Marines.lead_paragraph: Two marines were killed and five injured when their helicopter crashed early this morning in a mountainous area south of Bagram air base in northern Afghanistan. The helicopter, a CH-53E supply aircraft, crashed at about 8 a.m. 40 miles south of Bagram shortly after taking off on a supply mission, military officials here and at the Central Command in Tampa, Fla., said. Bagram is just north of Kabul, the Afghan capital.

headline.main: AIRBORNE TROOPS RELIEVING MARINES AT KANDAHAR BASE

Marines.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has ordered soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division to relieve the Marine Corps in southern Afghanistan, paving the way for a long-term American military presence in the country, military officials said today. Over the next two weeks, elements of the 101st out of Fort Campbell, Ky., will begin moving into a makeshift Marine Corps base at the Kandahar airport, where they will assume the duties now being performed by more than 1,000 marines.

headline.main: MARINES JOINING GROUND FIGHT; DETAINED TALIBAN STAGE REVOLT

Marines.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of marines landed at a makeshift airfield near the southern city of Kandahar today in the first major infusion of American ground troops into Afghanistan. Their arrival began what Pentagon officials said would be a period of sustained assaults against Taliban and Al Qaeda forces. The marines were to be the front edge of a powerful force of more than 1,000 combat troops who, the officials said, are likely to join the hunt for Osama bin Laden within days and then begin raids against Taliban forces concentrated in Kandahar and in mountain redoubts near the border with Pakistan.

headline.main: MARINES PUSHING FOR LEADING ROLE IN AFGHANISTAN

Marines.lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps is pressing to remove its forces from Iraq and to send marines instead to Afghanistan, to take over the leading role in combat there, according to senior military and Pentagon officials. The idea by the Marine Corps commandant would effectively leave the Iraq war in the hands of the Army while giving the Marines a prominent new role in Afghanistan, under overall NATO command.

headline.main: Secretary Expects Cuts In Marines And the Navy

Marines.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- On a trip to Afghanistan to visit Navy and Marine forces, the secretary of the Navy, Ray Mabus, said Saturday that he expected both branches to reduce their numbers after the Iraq and Afghan wars, and to return to their seafaring roots -- although both will have some new areas of focus. The Marines increased their numbers by about 27,000 in 2006 and 2007 to meet the demands of fighting the war in Iraq and the increase in troops there.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Speak Up, Executives Are Urged

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The president of the agency overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan warned yesterday that real estate and other business executives were in danger of not being heard. ''You're the people with the most knowledge about what would help,'' Louis R. Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said in a speech sponsored by Commercial Property News. He said discussions of the future of Lower Manhattan were in danger of being dominated by advocates like family members of Sept. 11 victims and area residents. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Site Group Criticized

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: City Council members have scolded representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency overseeing rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, for not having a more racially and ethnically diverse board and staff. Council members also said on Monday that they wanted a greater voice in planning the redevelopment. James Sanders Jr., chairman of the Council's Committee on Economic Development, said the agency's 11-member board did not resemble ''the city that it hopes to rebuild.'' Louis Tomson, executive director of the agency, said he would work harder to recruit more women and minorities. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Chairman For Development Corporation

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has named Avi Schick the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding at ground zero, and has named David Emil the corporation's president. Mr. Schick is president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency, and was a deputy attorney general under Mr. Spitzer. Mr. Emil owned Windows on the World, the restaurant on top of the World Trade Center. Mr. Schick, whose salary in the state job is $213,000, will not be further compensated; Mr. Emil's annual salary will be $185,000. DANNY HAKIM

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Residents of Lower Manhattan have until Saturday to apply for up to $14,500 in grants through a federal program meant to increase the residential population of downtown and help the area recover from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is administering the $306 million program, which offers grants to residents of three zones in Lower Manhattan. Most of the grants require two years' residency. Details are available at the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.com, or by calling (866) 736-3969. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation appointed Anita F. Contini as vice president and director for its memorial, cultural and civic programs yesterday. Ms. Contini will be responsible for overseeing the development of a memorial for victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 at the former site of the World Trade Center. In addition, she will coordinate efforts to bring cultural institutions to Lower Manhattan. Since 1999, she has served as a first vice president for global sponsorships and events marketing at Merrill Lynch. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Grants up to $50,000 and monthly rent subsidies of up to $5,000 for small businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack were proposed yesterday to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The roughly $200 million required for the initiative would come from federal Community Development Block Grants. Councilman Alan J. Gerson, above, one of the plan's supporters, said that too much aid had gone to businesses with revenues of more than $1 million. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Lower Manhattan Corporation Names Interim Chief

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation yesterday named Kevin M. Rampe, its executive vice president and general counsel, as interim president, filling the vacancy created last week by the retirement of Louis R. Tomson. Development corporation officials said a permanent president would be appointed ''in the coming weeks.'' As interim president, Mr. Rampe will oversee the day-to-day operation of the development corporation, which just chose Studio Daniel Libeskind as the architect for the World Trade Center site plan.

headline.main: Head of Downtown Rebuilding Agency to Leave

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Louis R. Tomson, the president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, who shepherded the rebuilding process through a sometimes chaotic first year, will resign from the agency effective the end of February, state officials said yesterday. In a letter to Gov. George E. Pataki outlining his plans, Mr. Tomson noted that he had long planned to step down once the development corporation had agreed with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on a development plan for the World Trade Center site and a setting for a memorial to the victims of the attack on the trade center.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Saying that the International Freedom Center planned for the World Trade Center site had become ''very controversial,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he had instructed his appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board to carefully read the center's new report on how it would operate. ''Then we'll discuss it and try to come to some resolution,'' the mayor said. The center was intended to put 9/11 in the context of the world's history of freedom but it has faced criticism that it would detract from the memorial and deprive the memorial museum of space. Speaking of exhibitions planned for the center, Mr. Bloomberg said, ''Some things you might want to put elsewhere.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Arts At Ground Zero: $100 Million or More?

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: A committee of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation on Wednesday recommended that the corporation allocate at least $100 million for the performing arts center planned for ground zero. The money would come from a pool of some $200 million formerly designated for utility companies. At the corporation's board meeting on Wednesday, Kate D. Levin, the New York City cultural affairs commissioner, said the money was important ''to fulfill this critical part of the master plan.'' The financing, which requires approval by the full board, would add to $50 million in federal money set aside for the project, which is controlled by the development corporation. Still unresolved is whether to build the center on the World Trade Center site, as called for in the master plan, or at 130 Liberty Street, site of the former Deutsche Bank building. The center's primary tenant is to be the Joyce Theater, which presents dance.

headline.main: Ground Zero Decision Expected

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: A meeting of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation this week is expected to produce a decision on a cultural component for the World Trade Center site, people involved in the process say. They said the main candidates were the Joyce Theater, which presents dance; the Signature Theater Company; and a Museum of Freedom. Other groups expected to provide programming on the site are the New York Hall of Science in Queens and the Drawing Center, which exhibits historical and contemporary drawings. The decision would bring to a close a competition among cultural institutions that began a year ago with an invitation to arts groups worldwide. The invitation brought 113 proposals in September, which were narrowed to 15 finalists in February. The board of the development corporation is to make its decision in coordination with the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts. ROBIN POGREBIN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but ''would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Revisions To 9/11 Memorial

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: There may be some fine tuning added to the design of the World Trade Center memorial to meet security concerns, the state's top antiterror official, James K. Kallstrom, said yesterday. Mr. Kallstrom, a senior adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki and director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said that the plans were reviewed months ago by the Police Department and that he did not foresee significant changes, but added that the design might be modified ''so that we can react to whatever threat we're at here in the city.'' At the same corporation board meeting, John C. Whitehead, the chairman, said the waterfalls within the twin memorial voids would be able to run year round. Construction of the memorial is to begin in March. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Tackling Trade Center Design

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: While high-profile architectural firms have offered competing proposals for the World Trade Center site, students from Stuyvesant High School, just blocks from ground zero, have formed an after-school club to offer their own ideas. The club, Stuyvesant Rebuilds, met once a week last semester to discuss the architectural and environmental issues they might face in redesigning Lower Manhattan. Guest speakers included MITCHELL MOSS, a professor of urban planning at New York University, and HUGH O'NEILL, a former assistant executive director of the Port Authority. The students will build a model conforming to architectural guidelines from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation next semester and plan to submit it for review in the spring. Mark Glassman

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Dismissed On Trade Center Floor Slab

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: A lawsuit by the Coalition of 9/11 Families seeking to compel the preservation of the concrete floor slab where 1 World Trade Center stood has been dismissed by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich of the State Supreme Court. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the lead defendant, received the decision yesterday. Justice Kornreich said it had been known since April 2004 that the slab would not be subject to historical preservation review, meaning that the lawsuit was filed too late. She wrote that the historical review process ''has been met'' restored text here and that the development corporation had acted in ''a commendable and sensitive manner.'' DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 1993 Terror Attack Representative

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The agency overseeing the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site agreed yesterday to add a representative from the families of victims of the 1993 terror attack on the twin towers. The agency, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said it would add Michael Macko, whose father, William J. Macko, a Port Authority mechanical supervisor, died nine years ago today, to one of its advisory committees. Senator Charles E. Schumer said he would ask President Bush to extend some benefits that are available to families of last year's victims to families of the victims of the 1993 attack. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Biotech Start-Ups Are Endorsed

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has endorsed a proposal by nine prominent institutions, including Columbia University, New York University, Cornell University, Mount Sinai and Albert Einstein medical schools and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, to build a biotechnology research centerdowntown. The chairman, John C. Whitehead, said on Tuesday that it was the type of project needed in the redevelopment effort near ground zero. The proposal could lead to one million square feet of office space devoted to commercializing medical discoveries. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: $350 Million Is Approved To Retain Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation approved a $350 million expansion of grant programs yesterday to encourage businesses to stay in downtown Manhattan or move there, raising the total available for those programs to more than $1 billion. The approval was less than half what city and state economic development officials had requested, however.

headline.main: What's Next

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: TOMORROW A public comment period begins with the opening of a six-week exhibit of plans with videos of architects explaining their work at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center. Open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily, through Feb. 3. Plans are also online at www.LowerManhattan.info and RenewNyc.org. Videos will also be distributed to public libraries in the city.

headline.main: Major Forum Is Scheduled To Discuss Trade Center Site

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Officials and civic groups involved in the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan said yesterday that they were planning a large public hearing and discussion about the effort in late July, with up to 5,000 participants. The sponsors of the meeting -- the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the city-state agency overseeing the rebuilding process, and the Civic Alliance, a coalition of nonprofit citizens' and planning groups -- said it would be based on the model for a similar forum that they held in February at the South Street Seaport.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Rejecting a request to immediately halt work at the World Trade Center site, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that site preparation for the World Trade Center Memorial could continue until late April. ''It seems to me that there's no building going on here, so we certainly don't need a temporary restraining order,'' Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich said, responding to a request by the families of trade center victims to halt construction of a $330 million memorial and a $160 million museum because, they argued, it would damage historic remnants in violation of state statutes. Lower Manhattan Development Corporation lawyers promised that only inspection, cleaning and protection of the remnants would proceed until an April 27 hearing. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

headline.main: Ex-Pataki Aide to Lead Trade Center Rebuilding

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: Kevin M. Rampe, a lawyer and former aide to Gov. George E. Pataki who also represented Kuwait in claims against Iraq stemming from the Persian Gulf war in 1991, was appointed yesterday to lead the agency overseeing redevelopment of the World Trade Center site. Mr. Rampe was appointed president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation by Mr. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg roughly 15 weeks after he was named interim president of the agency. He replaced Louis R. Tomson, a longtime Pataki aide who retired at the end of February.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

Lower Manhattan Development Corp..lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has reopened the exhibit of design concepts for the World Trade Center site. The exhibit, at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, has been reorganized to display the two designs under consideration: Memory Foundations by Studio Daniel Libeskind and the World Cultural Center by the Think team (Shigeru Ban, Frederic Schwartz, Ken Smith and Rafael Viñoly). The exhibit will continue until the end of this month, when a winner will be chosen and displayed through April. The exhibit is open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Partying For Money, But Quietly

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The National Republican Senatorial Committee is holding its seventh annual fund-raising bash tonight in Washington. It is the first to be held while Republicans control the White House, but it will not have the benefit of a White House headliner. Republicans say it would be inappropriate for either President Bush or Vice President Dick Cheney to make partisan fund-raising appeals in person while the nation is at war. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

headline.main: Obama Plans to Host Uruguay's President Next Month
headline.print_headline: Obama Plans to Host Uruguay's President Next Month

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House says Uruguay's president is planning to visit next month.

headline.main: White House Will Reopen for School Tours

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Public tours of the White House will resume on a limited basis for school groups in early February after being halted following the Sept. 11 attacks, the president's spokesman said today. ''Spring is often a time of great tourism in Washington,'' said the spokesman, Ari Fleischer, ''and much of that tourism comes from school groups coming to town, and the White House will again be open for business as schoolchildren visit.''

headline.main: A Burial at Sea Aimed to Prevent a Shrine on Land

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: White House officials decided before Monday's firefight in northern Pakistan that if American troops killed Osama bin Laden, they would bury him at sea in order to prevent his grave from becoming a shrine for his followers, a White House official said Monday. They planned to include all rites associated with Muslim burials, the official added. American officials stressed Monday that the sea burial followed Islamic custom. ''The disposal of -- the burial of Bin Laden's remains was done in strict conformance with Islamic precepts and practices,'' said John O. Brennan, President Obama's top counterterrorism adviser, who added that the administration had consulted with Islamic experts.

headline.main: BUDGET CHIEF IN
headline.kicker: TOP AIDE LEAVES WHITE HOUSE JOB

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush replaced his chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., with another longtime loyalist on Tuesday, a step unlikely to satisfy calls within his own party for fresh thinking to address the administration's troubles. In turning to Joshua B. Bolten, his budget director, as the new chief of staff, the president stayed within what one close associate called a ''circle of comfort'' and what Mr. Bush's critics consider a closed world that brooks little doubt or dissent.

headline.main: White House Apologizes for No Notice on Bergdahl
headline.print_headline: White House Apologizes for No Notice on Bergdahl

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House has apologized to key lawmakers for not notifying them in advance about the exchange of five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl (boh BURG'-dahl).

headline.main: Bush Plans Visit To Police Dept.

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush plans to visit the New York Police Department tomorrow to discuss the domestic antiterrorism portion of his budget, the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said yesterday.

headline.main: NATIONAL: October 6-12; COMING UP

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush is scheduled to meet with the Israeli prime minister at the White House on Wednesday. He plans to make campaign trips to Michigan on Monday, to Georgia on Thursday and to Missouri and Minnesota on Friday. Congress will try to wrap up its business before its election recess, considering legislation on homeland security, terrorism insurance and on a continuing budget resolution.

headline.main: Obama Names G.E. Chairman To Fiscal Panel

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. -- President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center. Here in the birthplace of General Electric, Mr. Obama introduced the new appointee, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, who will serve as chairman of his outside panel of economic advisers. Mr. Immelt succeeds Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down.

headline.seo: Benjamin Rhodes, Obama’s Voice, Helps Shape Policy
headline.main: Worldly at 35, and Shaping Obama’s Voice
headline.print_headline: Worldly at 35, And Shaping Obama’s Voice

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Benjamin J. Rhodes is a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation as the man who channels President Obama on foreign policy.

headline.seo: In Book, Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria Nuclear Site
headline.main: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in ’07
headline.print_headline: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in ’07

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: In a memoir, former Vice President Dick Cheney expresses little regret about Bush administration decisions.

headline.seo: Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election
headline.main: Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election
headline.print_headline: Handicapping Obama 2012

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The killer calculus of the president’s re-election chances.

headline.main: U.S. Is Gaining In Afghanistan, General Writes In Upbeat Letter

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Just hours before President Obama gave his State of the Union address, his commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David H. Petraeus, offered what amounted to his own ''state of the war'' address, one noticeably more upbeat than a White House assessment issued late last year. The general's assessment, in the form of a letter to troops posted on the NATO Web site, outlined a fight in which troops and the military machine here had gained the edge or was on the cusp of doing so on every front. He described victory as attainable only through a vast, coordinated effort to bring Afghanistan security, good governance and economic development.

headline.seo: Marc Thiessen Gets  an Earful for Waterboarding Views
headline.main: Defender of Waterboarding Hears From Critics
headline.print_headline: Catholic Defender of Waterboarding Gets an Earful From Critics

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Liberal and conservative Catholics have objected to arguments made by a former Bush speechwriter that church teachings permitted waterboarding.

headline.main: Page Two: June 13-19; THE WHITE HOUSE RESPONDS

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush and Vice President Cheney have frequently suggested, and sometimes said outright, that Iraq and Al Qaeda were working together and could pose a big threat to national security. So when the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks issued a report last week that concluded that Iraq had not supported Al Qaeda, it spelled political trouble. If the commission is correct, then one of Mr. Bush's reasons for taking the country to war with Iraq would be undermined.

headline.main: PRESIDENT ACTS ON TWO FRONTS AGAINST CRITICS

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush moved on Friday night to try to stem potentially damaging election-year questions about his military record and whether the White House mishandled intelligence threats before the Sept. 11 attacks.
