In dual announcements capping a week of intense political pressure on Mr. Bush, the White House said it had decided to release all documents from the president's National Guard files and, within hours, disclosed that Mr. Bush would appear before a commission investigating the terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Bush Emphasizes, More Than Once, That He Doesn't Have Anthrax

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: ''First of all,'' President Bush declared today, ''I don't have anthrax.'' A few minutes later, he repeated, ''I don't have anthrax.'' And then for a third time, perhaps to make sure he was understood, Mr. Bush ended a brief question-and-answer session with reporters by saying, ''I don't have it.''

headline.main: White House Evaluating Video of Purported Henning Beheading
headline.print_headline: White House Evaluating Video of Purported Henning Beheading

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House is aware of a video purporting to show the beheading of British hostage Alan Henning by Islamic State militants and is evaluating it, a U.S. official said.

headline.seo: For Pakistan, No Formal Remorse Yet From Obama
headline.main: Obama Refrains From a Formal ‘I’m Sorry’ to Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Obama Refrains, for Now, From a Formal ‘I’m Sorry’ to Pakistan

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House has for now overruled State Department officials who favored a show of remorse to help salvage relations after a NATO airstrike killed Pakistani soldiers.

headline.main: Domestic Security Adviser Named

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House named Kenneth L. Wainstein, a senior Justice Department official, to be President Bush's homeland security adviser. Mr. Wainstein now heads the National Security Division, which coordinates the Justice Department's counterterrorism, intelligence and counterespionage efforts. He was formerly the top federal prosecutor in Washington and general counsel and chief of staff at the F.B.I.

headline.seo: Obama Says Mosque Remarks Were Not Endorsement
headline.main: Obama Enters Debate With Mosque Remarks
headline.print_headline: Obama Says Mosque Remarks Were About Rights

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s attempt to reframe comments about a community center in New York City had him plunging into a debate about Islam and American identity.

headline.main: Obama Meets With Interim Secret Service Director
headline.print_headline: Obama Meets With Interim Secret Service Director

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The White House says President Barack Obama has met with the retired Secret Service agent who is leading the agency until a new director is named.

headline.main: Obama Strongly Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site
headline.print_headline: Obama Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: After weeks of avoiding the high-profile battle, President Obama stepped into the thorny debate, leaving little doubt about how he feels.

headline.seo: A Brief Victory Lap Before Budget Fight Strains ‘Unity’ Call
headline.main: A Brief Victory Lap Before Budget Fight Strains ‘Unity’ Call
headline.print_headline: A Brief Victory Lap Before Budget Fight Strains ‘Unity’ Call

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Despite national pride over the successful mission to remove Osama bin Laden, few see much prospect of a dawn of bipartisanship.

headline.main: A Bush Dinner Joke Amuses (and Does Not)

George W Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Laughter filled the room Wednesday night at the annual dinner for radio and television correspondents when President Bush displayed a photograph showing him down on his hands and knees looking under furniture in his office and saying, ''Those weapons of mass destruction have got to be somewhere!'' This morning the joke did not seem quite so funny. CNN, which showed a clip of the event, was getting e-mail messages from unhappy viewers. Foreign newspapers were reacting with outrage. And the White House was busy defending the joke that President Bush delivered as he put on a slide show, called the ''White House Election-Year Album,'' at the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association's 60th annual dinner.

headline.seo: In N.Y. Subway Cavern by Ground Zero, a 9/11 Deadline
headline.main: M.T.A. Crew in a Cavern Has an Eye on Sept. 11
headline.print_headline: M.T.A. Crew In a Cavern Has an Eye On Sept. 11

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Work at the southbound platform of the Cortlandt Street station, closed for 7 of the last 10 years, is said to be on schedule.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Victim Dies Of Wounds

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Three months to the day after the attack on the World Trade Center, the disaster claimed another victim. David Bernard, 57, of Chelmsford, Mass., died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital of injuries from being hit by the rain of debris from the north tower of the trade center. Mr. Bernard worked as an industry specialist for the Internal Revenue Service and was based in Boston. But he had traveled to Lower Manhattan for a meeting at the I.R.S. offices at 7 World Trade Center. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donation To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The producers of the film ''World Trade Center'' are donating $1.3 million, or 5 percent of its opening-weekend proceeds, to the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the foundation said yesterday. Another $1.3 million will be divided among three other 9/11-related charities. The producers of the Paramount Pictures film, about police officers trapped in the trade center rubble, had promised a total donation of 10 percent of the box office proceeds from its opening weekend to the foundation and the other charities.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: World Trade Center Site Expands

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The boundaries of the World Trade Center redevelopment project were expanded yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to include the 7 World Trade Center parcel immediately to the north, across Vesey Street. This could eventually permit the reopening of Greenwich Street, between Vesey and Barclay Streets, as a two-lane southbound roadway. It is now a dead end, used for drop-offs at 7 World Trade Center. South of Vesey Street, Greenwich Street is to be recreated through the main trade center site as a four-lane southbound roadway. It was closed in the 1960s to make way for the trade center superblock. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Deal Inked for World Trade Center Wi-Fi
headline.print_headline: Deal Inked for World Trade Center Wi-Fi

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Officials say commuters and visitors at the World Trade Center will be able to take advantage of free WiFi.

headline.main: Images to Aid Disaster Relief

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The run on postcards showing the World Trade Center gave James Danziger, chief executive of Artland.com, the idea of offering 11 high-quality prints by photographers in his stable -- Joel Meyerowitz, Sheila Metzner, Tom Baril and Richard Berenholtz. At right, ''The Twin Towers II'' by Ms. Metzner, $295 unframed. Proceeds go to the New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund. The color and black-and-white photographs are $195 to $295; www.Artland .com. MARISA BARTOLUCCI

headline.main: Page Two: Nov. 23-29; RE-OPENED FOR BUSINESS

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: In the most tangible way yet, the site of the former World Trade Center began its slow metamorphosis into something more than a place of loss: commuters returned aboard the PATH train. Last Sunday, the ceremonial reopening of the rebuilt World Trade Center station was mostly attended by the important and the curious. But by Monday, the station was filled with the suited, workaday crowds of Lower Manhattan. A few cried as they gripped the station's latticework walls and stared at ground zero, but others just charged up the escalators to get to work. Michael Luo

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to contribute $3 million to the Tribute Center, the temporary 9/11 memorial that is scheduled to open in the spring at 120 Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center site. The center's Introductory/Orientation Gallery will be named for the Port Authority, and Port Authority employees will lead tours of the site from there. Supporting the center ''is in line with our mission of revitalizing Lower Manhattan and redeveloping the World Trade Center site,'' said James Connors, a Port Authority executive. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

headline.seo: Payal Agrawal, Sanjay Divakaran - Weddings
headline.main: Payal Agrawal, Sanjay Divakaran
headline.print_headline: Payal Agrawal, Sanjay Divakaran

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The couple will marry in Boston.

headline.main: Payal Agrawal, Sanjay Divakaran

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Payal Agrawal, a daughter of Kusum Agrawal and Subhash Agrawal of Dracut, Mass., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Sanjay Divakaran, a son of Maria D. Divakaran and Dr. Diva Divakaran of East Meadow, N.Y. Pandit Srinivasa Shastri, a Hindu priest, is to officiate at the Seaport World Trade Center in Boston. The couple, both 25, met at M.I.T., from which they graduated.

headline.seo: For Bobby Fischer, The Drama Won’t Die
headline.main: For Bobby Fischer, the Drama Won’t Die
headline.print_headline: For Bobby Fischer, The Drama Won’t Die

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The chess master’s estate is disputed by a Japanese woman who claims she was his wife, a Filipino woman who says she is the mother of his child, and two nephews.

headline.seo: A 9/11 Widow Balances Her Family, a Job and Islam
headline.main: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
headline.print_headline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Hadidjatou Karamoko Traoré is a 9/11 widow who has had to balance an overnight job, three children and her Muslim faith.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Rejecting a request to immediately halt work at the World Trade Center site, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that site preparation for the World Trade Center Memorial could continue until late April. ''It seems to me that there's no building going on here, so we certainly don't need a temporary restraining order,'' Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich said, responding to a request by the families of trade center victims to halt construction of a $330 million memorial and a $160 million museum because, they argued, it would damage historic remnants in violation of state statutes. Lower Manhattan Development Corporation lawyers promised that only inspection, cleaning and protection of the remnants would proceed until an April 27 hearing. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

headline.seo: Trinity Church, a Sanctuary for Music, Cuts Back
headline.main: Churchly Sanctuary for Music Cuts Back
headline.print_headline: Churchly Sanctuary For Music Cuts Back

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: On a path to becoming a major cultural force downtown, Trinity Church blinks, announcing it would explore “additional funding sources and programming options.”

headline.main: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds
headline.print_headline: Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Larry Davis, owner of DCM Erectors Inc., is expected to be charged with evading requirements on hiring subcontractors, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. To Receive FEMA Aid

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: New York University said yesterday that the federal government had agreed to cover some of the expenses incurred from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The decision by the Federal Emergency Management Agency reverses an earlier determination that the university would not qualify for such reimbursement. N.Y.U. said the turnabout was a result of strong support from New York's Congressional delegation and Gov. George E. Pataki. N.Y.U. had submitted a list of about $10 million in expenses, which included the cost of rehousing students and removing debris from dormitories near the World Trade Center. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

headline.main: Scraping a Little More Sky Downtown
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have prohibited admission or other fees at the World Trade Center memorial, museum or visitor center, his office said yesterday. Mr. Pataki said the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation could not rule out charging the public, given what he estimated would be the $50 million annual cost of operating a memorial and museum at ground zero. State Senator Martin J. Golden, the Brooklyn Republican who introduced the bill, had said ''there should be no barriers,'' including fees, that would prevent people from paying their respects. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Loan Is Paid Off

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the developer Larry A. Silverstein used $702 million in insurance proceeds from the World Trade Center complex yesterday to pay off a lender and the company that operated the retail mall at the complex. In what he said was an effort to ease the rebuilding process, Mr. Silverstein paid GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation $562 million to satisfy the loan he took out when he leased the trade center in 2001. The Port Authority simultaneously paid Westfield America $140 million for its retail interest in the trade center. The deal allowed Mr. Silverstein to get back most of the $125 million in equity he and his partners put into the winning bid for the trade center leases. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.seo: Pleas to Rebuild Church Destroyed on 9/11
headline.main: Amid Furor on Islamic Center, Pleas for Orthodox Church Nearby
headline.print_headline: Amid Furor on Islamic Center, Pleas for Orthodox Church Nearby

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Amid a furor over a planned Islamic center near ground zero, a Greek Orthodox bishop joined two politicians in pressing for rebuilding St. Nicholas Church.

headline.main: World Trade Center Logo Captures Site’s Destruction and Rebirth
headline.print_headline: Resilience and Rebirth in Trade Center Logo

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey unveiled a new symbol on Wednesday for the 16-acre site — a stylized W packed with references to the area’s past and present.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Businesses Seek Aid

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Members of the World Trade Center Tenants Association called yesterday for more government grant money and urged that eligibility requirements for business-relief funds be eased. They urged the Empire State Development Corporation to quadruple the money it gives to trade center tenants, to 16 percent of each business's annual gross revenue, and to lower companies' eligibility to 4 employees or more from 10 or more. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: A Lone Oklahoma Tower's Clear but Uncomfortable Links to 9/11

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. -- The phones rattled with the sound of an explosion. It was Sept. 11, and some of the traders at an energy company here had been speaking with colleagues at a financial company in the World Trade Center in New York. Suddenly, routine business calls became frantic dictations of final messages to loved ones. Then the lines went dead. In a strange twist of fate, the office tower here where those messages were scribbled -- rising 52 stories above this sprawling oil town -- bears an eerie resemblance to those fallen twins in New York, one so striking that executives would joke that the architect who designed all three buildings had simply shrunk his blueprints.

headline.main: Thieves of Light, Built by Barbarians
headline.print_headline: Thieves of Light, Built by Barbarians

World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: One World Trade Center will soon return the title of tallest American building to New York City. But time was when the city tried to severely limit building height.

headline.main: Only ABC Broadcasts Bush Talk

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: President Bush's speech threw the broadcast networks into a quandary last night, separating them, at least for a time, between those committed to getting the president on the air and those committed to their hit shows. In the end, only ABC pre-empted its lineup to carry the president, beginning at 8 p.m.

headline.main: At CNN, No Reuters, or bin Laden

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Outside of a newsroom, a half-hour delay in obtaining video may seem like a minor inconvenience at best. But to television news executives, the lag in catching up to the competition can be a challenge. That was the predicament CNN faced just after 3:15 p.m. on Friday, as a grainy 75-second tape of Osama bin Laden's latest message began running in a seemingly endless loop on the cable news network's chief rivals, Fox News Channel and MSNBC.

headline.main: Fox Says It Won't Accept Ads For Its Special on 9/11 Attacks

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: The News Corporation's broadcast and cable news networks, Fox and Fox News Channel, have decided not to accept any advertisements or program sponsorships for their coverage of the one-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. The decisions come at a time when all of the cable news and broadcast networks are having a hard time attracting sponsors to their 9/11 programming. Many advertisers fear their sunny, everyday, 30-second spots will seem crass in contrast to the somber coverage. But Paul Rittenberg, the Fox News Channel senior vice president in charge of sales, said that as the network devised its full-day coverage plans, he realized he simply could not conceive of selling time just the same.

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Internet: MSNBC Starts Arabic Site

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: MSNBC inaugurated an Arabic-language news Web site yesterday, entering an area that is a hot market for news and media. The Web site, at www.gn4msnbc.com is produced with Good News 4 Me, a media company based in Cairo that was founded by Emadeddin Adib, a veteran journalist and television host. The site will provide selected news reports as well as streaming audio and video in Arabic. Good News 4 Me will operate and maintain the site. MSNBC already had Turkish, French and German versions of its site, but its deal with the Egyptian company is its first Arabic-language content. MSNBC.com, like other news sites, has had a surge in audience traffic since Sept. 11. According to a recent Jupiter Media Metrix report, MSNBC.com had a 66 percent jump in traffic in September, to 22.2 million visitors. CNN had even greater growth, with Web visitors more than doubling, to 24.8 million. CNN is creating CNNarabic.com, an Arabic-language site to be run out of a new CNN bureau being built in Dubai. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline.main: After the Military Strikes, Solid Information and Details Were Slow in Arriving

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: It has become an American television ritual: As United States military forces take action, sporting events, comedy shows and dramatic series give way to the grim faces of news anchors and the hazy green, night-vision images of explosions and antiaircraft fire. That ritual was repeated yesterday, but given the secretive nature of the campaign and the remoteness of the target, solid information was less available than it has been in other conflicts; clear pictures of the action were even harder to come by.

headline.main: Draping Newscasts With the Flag

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: On the Fox News Channel Tuesday, the anchor Jon Scott told Wolfgang Ischinger, the German ambassador to the United States, ''We look forward to working with your country in wiping out these terrorists.'' Reporting from the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, the CNN financial news anchor Lou Dobbs said, ''This country is blessed with a very strong economy and the greatest democracy in the world.''

headline.main: Networks Find Tape Provides Little News

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: The major TV news networks gave Osama bin Laden's latest message significant weight yesterday, even though most of what he said was not really new. All stayed true to promises made to the White House in October that they would handle Al Qaeda videotapes carefully lest they contain hidden messages to terrorist operatives. None showed the tape in its entirety.

headline.main: Hearts, Minds and Satellites

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: It was hard to tell what, exactly, was going on within the green, flashing static shown on CNN last Tuesday. The images were said to be an exclusive look at bombs dropping on Kabul, captured by a videophone. In the newsrooms of CNN's competitors, there were titters. The pixelated CNN screen was compared to an Etch-a-Sketch, a Rorschach drawing and an aquarium (''Was that a guppy that just swam by?'' asked one competing executive; another said he possibly saw the face of the Lord).

headline.main: Extensive Coverage Brings Strong Ratings For the Day

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: The extensive television news coverage of the events on the first anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks attracted strong ratings for cable news networks for their daylong coverage as well as for broadcast networks in prime time. But even after nonstop coverage on multiple channels all day, the biggest television event of the anniversary coverage was the replay by CBS of the documentary film about one company of New York firefighters and their escape from the first World Trade Center tower just before it collapsed. The film, ''9/11,'' attracted just over 12 million viewers, making it the most watched individual program broadcast on Wednesday.

headline.main: Fox News, Media Elite

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Election Night 2004 delivered more than one decisive victory. As Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News, and Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of its parent company, News Corporation, entertained their guests with cheeseburgers and hot dogs in a suite down the hall from the control room, Fox's cable news channel was dramatically consolidating its ratings gains of the past few years.

headline.main: Far Conflict Challenges TV Networks Shy of Cash
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE HOME SCREEN

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: As scores of journalists around the world scramble to get to Pakistan's capital, less than a three-hour drive from the Afghan border, American broadcast news operations are confronting the reality of two decades' worth of budget cuts in foreign news. Unlike the recent Macedonian conflict or the violent civil wars in Africa, the developments around Afghanistan since last week's terrorist attacks in the United States have the full attention of the American news media. But information about the terrorist network attributed to Osama bin Laden is scattered across a daunting region that the networks have tended to cover from London.

headline.main: Audience for Cable News Grows

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Immediately after Sept. 11, there were predictions that the terrorist attacks would prove to be a seminal moment for the television news business. Young people, some thought, would finally find more reason to watch the news on CBS than on MTV. Audiences that had long ago left cable news programs for documentaries on the History Channel or movies on Bravo would return to CNN -- and maybe even check out the relative newcomers, like the Fox News Channel and MSNBC. Broadcast news would return to prominence.

headline.main: 'Apprentice' Interrupted

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: One small side effect of the breaking news Sunday night was that it pushed Donald Trump off the air just as he was about fire somebody on NBC's ''Celebrity Apprentice.'' The news superseded that moment, of course, and left NBC with few options to let fans of ''Celebrity Apprentice,'' which is one of the network's most successful shows, see what transpired.

headline.main: Good Connections (and $30) Secures an Afghan Expedition

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the war began, Western reporters this week entered the Afghan city of Kandahar, sending out images of the battle on ABC News, CNN and the BBC and other outlets. To get there meant working their way through a bazaar of information brokers that has sprung up in the enclaves of Western reporters in the Pakistani cities of Islamabad and Quetta.

headline.main: Networks Move to Revive Foreign News

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Only a month ago, Walter Isaacson, the new chairman of CNN, spoke expansively about the need to broaden the definition of news. Audience interest in foreign affairs was waning, he said, and so was interest in Washington. CNN -- acknowledged to be the last holdout among the major news networks in veering toward softer subjects -- would increase its focus on entertainment and technology, health and fitness, he said. Personalities -- stars -- would carry programming when news could not. ''The goal should be to make the news smart, but also fun and fascinating,'' he said.

headline.main: The Nation: Perspective on the Press; Fox News Moves From the Margins to the Mainstream

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: LESLIE H. GELB, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, watches international news obsessively, skipping from channel to channel. ''I never watch a commercial,'' he said. He now considers Fox News Channel often to be a more reliable news source for international reporting than CNN or the nightly network news. Fox, he said, provides a ''fairer picture, a fuller version of the different parts of the arguments'' over world affairs.

headline.main: Taking To Television: Easing Back Into Political Scene, Cheney Grants ABC Interview

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Dick Cheney, who has been slowly re-entering political life since undergoing heart transplant surgery in March, will sit down Friday for his first network television interview this year. Jonathan Karl of ABC News will conduct the interview from Jackson Hole, Wyo., where Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, has a home. Portions of the interview will be broadcast first on Sunday on ABC's public affairs program ''This Week with George Stephanopoulos.'' And ABC will use other segments from the exclusive sit-down with Mr. Cheney on Monday during their three major news broadcasts, ''Good Morning America,'' ''World News with Diane Sawyer'' and ''Nightline.''

headline.main: Enormous TV Audience Peaked With Bush Talk

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: The coverage of the terrorist attacks in Manhattan and in the Washington area brought tens of millions of Americans to television sets throughout Tuesday, peaking with President Bush's address to the nation, which reached about 80 million viewers, according to preliminary figures. Complete national figures for the size of the audience on Tuesday will not be available from Nielsen Media Research until at least today. But several networks reported what are called preliminary ''fast national'' ratings for the prime-time hours on Tuesday night, and the cable news networks had preliminary figures from most of the country's 50 biggest cities.

headline.main: Connie Chung Gets CNN Prime-Time Spot

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: Connie Chung, who has been among TV's best-known news personalities for two decades, is moving from ABC News to CNN in what is the cable news network's latest effort to increase its roster of stars. Ms. Chung, who is one of only two women to have been regular co-anchors of a network evening newscast -- when she sat next to Dan Rather at CBS in a partnership that ended in bitterness -- will be the anchor of a new CNN program weeknights at 8.

headline.main: CNN Returns to Its Element but Faces High Expectations

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: One CNN correspondent was ordered out of Afghanistan on Monday under threat that his life was in imminent peril. Another correspondent became so ill he collapsed on camera while in the middle of a report. But CNN continues to promise that the network will be in a position to provide exclusive coverage of any American military action that might take place there. Until last week, CNN was on the defensive, having lost ground as the dominant provider of cable news to the rapidly growing Fox News Network.

headline.main: To Portray The Horror, News Media Agonize
headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: ISSUES OF TASTE

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: As photographs and videotaped images of the attack on four private security workers in Falluja arrived at news organizations yesterday, editors and producers faced an immediate challenge: how to show what happened without offending viewers and readers? Most large newspapers decided the horror of the day's events could not be fully conveyed without employing at least some of the more grisly images. But on television -- where the impact of the images would arguably be more powerful -- no consensus emerged.

headline.main: Network Coverage a Target Of Fire From Conservatives

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: As television news networks cover the war, they are increasingly coming under criticism from conservatives who say they exhibit a lack of patriotism or are overly negative toward the government. Although the networks say the criticism is not affecting their coverage, they are having to sort through basic issues like whether patriotism can coexist with objectivity and how to raise tough questions about the policies of an administration that is receiving overwhelming popular support.

headline.main: Rather Reports Another War, This Time in a Windbreaker

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: In one of the seminal moments of his career, Dan Rather sneaked into Afghanistan in 1980 and dodged Soviet bullets wearing the uniform of the Mujahedeen fighters for a report on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' The piece introduced the Afghan warriors to America and won Mr. Rather the nickname ''Gunga Dan.'' Since Sept. 11, news executives at competing networks have been wondering whether Mr. Rather would return to the country, and he has.

headline.main: BIN LADEN INTERVIEW

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: The Arab television station Al Jazeera said in a statement that it never aired an October interview with Osama bin Laden because it was conducted under duress and the questions were dictated to its correspondent. The statement was the latest Al Jazeera said CNN, which aired the interview on Thursday, had obtained the tape illegally. A CNN official denied that and said Al Jazeera should explain why it had never made the tape public.

headline.main: Afghanistan Is Pushing TV To the Sounds Radio Used

TV News Coverage.lead_paragraph: For all of television's technological advances, its video phones and high-speed satellite hookups, its coverage of the first two days of strikes against Afghanistan has provided so few pictures that television news executives compared their reports to radio dispatches. In fact, some even said radio reporters in World War II were better off. ''Not only is there a lack of pictures, we don't even have people to describe things -- there are no Edward R. Murrows anywhere,'' said Paul Friedman, the executive vice president of ABC News.

headline.main: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security
headline.print_headline: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Ellen Saracini wants airlines to have to install a second security door to the cockpit, but the airline industry says that isn’t necessary.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Settlement In Bias Case

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The government has reached a settlement with American Airlines over complaints that after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the airline unlawfully removed passengers it thought were of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, agreed to spend about $1.5 million over three years for civil rights training for employees who deal with the public. It did not admit that it broke federal antidiscrimination laws.

headline.main: No Charge to Fly Sept. 11

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines said today that it would not charge anyone for flying Sept. 11, the first anniversary of deadly terrorist attacks on the United States. The company said the offer was good for those booking flights by Sept. 8 through the airline's Web site or travel agents.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Sabena At The Edge

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The Belgian airline Sabena may be knocked into bankruptcy by last week's attacks on the United States, the airline's chairman, Fred Chaffart, said. Mr. Chaffart said reservations were drying up and fuel, insurance and other costs were climbing fast. The airline, which has not made a profit in nearly two decades, is embroiled in a fight with its unions over a proposed $399 million bailout plan that calls for eliminating 1,600 jobs. Paul Meller (NYT)

headline.main: Continental Announces the Layoff of 12,000

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: As losses mounted from the national grounding of air traffic last week, Continental Airlines announced yesterday that it would immediately lay off 12,000 people, or more than 20 percent of its work force, and reduce its flight schedule by 20 percent. It was the first major airline to announce layoffs, but airline executives predicted that others would soon follow.

headline.main: DISCOUNTS FOR BUSINESS TRAVELERS TO BE EXTENDED

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: United Airlines will extend discounts for business travelers to March from December as it tries to win back customers after the Sept. 11 attacks. The company, the second-largest airline, is offering business travelers 50 percent off an unrestricted business fare, which requires a 21-day advance purchase, and 25 percent off a ticket bought 10 days in advance. The offer was extended to March 31 from Dec. 31, it said in a statement. The airline, owned by the UAL Corporation, is based in Chicago.

headline.main: Airlines Ask for More Money, Citing Higher Security Costs

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The airlines asked Congress for financial help today, saying security costs imposed after the terrorist attacks are hampering their recovery. Little more than a year after the government gave the airlines $5 billion in cash, airline executives asked the House aviation subcommittee to consider tax relief, reimbursement for security costs and an extension of the terrorism insurance policies issued by the government after the attacks.

headline.main: US Warns of Explosives in Toothpaste Tubes
headline.print_headline: US Warns of Explosives in Toothpaste Tubes

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Homeland Security Department is warning airlines flying to Russia that terrorists may try to smuggle explosives on board hidden in toothpaste tubes.

headline.main: U.S. and Airline Settle Bias Complaints

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The government announced a settlement on Friday with Continental Airlines over accusations that the airline discriminated after the Sept. 11 terror attacks against travelers believed to have been of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The Transportation Department started getting complaints about Continental flights in the weeks after the attacks, a spokesman, Bill Mosley, said. Mr. Mosley said four passengers complained that they were removed from flights because of their ethnic background or national origin.

headline.main: Travel Advisory; Airlines Impose Curbs On Children Alone

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Children age 11 and younger can no longer fly unaccompanied on most major domestic airline flights that require a connection, even if the connection is on the same carrier. The new rules were adopted by most airlines following the Sept. 11 hijacking and destruction of four jetliners. ''The limitations are a precaution due to the uncertainty of flight schedules,'' said Al Becker, an American Airlines spokesman. ''All other rules and guidelines regarding travel by unaccompanied minors still apply.''

headline.main: CONTINENTAL PLANS SHARE SALE TO RAISE MONEY

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Continental Airlines plans to raise about $151.7 million by selling common shares next week, giving the company more cash as it contends with a loss this quarter. The 6.74 million shares of Class B stock, expected to be issued Monday, will be priced at $22.50 each, the airline said. Continental, which has about 55.4 million Class B shares outstanding, plans to use the money for general corporate purposes. Stock in Continental, which is based in Houston, fell $2.40, to $21.70 a share.

headline.main: Airlines May Create Own Insurance Plan

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: With the market for war liability insurance for airlines all but dried up since Sept. 11, the nation's major carriers are discussing the creation of their own insurance company. Working with an insurance unit of Marsh & McLennan Companies, the Air Transport Association, an industry group based in Washington, has developed a proposal that would provide airlines with as much as $1.5 billion in third-party war liability coverage. The industry-run policy could go into effect as early as next month.

headline.main: Boeing and United Plan to Lay Off Thousands

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: As the airline industry continues to hemorrhage cash in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks, the Boeing Company said last night that it would lay off 20,000 to 30,000 workers by the end of 2002 because of fewer orders for aircraft. Separately, United Airlines is expected to announce today that it is laying off 20,000 employees, or 20 percent of its work force. And American Airlines, the No. 1 carrier, is expected to announce job cuts tomorrow, along with Northwest Airlines, the No. 4 carrier. Yesterday, two smaller airlines, Frontier Airlines in Denver and Midwest Express in Milwaukee, said they would cut 440 and 450 jobs, respectively.

headline.main: Do All Airlines Deserve A Taxpayer Rescue?

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: AFTER the terrorist attacks forced the nation's airlines to beg Washington for life support last month, America West Airlines, based here, was named repeatedly by industry executives and analysts as the carrier most in danger of failing. In fact, testifying on Capitol Hill on Sept. 19, W. Douglas Parker, America West's young new chief executive, told lawmakers that the airline was losing $5 million a day and would be forced to file for bankruptcy within days if the government did not intervene.

headline.main: Wariness On Paying Extra Costs

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Some airline executives expressed dismay yesterday at the financing provisions in a Congressional plan for improving aviation security, saying that the already suffering carriers might be forced to absorb the cost. The legislation, approved by the House and Senate and sent to President Bush, would impose a $2.50 ticket surcharge for each flight segment to pay for new security measures, with the fees expected to raise at least $2.5 billion a year. Under the measure, airlines must begin collecting the fees within 60 days.

headline.main: Airlines, in Search of Relief, Warn of Bankruptcy

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Airline executives and analysts expressed grave concern for the industry yesterday, warning that mounting losses stemming from this week's terrorist attacks could force most of the country's major carriers into bankruptcy. ''This patient is dying very quickly,'' Gordon M. Bethune, the chairman and chief executive of Continental Airlines, the fifth largest carrier, said in a telephone interview, referring to the industry. ''We all are going to be bankrupt before the end of the year. There is not an airline that I know of that has the excess cash to handle this.''

headline.main: U.S. TAKES BIG ROLE IN AIRLINES' CRISIS

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Using power granted by emergency legislation, the federal government is taking on its biggest role in shaping the nation's airlines since the industry was deregulated a generation ago, government officials and airline executives say. By determining which airlines will receive $10 billion in federal loan guarantees and on what terms, the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, established under the bailout legislation passed two weeks ago, will wield extraordinary power to determine which airlines survive the current crisis and in what financial condition.

headline.main: Economy & Business; A New Sense of Urgency in Debating the Future of Airlines

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Long before Sept. 11, many executives, analysts and consultants were convinced that the airline industry had fundamental problems. Even in the best years, returns lagged those of other industries. And recently, with profits slim to nonexistent, the calls for better service, cheaper fares, more public accountability and tighter security have grown louder and louder. Now, after the attacks, which presented the biggest commercial threat to the airlines in aviation history, the question of the industry's future has taken on new urgency.

headline.main: Even for Sickest of Airlines, Financial Skies Can Be Friendly

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: When Glenn F. Tilton, the chief executive of United Airlines, finished outlining the steps the airline was taking to eventually emerge from bankruptcy protection at a crowded investment conference last week, a voice piped up from the back of the room. Why shouldn't United just remain in bankruptcy? Mr. Tilton was asked.

headline.main: British Airways and American Add Flights

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: American Airlines and British Airways, which cut services after the Sept. 11 attacks, said today that they were increasing the number of flights on their trans-Atlantic routes. Traffic on North Atlantic routes was down 7.7 percent in February compared with the level a year earlier. That, however, was an improvement over October's year-to-year decline of 31.3 percent.

headline.main: U.S. and Japan Reach Deal for More Open Air Traffic

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The United States and Japan reached a landmark agreement Friday to relax limits on flights between the two countries, opening up the possibility of broader cross-border airline alliances and more options for air travelers. Under the agreement, which still must be finalized by both governments, airlines from both countries would be allowed to select routes and destinations based on consumer demand for both passenger and cargo services without limitations on the number of United States or Japanese carriers that can fly between the two countries or the number of flights they can operate.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Assistance

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: The South Korean air carriers, Korean Air and Asiana Airlines, are to receive $191 million in loans under a special $1.5 billion budget. The plan also provides for rolling over about $300 million in bonds that were issued by Korean Air along with a request that Asiana's creditor banks, most of them owned by the government, extend nearly $200 million in new loans. In addition, the two airlines were exempted from paying about $11 million in taxes through 2002. The losses for the airlines as a result of declining business since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States were expected to total $400 million this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; AIRLINES' DEBTS

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Airlines are improperly withholding more than $20 million they owe Afghanistan, American officials said. The State Department has urged the International Air Transport Association to turn over the money, which airlines paid to fly over Afghanistan. The funds were collected under a contract with the Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism and delivered to the Taliban until United Nations sanctions were applied in 1999; after that, some payments were made under United Nations supervision, the last in August 2001. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Despite big losses at American and Continental, executives say airlines may recover in 2002.

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: AMERICAN AIRLINES and Continental Airlines reported large fourth-quarter losses yesterday, reflecting the plunge in air travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But executives at the airlines expressed some optimism that the industry might recover later this year. American, the largest airline in the world, said that its parent, the AMR Corporation, lost $798 million, or $5.17 a share, during the quarter. Revenue declined nearly 22 percent, to $3.80 billion. In the year-earlier period, AMR had $4.86 billion in sales and earned $47 million, or 29 cents a share.

headline.main: Bailout for Airlines Showed the Weight Of a Mighty Lobby

Airline Industry.lead_paragraph: Just one day after terrorists hijacked and crashed four commercial jets, lobbyists for the airline industry were already at work, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar plan to rescue the industry. With the airlines grounded and passengers fearful of flying, platoons of well-connected and highly experienced lobbyists -- among them Linda Hall Daschle, wife of the Senate majority leader -- began sorting through their options, perhaps a ticket tax, perhaps something else. But, as Mrs. Daschle, an American Airlines lobbyist, explained, the group quickly settled on the simplest plan: a cash payment and loan guarantees.

headline.main: Feb.23-March 1; COMING UP

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: President Bush plans to speak at an American Medical Association conference in Washington on Tuesday and will meet with the president of Rwanda. Congress will hear testimony from Attorney General John Ashcroft, Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge and Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I., regarding the war on terrorism.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Department Recommends Asylum For Woman

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security recommended that Attorney General John Ashcroft grant asylum to a Guatemalan woman in a case that may have far-reaching implications for women seeking asylum in the United States on the grounds that they were persecuted because of their sex. The woman, Rodi Alvarado Pena, fled her country to escape an abusive husband. Bill Strassberger, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, said a final decision from Mr. Ashcroft was expected soon. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Ashcroft Won't Aid Asylum Seeker

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft has declined to intervene in an immigration case for a Guatemalan seeking asylum in the United States on the ground that she was persecuted because of her sex. The Department of Homeland Security had recommended that Mr. Ashcroft grant her asylum, federal officials said. The woman, Rodi Alvarado Peña, says she fled her country to escape an abusive husband. The matter will be returned to the Board of Immigration Appeals, Mrs. Alvarado's lawyer said. The security department and the Justice Department are considering rules to permit asylum in cases like Mrs. Alvarado's, opening the door to women fleeing countries that condone severe domestic abuse, genital mutilation and other forms of acute violence against women. John Files (NYT)

headline.main: Page Two: March 7-14; ASHCROFT 2004

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft's gallbladder surgery has revived speculation about the always-hot topic of his political future, but his advisers and associates say they have no doubt he will return to lead the Justice Department. ''Everyone's expecting him back -- absolutely,'' said a senior adviser. ''Assuming he recovers fully and he's feeling good, he'll be back.''

headline.main: Hope You Can Come!

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department wants to talk terrorism with 5,000 Middle Eastern men, but not in a confrontational way. ''We're being as kind and fair and gentle as we can,'' Attorney General John Aschcroft said on Tuesday.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Revamping Appointments

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Concerned about the recent dismissal of several prosecutors by the Justice Department, the Senate Judiciary Committee moved to strip the department of some of its power to appoint interim United States attorneys. Voting 13 to 6, the panel sent legislation to the full Senate that would limit the attorney general's appointment of an interim United States attorney to 120 days. After that, a federal judge would have to appoint the prosecutor. The bill revokes a provision inserted in the USA Patriot Act last year that gave the sole authority for naming interim attorneys to the attorney general.

headline.seo: One U.S. Prosecutor Behind Many Qaeda Convictions
headline.main: One U.S. Prosecutor in Brooklyn Is Behind Many Terrorism Convictions
headline.print_headline: One U.S. Prosecutor in Brooklyn Is Behind Many Terrorism Convictions

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey H. Knox has supervised nearly all successful recent cases involving post-9/11 activities by core operatives of Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Ashcroft Is Rebuked For Terror Remarks

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has admonished Attorney General John Ashcroft for violating a court order by making remarks about defendants in the nation's first major terror trial after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The judge, Gerald E. Rosen of Federal District Court, said in an opinion released Tuesday that Mr. Ashcroft's statements could have compromised the defendants' rights to a fair trial but that the violations did not warrant contempt charges or require Mr. Ashcroft to appear in court to explain himself.

headline.main: Holder Did Not Disclose Briefs on ‘Enemy Combatant’
headline.print_headline: Holder Did Not Disclose Briefs on ‘Enemy Combatant’

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The future attorney general did not notify the Senate that he had urged rejection of President Bush’s claim of the power to imprison an American as an “enemy combatant.”

headline.main: Changing His Pinstripes

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: As if the city needed further evidence that life is truly upside down, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that he would attend a Mets game. Yes. He said he wanted to thank them for wearing Fire Department hats, and to show that all partisan bets were off, even in baseball.A reporter could write here now that the mayor is a rabid Yankees fan, but that would insult the reader.

headline.main: On Terror, Spying and Guns, Ashcroft Expands Reach

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: In the bureaucratic reshuffling over domestic security, Attorney General John Ashcroft came out a winner. Mr. Ashcroft grabbed control of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and with it an issue dear to his conservative agenda, guns. And he shucked responsibility for two areas of law enforcement that had brought ridicule to the Justice Department, the color-coded threat alert system and immigration. In recent months, Mr. Ashcroft, once regarded as a peripheral, even clumsy, player in the Bush administration, has not only honed his skills as a bureaucratic infighter, he has also patched his tenuous relations with President Bush, who told Mr. Ashcroft last month that he was doing ''a fabulous job.''

headline.main: Domestic Security Adviser Named

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The White House named Kenneth L. Wainstein, a senior Justice Department official, to be President Bush's homeland security adviser. Mr. Wainstein now heads the National Security Division, which coordinates the Justice Department's counterterrorism, intelligence and counterespionage efforts. He was formerly the top federal prosecutor in Washington and general counsel and chief of staff at the F.B.I.

headline.main: Ashcroft Praises Precautions for Winter Games

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: On his first visit here to discuss security for the Winter Olympics next month, Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that the plans were so thorough that they would serve as a model for large events in the future. ''This will set a new standard,'' Mr. Ashcroft said at a news conference on the first day of a four-day visit to the area.

headline.main: At Ashcroft's Farewell, Much Reverence

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: There were, of course, the good-natured gibes at the guest of honor's expense over his public image. As one senior Justice Department official playfully reminded Attorney General John Ashcroft at his going-away party on Monday, David Letterman had said that Mr. Ashcroft was stepping down because ''he wants to spend more time spying on his family.'' Then there were the mock complaints from another senior aide, who said that the Justice Department's appellate lawyers might have too much time on their hands now without a full docket of cases bearing the attorney general's name, like Ashcroft v. American Civil Liberties Union.

headline.main: Ashcroft Criticized For Talks on Terror

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft faced sharp criticism today from Democrats and others over his decision to give more than a dozen speeches around the country in defense of anti-terrorism legislation passed after the Sept. 11 attacks. Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, told Mr. Ashcroft in a letter that he should either ''desist from further speaking engagements'' or explain why they do not violate restrictions on political activities by government officials.

headline.main: Deputy Attorney General Is Latest to Leave the Justice Dept.

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department faces potential tumult in the months ahead with the departures of a cadre of senior aides to Attorney General John Ashcroft who have made up his brain trust and a bulwark against his critics. The latest resignation came today with the announcement from Deputy Attorney General Larry Thompson that he would leave at the end of the month. Mr. Ashcroft said he was losing ''my partner.''

headline.main: Terror Lesson Fading for Some, Aschcroft Says in Manhattan

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Standing on the site where Congress adopted the Bill of Rights, Attorney General John Ashcroft brought his defense of the Patriot Act to the edge of ground zero yesterday and suggested that critics of the act, a sweeping antiterrorism law, ''have forgotten how we felt'' on Sept. 11, 2001. By choosing history-laden Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan as the backdrop to the latest stop in a cross-country round of speeches in support of the Patriot Act, Mr. Ashcroft invited attention to a sharp debate over whether some aspects of the law conflict with constitutional safeguards for individual liberties.

headline.main: Ashcroft Briefed Regularly On Inquiry Into C.I.A. Leak

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft's top aides have regularly briefed him on key details in the investigation into the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity, including the identities of those interviewed by the F.B.I., a senior Justice Department official told members of Congress on Tuesday. Mr. Ashcroft's regular, detailed briefings suggest that he has taken a more hands-on role in the politically charged investigation than the department had acknowledged. Senate Democrats said the arrangement threatened to compromise the independence of the investigation, a contention that Justice Department officials rejected.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Confirms Woman As Head Of D.E.A.

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Senate has confirmed a longtime Justice Department official to become the first woman to lead the Drug Enforcement Administration. The official, Karen Tandy, a former federal prosecutor who currently heads the Justice Department task force on drug trafficking, was confirmed by the Senate without dissent late Thursday night. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, praised Ms. Tandy for ''a long and impressive 25-year career with the Department of Justice.'' She succeeds Asa Hutchinson, who left the D.E.A. this year to become undersecretary of homeland security. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

headline.main: Ashcroft Wants Quick Action On Broader Wiretapping Plan

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that he would press Congress to vote this week on a package of counterterrorism measures that would dramatically expand the ability of the Justice Department to place wiretaps on telephones and computer terminals. Under intense pressure to move quickly on antiterrorism legislation in response to the deadly attacks in New York and at the Pentagon, lawmakers said the House and Senate Judiciary Committees would debate the administration's proposals as soon as Congress reconvened on Thursday, pushing aside other business.

headline.seo: Justice Department Report Finds John Yoo and Jay Bybee Not Guilty of Misconduct
headline.main: Report Faults 2 Authors of Bush Terror Memos
headline.print_headline: Report Faults 2 Who Wrote Terror Memos

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A Justice Department report found that Bush administration lawyers used flawed reasoning on brutal interrogation tactics but were not guilty of professional misconduct.

headline.main: Ashcroft Relents on Data

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from lawmakers and civil rights groups over the Justice Department's antiterrorism initiatives, Attorney General John Ashcroft reversed course today and agreed to declassify data showing how often federal agents had demanded records from libraries and other institutions. Civil rights advocates said the decision was a significant victory in their efforts to lift the secrecy surrounding the legislation known as the USA Patriot Act.

headline.main: U.S. Identifies a Canadian As Taker of Martyrdom Pledge
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TERROR SUSPECTS

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department today identified a Canadian citizen of Tunisian descent as the fifth suspected Al Qaeda follower who the authorities said had pledged himself to martyrdom on a videotape found in Afghanistan, indicating he might be preparing for a suicide attack. At a news conference, Attorney General John Ashcroft identified the man as Al Rauf bin Al Habib bin Yousef al-Jiddi, who is 36 years old and had lived in Canada for several years, but had recently been in Afghanistan, where the videotape was recorded. His immediate whereabouts were unknown.

headline.main: A Partnership Forged To Thwart Terrorism

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, went over the checklist one last time together. As American jets prepared to drop the first bombs on Afghanistan on Oct. 7, the two men gathered with aides in the F.B.I.'s high-tech fifth-floor operations center to review a list of potential targets that needed extra protection if Osama bin Laden chose to retaliate. The list included nuclear plants, refineries, chemical plants and airports.

headline.main: Justice Dept. Alters Stand On 3 Detained
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

John Ashcroft - Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Backing away from remarks by Attorney General John Ashcroft, the Justice Department suggested today that it did not know whether three Arab men now in custody in Michigan had advance knowledge of the terror attacks of Sept. 11. ''At this time, the Department of Justice does not take the position that the three Michigan men had knowledge of the Sept. 11 events,'' the department said in its statement.

headline.main: Plea Today in Terror Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the first man to be indicted on charges involving the Sept. 11 attacks, is scheduled to be in court on Wednesday to enter a plea on charges of conspiring with Osama bin Laden and others to murder thousands of people. Mr. Moussaoui, 33, a French citizen of Moroccan descent, will be arraigned in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., on charges set out in a Dec. 11 indictment. Judge Leonie M. Brinkema may set a date for the trial to begin.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Warning On Terror Trial

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen,is charged with conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Philip Shenon (NYT)

headline.main: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; SURPRISE PLEA

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, acknowledged in a Virginia court that he was part of the Qaeda network and tried to plead guilty to conspiring in the attacks. Mr. Moussaoui offered his plea even as he repeated his contention that he was not directly involved in the plot. The judge refused his surprise request, saying she would give him a week to reconsider a decision that could guarantee his execution. Philip Shenon

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court's order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: August Decision Seen In Moussaoui Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The judge in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person facing trial in the United States in the Sept. 11 attacks, made it clear that she would not decide whether to dismiss the case or impose other sanctions on the Justice Department for at least next month. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., said she would delay her decision until prosecutors and defense lawyers had offered their views on what sanctions she should impose for the government's refusal to grant Mr. Moussaoui the chance to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda. Philip Shenon (NYT)

headline.main: Terror Suspect Won't Attend Hearing on a Qaeda Member

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A dispute over whether Zacarias Moussaoui has the right to be present during a court hearing next week on his access to an imprisoned member of Al Qaeda has been ended by his decision not to attend the hearing, a judge said today. Prosecutors sought on Wednesday to bar Mr. Moussaoui from the closed proceeding on the grounds that classified information would be discussed.

headline.main: Defendant Yields on Refusal to See Psychiatrist
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person arrested so far in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, has met with a court-appointed psychiatrist who is helping a federal judge determine if he is mentally competent to defend himself at trial, according to court papers made public today. The conclusions of the psychiatric report, which was filed with the Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., outside Washington, were not revealed. But the court papers do reveal that Mr. Moussaoui backed down from his refusal to meet with the psychiatrist, Raymond Patterson, a former administrator of St. Elizabeth's Hospital for the criminally insane in Washington.

headline.main: Ruling Leaves Legal Standoff In 9/11 Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A trial judge today threw the fate of Zacarias Moussaoui back into the hands of a federal appeals court, saying she could not accept a Justice Department compromise over classified evidence that might have allowed the trial of Mr. Moussaoui to go forward. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, said the compromise, which would have required federal prosecutors to turn over some classified information to Mr. Moussaoui in place of testimony from a captured leader of Al Qaeda, was not sufficient to guarantee Mr. Moussaoui a fair trial. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen, is the only person charged in the United States with involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Dismissal of Indictment Is Sought

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Zacarias Moussaoui have urged a federal trial judge to dismiss his indictment, saying he cannot receive a fair trial because the government refuses to make captured members of Al Qaeda available to testify, according to court papers made public today. The court-appointed defense lawyers said that short of dismissing the indictment the judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, must bar the government from seeking the death penalty against Mr. Moussaoui, a Frenchman who is the sole person charged in an American court with conspiring in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Suspected Terrorist Questions a Witness

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui has been allowed to conduct a pre-trial deposition of at least one potential trial witness in his case, a Malaysian terrorism suspect who the authorities say met with Mr. Moussaoui in Southeast Asia before the Sept. 11 terror attacks, according to court papers made public today. The court papers show that Mr. Moussaoui, acting as his own lawyer, questioned the witness, Faiz Bafana, in a videoconference last year, with federal prosecutors cross-examining Mr. Bafana.

headline.main: Judge Ejects 9/11 Suspect After Outburst

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal trial judge ejected Zacarias Moussaoui from the courtroom on Tuesday after his latest outburst and said he could observe the next weeks of his trial only from a closed-circuit television system in a nearby cell. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, ordered that Mr. Moussaoui, the only person to stand trial in America in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, be barred from the courtroom during jury selection. Defense lawyers and prosecutors are expected to spend the next few weeks questioning and screening 500 residents of Northern Virginia to choose the jury that will decide whether Mr. Moussaoui is sentenced to death or life without parole.

headline.main: Mother Hires Lawyer to Persuade Defendant to End Defense Plan
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The mother of Zacarias Moussaoui, the the only person charged in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks, has hired a civil rights lawyer here to persuade her son to abandon his plans to represent himself at his trial. The lawyer, Randall B. Hamud, an Arab-American, said Mr. Moussaoui's mother, Aïcha el-Wafi, of Narbonne, France, retained him last week.

headline.main: Man Charged in Terror Seeks to Meet Reporters

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, has asked the judge in the case to allow him to meet with reporters. In a handwritten motion, one of several made public today, Mr. Moussaoui, who is accused of being the 20th hijacker, added that he would expect financial compensation from any news organization given an interview, to help pay for his defense.

headline.main: Moussaoui Seen As Too Isolated

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui is so isolated in jail that he is unable to defend himself against charges that he aided the Sept. 11 attackers, his lawyer said today. ''With his life hanging in the balance,'' it is essential that Mr. Moussaoui have a computer work station and that officials ease his conditions of confinement, the lawyer, Frank Dunham Jr., said in a motion filed in Federal District Court.

headline.main: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor on Monday asked a jury to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death, saying his willful decision to conceal his knowledge of the Sept. 11 terrorist plot when he was arrested weeks earlier made him responsible for the thousands of deaths that day. In response, a court-appointed lawyer for Mr. Moussaoui told jurors they could not order the execution of a man on no more than a supposition: that had he revealed his knowledge of Al Qaeda's interest in flying planes into public buildings, the federal authorities would have prevented the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: New Ruling Favors Suspect In Terror Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ordered that the terrorist suspect Zacarias Moussaoui be given the opportunity to question two high-level operatives of Al Qaeda, including the man officials say masterminded the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. The decision on Friday by Judge Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., promises to further complicate a government prosecution that has already become entangled by unexpected legal obstacles. Officials have been considering whether to move Mr. Moussaoui to a military tribunal rather than continuing to prosecute him in civil court, and Judge Brinkema's decision could increase the likelihood of such a move.

headline.main: Jailed Man Accused of Having Ties to Al Qaeda

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The federal authorities in Minnesota have arrested a man who is accused of having ties to the terrorist network of Al Qaeda and to Zacarias Moussaoui, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday. The officials said that the jailed suspect had been under surveillance for some time and that he was arrested on Tuesday by members of an F.B.I. terrorism task force in Minnesota, where Mr. Moussaoui was arrested a month before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Court Psychiatrist Concludes Defendant Is Not Mentally Ill
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A court-appointed psychiatrist has determined that Zacarias Moussaoui, the sole person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, is not mentally ill. The finding could clear the way for Mr. Moussaoui to be his own lawyer, government papers filed today showed. Federal prosecutors disclosed the findings in papers in which they urged Judge Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., to find Mr. Moussaoui mentally competent to dismiss his court-appointed lawyers and defend himself at a trial in which he faces the death penalty.

headline.main: Moussaoui Should Get Details In '5th Plane' Theory, Judge Says

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge today ordered the Justice Department to provide Zacarias Moussaoui with details to support the department's theory that Mr. Moussaoui was meant to participate in a terrorist hijacking separate from the four on Sept. 11, 2001. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, ordered the department to begin preparations to provide Mr. Moussaoui with a transcript of a secret court hearing in January in which prosecutors outlined the theory that Mr. Moussaoui was intended to be aboard a fifth plane, which was to crash into the White House.

headline.main: Court Bolsters Terror Defendant On Questioning

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court affirmed on Monday that Zacarias Moussaoui may submit written questions to people held by the United States as enemy combatants to bolster his assertion that he was not involved in the Sept. 11 attacks. In its ruling, heavily censored for reasons attributed to national security, the court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, said the statements could help in the defense of Mr. Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the attacks.

headline.main: Judge, Fearing Potential Aid to Terrorists, Denies Moussaoui Access to Aviation Security Files
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ruled that Zacarias Moussaoui, the sole person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, may not have access to classified prosecution evidence about the aviation security system because it might end up in the hands of terrorists ''intent on attacking civil aviation.'' The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Alexandria, Va., did not describe the evidence in detail but said it contained information ''on security countermeasures which might assist a potential hijacker or terrorist in circumventing aviation security procedures intended to protect the traveling public.''

headline.main: Appeal by Sept. 11 Suspect

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, filed an appeal on Thursday of a recent ruling allowing prosecutors once again to seek the death penalty in the case, court records show. The filing seeks to have the ruling, made on April 22 by a three-judge federal appeals panel in Richmond, Va., reviewed by the full appeals court. It was placed under seal because of secrecy rules in the case, which involves a variety of classified information.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE 20th SUSPECT; Man Held in U.S. Was Wired 2 Large Sums From Germany

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old immigrant who has emerged as a key suspect in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks received $15,000 in unexplained money transfers from Germany in August, say German investigators who are trying to determine if the plot had its origins in their country. American law enforcement officials say they suspect that the man, Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen of Moroccan descent, was meant to be the 20th hijacker in the attacks.

headline.main: Defendant In 9/11 Case Heeds Judge

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui resumed his place in a federal courtroom here on Wednesday and sat quietly as lawyers questioned potential jurors after he apparently reversed course and agreed not to disrupt the proceedings. A day earlier, Judge Leonie M. Brinkema ejected Mr. Moussaoui from the courtroom after he refused to heed her warnings to defer to his court-appointed lawyers and stop making speeches about his case. She ruled that Mr. Moussaoui, the only person to face trial in the United States in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, would be able to observe the next few weeks of the proceedings only from a closed-circuit television hookup in a jail cell.

headline.main: Judge Lets Man Accused in Sept. 11 Plot Defend Himself
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled today that Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, will be allowed to represent himself at his trial, a decision that his court-appointed lawyers warned could turn the courtroom into a circus. The decision came at a hearing here in which Mr. Moussaoui insisted that he had never had contact with any of the Sept. 11 hijackers, and that there was evidence that he had been under surveillance by American officials since he arrived in the United States last May for flight training.

headline.seo: Kurdish Advocate’s Visa Delay Prompts Push for Answers
headline.main: Advocate’s Visa Delay Stirs Questions
headline.print_headline: Advocate’s Visa Delay Stirs Questions

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Kerim Yildiz, a prominent Kurdish activist, had no problems visiting the United States, until last fall’s application. The American Civil Liberties Union wants an explanation.

headline.main: Amnesty International Seeks Guantánamo Bay Closing

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: In an annual report on human rights worldwide, Amnesty International again urged the United States to close the Guantánamo Bay detention camp. It also said ''flash points'' in the Darfur region of Sudan and in Zimbabwe, Gaza, Iraq and Myanmar ''demand immediate action'' from world leaders. Amnesty, a human rights watchdog group, accused the European Union of complicity in the practice of rendition, the transporting of terrorism suspects secretly to other countries for interrogation; urged China to ''live up to the human rights promises it made around the Olympic Games;'' and said Russia should ''show greater tolerance for political dissent, and none for impunity on human rights abuses in Chechnya.''

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Rights Group Criticizes Terror Laws

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Amnesty International accused governments of violating civil liberties in the name of combating terrorism since the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. ''The United Nations member states, individually and collectively, have failed to uphold human rights,'' Colm O'Cuanachain, head of the group's international executive, said at a meeting of winners of the Nobel Peace Prize, which was awarded to Amnesty International in 1977.
