''In response to the horrific human rights abuses of Sept. 11, governments are moving to restrict civil liberties and human rights, ostensibly to promote security,'' he said.

headline.main: Report Says U.S. Human Rights Abuses Have Eroded Support for Efforts Against Terrorism

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: International support for the campaign against terrorism is weakening because of human rights abuses by the United States, Human Rights Watch charged in a report published today. The report, the group's annual survey of human rights issues worldwide, cited the Bush administration's detention of so-called enemy combatants without formal charges or access to lawyers, closed-door deportation hearings of terrorism suspects and the refusal to abide by the Geneva Convention in the treatment of prisoners held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, among other examples.

headline.main: Nigeria Commission Fines Agency in Killings
headline.print_headline: Nigeria Commission Fines Agency in Killings

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Nigeria's National Human Rights Commission finds security agents responsible for the unlawful killings of eight civilians in a September raid in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Leader To Meet Bush

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: President Islam Karimov is to meet President Bush today in Washington to discuss the new ties the two countries have forged during the American-led war on terrorism. The autocratic leader, a former Communist Party boss, emerged as an important United States ally when he allowed Americantroops to use an Uzbek military base for operations in neighboring Afghanistan. A State Department report on human rights issued last week said Uzbekistan is an ''authoritarian'' state with a ''very poor'' human rights record.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Hitting Back

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: China officially retaliated against a State Department critique of its human rights record, saying American human rights standards had deteriorated sharply even as the United States was ''pretending to be the world's judge.'' The report by China's State Council said discrimination, especially against Arabs and Muslims, was on the rise in the United States since the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks. It said the United States was inflicting vast suffering on the people of Afghanistan and Iraq, while practicing ''democracy of the rich'' at home. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

headline.seo: Iran Defends Rights Record Opposition Cancels Rally
headline.main: Iran Defends Rights Record as Opposition Cancels Rally
headline.print_headline: Iran Defends Rights Record As Opposition Cancels Rally

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: At the United Nations Human Rights Council, Iran was questioned about its lack of public accounting for the violence and imprisonment protesters faced after the disputed election last year.

headline.main: New Soldiers in the Fight for Human Rights

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: When Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, attended Yale Law School in the late 1970's, it offered one course in human rights. He signed up for it each year he was there, and each year it was canceled. ''I learned on the job,'' he says. That is no longer necessary. With Taliban and Al Qaeda detainees at Guantánamo Bay, China cracking down on scholarly dissidents and Haitian refugees still seeking safe haven, human rights is emerging as a leading academic concept for a new age of globalization and service.

headline.seo: Rights Reports Show Difficulty in Identifying Afghan Insurgents
headline.main: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO’s Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO’s Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Allied forces say they killed the right man — a shadow governor affiliated with Al Qaeda — but a human rights report paints a murkier picture involving acquaintances and false names.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia Admits Handing 6 Algerians Over To U.S.

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The government of Bosnia and Herzegovina has confirmed to the Council of Europe, the continent's main human rights watchdog, that it allowed American forces to seize six Algerian-born men in January 2002 for transfer out of the country, the council reported. The men have been detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since then as enemy combatants. While the seizure and transport of the men has long been known, Bosnia is the only one of the council's 46 members to acknowledge it had breached the European Convention on Human Rights by participating in an extrajudicial seizure of individuals by United States authorities. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

headline.seo: Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova, Former Leader of Salvadoran Military, Faces Deportation
headline.main: Salvadoran in Florida Faces Deportation for Torture
headline.print_headline: Ex-Leader of Salvadoran Military Faces Deportation Hearing

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova could be deported on charges that he participated in torture three decades ago.

headline.main: At Rights Meeting, Anxiety That Terror Fight Takes Lead

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: One year ago, terrorism was barely noted by officials from the 53 countries who gather here annually for the Commission on Human Rights. But as the main United Nations rights body opened its review this year, terrorism was reshaping the debate. That worries rights campaigners, some of whom say that invoking terrorism allows countries with questionable records to escape condemnation by the commission.

headline.main: Few Punished in Abuse Cases

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: One-third of about 410 military and civilian personnel investigated by the authorities on accusations of abusing detainees in Iraq, Afghanistan or Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have faced disciplinary action, according to a report issued yesterday by human rights groups. The report, by the Center for Human Rights and Global Justice at New York University, Human Rights Watch and Human Rights First, criticized the government as having failed to conduct a vigorous investigation into the accusations and punish offenders.

headline.main: U.S. Strikes on Nusra Front in Syria Kill Over 50: Monitoring Group
headline.print_headline: U.S. Strikes on Nusra Front in Syria Kill Over 50: Monitoring Group

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The death toll from U.S. strikes on al Qaeda-linked militants in northern Syria has risen to 50, a monitoring group said on Tuesday.

headline.main: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, a member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, lashed out at statements in President Bush's State of the Union address that said Iran was violating human rights and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. Ayatollah Yazdi rejected the president's claims and responded with his own: that White House policies after the Sept. 11 terror attacks violated the rights of Muslim immigrants. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline.main: BOSNIA SUSPECT

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: NATO peacekeepers in Bosnia handed over to the local police a Muslim man they had detained since October on suspicion of spying on their troops and having links with Al Qaeda. Sabahudin Fiuljanin, who denies the allegations, has not been formally charged with any crime, and the American-led NATO force has come under pressure from human rights organizations to present evidence against him before a court. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

headline.main: Rights Group Assails U.S. Over Its Handling of Terror Suspects

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: Human Rights Watch asserted Wednesday that the Bush administration had undertaken a deliberate strategy of abusing terror suspects during interrogations, in ways, the group said, that undercut broader American interests. The criticism drew an unusually direct rebuff from the White House. ''In the course of 2005, it became indisputable that U.S. mistreatment of detainees reflected not a failure of training, discipline or oversight, but a deliberate policy choice,'' the rights group said in a sweeping critique in its annual report. ''The problem could not be reduced to a few bad apples at the bottom of the barrel.''

headline.seo: Patricio Guzmán’s ‘Nostalgia for the Light’ to Open
headline.main: Surveyor of a Desert Where the Past and Present Coexist
headline.print_headline: Surveyor of a Desert Where the Past and Present Coexist

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The documentarian Patricio Guzmán’s new film, “Nostalgia for the Light,” another of his looks at the Atacama Desert in Chile, opens on Friday.

headline.main: U.N. to Open Rights Review With U.S. On Sidelines

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The United Nations' chief human rights body, composed of 53 nations, will begin on Monday its annual review of abuses worldwide facing concerns that the international commitment to human rights is being eroded by the war against terrorism. Human rights campaigners have accused the United States, Russia, China and other countries of adopting security measures that jeopardize basic rights.

headline.main: Departing Rights Commissioner Faults U.S.

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: In the final days of her five years in office, Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, has sharply criticized the United States for eroding civil liberties at home and human rights standards around the world since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. ''The United States could be a leader in combating terrorism while upholding human rights,'' Mrs. Robinson said in an interview here on Monday. ''Instead it has sought to put all the emphasis on combating terrorism and has not been fully upholding human rights standards. And that's having a ripple effect on other less democratic countries.''

headline.main: U.N. Human Rights Official Won't Seek Another Term

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The United Nations' top human rights official, Mary Robinson, unexpectedly declared today that she would not be a candidate for a new term when her appointment expires in September. Mrs. Robinson, a former president of Ireland, made the announcement on the opening day of the annual session of the Commission on Human Rights, the United Nations' chief monitor of rights abuses worldwide.

headline.main: Amnesty Calls World Less Safe

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The world has become more dangerous, and governments more repressive, since the effort to fight terrorism began after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States, the human rights group Amnesty International said today. Releasing its annual report, the group singled out the United States for particular opprobrium, condemning its detention of 600 foreign nationals at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as a ''human rights scandal'' and calling on the government to release or charge those held there.

headline.seo: European Court Says Britain Can Send Terror Suspects to U.S.
headline.main: European Court Says Britain Can Send Terror Suspects to U.S.
headline.print_headline: European Court Says Britain Can Send Terror Suspects to U.S.

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: In a major precedent relating to conditions in an American maximum security prison, the court allowed for the extradition of the cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri and four other defendants.

headline.main: U.S. Could Come Under Scrutiny of the U.N. Rights Commission

Human Rights Watch.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights, with Libya's ambassador as its chairman, is about to begin an unusual annual session that is likely to focus on the United States record and recent actions. Commission participants said they might hold a ''special sitting'' to discuss accusations that the United States is violating rights in its handling of people accused of terrorism and in its counterterrorism measures. They also said that during the six-week session the commission could look at any action the United States took in Iraq.

headline.main: Somalia: Rebels Join Al Qaeda

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Somali militants known as the Shabab have formally joined Al Qaeda, according to a video translation released Thursday of a message from Al Qaeda's leader, Ayman al-Zawahri. Mr. Zawahri said he gave ''glad tidings'' that the Shabab had joined Al Qaeda ''to support the jihadi unity against the Zio-Crusader campaign,'' according to the translation by the SITE Intelligence Group. The Somali rebels had previously pledged allegiance to Al Qaeda, but the video appeared to formalize the relationship.

headline.main: World Briefing | United Nations: Funds Still Flow To Al Qaeda, Panel Says

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: A lack of international cooperation and political resolve in many countries undermines attempts to stem the flow of money and weapons to Al Qaeda and allows the group's influence to spread, a special committee of the Security Council said. Iraq in particular has become ''a fertile ground'' for Al Qaeda and ''is readily accessible to Al Qaeda followers anxious to take up the battle against the coalition forces and other 'Crusaders,' '' the committee said. The committee was set up by the Security Council to monitor measures against Al Qaeda, the Taliban and their associates. Only 83 of the 191 member countries have submitted fourth-quarter reports to the committee. Kirk Semple (NYT)

headline.main: Qaeda Official Speaks About Bin Laden's Death

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Ayman al-Zawahri, long the second in command of Al Qaeda, delivered his first public comments on the killing of his boss Osama bin Laden in an American raid last month, saying in a video eulogy posted by Al Qaeda's media arm on Wednesday that Bin Laden had ''terrified America in his life'' and ''will continue to terrify it after his death.'' The 28-minute video, titled ''The Noble Knight Dismounted,'' begins with old footage of Mr. Zawahri and Bin Laden seated together in a mountainous setting before cutting to Mr. Zawahri alone, dressed in white and seated with a rifle in front of a black background. He alternates between poetry and verse eulogizing Bin Laden, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which tracks jihadist communications and translated the video.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Al Jazeera Reporter Arrested

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The police arrested a reporter for the Arabic television station Al Jazeera on suspicion of having links to the terror network Al Qaeda. The suspect, Tayseer Allouni, of Syrian origin, was accused of assisting the leader of the network's Spanish cell, who was arrested in November of 2001, and of transferring money to Al Qaeda operatives in Afghanistan, the news agency EFE reported. Mr. Allouni's wife disputed the accusations, as did the director of Al Jazeera. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

headline.main: Taliban and Qaeda Sanctions Are Split

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council voted Friday to treat Al Qaeda and the Taliban separately when it comes to sanctions, a move that is aimed at supporting the Afghan government's reconciliation efforts and that could help clear a path for negotiations with the Taliban. The American ambassador, Susan E. Rice, said the vote would send ''a clear message to the Taliban that there is a future for those who separate from Al Qaeda.''

headline.main: Jitters Over Al Qaeda

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The leader of Germany's foreign intelligence agency warned Tuesday of an increased likelihood of a major terror attack by Al Qaeda in the weeks before the American elections. ''There is fear of a big attack on America by the terror organization Al Qaeda before the presidential elections in November,'' August Hanning, director of the Federal Intelligence Service, said in a speech in Heidelberg, Deutsche Presse-Agentur reported.

headline.seo: A Man Behind the Hunt for Al Qaeda
headline.main: Soldier, Thinker, Hunter, Spy: Drawing a Bead on Al Qaeda
headline.print_headline: Soldier, Thinker, Hunter, Spy: Drawing a Bead on Al Qaeda

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Michael Vickers’s preoccupation — “my life,” he says — is dismantling Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Yemen: Al Qaeda Says It Planned Suicide Bombing in Country’s South

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The group claimed responsibility for a suicide car bombing last weekend that killed at least 25 people, calling it a warning to the United States to stop meddling in Yemen’s affairs.

headline.main: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; TERROR MONEY

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Enamm M. Arnaout, a Syrian-born Chicago resident, was so close to Osama bin Laden in the late 1980's, F.B.I. officials say, that he once looked after one of his wives. Mr. Aranout's alleged links to Al Qaeda led to his indictment, which alleged that as the leader of an Islamic foundation, he diverted money to Al Qaeda. Lawyers for Mr. Arnaout called the charges baseless. Eric Lichtblau

headline.main: Al Qaeda Confirms Bin Laden’s Death
headline.print_headline: Al Qaeda Confirms Bin Laden’s Death

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda released a statement on militant Web sites Friday confirming the death of Osama bin Laden, news agencies reported.

headline.main: Yemen: 6 Killed In Ambush On Government Officials

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Gunmen ambushed a government motorcade in the eastern province of Hadhramaut on Tuesday, killing three top provincial officials and three guards in an attack that had all the hallmarks of Al Qaeda's regional arm. The ambush was the deadliest attack on government officials in years in Yemen, where Al Qaeda has been building up a regional base with the aim of overthrowing the state.

headline.main: For Obama, Steep Learning Curve as Chief in War
headline.print_headline: A Wartime Chief’s Steep Learning Curve

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The president has made war decisions after agonizing deliberation but also with dizzying swiftness, while he and the military have had a sometimes edgy relationship.

headline.main: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- At some point in coming days, a shadowy group of Al Qaeda operatives in Pakistan who make up the network's ''General Command'' is likely to announce a replacement for Atiyah abd al-Rahman, the Libyan chief of operations who was killed last week in a drone strike launched by the Central Intelligence Agency. But as the 10th anniversary of the group's most successful strike approaches, the key question is: Does it matter?

headline.main: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent
headline.print_headline: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda is expected to announce a successor to its slain operations chief soon, just as its affiliates are growing more independent.

headline.main: Somalia: Al Qaeda's Leader Encourages Militants

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda's leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, has released a new video in which he encourages Somali militants to fight on despite the challenges. In the video, reported Friday by the Site Intelligence Group which monitors militant activities, Mr. Zawahri urges the Shabab militants not to be deterred by American drone attacks. It is Mr. Zawahri's second video address to the group, which formally joined Al Qaeda in February. The Shabab's fighters have increasingly come under pressure in recent times from regional armies and government forces who are pushing them from three sides inside Somalia.

headline.main: Lebanon: Six Soldiers Killed

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Six Lebanese soldiers were killed in fighting with militants inspired by Al Qaeda holed up in a Palestinian refugee camp in north Lebanon. In nearly eight weeks of fighting between the army and Fatah al Islam in and around the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, 178 people have been killed, including 90 soldiers and at least 68 militants.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 10 Qaeda Agents Said To Be In Caucasus

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: More than 10 Qaeda members are in the Caucasus collaborating with Chechens, Russian intelligence officials have been telling Russian news outlets. The fresh details seemed intended to bolster the Kremlin's claim that the war in Chechnya is part of the battle against Al Qaeda. Aleksandr Potapov, who supervises intelligence in Chechnya, asserted that Al Qaeda's main representative is an Arab mercenary, Abu Khavs. Another Arab, Abu Zeit, was described as coordinating terror in Ingushetia. Mr. Potapov said the relationship between Qaeda figures and Shamil Basayev -- the Chechen who has claimed responsibility for terrorist acts including the school siege in North Ossetia but has denied Qaeda support -- have not been firmly established. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

headline.seo: Unrest Continues to Shake Yemen, Especially in South
headline.main: In Yemen, One Islamist Is Dead, but the Battle Goes On
headline.print_headline: In Yemen, Unrest Is Persistent Despite Death of a Top Militant

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Despite the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, the infamous Yemeni-American cleric and propagandist for aspiring jihadists, Yemen’s battle against Al Qaeda is far from complete.

headline.main: Iran Plans to Try Qaeda Suspects

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: An Iranian government minister has said that foreigners suspected of being Al Qaeda operatives whose home countries refuse to take them back will be put on trial in Iran, the daily Entekhab reported today. Ali Yunessi, Iran's minister of intelligence, said such people ''will be tried in Iran and the trial will follow its legal procedure,'' Entekhab said.

headline.main: Pentagon Says Still Investigating if Khorasan Leader Killed in Syria
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Says Still Investigating if Khorasan Leader Killed in Syria

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon on Wednesday said it was still investigating whether U.S. strikes in Syria on Tuesday killed a leader of the al Qaeda-linked Khorasan group, adding that it could take time to determine.

headline.main: Al Jazeera Reporter Jailed

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: A Spanish judge jailed a correspondent for Al Jazeera today after he was accused of being a member of Al Qaeda. The judge, Baltasar Garzón, accused the journalist, Tayssir Alouni, of transferring money to Qaeda operatives, recruiting new members for terrorist training camps and sharing information with leaders of the network's Spanish cell, which was rounded up in November 2001.

headline.main: At Least 8 Soldiers, 10 Militants Killed in South Yemen Fighting
headline.print_headline: At Least 8 Soldiers, 10 Militants Killed in South Yemen Fighting

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: At least eight Yemeni soldiers and 10 al Qaeda militants were killed in heavy clashes in the southern province of Shabwa on Wednesday, military sources involved in the fighting said.

headline.main: Yemen Strike Reflects U.S. Shift To Drones as Cheaper War Tool

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The C.I.A. drone strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Al Qaeda's rising franchise in Yemen, was one more demonstration of what American officials describe as a cheap, safe and precise tool to eliminate enemies. It was also a sign that the decade-old American campaign against terrorism has reached a turning point. Disillusioned by huge costs and uncertain outcomes in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Obama administration has decisively embraced the drone, along with small-scale lightning raids like the one that killed Osama bin Laden in May, as the future of the fight against terrorist networks.

headline.main: Saudi Official Links Al Qaeda to Bombings

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the Saudi interior minister accused Al Qaeda in last month's bombings in Riyadh in an interview published today, and his ministry identified 12 of the attackers. The minister, Prince Nayef, said 25 people were in custody in connection with the bombings on May 12 at three Western housing compounds in Riyadh. Thirty-five people were killed, including at least nine suicide bombers.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pakistani Seeks Access To U.S. Prisoners

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a Pakistani man accused of aiding Al Qaeda told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that to mount a proper defense, they need access to a former senior officer of Al Qaeda who is in American custody. In a similar case involving, Zacarias Moussaoui, who is accused of being involved in the Sept. 11 attacks, prosecutors are resisting granting access to Qaeda prisoners because, they said, doing so may compromise national security. In the case of the Pakistani man, Uzair Paracha, 23, who is accused of trying to help a Qaeda member get into the United States, defense lawyers want to interview prisoners with ties to Al Qaeda, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the former Qaeda operations chief suspected of planning the attacks. Mr. Paracha's lawyer, Anthony Ricco, said the defense would file motions similar to those in the Moussaoui case. The motions are due by Nov. 25. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Coast Guard Vice Admiral Tapped as Next Commandant
headline.print_headline: Coast Guard Vice Admiral Tapped as Next Commandant

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama is nominating a Coast Guard vice admiral to be the next Coast Guard commandant.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New York Harbor Limits Lifted

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Small boats returned to New York Harbor yesterday, a day after federal authorities barred the vessels from entering the harbor because of reports of a possible New Year's Eve terrorist attack. Coast Guard officials reported no arrests as a result of the restriction, which ended at 8 a.m. yesterday, 16 1/2 hours after it was announced. ''We had a couple of incidents of recreational boaters not realizing that a security zone was in place,'' said Petty Officer Mike Hvozda, a spokesman for the Coast Guard. ''But it was basically a nice quiet night.'' Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

headline.main: More Patrols Planned On Connecticut River

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The top United States Coast Guard officer in the state said Monday that the Coast Guard would increase its patrols on the Connecticut River this summer. Capt. Peter Boynton of the Port for Long Island Sound said the Coast Guard would station a boat in Middletown on at least eight weekends this summer, compared with about three weekends last summer.

headline.main: Coast Guard Calls for Ports to Be on Alert

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard issued a nationwide alert this weekend, saying it had received reports of a possible maritime threat against the nation's ports and harbors. It recommended security action by Coast Guard personnel and people in the maritime industry. Cmdr. Jim McPherson, a Coast Guard spokesman in Washington, said he could not speculate on targets or security measures taken in response to the reports. But he said the reports concerned potential threats from swimmers and divers.

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Tanker Enters Boston Harbor

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A tanker carrying liquefied natural gas entered Boston Harbor for a delivery after a federal judge ruled that the city could not block it for security reasons. It was the first such ship allowed in since Sept. 11. The Coast Guard said it could ensure the safety of the tankers. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

headline.seo: Japan-China Trade Ties Complicate Island Dispute
headline.main: Sleepy Islands and a Smoldering Dispute
headline.print_headline: Sleepy Islands and a Smoldering Dispute

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A clash over contested territory has set off worries about the effect on business ties between China and Japan.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lower Township: Military Closes Beach

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A popular Cape May County beach will remain closed indefinitely because it is close to a Coast Guard base, a Coast Guard official said yesterday. United States Fish and Wildlife officials agreed to keep the beach, Two Mile Beach, in Wildwood closed to the public as a security buffer to the base, the Long Range Aid to Navigation Support Unit. Along with other military installations, it was closed to the public after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Hudkins, a spokesman, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.seo: Gulf Sees Familiar Face in Charge of Oil Spill Cleanup
headline.main: Crisis-Tested Veteran Gets Arduous Final Task
headline.print_headline: Crisis-Tested Veteran Gets Arduous Final Task

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard is overseeing the federal response to the gulf oil spill. He did the same for Hurricane Katrina.

headline.main: Commander Accustomed To Scrutiny And Crises
headline.kicker: STORM AND CRISIS: THE RECOVERY CHIEF -- MAN IN THE NEWS

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen, who has been put in charge of the federal response to Hurricane Katrina, is known as a steady Coast Guard commander already tested by major crises, including some that drew intense public scrutiny. After the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, he commanded the Coast Guard response up and down the Atlantic Seaboard, moving ships and personnel to patrol the waters and secure the ports.

headline.main: BEACH CLOSED

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Two-Mile Beach, a part of a national wildlife refuge in Lower Township, Cape May County, which normally opens to hiking and surf fishing on Oct. 1, will remain closed indefinitely because of security concerns for the Coast Guard station situated next to it, said Bruce Luebke, assistant manager for the Cape May National Wildlife Refuge. The beach is closed from spring until fall because it is a nesting ground for the endangered piping plover, but it is usual opens after the nesting season ends. The Coast Guard base by the beach houses the Loran Support Unit, an electronic navigational facility that guides planes and boats. Karen DeMasters

headline.main: CNN Rivals Criticize Its Tactics

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: CNN presented the first aerial video footage of the devastation in New York yesterday, a series of spectacularly vivid images of collapsed buildings. But the way CNN obtained the footage was immediately criticized by some of its competitors. Executives at MSNBC accused CNN of using a government vehicle, a Coast Guard helicopter, for its own purposes. CNN said it had arranged for a camera operator to ride with the Coast Guard as part of a planned report on the threat to the nation's waterways. When the views of the destruction proved to be so remarkable, the network decided to broadcast the videotape immediately.

headline.main: Container Ship Is Held Offshore After Search Discovers Radiation

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Department of Energy technicians and F.B.I. agents continued today to pore over a German container ship that raised security concerns when its cargo showed traces of radioactivity after it steamed into port here early Tuesday morning. The freighter, Palermo-Senator, was moved to a secure area Tuesday night about six miles off shore after Coast Guard members detected radiation during a search of the ship, said Sandra Carroll, an F.B.I. spokeswoman.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Coast Guard Commandant Candidate

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The White House announced its intention to nominate Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen to be commandant of the United States Coast Guard. President Bush put Admiral Allen, right, in charge of the federal relief effort related to Hurricane Katrina in September, after Michael D. Brown, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was stripped of his oversight duties. Since 2002, Admiral Allen has been chief of staff of the Coast Guard, an agency that provides military-style security and support like search-and-rescue missions, environmental cleanups, maritime safety and law enforcement. Admiral Allen also commanded the Coast Guard's response along the Atlantic Seaboard after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. JOHN FILES (NYT)

headline.main: Coast Guard Rescues Eight Cuban Migrants Off Miami, 5 Missing
headline.print_headline: Coast Guard Rescues Eight Cuban Migrants Off Miami, 5 Missing

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard on Monday said it was searching for up to five Cubans migrants after pulling eight others from the waters off Miami.

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: National Guard Troops Sue For Expenses

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Four National Guard members filed a class-action suit against Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Massachusetts Guard, Gov. Mitt Romney and other military officials contending that the troops were not reimbursed for expenses while on duty after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, John Shek, said troops called up by the federal National Guard office were allowed reimbursement, but not those put on active duty by the Massachusetts Guard. One plaintiff in the $73 million suit, Louis P. Tortorella, said he spent more than $14,625 commuting two and a half hours to guard the Quabbin Reservoir from September 2001 to late 2003. A spokesman for the Massachusetts Guard had no comment. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

headline.main: Coast Guard Reduces Use of Live Animal Training
headline.print_headline: Coast Guard Reduces Use of Live Animal Training

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard won't use as many live animals for its combat medical training after an animal rights group showed a goat's legs being removed with tree trimmers.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Terrorism Interrogation

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The authorities are questioning a suspected smuggler of immigrants for possible connections with Al Qaeda. Officials refused to release any details but said American and British intelligence had been called into the investigation. The state-run NET television identified the suspect as a Pakistani and one of three smugglers arrested last month by the Greek Coast Guard. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Missing Woman's Body Found

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard has tentatively identified the body of a Long Island woman who had been missing after she and a companion began a kayaking trip three days ago. What are believed to be the remains of Mary Jagoda, 20, of Huntington, were found off the coast of Monomoy Island near Cape Cod yesterday, Sgt. James Plath of the Massachusetts State Police said. Ms. Jagoda, a junior at Brandeis University, was the sole remaining child of Louis and Anna May Jagoda. Her brother, Jake, 24, an employee of Cantor Fitzgerald, was killed in the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. Another child died in infancy 20 years ago. Ms. Jagoda and a friend, Sarah Aronoff, 19, of Bethesda, Md., started at a boat launch in Harwich Port, paddling eight-foot plastic kayaks into foggy conditions on Sunday afternoon. A friend reported them missing later that day. The Coast Guard called off the search for Ms. Aronoff last night.

headline.main: Coast Guard Is Criticized On Overhaul; Waste Is Cited

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by reports of ships with cracking hulls, design flaws, cost overruns and construction delays, lawmakers demanded Tuesday that the Coast Guard's leadership overhaul its $24 billion effort to rebuild its fleet or risk the program's cancellation. At a hearing of the House Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation, committee members delivered a bipartisan lashing to the Coast Guard, which has spent several billion dollars for a new fleet but now has fewer ships available for patrols than it did in 2001.

headline.main: Some Ships Get Coast Guard Tip Before Searches

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Under intense pressure from shipping companies concerned about costly delays, the Coast Guard is tipping off some large commercial ships about security searches that had been a surprise, according to high-ranking Coast Guard officials. The searches began after the Sept. 11 attacks as part of a major revamping of the Coast Guard and its new antiterrorism mission. But shipping companies say the surprise boardings at sea cause unnecessary delays, costing up to $40,000 an hour.

headline.main: A New, Experienced Protector For the Navy in Home Waters
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE COAST GUARD

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The Firebolt, one of the Navy's newest, fastest ships, built to insert and extract commandos in exotic places around the globe, zipped through the Chesapeake Bay this morning on a new mission: homeland defense. And in place of Navy Seals, it had a new strike team: a boarding party from the United States Coast Guard. For the first time since World War II, the Coast Guard is defending Navy ships in United States waters as well as taking a more vigorous look at thousands of ships entering those waters, checking their cargoes and crews.

headline.main: Review by Coast Guard Says 9/11 Exercise Was Poor Idea
headline.print_headline: Review by Coast Guard Says 9/11 Exercise Was Poor Idea

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: An internal Coast Guard review said a training exercise that led to false news reports of gunshots on the Potomac River on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks was ill-advised.

headline.main: Coast Guard Chief Announces Plans to Overhaul the Service

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging that the Coast Guard has failed to keep up with changing times, its commandant, Adm. Thad Allen, unveiled a plan Tuesday to restructure its management radically and expand its surveillance efforts along the nation's coasts. The overhaul is intended to address mounting criticism of a $24 billion equipment program known as Deepwater, which is replacing or rebuilding most of the service's large ships, planes and helicopters.

headline.main: Ship's Radiation Is Traced to Harmless Tiles

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A German container ship was allowed to dock in Port Newark today after more than two days of inspections determined that the radioactive readings that it registered were emanating from naturally occurring radiation in ceramic tiles among the cargo. The 708-foot Palermo Senator and its crew of 21 steamed into port here this afternoon after a determination that it and its cargo ''posed no danger or threat,'' said Sandra Carroll, a spokeswoman and special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline.main: Coast Guard Lets Skullcap Stay, Meaning This Recruit Will, Too

US Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The skullcap can stay on the Coast Guard auxiliarist's head after all. Jack Rosenberg, a 35-year-old Hasidic Jew from Rockland County, signed up for the Coast Guard Auxiliary last year and passed his training, only to be informed that regulations forbade him to wear his skullcap during some duties.

headline.main: Alliance Strikes Taliban Troops Outside Kabul

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance soldiers attacked a stranded and desperate Taliban force early this morning here, about 12 miles west of Kabul. The Taliban were surrounded, according to alliance commanders. A week of negotiations had foundered before troops began to move toward the forward posts of the trapped militia.

headline.main: Taliban Negotiating Surrender of Kunduz, Their Last Stronghold in Afghanistan's North

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: A large garrison of Taliban troops trapped in Kunduz, in northern Afghanistan, continued to defy the Northern Alliance on Wednesday as warlords from both sides met for several hours to try to avert a bloodletting. Commanders from the Taliban and the Northern Alliance gathered in Emam Sahib, about 30 miles north of here, in an effort to negotiate a peaceful handover of the city.

headline.main: TALIBAN FOES SAY KUNDUZ IS THEIRS

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance commanders said Sunday night that their troops had captured the city of Kunduz in the dark, overrunning the last Taliban stronghold in northern Afghanistan. The deputy defense minister of the Northern Alliance, Atiqullah Baryalai, said that his men had taken control of the city and that Taliban troops had fled to the west, straight toward the army of another Northern Alliance general, Abdul Rashid Dostum.

headline.main: Vanquished Yield Arms To Victors

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance units have been spreading out through this northern city and nearby villages over the last two days, beginning to disarm Taliban soldiers who surrendered last week. The effort to remove weapons from the hands of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of local Afghan Taliban troops followed the arrests of three former Taliban leaders suspected of plotting insurrection.

headline.main: Rebels Pause for Ramadan, but Vow Swift Attack on Kunduz

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance fighters who have encircled the besieged city of Kunduz paused briefly today to celebrate the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, but their commanders said they would be moving ahead -- perhaps within 24 hours -- to attack the city where they have as many as 20,000 Taliban fighters surrounded. As the siege of Kunduz entered its fifth day, the alliance commanders said they would give the local Taliban one last chance to change sides or surrender -- or else they would die.

headline.main: Rapid Advances by Northern Alliance Deal a Setback to Pakistan's Policy

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: The stunningly swift successes of the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan amount to a huge setback for the longtime policy of Pakistan, which until the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 had supported the ruling Taliban. Under pressure from Washington, which gave Pakistan's military government little choice but to join the coalition against terrorism, Pakistan has become an indispensable American ally. But it has insisted that the Northern Alliance, which consists mainly of ethnic groups that rival the Pashtun who dominate southern Afghanistan and northern Pakistan, not be allowed to take over Kabul, the capital.

headline.main: Taliban Withdrawing From Kabul as Rebels Move Toward Capital

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: After a string of successes by the Northern Alliance, the forces of the Taliban retreated early this morning from the Afghan capital, heading southward to their heartland in a move that smacked of tactical withdrawal. On the city outskirts, women forced into virtually total seclusion under Taliban rule waved excitedly to foreigners. Hundreds of people celebrated in the streets. At least one child flew a kite, an act also banned under the Taliban.

headline.main: Northern Alliance, in Charge, Tries to Ease Fears of Captives

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Serving alongside Pakistani, Chechen and Arab volunteers, Atiqurahman manned a post on the second line of Taliban forces in the village of Kalai Nasro near the Bagram air base 35 miles north of Kabul. Now, after abandoning his position and trudging toward the capital as Northern Alliance forces burst through his line, the 23-year-old soldier from Kandahar is a prisoner, and fearful of his future.

headline.main: Talks Fail With Taliban Besieged In Kunduz

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Talks to secure a peaceful handover of the besieged Taliban-held city of Kunduz collapsed today, setting the stage for a possible battle involving thousands of foreign Taliban troops believed to be trapped in the northern Afghan city. American B-52's and fighter-bombers struck Taliban positions outside the city for the first time, and Northern Alliance commanders decided that they would move into the city, which its troops had surrounded. The actions followed the breakdown of negotiations between Taliban and Northern Alliance fighters set up to find a way to avert a battle.

headline.main: A Would-Be Warlord Is Given Short Shrift by New Rulers

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance soldiers forced Sayed Jaffar, the would-be governor of Baghlan province, to flee his home here and take to the mountains with his men. Mr. Jaffar, 35, the American-educated son of a family that has traditionally held the governorship, tried to take the city of Pul-i-Khumri by force on Wednesday but was quickly repulsed by Northern Alliance troops in charge of the town.

headline.main: Rebel Alliance Is Frustrated By U.S. Raids

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: A week ago tonight, soldiers and commanders of the rebel Northern Alliance gleefully watched American bombs begin to fall on Taliban positions just north of Kabul. Seven days later, American jets have bombed the wrong side of the front line twice, including an errant bomb that killed one person and wounded eight, among them four children, in a campaign that has left the alliance baffled.

headline.main: Swedish Journalist Slain as Fears Rise for Safety of Reporters

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: A Swedish journalist was killed early this morning in northern Afghanistan, where the fighting and static front lines between the Northern Alliance and Taliban soldiers have been replaced by pockets of lawlessness and roaming bands of young gunmen. The journalist, Ulf Stromberg, was a cameraman for Sweden's TV4. He was shot and killed by young men who robbed the home in which he was staying with other journalists in Taliqan, a city that was taken by the Northern Alliance roughly two weeks ago.

headline.main: SURRENDER OF TALIBAN BEGINS AT FINAL NORTHERN STRONGHOLD

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Taliban soldiers streamed out of the besieged northern city of Kunduz today, some to the welcoming arms of joyous crowds, others to the custody of their adversaries, each group following a script of surrender that culminated a two-week standoff in one of the last Taliban strongholds. Even as the Taliban poured out of Kunduz to give themselves up, American jets bombed the city, as if to warn the soldiers of their fate should they change their minds. Northern Alliance tanks stood on the hills overlooking the surrender routes.

headline.main: U.S. Bomb Wounds G.I.'s as Battle Rages at Fort

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: A battle raged here today between Taliban prisoners and the American-backed troops of the Northern Alliance, and the Bush administration revealed that five Americans had been wounded. The sounds of fighting echoed around the 19th-century Qala Jangi fortress, a great hulking mass of brown crenelated walls, standing alone in the flat fertile fields several miles west of Mazar-i-Sharif.

headline.main: FOREIGN MILITANTS SEEK SAFE PASSAGE FROM AFGHAN CITY

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Foreign militants, trapped inside the besieged city of Kunduz and desperate to save their lives, have asked to leave the country through a protected corridor and travel overland to Pakistan, a senior Northern Alliance official said here today. The militants' evacuation request surfaced here as leaders of the Taliban and Northern Alliance gathered in two distant meetings to discuss the possible surrender of Kunduz. As of late tonight, the city's fate, and that of the foreign fighters trapped inside, remained uncertain amid conflicting reports from the negotiations.

headline.main: An American Is Said to Be Killed During a Failed Prison Uprising

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Surrendered Taliban troops staged a revolt today at a prison where hundreds of them were being held under the control of the Northern Alliance, and American warplanes bombed the prison to help quell the uprising. An unknown number of people died, possibly a great number, at the prison, which is outside Mazar-i-Sharif. A United States Special Forces soldier at the scene told the BBC that hundreds of prisoners had died in the revolt.

headline.main: Armed Adversaries Maintaining Fragile Radio Contacts Across the Front Line
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: NORTH OF KABUL

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: The voice on the other end of the radio was distorted, but clear. After exchanging pleasantries with a translator on the opposition Northern Alliance side of the front line, the Taliban soldier started asking questions.

headline.main: As Alliance Deals With a Warlord, Taliban Fighters Slip Away

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: The warlord of this dusty collection of villages just 12 miles from Kabul today surrendered to, joined or made a deal with the Northern Alliance. Just which it was still was not clear after a day of frantic negotiations and marshaling of forces. What was clear was that as the negotiations went on -- and apparently as a part of them -- the hard-core Taliban fighters and an unknown number of foreign Islamic zealots had simply melted away. They crossed the brown hills and ridge lines, and slipped away. They could be headed for the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, or they could simply be disappearing into the mountains, perhaps to fight another day as guerrillas.

headline.main: REBEL FORCES SAY THEY HAVE TAKEN A 2ND AFGHAN CITY

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Forces opposed to the Taliban said Sunday that they had captured the northeastern city of Taliqan, in their second apparent victory in three days. Early this morning, the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance opened a major assault on Taliban positions north of Kabul, backed by American airpower. Northern Alliance leaders claimed that their soldiers had entered Taliqan without firing a shot, after making a deal with the local Taliban warlord to switch sides. The warlord, identified as Abdullah Gard, and Northern Alliance leaders closed the deal just before sunset Sunday, and the alliance soldiers then marched into the city, the opposition leaders said.

headline.main: On One Afghan Front Line, the Rebel Tide Surges, Then Flows Back

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: On the first day of the Northern Alliance's long-awaited offensive along the front lines here, the men ran forward. On the second day, they ran back.

headline.main: Bush Says Aim Is to Ease Entry Of Land Force

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: President Bush said today that the blitz of American air attacks in Afghanistan was intended to pave the way for anti-Taliban forces on the ground to defeat the government. ''The enemy's air force and air defenses are being demolished,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We're paving the way for friendly troops on the ground to slowly but surely tighten the net to bring them to justice.''

headline.main: Key Players Confer at U.N. On a Post-Taliban Regime

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: As fighters from the Northern Alliance sweep across northern Afghanistan, the Bush administration is struggling to answer a critical question: Who will govern Kabul if the Taliban abandon the capital? The issue will be taken up on Monday when Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, his Russian counterpart, representatives of Afghanistan's six neighbors and United Nations officials meet in New York on the fast-moving situation.

headline.main: After Defeat, Journey to Uncertain Fate

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate. The prisoners, crawling and writhing on one another like turtles in a pet shop, were the sorry byproduct of the Northern Alliance's most recent victory. Until Monday, the Taliban soldiers had been hunkered down in the northern city of Kunduz, and when the Northern Alliance laid siege to the place for the last two weeks, the Taliban troops faced the choice of surrendering or fighting to the death. First they retreated, then they gave up.

headline.main: Afghan Warfare: Taliban Trick Throws Rebels Into Retreat

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: The scene was set today for Northern Alliance troops to make another triumphant entrance into a city taken from the Taliban. Then everything went wrong. Early this afternoon, the word spread that a Taliban commander in Kunduz, in northeastern Afghanistan, had switched his allegiance to the Northern Alliance and invited its troops to enter.

headline.main: Special Forces, On the Ground, Aid the Rebels

Northern Alliance.lead_paragraph: A small number of American troops have been on the ground in northern Afghanistan working closely with rebel militias for several days, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today. Providing the first details of the expanding ties with the resistance forces facing the Taliban, Mr. Rumsfeld said the American forces were working with the Northern Alliance to establish supply routes, improve communications with American commanders and target specific Taliban military positions for air strikes against the front lines.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun planning a ceremony for when the cleanup at ground zero ends. The ceremony would be for those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and those who have labored at the site. The site will be shut down sometime in late May, Mr. Bloomberg said, depending on the weather and other factors. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: A Mayor Often Ill at Ease, and Usually Muted on Iraq
headline.print_headline: A Mayor Often Ill at Ease, And Usually Muted on Iraq

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Aides to Michael Bloomberg say he has been quiet about the war because to do otherwise would simply be grandstanding.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Can't Fly With Mayor-Elect

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is still hoping to travel to Israel this weekend, but an aide said yesterday that a scheduling conflict would prevent him from flying aboard Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's private jet. Mr. Giuliani said earlier this week that he hoped to join Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg tomorrow for the flight on Mr. Bloomberg's plane to Israel, where they planned to stay overnight to show their support in the wake of the recent suicide bombings. But last night the mayor's spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, said that the mayor would not be able to make the flight because he planned to attend the funeral of a firefighter who died in the World Trade Center terrorist attack, tomorrow afternoon. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 anniversary remembrance will not be held at its original location at ground zero this year because construction on the site has made it unsafe for a large public gathering, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The ceremony will be held at a plaza near the southeast corner of the site. Some family members of victims have protested, but the mayor said that the decision was final and that ''it would be a big shame'' if anyone skipped the event out of anger.

headline.main: For a Skilled Fund-Raiser, Lhota Looks No Further Than Home
headline.print_headline: For a Skilled Fund-Raiser, Lhota Looks No Further Than Home

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Tamra Roberts Lhota, the wife of Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for New York City mayor, says her husband would  preserve the city’s quality of life.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor To Lead Memorial Group

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was named chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation yesterday, despite strong opposition from several relatives of those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. Many of the family members say they will continue to press to have the names of the dead, with ages, organized by affiliation and where they died; Mr. Bloomberg wants them listed at random. With a new $10 million gift from American Express, Mr. Bloomberg's chief function will be to raise the additional $155 million needed for the project. Mr. Bloomberg has been cleared for that work by the city's Conflicts of Interest Board, but must either stay out of government decisions affecting people or entities from whom he is seeking donations or not ask them for money. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)

headline.seo: Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Muslim Center
headline.main: N.Y. Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Islam Center
headline.print_headline: Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Islam Center

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg affirmed his support for the center near ground zero, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, voiced forceful opposition.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg To Address U.N.

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will address the United Nations on Friday, his aides said yesterday. The mayor, who earlier this summer took action to crack down on diplomats with outstanding parking tickets, will take a global tone in his speech to the General Assembly. ''He's going to talk about the renewed importance of New York's role as the host city for the United Nations in light of Sept. 11, and thank the freedom-loving countries who have supported New York City,'' said his spokesman, Edward Skyler. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: The Mayor And His Firm Use This Card

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: During his first address to the City Council in January, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he was so pleased that American Express was returning to its New York headquarters that he was urging New Yorkers to use only their American Express cards. And yesterday, his company, Bloomberg L.P., sent its employees an e-mail message saying that ''Bloomberg is switching to the American Express Corporate Card.'' (The company has been using Diners Club, whose headquarters are in Chicago.)

headline.seo: Andrew Kirtzman, Guardian of Fire Island Pines
headline.main: Guardian of the Pines
headline.print_headline: Guardian of the Pines

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: A former political reporter now at the helm of a beachside gay community, Andrew Kirtzman is working to turn a timeworn Shangri-La into a chic resort.

headline.main: One Thing's Almost Certain: He Wasn't at Gracie Mansion

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Another weekend, another mystery about who was running the City of New York. It might have been Michael R. Bloomberg, who was elected mayor in November. Or it might have been Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw, an appointee who takes over whenever Mr. Bloomberg leaves town. But for the second weekend in a row, it was a secret: Bloomberg administration officials refused to say yesterday who was in charge.

headline.main: Bloomberg Has His Doubts On Stadiums

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg expressed doubts yesterday about whether the city should agree to help pay for new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets in the current fiscal climate. ''We'd all like to have stadiums,'' he said. ''The question is, how can we afford it?''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Giuliani Defends Bush

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the Bush administration's handling of intelligence information before Sept. 11, saying he did not believe the federal government could have anticipated the terrorist attacks. Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, suggested that the Clinton administration should also be accountable given that much of the intelligence now coming under scrutiny was collected during its watch. ''Remember, the Bush administration when this attack took place was a very new administration, and they had just inherited the intelligence apparatus put in place by the Clinton administration, so when you look at this you're going to have look at both,'' Giuliani told The Associated Press after a speech to graduates of Georgetown Law School in Washington.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Families Of 9/11 Victims Plan Ceremony

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Members of several families who lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terror attack plan to hold their own ceremony on June 2, a Sunday, to mark the end of efforts to recover remains from ground zero. The city, which will hold its official ceremony next Thursday, will issue a permit to the group as long as it complies with safety regulations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg has pointed out that next Thursday was chosen because it will not interfere with religious observances, while the families want a weekend observance. Mr. Bloomberg said he did not know if he would be invited to the group's ceremony, but he added that ''if people want to have other days that's perfectly appropriate.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

headline.main: In Homestretch of Campaign, Mayor Endorses Bloomberg

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: With the race for mayor approaching its final and most critical week, Michael R. Bloomberg officially received the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday during a news conference outside City Hall. The backing by the mayor, who has enjoyed enormous popularity since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, had long been regarded by the Bloomberg campaign as the crown jewel of endorsements. As the mayor spoke, a campaign film crew was capturing his remarks for a television advertisement soon to be broadcast by Mr. Bloomberg.

headline.main: Sept. 23-29; Two Mayors? It's a Thought

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Democrats who went to the polls in New York on Tuesday -- two weeks after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center -- might have thought they were beginning to settle the question of who would succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at the end of the year. They were wrong.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Democrats Drop Plan For 9/11 TV Ad

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: With an assurance from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that Democrats will not be shut out of the city's Sept. 11 anniversary ceremony, the state Democratic Party said yesterday that it had dropped its plan to broadcast an advertisement with elected leaders reciting the Gettysburg Address. The plan had drawn controversy because Gov. George E. Pataki will read the address on Sept. 11 at the official city-organized ceremony. The plan was dropped after Mr. Bloomberg assured Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver that Democratic officials would be invited to read the names of the dead at the city ceremony. Randal C. Archibold

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor and Senate Leader Confer

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Bill Frist, left, the majority leader of the United States Senate, met with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for a half-hour yesterday afternoon. The two officials, both Republicans, discussed federal aid for New York City, homeland security funds, preparations for this summer's Republican National Convention and transportation issues, said Edward Skyler, the mayor's press secretary. The mayor and Senator Frist had met at the Capitol at the end of January. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Mayor Reviews Six Proposals For Rebuilding

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: At a rare Saturday news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg breezed through several topics yesterday, including charter revision and the future of the World Trade Center site. Mr. Bloomberg said that he had seen the six preliminary plans for the future of Lower Manhattan, to be released Tuesday, and called them ''a start.''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Saying that the International Freedom Center planned for the World Trade Center site had become ''very controversial,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he had instructed his appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board to carefully read the center's new report on how it would operate. ''Then we'll discuss it and try to come to some resolution,'' the mayor said. The center was intended to put 9/11 in the context of the world's history of freedom but it has faced criticism that it would detract from the memorial and deprive the memorial museum of space. Speaking of exhibitions planned for the center, Mr. Bloomberg said, ''Some things you might want to put elsewhere.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Agency Powers Proposed

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democratic candidate for mayor, proposed strengthening the city's Office of Emergency Management yesterday and renaming it the Homeland Security Office. Under Mr. Miller's proposal, the office would reassume the authority it once had under Rudolph W. Giuliani to settle jurisdictional disputes between the Police and Fire Departments, and would coordinate the antiterrorism efforts of various agencies. Currently, the emergency management agency can help mediate disagreements, but does not have the power to rule on them. Paul Elliott, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, called the proposed changes unnecessary and ''an added bureaucracy.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

headline.main: Giuliani Is Resolute on Extending His Term

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: Now that the Democratic mayoral primary runoff is over, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is making it clear that he meant what he said about wanting to stay. A few weeks ago, he summoned the mayoral candidates to his command center and told them that he wanted a three-month term extension, and that if they did not agree, he might try to go around the city's term limit laws and run again. Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green said sure, and Fernando Ferrer said no.

headline.main: 'SNL' Debuts With Tribute

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: In a decidedly solemn opening to ''Saturday Night Live,'' last night, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani paid tribute to the city's emergency workers and those killed on Sept. 11, saying ''our heroes met the worst of humanity with the best of humanity.'' Mr. Guiliani appeared with Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik and Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen, and several firefighters and police officers.

headline.main: Page Two: May 16-22; STUDYING NEW YORK'S 9/11

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: The independent Sept. 11 commission traveled to New York to confront the city's current and former leaders with a public accounting of what went wrong in its emergency response at the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Road Repair

NYC Mayors - Giuliani and Bloomberg.lead_paragraph: The city is repaving the streets on roughly 240 city blocks in Lower Manhattan that were damaged by heavy trucks carting away debris from the World Trade Center site, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The project, which is to be completed by June 1, is being paid for by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Officials said that roughly two-thirds of the streets will have to be ripped up again and repaved later, as the supporting infrastructure below them is replaced. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: More Security For Producer Of Vaccine

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The National Guard is providing extra security at the company that is the nation's sole producer of the anthrax vaccine. Pentagon officials called on the Guard after examining company security measures at the BioPort Corporation, in Lansing. The company supplies the military with a vaccine for anthrax, which can be used as a biological weapon. The vaccine is not available to the public. A company spokesman said BioPort had not been threatened. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

headline.main: Talks on Vaccine For Smallpox

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said yesterday that the government was negotiating with seven companies to manufacture smallpox vaccine that could be used in case of a terrorist attack. Mr. Thompson did not disclose the names of the companies, but among them is Merck & Company, one of the nation's four largest vaccine makers. Proposals from the companies are due today.

headline.main: Vaccine Maker Hopeful Over License

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The nation's only manufacturer of anthrax vaccine expressed confidence today that it would soon win federal approval to distribute the vaccine. The manufacturer, the BioPort Corporation of Lansing, has been making the vaccine since 1998 but has been unable to ship it after failing federal inspections of its laboratories in 1999 and 2000.

headline.main: U.S. Seeks Anthrax Vaccine for Almost a Million People

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The government wants access to a stock of anthrax vaccine large enough to protect almost a million people, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said yesterday. The stock is held by the BioPort Corporation of Lansing, Mich., but it cannot be used yet because the Food and Drug Administration has not completed its inspection of the vaccine lots or of the plant where they were manufactured.

headline.main: Anthrax Shots for Military Personnel to Be Limited to High Risks

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon wants to abandon its policy of anthrax vaccinations for all troops and limit shots to those with the highest risk, officials said today. The program to vaccinate all 2.4 million members of the active and reserve military was started in 1998, but it was radically reduced after safety and other violations by the nation's sole anthrax vaccine manufacturer left the Pentagon with a dwindling supply. In addition, some soldiers were highly reluctant to take the shots.

headline.main: President Is Said to Be Near a Decision on Who Receives the Smallpox Vaccine, and When
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE BIOTERROR THREAT

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: After months of speculation and internal White House debate over who should have access to the smallpox vaccine, President Bush is nearing a decision and is likely to announce his policy, or parts of it, in the next month, administration officials said today. Mr. Bush is widely expected to offer the vaccine to some members of the military and about 500,000 health care workers. But officials said today that the president had yet to resolve the most difficult issue before him: whether to offer the vaccine to millions of ordinary Americans as a precaution against a biological attack.

headline.main: Production of Smallpox Vaccine to Begin by December, U.S. Says

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the health and human services secretary, said yesterday that he expected production of smallpox vaccine to begin by late November or early December. So far, the government has selected one company, Acambis, a small biotechnology company, to make 54 million doses of smallpox vaccine. That contract was signed last year, after the government put out a bid as part of a program to stockpile drugs against the threat of bioterrorism, which at the time was considered only a theoretical threat.

headline.main: Smallpox Vaccine Costlier Than Expected

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, warned tonight that procuring 246 million doses of smallpox vaccine would cost more than the $509 million he had previously predicted. Mr. Thompson said that he told the Office of Management and Budget today that the cost would be higher, although he did not specify what it would be. The government had sought to pay a little more than $2 a dose.

headline.main: Drug Makers Plan Vaccines For Smallpox

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration's plan to buy enough smallpox vaccine to inoculate every American has produced an unexpected surge of interest by pharmaceutical companies, federal health officials said today. Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, asked Congress last week for $509 million to acquire 300 million doses of smallpox vaccine, and the government initially invited four companies to work on vaccines. Ten vaccine makers have already submitted proposals outlining their capabilities, Mr. Thompson said yesterday. The deadline for proposals has been extended one day, to Thursday.

headline.main: Wrangling Impedes Transfer Of Civilian Anthrax Vaccine

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Despite pledges two years ago to maintain a stockpile of drugs to protect Americans in the event of a bioterrorism attack, the federal government has so far set aside only 159 vials of anthrax vaccine for the civilian population enough for only 530 people, according to congressional and administration officials. The officials said the failure to transfer more of the vaccine from military to civilian control was caused by legal and bureaucratic wrangling among government agencies. They also cited the government's desire to buy a new vaccine that is potentially both cheaper and more efficient. That vaccine has not yet been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline.main: Smallpox Inoculation Urged For Employees of Hospitals

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: A panel of specialists advising the government on smallpox vaccinations recommended today offering the immunization to an estimated half-million emergency room and other hospital workers because of the possibility of a bioterrorist attack. The panel chose not to recommend offering vaccinations to the estimated 10 million paramedics, firefighters, police officers and other health care and law enforcement workers who might also be among the first to respond to a biological attack.

headline.main: Fertility Isn't Hurt By Anthrax Shots

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The anthrax vaccine does not appear to harm women's fertility, a study of Army women has found. The study involved women who were not believed to have been pregnant when they got their anthrax shots. It found that the vaccine appeared to have had no ill effects on pregnancy rates and birthrates.

headline.main: U.S. Moves Toward Making Anthrax Vaccine Available

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Government health officials have taken the first step toward opening a second line of defense against anthrax in the form of a vaccine. Though the only well-known source of vaccine is a small stockpile owned by the Department of Defense, a large amount of new vaccine has been manufactured by BioPort, the sole maker. It is unavailable because the Food and Drug Administration has not yet approved BioPort's new plant or completed testing its vaccine lots, a company spokeswoman said.

headline.main: 4 Drug Makers Finally Outline Their Intentions

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: For weeks, most of the largest pharmaceutical companies have largely kept quiet as the nation prepared to battle anthrax, smallpox and other potential agents that could be used by terrorists. The big drug companies, which have dozens of factories and hundreds of scientists with expertise in infectious diseases, have said they are willing to help the government but they gave few details.

headline.main: On Many Fronts, Experts Plan for the Unthinkable: Biowarfare

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Protection against biological and chemical attack was never very high on lists of national priorities -- until the days after Sept. 11, when it collectively occurred to Americans how vulnerable they were. An envelope that might (or might not) be filled with ominous powder, the possibility that someone might slip across a border with a jar of viruses, the impossibility of guarding every subway entrance and roof ventilator against a terrorist with a spray can: ''In these times,'' said Dr. Frank Bia, an expert on infectious diseases and microbiology at Yale, ''the unthinkable has become thinkable.''

headline.main: A National Challenged: The Bioterror Threat; Smallpox Vaccine Stockpile Is Larger Than Was Thought

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said yesterday that they might now have access to much more smallpox vaccine than had been thought, a finding that many said changed their options in responding to a terrorist attack with smallpox. The 15.4 million doses in a government stockpile can be diluted with confidence fivefold without losing potency. In addition, a drug company, Aventis Pasteur, said it had more than 85 million doses of vaccine, which has been stored, frozen, for decades. An official of the company said in an interview that tests showed that the vaccine was still effective. Other tests are under way to see if it too can be stretched to cover more people. [Page A13.]

headline.main: Researchers Call Anthrax Vaccine Safe and Likely to Work

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The anthrax vaccine is safe and effective, and is likely to work even against strains of the bacteria that have been engineered as weapons, according to a new study that could clear the way for the Pentagon to resume its program of vaccinating all soldiers. The study, financed by the Pentagon and made public today by the Institute of Medicine, an independent research institution that advises the federal government, is the most comprehensive study ever conducted of the vaccine's safety and effectiveness.

headline.main: SMALLPOX PROGRAM ENDS

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The state has suspended plans to vaccinate additional safety and health officials against smallpox. ''We feel we have sufficient personnel vaccinated to satisfy our preparedness plan in New Jersey,'' Dr. Clifton R. Lacy, commissioner of the state Department of Health and Senior Services, said last week. Last winter, 671 doctors, nurses, emergency medical technicians, firefighters and police officers received the vaccine, far fewer than the 1,000 who signed up for the voluntary program. The vaccination carries some risk of side effects, Dr. Lacy said. As people who have been vaccinated retire or leave the area, he said, others will be vaccinated to keep the number sufficient in the event of a terrorist smallpox attack. Debra Nussbaum

headline.main: New Fight for an Old Warrior

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The old smallpox warrior sat quietly in the audience today, his blue briefing book in his lap, wire-rimmed glasses resting on ruddy cheeks, as President Bush announced his long-awaited decision on who should get the smallpox vaccine. For Dr. Donald A. Henderson, it was a moment tinged with sadness. Dr. Henderson is the man who made the world safe from smallpox. From 1966 to 1977, he ran the worldwide effort to wipe out the disease. He oversaw countless public health workers who toiled under the most grueling conditions, living in villages without water or electricity and slipping in and out of war-torn nations to vaccinate people exposed to the virus, until the disease was no longer a threat.

headline.main: Civilians Are Reluctant to Join U.S. Test of Anthrax Vaccine
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: STEPS AGAINST ANTHRAX
