Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Of 10,000 people who may have been exposed to anthrax during the recent attacks, fewer than 2 percent have taken the anthrax vaccine, a figure that reflects postal employees' deep reluctance to enroll in a medical experiment, federal health officials said today. The postal workers were so unwilling that officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention considered asking them to enroll in a second study to explore their reasons for refusing the vaccine. But the agency deemed the plan too politically sensitive, and it was dropped.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Attacks Led to Push For More Smallpox Vaccine

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: In late September, in the days before a series of anthrax-tainted letters made bioterrorism a reality in the United States, President Bush decided that the federal government should acquire enough vaccine to protect every American against an even more menacing biological threat: smallpox. Although smallpox was eradicated as a disease in the 1970's, American intelligence had suspected for years that Iraq and North Korea, and possibly other rogue nations, had maintained clandestine stocks of the deadly smallpox virus.

headline.main: Doubts Are Raised Over Push to Supply Anthrax Vaccine

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: In ordering a new $877 million anthrax vaccine last month, the federal government said it was a major step toward creating a ''bioshield'' to protect Americans from germ warfare. But delivering that protection may be difficult: the vaccine is unproven in humans, the maker has legal and accounting troubles, and health officials are not prepared to distribute the vaccine quickly if it is needed. Bush administration officials, as well as the top executives at VaxGen, the manufacturer in California, say they are confident they can fulfill their promise.

headline.main: U.S. Looks for More Vaccine Sources

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: The United States has begun looking for scarce anthrax vaccine overseas as a precaution in case lingering production problems cannot be resolved at an American vaccine factory. Britain has already provided samples of its vaccines for testing, and more samples are being sought from other countries, federal health officials said. The Food and Drug Administration does not accept medicines produced overseas until they have been extensively tested in the United States, which sometimes takes years.

headline.main: 3 Smaller Companies Say Their Vaccines Are Cheaper

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Three small vaccine manufacturers that lost out in the first round of bidding for a government contract for smallpox vaccines complained today that they could supply the vaccines for a price that large drug makers still in the running say they cannot meet. The dispute over vaccine pricing reflects a split in the pharmaceutical industry. Some small biological research companies that have done considerable work on smallpox vaccines over the last two years say that they have the viral seed stock to produce the vaccines and could do so quickly and cheaply by renting space at larger laboratories.

headline.seo: Officials Defend Handling of Flu Vaccine
headline.main: Officials Defend Handling of Flu Vaccine
headline.print_headline: Officials Defend Handling of Flu Vaccine

Smallpox Vaccine.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said the root causes of a nationwide shortage of swine flu vaccine were beyond their control.

headline.main: The Hole in the City's Heart

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: On July Fourth two years ago, eight weeks before the Republican National Convention in New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki traveled from the Hamptons summer home of his senior economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, to the dusty crater in the center of Lower Manhattan. Draped in the symbolism of Independence Day, the two men descended into the baking-hot pit at ground zero. There they oversaw the ceremonial laying of a 20-ton Adirondack granite cornerstone -- flecked with garnet, the state gem -- for what was to be the first building to rise at the new World Trade Center: the 1,776-foot Freedom Tower.

headline.main: Use of Air Masks at Issue In Claims of 9/11 Illnesses

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: With mounting evidence that exposure to the toxic smoke and ash at ground zero during the nine-month cleanup has made many people sick, attention is now focusing on the role of air-filtering masks, or respirators, that cost less than $50 and could have shielded workers from some of the toxins. More than 150,000 such masks were distributed and only 40,000 people worked on the pile, but most workers either did not have the masks or did not use them.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun planning a ceremony for when the cleanup at ground zero ends. The ceremony would be for those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and those who have labored at the site. The site will be shut down sometime in late May, Mr. Bloomberg said, depending on the weather and other factors. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Obama Says Mosque Upholds Principle of Equal Treatment
headline.print_headline: Obama Says Building Mosque Upholds Principle of Equal Treatment

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: President Obama said that in defending the Islam center near Ground Zero he was not trying to promote the project, but rather sought to make a statement about freedom of religion.

headline.seo: Pastor Cancels Koran Burning and Plans to Meet Imam
headline.main: Minister Wavers on Plans to Burn Koran
headline.print_headline: Florida Minister Wavers on Plans to Burn the Koran

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The pastor, Terry Jones, said at one point that he had canceled his plan. Later he said it was suspended.

headline.seo: Obama Says Mosque Remarks Were Not Endorsement
headline.main: Obama Enters Debate With Mosque Remarks
headline.print_headline: Obama Says Mosque Remarks Were About Rights

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s attempt to reframe comments about a community center in New York City had him plunging into a debate about Islam and American identity.

headline.main: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 anniversary remembrance will not be held at its original location at ground zero this year because construction on the site has made it unsafe for a large public gathering, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The ceremony will be held at a plaza near the southeast corner of the site. Some family members of victims have protested, but the mayor said that the decision was final and that ''it would be a big shame'' if anyone skipped the event out of anger.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Official To Quit

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The federal official overseeing the controversial cleanup and environmental testing of apartments near ground zero has submitted her resignation. In a letter dated Oct. 12, the official, Jane M. Kenny, said she would leave her job as the Environmental Protection Agency's Region 2 administrator on Nov. 12 for a ''new opportunity,'' but was not more specific. Ms. Kenny, who was appointed to her post in 2001, has rejected claims that residents and workers were allowed to return to the area around ground zero too soon. She also oversaw the cleanup and testing of thousands of apartments in Lower Manhattan, some of which will have to be retested.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: First Look Inside the Proposed Islamic Center
headline.print_headline: Islam Center Offers Look At Its Design

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The planners of Park51 revealed sketches of the center, to be built near ground zero, to the wider public for the first time.

headline.main: PATH STATIONS TO REOPEN

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: PATH stations in Jersey City and lower Manhattan, closed since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, will reopen this year and will eventually become part of a hub in Lower Manhattan that will link trains, subways, ferry service and buses to accommodate commuters and visitors to the planned memorial at Ground Zero. The Exchange Place station in New Jersey is to reopen in June and the Ground Zero station in December, Port Authority officials said last week. Karen DeMasters

headline.seo: Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Muslim Center
headline.main: N.Y. Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Islam Center
headline.print_headline: Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Islam Center

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg affirmed his support for the center near ground zero, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, voiced forceful opposition.

headline.seo: Imam Says Politics Stokes Debate on Islamic Center
headline.main: Imam Says Politics Has Stoked Controversy Over Center
headline.print_headline:
Imam Cites
Politics
In Quarrel
Over Center

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Commenting on the Islamic center controversy, Feisal Abdul Rauf said he was intent on eliminating the notion that Islam can be equated with extremism.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hotel Reopens Near Ground Zero

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday officially reopened the Marriott Financial Center hotel, which had been used as a Red Cross center for workers at ground zero since the Sept. 11 terror attack. The 504-room hotel at 85 West Street, a few blocks south of ground zero, suffered extensive water damage from fire hoses after the attack but has since been repaired. ''I want everyone to understand that New York is safe, it's clean and it's open for business,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Obama Strongly Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site
headline.print_headline: Obama Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: After weeks of avoiding the high-profile battle, President Obama stepped into the thorny debate, leaving little doubt about how he feels.

headline.main: The Joyce Ponders New Sites
headline.print_headline: The Joyce Ponders New Sites

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The Joyce Theater has begun to explore its options beyond a move to ground zero, as the lease on its Chelsea location comes up for renewal in 2016.

headline.seo: On the 9/11 Anniversary, Loss and Tension
headline.main: On Sept. 11 Anniversary, Rifts Amid Mourning
headline.sub: Not at War With Islam, President Declares at the Pentagon ;
headline.print_headline: On Anniversary Of Sept. 11, Rifts Amid Mourning

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Thousands of relatives of 9/11 victims gathered as a nation debated whether an Islamic center should be built near ground zero and President Obama pleaded for religious tolerance.

headline.main: Officials Slow To Hear Claims Of 9/11 Illnesses

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Five years after the World Trade Center towers collapsed in a vortex of dust and ash, government officials have only recently begun to take a role in the care of many of the 40,000 responders and recovery workers who were made sick by toxic materials at ground zero. But for many of the ill and those worried about becoming sick, government actions -- coming from officials whom they see as more concerned about the politics of the moment than the health of those who responded to the emergency -- are too limited and too late.

headline.main: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance
headline.print_headline: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Religious leaders held an “emergency summit” to denounce bigotry toward Muslim Americans.

headline.seo: New Yorkers Divided Over Islamic Center, Poll Finds
headline.main: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site
headline.print_headline: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The poll indicated that support for a center planned near ground zero is tepid in its home town.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: A jury has acquitted a city engineer who was charged with assaulting Port Authority police officers during a scuffle at ground zero last year. The engineer, Michael Kenny, 41, faced up to one year in jail before the jury cleared him in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday. Mr. Kenny, who works for the Department of Design and Construction, which oversees the ground zero cleanup, was accused of interfering with the arrest of a laborer involved in a dispute with the officers. Mr. Kenny resisted arrest, the complaint said. Last Friday, he testified that he was trying to help a man and did not know he was interfering with an arrest. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.seo: New, Quiet Effort for Big Islamic Center Near Ground Zero
headline.main: Developers of Islamic Center Try a New Strategy
headline.print_headline: After Uproar, a New Tack To Build an Islamic Center

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The developers of a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan have embraced a more deliberate approach.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cultural Development Studied For Ground Zero

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: City officials pledged at a City Council hearing yesterday to work with the state, the Signature Theater and the Joyce Theater to produce a feasibility study in eight weeks on cultural development at ground zero. The cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, said she hoped to have a better sense of the artistic programming, construction costs and a timetable in the next two months. The Joyce, which presents dance, will be the sole occupant of a performing arts center at the ground zero site; the Signature Theater was supposed to share the center, but is considering a move into nearby Fiterman Hall because sharing seems too complicated. ROBIN POGREBIN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Sets New Rules On Recovery

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: The Fire Department has banned fire companies from rushing to ground zero when a firefighter's remains are found. Firefighters had developed an informal policy of going to the site in keeping with the tradition in which firefighters carry their fallen brethren from the scene of a disaster. In explaining the new policy, reported yesterday in The Daily News, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said the department was seeking to maintain order. ''We are trying to keep an official notification process, where a body is removed respectfully by those who are at the site,'' he said.

headline.seo: In N.Y. Subway Cavern by Ground Zero, a 9/11 Deadline
headline.main: M.T.A. Crew in a Cavern Has an Eye on Sept. 11
headline.print_headline: M.T.A. Crew In a Cavern Has an Eye On Sept. 11

Ground Zero Site.lead_paragraph: Work at the southbound platform of the Cortlandt Street station, closed for 7 of the last 10 years, is said to be on schedule.

headline.main: Walker to Be Moved From Ship to Airport Camp

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian captured with Taliban soldiers in northern Afghanistan, will be moved from a Navy ship in the Arabian Sea as early as Tuesday on the first leg of his journey back to the United States, Pentagon officials said today. Mr. Walker will be transported from the Bataan, an amphibious assault ship, to a detention camp at Kandahar airport in southern Afghanistan. From there he will be placed on a transport plane that will return him to the United States to face criminal charges. Once in the United States, he will be turned over to the Justice Department, but the government has not said where he will be held.

headline.main: U.S. Hopes American Taliban Will Tell All

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American who was captured with Taliban soldiers in northern Afghanistan, could provide a bounty of useful intelligence about the recruiting methods, hide-outs, supply routes and lower-level command structure of the Taliban military, senior Pentagon officials said today. The officials said American Special Forces troops were holding Mr. Walker, who goes by his mother's last name. They said he was being treated for a variety of injuries, somewhere near Mazar-i-Sharif.

headline.main: Lawyer Demands to Meet Client Held by Military for Two Weeks
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Frustrated that military officials have interrogated John Walker Lindh, the Californian found with Taliban fighters, without allowing him access to his lawyer, the lawyer said today that the government was violating Mr. Walker's rights and demanded to meet with his client. In a statement issued here, the lawyer, James J. Brosnahan, said that despite the growing discussion in the country about the extraordinary case, officials have interrogated Mr. Walker, who is 20, for 16 days without responding to Mr. Brosnahan's request to see him.

headline.main: With the Military Present, Red Cross Officials Talk to Captured U.S. Citizen

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Red Cross officials said today that they had paid two visits in Afghanistan to John Walker Lindh, the American captured with the Taliban last week, and had taken a letter from him to carry to his family. Red Cross officials said the visits, at an undisclosed location somewhere inside the country, were hindered by the presence of American soldiers, who have Mr. Walker in custody. Red Cross officials said they would seek to see Mr. Walker, whom they consider a prisoner of war, without the soldiers present.

headline.main: U.S. Detainee Sends Letter to Parents

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American captured with Taliban fighters in Afghanistan, sent a letter to his family saying he was safe and apologizing for not being in touch and causing them ''a lot of grief.'' The brief letter, dated Dec. 3, was apparently dictated to an International Red Cross volunteer. It was released tonight by the family's San Francisco-based lawyer, James Brosnahan.

headline.main: U.S. Expatriate Is Seen Facing Capital Charge
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Administration officials said today that John Walker, the American who was captured in Afghanistan, would probably face at least one charge that would carry the death penalty, and President Bush linked Mr. Walker directly with the terrorist group Al Qaeda. Mr. Bush said he had not decided on the specific charges to be filed against Mr. Walker, who is expected to be returned to the United States soon. Mr. Bush said he had not ruled out a charge of treason, but said he asked the National Security Council to provide guidance on what to do in the case of members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban captured in Afghanistan, including Mr. Walker.

headline.main: Before He Died, C.I.A. Man Interrogated U.S. Captive

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Just hours before he was slain in Afghanistan, Johnny (Mike) Spann of the Central Intelligence Agency interrogated John Walker Lindh, the American who joined the Taliban, and loudly discussed with a colleague whether Mr. Walker wanted to live or die, Newsweek reported today. The encounter was videotaped by an Afghan film crew and showed Mr. Spann and a second C.I.A. agent, identified only as ''Dave,'' questioning a kneeling Mr. Walker, who refused to respond or even state his name.

headline.main: Walker to Arrive in U.S. Today To Await His Conspiracy Trial
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN CAPTIVE

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian accused of fighting in Afghanistan against his own countrymen, is expected to arrive on American soil on Wednesday to await trial, officials said today. Mr. Walker is to be taken to a prison in the Washington area in preparation for his trial, to be held in the Federal District Court in nearby Alexandria, Va., a jurisdiction known for its conservative juries.

headline.main: U.S. Detainee Is Questioned, But His Fate Is Still Unclear

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American who fought with the Taliban, has provided useful information to United States officials who have detained him at a desert Marine base in southern Afghanistan, American officials said today. Vice President Dick Cheney, appearing on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' said he understood that Mr. Walker, who uses his mother's surname, had provided some useful information and that once the United States was ''through debriefing him he will be turned over to the civilian authorities,'' most likely the Justice Department.

headline.main: Document Paints Portrait Of Committed Taliban Fighter

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian captured while fighting with the Taliban, learned of plans to send suicide teams to the United States three months before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the criminal affidavit filed against him. Mr. Walker learned of the plans while completing a seven-week course in a Qaeda training camp. There, he met at least once with Osama bin Laden, who ''thanked him for taking part in jihad,'' the affidavit said.

headline.main: WALKER WILL FACE TERRORISM COUNTS IN A CIVILIAN COURT
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the American wanderer turned Taliban warrior, was charged today in a criminal complaint with conspiring to kill United States citizens and supporting terrorist groups. He will be tried in federal court in Alexandria, Va., and could face life in prison if convicted. The complaint against the 20-year-old California man said he trained in explosives and firearms at a Qaeda camp and fought shoulder to shoulder with the Taliban before he was captured in November near Mazar-i-Sharif. The charges ended a sharp debate within the Bush administration over whether Mr. Walker would be charged in a civilian court or in a military court-martial.

headline.main: No Shortage Of Great Ideas

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Jay Walker, the creator of Priceline.com, maintains plenty of enthusiasm for inventiveness. ''I'm still trying to create business models that work on a large scale,'' said Mr. Walker, 48, the consummate big thinker who at times may have been better at selling a business idea than in making it pay for its backers.

headline.main: Walker Is Returned to U.S. And Will Be in Court Today
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker, whose spiritual quest, prosecutors say, led him to fight against his fellow Americans in Afghanistan, returned to the United States today and is scheduled to appear in court on Thursday in Virginia. Mr. Walker arrived at Dulles International Airport outside Washington shortly after 6 p.m. and was flown by helicopter to the Alexandria Detention Center.

headline.main: For Many, Verdict's In for Taliban Volunteer (and Skip the Trial)
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN FIGHTER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: If John Walker Lindh's fate were in the hands of many people here, he might well be headed for execution, life in prison or any other penalty suffered by turncoats. ''He's a traitor,'' said Ted Gaines, a Vietnam veteran who works at Grandpa's Pawn Shop. ''He should be prosecuted as a traitor. He was fighting with our enemy. He was fighting with terrorists.''

headline.main: Bush Nears a Decision on American Taliban Member
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: President Bush is nearing a decision about what to do with John Walker, the Californian-turned-Taliban-fighter, weighing options including a charge of treason, which can carry the death penalty, and one of providing material support to a terrorist organization, which carries up to 10 years in prison. Today, CNN broadcast a videotaped interview of Mr. Walker, recorded on Dec. 2, in which he said that he had not participated in a bloody uprising that resulted in the death of a C.I.A. officer at a prison near Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan.

headline.main: Defending, and Recasting, an Unloved Client
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: When the lawyer for John Walker Lindh, the American captured with the Taliban, talks about his client, he sidesteps the hyperventilated debate that has led people to call Mr. Walker a Benedict Arnold and a rat. The lawyer, James J. Brosnahan, says that in time there will be a different view of the young man who climbed out of a sooty prison basement in Mazar-i-Sharif into plenty of legal trouble.

headline.main: Whether Walker Knew of Counsel Is Issue
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: A battle has broken out between Attorney General John Ashcroft and lawyers who say they represent John Walker, the Californian-turned-Taliban warrior, about whether investigators improperly kept Mr. Walker from conferring with the lawyers while he was being questioned. Legal experts said the battle might be laying the groundwork for a defense claim that Mr. Walker's constitutional rights had been violated. If the courts agreed, they could bar prosecutors from using the statements Mr. Walker made during the 45 days he has been held.

headline.main: Ashcroft's Message: Case Against Walker Is Solid
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEGAL CASE

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: When Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the charges that 20-year-old John Walker will face in an American civilian court, it was the start of the public dance that comes in many public cases. Prosecutors have their audiences, and Mr. Ashcroft played to his: the American public, people around the world and the defense in the case itself.

headline.main: A U.S. Convert's Path From Suburbia to a Gory Jail for Taliban
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN FIGHTER

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: John Walker Lindh's parents knew he was a different sort of boy. When others his age were filling their heads with football and fast cars, John was holed up in his room studying thick treatises on world religions. Buddhism, Native American religions, Hinduism. John, raised a Catholic but encouraged by his parents to choose his own spiritual path, studied them all.

headline.main: One For His Country, and One Against It

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Shortly before he left for Afghanistan, Johnny Micheal Spann sent an e-mail message to his parents back in Winfield, Ala. ''What everyone needs to understand is these fellows hate you,'' wrote Mr. Spann, a Central Intelligence Agency officer. ''They hate you because you are an American. Support your government and your military, especially when the bodies start coming home.''

headline.main: Networks Shared $80,000 Cost of Tape of C.I.A. Men Quizzing Captured Californian

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Remarkably, an Afghan cameraman videotaped the C.I.A. officer Johnny Michael Spann as he tried to interrogate the young American Taliban fighter, John Walker, in a prison in Mazar-i-Sharif. Shortly afterward, Mr. Spann was killed in the prison uprising, and Mr. Walker, now being detained by American forces in Afghanistan, was shot in the leg. Almost as remarkably, the videotape, first reported by Newsweek on its Web site on Thursday, was shown on both ABC and CBS yesterday morning, after the two network rivals agreed to share its unusually high cost, $80,000.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; REBUTTAL IN LINDH CASE

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors denied claims by lawyers for John Walker Lindh that he had been threatened with torture by the American military after his capture with Taliban forces in Afghanistan, saying Mr. Lindh got medical treatment, healthy meals and a haircut. The prosecutors were responding to court papers filed by the defense that requested a broad variety of government documents and access to captured Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners. A court hearing on the request is scheduled for Monday. Mr. Lindh, a Californian who converted to Islam and joined the Taliban, faces an Aug. 26 federal trial on a 10-count indictment that accuses him of conspiring to kill Americans abroad.

headline.main: Given Life Term, Drug Offender Hopes for Clemency
headline.print_headline: Given Life Term, Drug Offender Hopes for Clemency

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: From the very start, Scott Walker refused to believe he'd die in prison.

headline.main: Officer's 2 Girls Orphaned

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: The former wife of Johnny Michael Spann, a C.I.A. officer killed in Afghanistan five weeks ago, has died of cancer, leaving their two young daughters as orphans. The former wife, Kathryn King, who grew up in northwestern Alabama, died on Friday and was buried in suburban Washington. She was 30.

headline.main: Unknown Architect Is Teamed With a Veteran

John Walker Lindh.lead_paragraph: In November, when Michael Arad's design was chosen as a finalist in the competition for a World Trade Center memorial, he said he had ''felt compelled to do something before there was a competition.'' Mr. Arad, an architect with the New York City Housing Authority who has worked on designs for police stations in Brooklyn and the Bronx, said in a videotaped statement in November that his design, Reflecting Absence, had evolved.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The city has announced an aid program to reduce by up to 15 percent the electric bills for nonretail small businesses in Lower Manhattan. The program, created with Consolidated Edison, covers the next three years. It will apply to businesses from Houston Street to the Battery that meet particular electricity-use requirements and that have qualified for aid under either of two other programs, the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program and the Small Firm Attraction and Retention Grant program. The city's Economic Development Corporation said it would soon notify about 2,300 businesses that it believes are qualified. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Business Aid At Ground Zero

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Two groups said they would offer about $15 million in grants and loans to small businesses seeking to remain in Lower Manhattan. The groups, Seedco, a nonprofit community aid group, and the Alliance for Downtown New York, said that businesses with 10 or fewer employees could apply for the aid if they were on or below Chambers Street. The grants have a maximum of $50,000 and the low-interest loans, $100,000. Information is available at (866) 473-3326. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Assessment Of Small-Business 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: A Congressional study made public yesterday gave ammunition to critics and supporters of the major government aid program for small businesses hurt as a result of Sept. 11. As the state and city agencies that run the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program have contended, the program did not overlook the smallest businesses. The study found that about 75 percent of the businesses that received funds had fewer than 10 employees. But as critics have argued, the study by the General Accounting Office also found that the program did not pay ''a substantial portion'' of the losses of most of the businesses in the program. A recent rule change should reduce shortfalls in some cases, the study said. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Aid for Small Companies

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: A business and civic group awarded $650,000 in grants and other aid to 14 small businesses in Lower Manhattan yesterday. The aid is part of a $7 million program to assist retailers and manufacturers harmed by the attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Small Business and Workforce Retention Project offers grants of up to $25,000, low-interest loans of up to $100,000 and payments to subsidize up to 50 percent of some employees' wages. Eligible businesses are those south of Canal Street with no more than 50 employees. The project's sponsors include the Alliance for Downtown New York, Seedco, Asian Americans for Equality and the Henry Street Settlement. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Grants up to $50,000 and monthly rent subsidies of up to $5,000 for small businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack were proposed yesterday to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The roughly $200 million required for the initiative would come from federal Community Development Block Grants. Councilman Alan J. Gerson, above, one of the plan's supporters, said that too much aid had gone to businesses with revenues of more than $1 million. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Business Grants

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, said yesterday that she had created emergency grants for shops, restaurants and other small businesses below Canal Street in danger of closing. The $30,000 fund will be administered by the Manhattan Borough Development Corporation. To be eligible for a $1,500 grant, a business must have been open for three years. Terry Pristin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Grants For Retail Businesses

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday announced a $20 million program to provide grants of up to $10,000 for small and medium-size businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Owners of retail businesses with fewer than 50 employees and who intend to remain in New York will be eligible. The Empire State Development Corporation will review applications and disburse grants within 10 days at a center at 199 Church Street. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: New York Announces Details Of Greater 9/11 Business Aid

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: New York State and City gave details yesterday of their plans to increase aid to small businesses in Lower Manhattan that are suffering as a result of the terrorist attack last September. In the largest increase, small businesses that were in the World Trade Center or its immediate vicinity on the day of the attack are eligible for up to 25 days' worth of revenue losses, instead of up to 10 days' worth, as was previously the case. A $300,000 maximum for those businesses remains in place.

headline.main: More Aid Seen For Business Downtown

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: New York State and City are planning to increase financial aid to small businesses near the World Trade Center site that suffered financial losses stemming from the Sept. 11 attack, a government official knowledgeable about the plan said last night. The increase would come after months of criticism from business people in the area that the amounts available in the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program were too small to provide meaningful aid to small businesses that were forced to remain closed the longest and suffered the biggest losses.

headline.main: Officials Seek Changes in Rules For Sept. 11 Business Program

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Businesses that were in the World Trade Center should get more money than other businesses from a program granting relief from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, a group of officials said yesterday. Under the current rules for the aid plan, called the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program, small businesses that were in the trade center when it was destroyed are treated the same as small businesses on the blocks around them, the officials said as they called publicly for different rules for the program.

headline.main: Pace Receives $850,000

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has given $850,000 to Pace University in downtown Manhattan for programs related to Sept. 11. A $500,000 grant will help Pace create fall online courses for students whose education was disrupted. A $350,000 grant will be for internships with small businesses and nonprofit groups downtown that need help to recover. Karen W. Arenson

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Residents of Lower Manhattan have until Saturday to apply for up to $14,500 in grants through a federal program meant to increase the residential population of downtown and help the area recover from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is administering the $306 million program, which offers grants to residents of three zones in Lower Manhattan. Most of the grants require two years' residency. Details are available at the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.com, or by calling (866) 736-3969. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tax Credits For Ground-Zero Jobs

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that small businesses in Lower Manhattan that continued operating after the Sept. 11 terror attack are eligible for tax credits for employing others. The plan calls for companies to receive up to $2,400 in tax credits for each part- and full-time employee. Citing a recent tax code change, the I.R.S. announced yesterday that companies that operated on or south of Canal Street until the attack, and that currently employed no more than 200 employees, were eligible. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Hardest-Hit Small Businesses to Get Leftover 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: As the deadline approaches for aid requests to the biggest grant program helping small businesses recover in Lower Manhattan, a state agency said yesterday that any leftover money would probably be added to the grants already given to the businesses ''most severely impacted'' by last year's terror attack. About $80 million has yet to be distributed, and some critics of the program welcomed what they said was the firmest indication yet of how any leftover money would be used. Those critics had contended that the program had not given enough to the hardest-hit small businesses -- mostly those that were in the World Trade Center. They expressed satisfaction, however, that the agency's statement indicated that the businesses that were obliterated when the towers fell would get more help than those nearby, which suffered more from street closings, lost revenue and other factors.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The Jan. 11 deadline for victims of the World Trade Center attack to apply for federal assistance has been extended to March 11, state and federal officials said yesterday. Under the program, disaster victims are eligible for crisis counseling, and those whose homes or belongings were lost or damaged, as well as business owners whose businesses were harmed, are eligible for low-interest loans or grants. Those seeking assistance should call the Federal Emergency Management Agency, (800) 462-9029, or check the Web site at www.fema.gov.

headline.main: Downtown Small-Business Grants Are Called Too Restrictive

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: A program that gives money to small businesses to stay in Lower Manhattan or move there has attracted 117 applications and given 80 grants since it opened for business more than three months ago, leading critics to say the numbers are too low and the program's rules are too restrictive. The program has given $6 million in grants out of the total $291 million in federal money it has, although almost two-thirds of that total has not been available until recent weeks, officials say.

headline.seo: Five Businesses That Did Not Survive 2011
headline.main: 5 Businesses That Failed to Survive Trials of 2011
headline.print_headline: 5 Businesses That Failed To Survive Trials of 2011

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: For a second consecutive year, it was a challenge for owners to keep the cash coming in the front door.

headline.main: I.R.S. Says 9/11 Grants To Businesses Are Taxable

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service says that government money to help Lower Manhattan small businesses recover from the September 2001 attack is subject to federal taxes, even though grants to individuals for personal expenses like housing are not. In a letter sent Wednesday to New York's Congressional delegation, Charles O. Rossotti, on his last day as I.R.S. commissioner after recently announcing his resignation, said that current law required this. But he also said that a business receiving the aid would generally not pay taxes on the full amount, because it could offset against the grant amount the deductible business expenses paid with the money.

headline.main: $500 Million Left in 9/11 Aid, But Small Businesses Don't Ask

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: David Mirzayev, whose hair salon on Madison Street in Lower Manhattan was closed for two weeks after the attack on the World Trade Center, said ''nothing happened'' after he applied to a disaster aid program in April, discouraging him from seeking other programs. Down the block, Peter Migliorini, whose small grocery is doing 40 percent less business than before the attack, said he had not been aware of government programs offering thousands of dollars in grants for which he could apply.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Efforts by Russian government reformers to reduce red tape for small businesses have not succeeded, said German Gref, the minister of economy and trade, citing a new study by the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research. The study, a survey of 2,000 businesses in 20 Russian regions, found that companies have seen little improvement in business conditions since the state simplified the rules. Russia's economy is in its fourth year of growth, but economists say the growth is confined to large companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: 9/11 Program Finally Gets Flood of Requests for Help

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: A flood of last-minute requests to the biggest program aiding small businesses and nonprofit groups in Lower Manhattan in the wake of the World Trade Center attack has pushed the amount of aid approved to more than the $481 million allotted for the program, according to the state agency that runs the program. Beyond that, 1,700 applications remain to be processed. Officials of the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program say they have approved more than 13,000 applications for $492 million. Michael Marr, a spokesman for the agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, added that most of the 1,700 applications still pending flooded in on the last days before the program's filing deadline on Dec. 31.

headline.main: Insurance; Quick Passage Of Terrorism Bill

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: Insurance executives said Republican control of the Senate offered a better chance to gain the government-backed terrorism-insurance program they have been calling for since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. If such a program were created, the government would pay most claims for damages suffered in a big terrorist attack.

headline.main: 9/11 Small-Business Grants Exceed Approved Financing

Lower Manhattan Grants.lead_paragraph: The biggest 9/11 program aiding small businesses in Lower Manhattan has approved payments totaling $49 million more than the amount allotted to the program, and state officials are scrambling to come up with the extra money. headline.main: War Names

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: In the most famous line of his masterwork ''On War,'' published in 1832, Carl von Clausewitz called war ''nothing but a continuation of political intercourse, with the intermixing of other means.'' He went on (and it's always worth reading on after a famous quotation): ''Is not War merely another kind of writing and language for political thoughts? It has certainly a grammar of its own. . . . The Art of War in its highest point of view is policy, but no doubt, a policy which fights battles instead of writing notes. . . . War is an instrument of policy . . . is therefore policy itself, which takes up the sword in place of pen.'' Battles instead of notes? Swords instead of pens? Since 9/11 there has been an unmistakably Clausewitzian flavor to American foreign policy. War, it seems, has made a comeback this year as a legitimate tool for ''the continuation of political intercourse.'' At West Point in June, President Bush revived the traditional 19th-century doctrine of ''pre-emptive'' war, the argument for which was set forth more fully three months later by the White House in a 33-page document titled ''The National Security Strategy of the United States.'' Because ''deliverable weapons of mass destruction in the hands of a terror network or murderous dictator . . . constitute as grave a threat as can be imagined,'' the United States has claimed the right to initiate hostilities to forestall any ''mortal threat'' to its security. Repeatedly in 2002, key figures in the Bush administration have spoken of the desirability of ''regime change'' in Iraq, and war is the only plausible means of achieving such a change.

headline.main: The Alarm On Security Is Sounded, Quietly

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: DURING World War II, the Office of War Information as well as other government and private agencies mobilized leading public relations experts, graphic designers and copywriters to produce posters warning the public about fifth columnists, spies and saboteurs. Slogans like ''Loose Lips Sink Ships'' and ''He's Watching You'' (which was famously illustrated with a painting of a helmeted German soldier gazing directly at the viewer) stoked collective fears, yet also raised awareness about threats to America's security. For years, these words and images seemed quaint reminders of difficult times. But today, given the war on terror, the cautionary poster as a tool of homeland security is making a comeback.

headline.main: The Battle for History

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: In February, the last surviving American veteran of the First World War died. It is hard to imagine the day when we say goodbye to the last survivor of the Second World War, so large do the ''good war'' and the ''greatest generation'' still loom in the national imagination. But the calendar and the census do not lie. Some 16 million Americans served in the military during World War II. On the 60th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor in 2001, about 5.5 million were still living. This year, as we prepare to mark the 70th anniversary, the number is closer to 1.5 million, and it drops by almost a thousand a day. The passage of time doesn't just turn life into history; it also changes the contours of history itself. Over the last several years, historians, philosophers and others have begun to think about the Second World War in challenging and sometimes disturbing new ways, reflecting the growing distance between the country that fought the war and the country that remembers it. As always when history is debated, the stakes are not just the past but the present and future as well. Even as the long wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have made Americans less confident about the ways we use our military power, the struggle with the Axis remains the classic example of American might deployed for virtuous ends. President Obama had that history in mind when he explained his decision to intervene in Libya's civil war: ''To brush aside America's responsibility as a leader and -- more profoundly -- our responsibilities to our fellow human beings under such circumstances would have been a betrayal of who we are,'' Obama said. ''Some nations may be able to turn a blind eye to atrocities in other countries. The United States of America is different.'' Even today, World War II helps underwrite our claim to that moral difference.

headline.main: Who Owns the Rules of War?

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: During the euphoria of the opening air campaign against Baghdad, commentary was filled with triumphal rhetoric about hitting ''legitimate military objectives'' while causing little or even no loss of civilian life. A week ago, the air war was pounding more than symbols of the regime, and the ground war had become a real war. Scarcely a speech, briefing or interview was being given that failed to mention the laws of war. The Iraqi regime, for its part, was broadcasting denunciations of American airstrikes replete with images of corpses and wounded civilians in hospitals; the United States responded that Iraq had systematically situated military targets and equipment in the midst of civilian areas. The sheer frequency of these references on all sides belied the ancient maxim inter arma silent leges -- in time of war law is silent. People throughout the world obviously care about what is called jus in bello, law governing conduct during war. This is so even if they differ about jus ad bellum, law governing not the conduct of war but rather the resort to force itself. But even while there is agreement on the need for fundamental rules governing the conduct of war, there is profound disagreement over who has authority to declare, interpret and enforce those rules, as well as who -- and what developments in the so-called art of war -- will shape them now and into the future. In short, who ''owns'' the law of war?

Where would the movies be without the rockets' red glare? In his slipstream he left a nation part awed by statesmanship compared to Gladstone or Churchill -- pillars of Britain's national memory -- and part seething to deny him a place on that pedestal. Since Sept. 11 and the attacks on New York and Washington, Mr. Blair has emerged, as he did in the Kosovo crisis, from the grind of domestic politics, where even grumpy truck drivers and the angry matrons of the Women's Institute could unsettle him, to stride a world stage.

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: With Britain casting itself increasingly as America's bridge to unlikely and unspoken allies in the fight against terrorism, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw announced today that he would move up a planned trip to Iran to next week. That will be the first visit to Tehran by a British minister of his rank since the Islamic revolution in 1979. Mr. Straw depicted the trip as part of the efforts to build a coalition against terrorism since the attacks on New York and Washington. The United States and Britain have identified Osama bin Laden, based in Afghanistan, as the prime suspect. ''It's important to build alliances with every country that we can,'' Mr. Straw told reporters.

headline.main: Bush and Blair Trade Praise At White House Love Fest

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: No one ever said they would be soulmates, and they aren't. But today President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood side by side at the White House as unwavering allies joined by war, national self-interest and what their aides say is a growing personal chemistry. Although Mr. Blair is not nearly as close to Mr. Bush as he was to Bill Clinton, he has told his advisers -- just as Mr. Clinton has told friends -- that they are wrong to underestimate the president.

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday defended his handling of a contentious and ultimately doomed $12 billion bid by the media conglomerate owned by Rupert Murdoch to take control of Britain's most powerful and lucrative pay-television network, and offered new backing to an embattled cabinet minister who had pushed energetically for the bid's approval. On a day when Britain's newspapers splashed their front pages with accounts of earlier maneuvering to assure approval for the bid by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, Mr. Cameron appeared on a morning television show to offer a rebuttal of any wrongdoing on his part or by the minister, Jeremy Hunt, who lobbied for the Murdoch bid before Mr. Cameron appointed him to oversee the regulatory process involved.

headline.main: Blair Gives Bush Support, But Receives Little Back

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: On the first two days of his three-day visit here, President Bush got fresh assurances of political, military and moral support from Prime Minister Tony Blair in his antiterrorism efforts. But he gave little back on several issues on which the United States and Britain are at odds, intensifying the domestic political pressure on Mr. Blair. Mr. Blair has been pressing Mr. Bush to address his government's concerns about nine British citizens captured during the war in Afghanistan who are detained at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline.main: British Detainee To Return Home

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- A British terrorism suspect, Binyam Mohamed, who says he was tortured while in American custody, was examined Sunday by a British medical team at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in preparation for his return home, British officials and the detainee's lawyers said. The British team concluded that Mr. Mohamed, who has been in American custody for seven years and began a hunger strike last month, could travel. One of his lawyers, Clive Stafford Smith, said Mr. Mohamed was expected to return to Britain this week.

headline.main: Blair, in Kabul, Warns That Fight Against the Taliban Will Take Decades

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: In his first visit to the Afghan capital, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain warned Monday that the fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda would be a generation-long one, and he said NATO had to refocus on its commitment in Afghanistan until the job was done. ''Now is the right time, with the Riga summit coming up, for NATO to bring into sharp focus the need for us to stay with the Afghans in their journey of progress, and rediscover within ourselves the belief and the vision that took us here and should keep us here until the job is done,'' he said, speaking at a news conference with President Hamid Karzai in the gardens of the presidential palace. ''There's a very strong sense of unity in Europe at the moment for very obvious reasons after what has happened in Madrid,'' Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain told reporters on Friday.

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: With some wisecracks and familiar rhetorical flourishes, Prime Minister Tony Blair delivered his final speech as Labor leader to the party's annual conference on Tuesday, saying it was ''hard to let go'' but ''right to let go.'' He offered no formal endorsement of his presumptive heir, Gordon Brown, however, and did not set a date for his own departure, suggesting that he would pursue a Middle East peace initiative and other projects for ''months'' to come.

headline.main: Blair Says He Wants to Avoid War and Work With U.N., but That Iraq Must Disarm

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that he was eager to avoid war in Iraq and determined to try to work through the United Nations, but that his belief in the need for Iraq to be disarmed -- by force, if necessary -- was firm. Against the backdrop of fervent opposition in much of Europe and his own country to the prospect of an American-led invasion of Iraq, Mr. Blair used a news conference here to assert, as forcefully as ever, that neither he nor President Bush were driving events toward a military confrontation.

Tony Blair.lead_paragraph: Every British prime minister faces dark hours, but for Tony Blair it seems as if time has stood still at the nadir of his political career. The slump in his popularity brought on by the war in Iraq stubbornly will not come to an end. Mr. Blair bounded into the top floor conference room at No. 10 Downing Street this week, radiating his trademark charm and sunny disposition to 100 reporters gathered for his monthly news conference.

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A Texas laboratory worker who contracted skin anthrax last month probably got it because he was not wearing gloves when he handled vials of spores collected from last fall's mail attacks, the government said today. The worker handled the spores a day after cutting his jaw while shaving, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. He then apparently touched his face and developed an anthrax sore on his jaw.

headline.main: Fed Building Is Untainted By Anthrax

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities said today that they had found no evidence of anthrax contamination at the Federal Reserve's headquarters, a day after Fed officials said that a batch of mail sent to the agency had tested positive for anthrax. After a series of tests, officials said that technicians had found no indication of anthrax inside the Fed building or in a courtyard around the Fed's mail processing center. They said the tests suggested that no anthrax spores had entered the building.

headline.main: No Swift Anthrax Test

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: In response to the recent spate of anthrax threats, anxious citizens are demanding that doctors test them for the disease. But, unlike strep throat, there is no rapid screening test for anthrax. In Florida and New York, authorities have used nasal swabs to confirm exposure to the germ. But experts say swabs are not necessarily a reliable indicator of whether someone is actually sick.

headline.main: Medical Treatment Should Not Await a Definitive Diagnosis of Anthrax, Health Officials Say

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Confirming a case of anthrax requires several steps, and results are not immediate. Because a patient can fail rapidly once inhalation anthrax takes hold, health officials say treatment should begin immediately, without waiting for test results, in anyone likely to have been exposed to anthrax spores. A person shows up at a doctor's office weak, with fever and aches -- symptoms that fall under the description ''flulike.'' A doctor may suspect anthrax, but a definitive diagnosis takes hours to days.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?
