Six people in the mailroom were decontaminated after they were exposed to the package, a spokesman said. It was taken to the Centers for Disease Control for further tests. David Firestone (NYT)

headline.main: Letter Sent to Chile Tests Positive for Anthrax

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A letter mailed to Chile has tested positive for anthrax, the director of a Miami laboratory affiliated with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. The agency has not yet verified the finding in its own laboratories. Dr. Antonio Banfi, a professor of pediatric diseases at the Calvo Mackenna Hospital in Santiago, Chile, received the letter at a laboratory where he does research. He regarded it as suspicious because the return address in Florida differed from the Zurich postmark. A Chilean laboratory found anthrax spores in the sample and the Centers for Disease Control was asked to confirm the result.

headline.main: Anthrax Discovery Closes Mail Center

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A mail processing center that serves most of southern New Jersey was closed last night after anthrax spores were found on a mail-sorting machine, officials said. The center had been shut down and reopened last week after an employee showed symptoms of anthrax exposure. The South Jersey Processing and Distribution Center in Bellmawr, which employs 1,300 workers, was expected to reopen this morning, according to a spokesman for the United States Postal Service.

headline.main: Sterilized Mail To Be Scanned For Evidence

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Nearly 70 tons of mail that was shipped to Ohio for decontamination will be trucked back to Washington and scoured piece by piece for anthrax, law enforcement and postal authorities said today. ''We are working very hard'' to identify mail with anthrax and find out who sent it, Attorney General John Ashcroft said.

headline.main: Investigators Find Anthrax Throughout Tabloid Office

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Anthrax spores have been found throughout the headquarters of a tabloid publisher, leading local health officials to suspect it received more than one tainted letter. Investigators said today that it was unlikely that just one letter had spread spores to all three floors of the 68,000-square-foot American Media Inc. building in Boca Raton.

headline.main: Worker Testing Anthrax Item Gets the Disease

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A Texas laboratory worker testing specimens from the anthrax attacks last fall contracted the skin form of the disease this month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported today. It was the first confirmed case of anthrax infection in the United States since November. Officials did not identify the laboratory or the worker, but said he was being treated with antibiotics and was recovering. No other workers are known to be infected, the officials said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Anthrax Tests Negative

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Anthrax tests at a dozen family planning centers that provide abortions came back negative, Lisa Bull, a spokeswoman for the F.B.I., said yesterday. The state centers received letters on Nov. 8 containing a white powder and a note saying that the powder was anthrax, state and federal officials said. The letters were sent via Federal Express to two clinics in Hartford, two in Danbury, two in New Haven and one each in Bridgeport, Norwalk, Waterbury, Meriden, New London and Avon.

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Treatment In Anthrax Cases

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jeanne Shaheen has asked the new director of homeland security, Tom Ridge, to set consistent policies on anthrax cases. In a letter, Ms. Shaheen, a Democrat, wrote that both the State Department's visa processing center in Portsmouth and a post office in Manchester received mail from the Washington mail center where anthrax killed two people, but only the visa employees were told to take antibiotics. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

headline.main: Workers Being Kept on Cipro After Tests Prove Inconclusive
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FLORIDA CASES

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: State and local health officials began notifying about 400 American Media employees today that despite two blood tests analyzed by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, they could not definitively determine which of the workers had been exposed to anthrax. Therefore, anyone who spent an hour or more in the American Media building in Boca Raton in the two months ending Oct. 7 should consider themselves exposed and continue a 60-day regimen of Cipro antibiotics, the health officials told the workers.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Schumer Urges Terror Penalties

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer proposed legislation yesterday that would make terrorist hoaxes a federal crime punishable by up to five years in prison, fines of at least $10,000 and reimbursement of all expenses, such as police overtime. Senator Schumer said no federal law outlaws false alarms and pranks, such as falsely writing that a letter contains anthrax spores. In the first three months of October, Senator Schumer said, the F.B.I. alone responded to 2,500 anthrax reports.

headline.main: Florida Man Is Hospitalized With Pulmonary Anthrax

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A 63-year-old Florida man has contracted pulmonary anthrax and has been hospitalized with the infection, health officials said yesterday. But, the officials said, there is no evidence that the man's disease was caused by a terrorist attack and there is no public health risk.

headline.main: Bush Emphasizes, More Than Once, That He Doesn't Have Anthrax

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: ''First of all,'' President Bush declared today, ''I don't have anthrax.'' A few minutes later, he repeated, ''I don't have anthrax.'' And then for a third time, perhaps to make sure he was understood, Mr. Bush ended a brief question-and-answer session with reporters by saying, ''I don't have it.''

headline.main: 2 New Anthrax Infections Found; Previous Cases Share Same Strain
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NEW CASES

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Two more cases of anthrax were disclosed yesterday in the New York area, with a second postal worker near Trenton hospitalized and an employee of The New York Post, who had been taking antibiotics for fever and a cut finger, learning she had been infected. In addition, executives at The New York Times said that an envelope postmarked in New York City and received at its offices in Rio de Janeiro had shown traces of anthrax in preliminary tests, again broadening the area where contaminated letters had been sent.

headline.main: Agency Looks Into Claim Doctor Had Skin Anthrax

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A cardiologist in New Jersey said yesterday that he thought he might have contracted skin anthrax in the first week of September. Should the case of the cardiologist, Dr. Gerald M. Weisfogel, turn out to have been anthrax, it would be of considerable interest to investigators. It precedes the first batch of anthrax letters that was sent out on or around Sept. 18 and would indicate a new and earlier source of exposure.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Little Fear Of Anthrax Or The Economy

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: A new Quinnipiac University poll shows that most state residents do not fear being exposed to anthrax, despite the death last month of an Oxford woman from inhalation anthrax, and that they believe the state's economy is outperforming the nation's. More than 70 percent of registered voters polled said they were ''not too worried'' or ''not worried at all'' about being exposed to anthrax in the mail, and 91 percent said they believed the mail was safe, the survey found. More than half said that the economy was good or excellent, and that they expected it to remain so through next year. A total of 1,194 registered voters were polled by telephone between Dec. 10 and Dec. 17. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

headline.main: Anthrax Prods a Rewriting Of Medical Dogma, Quickly

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: Inhalation anthrax used to be seen as virtually a death sentence. Now, doctors are not so sure. With 10 confirmed cases in recent weeks, the death toll stands at three, with a fourth patient very seriously ill. Cutaneous anthrax was so rare and unexpected that no doctor would have considered it until a person developed a characteristic black scab in the middle of a pustule on his skin. No more. In some postal workers, the disease was diagnosed and treated so soon that they never developed the characteristic scab.

headline.main: BAFFLED F.B.I. ASKS FOR AID IN SOLVING RIDDLE OF ANTHRAX

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that after weeks of investigation, the government had no idea who was behind the anthrax attacks, and he appealed to the public for help in solving the case. The director, Robert S. Mueller III, said the F.B.I. had been unable to determine the source of the microbes that have killed four people.

headline.main: Officials Admit Underestimating Danger Posed to Postal Workers

Anthrax.lead_paragraph: As more postal workers fell sick and two were confirmed dead from anthrax, federal officials dramatically stepped up their public health response today and acknowledged that they had underestimated the danger that anthrax-contaminated letters posed to those who carry and sort the mail. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, told Congress that from now on, any time a letter containing anthrax was received, his agency would immediately conduct environmental tests at post offices through which it might have passed and offer antibiotics to everyone who worked there.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donations Urged For Nonprofits

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: After raising $425 million, the September 11th Fund called on people yesterday to direct contributions to other charitable causes. The fund is asking for donations to other causes, officials said, because more than enough government and philanthropic aid is available to victims of the terror attacks. Nonprofit groups, from museums to homeless shelters, have reported a sharp drop in donations. Of the $425 million raised by the fund, a project of the New York Community Trust and the United Way of New York City, more than $160 million has been distributed. David Barstow (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Giuliani Neckties Help 9/11 Fund

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Handbags made from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's old neckties will be sold in a charity auction to benefit families of those killed on Sept. 11. Proceeds from the auction, which takes place tomorrow evening at Henri Bendel department store on Fifth Avenue, will benefit the Twin Towers Fund, a charity Mr. Giuliani established to assist families of the uniformed rescue workers who were killed. Mr. Giuliani said he found several dozen neckties while cleaning out his office at City Hall last year. His companion, Judith Nathan, suggested they might be donated to charity, he said. Larry Levy, president of the Twin Towers Fund, said $185 million had been raised for the charity, $155 million of which has been distributed.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donation To 9/11 Memorial

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The producers of the film ''World Trade Center'' are donating $1.3 million, or 5 percent of its opening-weekend proceeds, to the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the foundation said yesterday. Another $1.3 million will be divided among three other 9/11-related charities. The producers of the Paramount Pictures film, about police officers trapped in the trade center rubble, had promised a total donation of 10 percent of the box office proceeds from its opening weekend to the foundation and the other charities.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fund For Queens Air Crash

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city had started a charity to raise money for the families of those killed when a plane crashed in the Belle Harbor section of Queens. Two hundred and sixty-five people died on Nov. 12 when American Airlines Flight 587 crashed on its way to the Dominican Republic. The fund will be administered by the same nonprofit organization that is operating the Twin Towers Fund, a charity for relatives of victims of the World Trade Center terrorist attack. The new fund is called the Flight 587 Relief Fund and donations can be sent to General Post Office, P.O. Box 26878, New York, N.Y. 10087. Chase Bank is administering the deposits. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

headline.main: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; PLEA IN TERROR CASE

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: One of the most important criminal cases to grow out of the Sept. 11 attacks ended in a draw when the director of a prominent Muslim charity agreed to a plea bargain in Chicago. Enaam Arnaout, head of the Benevolence International Foundation, admitted having illegally funneled donations to rebel fighters in Chechnya and Bosnia, but prosecutors dropped all charges related to alleged financial links to Al Qaeda or terrorism. Eric Lichtblau

headline.main: Giuliani Seeks To Lead Fund For Uniformed After Jan. 1

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that after leaving office he would like to continue to run the city's charity for uniformed victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and to convert the fund into a private charity. The Twin Towers Fund has raised $113 million so far for the relatives of the nearly 400 firefighters and police officers killed in the World Trade Center attack, the mayor said yesterday. About $46 million of that money is currently being distributed to families.

headline.main: Officers' Relatives Hire Lawyer To Look Into Twin Towers Fund

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: A group of relatives of police officers killed at the World Trade Center has retained a lawyer to raise concerns over Rudolph W. Giuliani's handling of the Twin Towers Fund, the charity that so far has raised more than $150 million for the families of rescue workers. The lawyer, Edward W. Hayes, said the families had asked him to represent their interests related to the fund and in particular to look into several issues, including Mr. Giuliani's efforts to transfer most of the money in the fund to a private nonprofit group that he controls.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Twin Towers Fund Distribution

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Twin Towers Fund has begun distributing its third round of benefits totaling more than $103 million. The distribution will go to rescue workers not included in previous distributions. The fund was established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to benefit the families of uniformed rescue workers who perished during the terrorist attacks. It has distributed a total of $155 million to 436 families, including 789 children. The typical distributions are $150,000 to each spouse, $60,000 to each child 23 and younger and $25,000 to children 24 and older. The fund continues to seek donations and hopes to include unmarried domestic partners in the next distribution, Laurence Levy, the president of the fund, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Turning to the Internet To Give to Charities

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Donations have poured into charities and relief funds for victims of the terrorist attacks, and the Internet is playing a big role in collecting them. The American Red Cross says about one-third of its contributions have come through the Internet; the Salvation Army puts the tally at about half.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Gay Terror Victims

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: A new relief fund benefiting the families of gays killed in the Sept. 11 terror attack was announced last week by local gay groups. Known as the September 11 Gay and Lesbian Family Fund, the charity has already raised about $141,000 in private donations. The money will be divided equally among the estimated three dozen surviving gay partners and their families, according to an organizer, Joe Grabarz, executive director of the Empire State Pride Agenda. Mr. Grabarz said there was a need for a special charity because gay partners have been denied public assistance, such as workers' compensation and Social Security, that is available to heterosexual husbands and wives. Denny Lee (NYT)

headline.main: Personal Business; Before Donating, Don't Be Afraid to Ask Questions

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS have opened their hearts and their wallets in the weeks after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, eager to help the victims and their families, as well as the thousands of volunteers at the disaster sites. Now specialists in charitable giving are advising people to take a few minutes to learn how to do the most good with their gifts. ''It is so important to give money away intelligently,'' said Daniel Borochoff, president of the American Institute of Philanthropy, a consumer watchdog group in Bethesda, Md. ''People can exponentially increase the good of their donations.''

headline.main: Drop in Gifts to Muslim Charities Is Attributed to U.S. Scrutiny

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The government's scrutiny of Muslim charities in the United States since the Sept. 11 attacks has contributed heavily to a sharp drop in donations to those groups, many relief organizations say. Donations to Muslim charities in the United States during the month of Ramadan are down by more than 50 percent from the period last year, the organizations report.

headline.main: Making Sure Your Money Goes Where It's Intended

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: HOW do you know whether your gift to a charity will be used as you intended? With upward of 200 organizations, many of them new, raising money in response to the Sept. 11 attacks, and with 1.2 million charities on the cumulative list kept by the Internal Revenue Service, is anyone making sure this money is not diverted to a different cause or to a crooked charity organizer's personal bank account?

headline.main: Footlights; Museum Gets Back to Business

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Like many of its counterparts in Manhattan, the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers waived its admission fee for several days after the terrorist attacks. Now regular admission fees have resumed, and the museum is asking visitors to contribute to the September 11 Fund in lieu of additional donations to the museum. The fund, established by the United Way and the New York Community Fund, channels money to those directly affected by the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.main: Charity Seeks To Transfer Money Frozen By Treasury

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development, one of three charities whose assets have been frozen because they are suspected of funneling donations to terrorist organizations, has asked the Treasury Department for permission to transfer some of its charitable assets to another nonprofit organization. If the department approves, the foundation will give $50,000 to the Palestine Children's Relief Fund, which works to bring medical services to needy children in the Mideast.

headline.main: Cultural Group Receives $5 Million Grant

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, a nonprofit group that supports arts organizations, has received a $5 million grant from the September 11th Fund that will be used to finance dozens of arts groups in Lower Manhattan over the next three years, the council announced yesterday. Starting in January, nonprofit organizations in Lower Manhattan or sponsoring activities there can apply for the grants, which will range from $5,000 to $250,000, said Tom Healy, president of the council. The money is meant to help arts groups with marketing, programming and capital expenses, he said.

headline.seo: Foundation to Distribute $4 Million to Families Affected by Newtown Massacre
headline.main: Foundation Releasing Aid to Families in Newtown
headline.print_headline: Foundation Releasing Aid To Families In Newtown

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Newtown-Sandy Hook Community Foundation said the money would be given to the families of the children and educators killed in the Dec. 14 shooting, among others.

headline.main: Arts Grants Offset Sept. 11 Attack

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Andrew Mellon Foundation announced yesterday the first in a series of grants totaling $50 million to aid cultural institutions directly affected by the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11. The first awards, $2.65 million each, will go to three New York groups that are grant-making organizations themselves: the Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York, the American Music Center and the New York Foundation for the Arts.

headline.main: Britain to Tighten Charities Laws to Tackle Terrorism Funding
headline.print_headline: Britain to Tighten Charities Laws to Tackle Terrorism Funding

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: British Prime Minister David Cameron will announce plans on Wednesday to tighten the law to help stop charities being used as a front to raise funds for terrorist groups.

headline.main: Bush Plan Would Revise Bill to Aid Charities

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: President Bush asked the Senate leadership today to pass a slimmed-down version of his plan to give federal money to religious charities, saying all charities were hard-pressed to provide disaster relief for the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks while helping the needy. These pressures from the war on terrorism helped persuade Mr. Bush to eliminate the most contentious parts of his religion-based initiative to win passage of the law before the end of the year.

headline.main: Large Charity Blocks Funds To Several Islamic Groups
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RELIEF ORGANIZATIONS

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The nation's second-largest public charity, Fidelity Investments' Charitable Gift Fund, and two smaller funds have decided to block donations that their contributors might direct to any of several prominent Islamic relief groups based in the United States. The funds cite concern that those groups may be linked to terrorism. The Bush administration this week froze the assets of one of the groups, the Holy Land Foundation, based in Texas, contending that it had helped finance the militant Palestinian organization Hamas, which carried out the recent series of suicide bombings in Israel.

headline.main: Students Will Skip Dinner to Raise Money

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: Cornell University students have come up with another way to help families affected by the World Trade Center disaster. By giving up a dinner through their university meal plan, the students hope to raise $20,000 for the United Way Sept. 11 Fund. The goal is for 3,000 students to donate the money that would ordinarily go toward their dinner on Oct. 12. The donations will close down three campus dining halls that Friday evening because the money raised would usually go toward running the halls. Allison Fass

headline.main: Plan to List Who Receives Disaster Aid Stirs Concern

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: In an effort to coordinate the flow of charity to victims of the World Trade Center disaster, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has proposed creating a formal list of every person who gets help and how much money each receives. The central roster of aid recipients, which would be the first ever created in response to a major American disaster, would help ensure funds were being shared fairly and without duplication, Mr. Spitzer said yesterday, after a two-hour meeting with more than a dozen charitable groups. But creating such a list would also raise serious privacy concerns, especially for illegal immigrants who might need help, he acknowledged.

headline.main: A Scholarship Fund for Children of Those Who Suffered Financial Losses

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: AXA Financial Inc., the financial services company, is donating $3 million to start a new scholarship fund for victims of the terror attacks on Sept. 11. The fund, named Families of Freedom 2: Building Futures Through Education, will devote itself to providing scholarships and educational support for indirect victims of the attacks -- those who lost jobs and businesses -- and their children who are on the verge of going to college. AXA will announce the fund's formation today.

headline.main: Number Overstated for Storm Evacuees in Hotels

Charitable Funds.lead_paragraph: The Red Cross and federal government said Tuesday that they had been significantly overreporting the number of Hurricane Katrina evacuees in hotels. Instead of 600,000 people, 200,000 remain in hotels, the charity said. Although the lower number means that the Federal Emergency Management Agency and cities receiving evacuees will find new housing for far fewer people, the count shows the lack of knowledge that FEMA has about the relocations and its limited oversight over the money it is committed to spend on such housing.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; ATTACK ON MOSQUE

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: A man who said he hated Muslims drove a truck into a Florida mosque just 30 minutes before evening prayers, the police said. No one was injured on Monday in the Islamic Center of Tallahassee at Florida State University. The driver, Charles Franklin, 41, was arrested later at a campus bar. Investigators said Mr. Franklin told the police that he tried to join the military to kill Muslims but was turned down.

'Every Muslim Is Osama bin Laden' Several hundred Muslims poured out of the Jamia Mosque this afternoon and began denouncing the United States. headline.main: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance

headline.main: Moderates Start Speaking Out Against Islamic Intolerance
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: MUSLIMS IN AMERICA

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: Outrage, it seems, has helped shatter the silence. After years of quietly watching a harsh, puritanical strain of Islam enter America, many moderate Muslims are speaking out in favor of a more tolerant form of their faith. They are emboldened by their sense of anger at the Sept. 11 attacks and embarrassed by what they see as a distorted vision of their religion.

headline.print_headline: Complicated Balancing Act For Imam in Mosque Furor

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: For much of his life, Feisal Abdul Rauf, who led the proposal for a Muslim center downtown, has found distrust as he tried to reconcile Islam with America and modernism.

headline.main: Seeing Islam as 'Evil' Faith, Evangelicals Seek Converts

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday in a church fellowship hall here, evangelical Christians from several states gathered for an all-day seminar on how to woo Muslims away from Islam. The teacher urged a kindly approach: always show Muslims love, charity and hospitality, he said, and carry copies of the New Testament to give as gifts. The students, scribbling notes, included two pastors, a school secretary and college students who said they hoped to convert Muslims in the United States, or on mission trips abroad.

headline.main: Stereotyping Rankles Silent, Secular Majority of American Muslims

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: Khalid Pervaiz is an American Muslim, an investment banker in Los Angeles with two young daughters. On the door of his home is a Christmas wreath made by his 7-year-old, and in the living room is a Christmas tree with an angel on top. His daughters go to the mosque, or masjid, on Sundays for classes in the Koran, but Mr. Pervaiz himself goes once a year on the major Muslim holiday of Id al-Fitr. ''I had the privilege of being exposed to other religions from the very beginning, so I wasn't so fixed on the idea that Islam is the only way to live,'' Mr. Pervaiz said. ''Every once in a blue moon I will go for my Friday prayers, but I still think I'm a good Muslim. If I don't go and pray five times a day, I don't think I'm less of a Muslim. I'm just not a practicing, going-to-the-masjid Muslim.''

headline.print_headline: The Evolution of a Radical Cleric

headline.main: Queens Muslim Group Says It Opposes Violence, and America

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: The young Muslim men, with beards and bullhorns, work the streets of Jackson Heights on the weekends. They surface at parades and protests around the city, loudly declaring America the enemy and advocating for an Islamic state. Several weeks ago, they publicly tore up an American flag as payback for the reported desecration of the Koran at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Their own videos of violence against Muslims, one with the title ''Muslim Massacres,'' have recently appeared on Queens Public Television. In the annals of New York City's political outspokenness and fringe-group culture, the Islamic Thinkers Society may seem unremarkable at first glance. But after 9/11, in the city most damaged and unsettled by the terrorist attacks, the emergence of this young, however limited, Muslim-American voice is strikingly bold. In its fliers and on its Web site, the group describes itself as an ''intellectual and political nonviolent organization,'' but it bears a strong resemblance to Islamist movements in England that try to unite Muslims by inciting anger.

headline.main: A Plea for Healing

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: As the drone of a lawn mower drifts through an open window, the chanting begins. Men and boys in stocking feet kneel and touch their heads to the green wall-to-wall carpeting, while a toddler pulls at his traditional Muslim cap, or kaffiyeh. It is one of five daily prayers at the austere Westchester Muslim Center mosque in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and in most every way, it is the same as ever. But today, the Muslims who worship here are emerging from a year marked not only by collective grief for the victims of the terror attacks, but also by occasional outbursts of blame and suspicion from non-Muslims.

headline.seo: King Hearings on Muslims Show Deep Partisan Rift
headline.main: Domestic Terrorism Hearing Opens With Contrasting Views on Dangers
headline.print_headline: Deep Partisan Rift Emerges in Hearings on U.S. Muslims

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: Some witnesses described what they called a stealth campaign to promote extremism in American mosques, while others expressed concern that such broad accusations could themselves alienate Muslims.

headline.main: For Muslims, an Uneasy Anniversary; Urge to Speak Out Conflicts With Low-Profile Instincts

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: One day next month, when all of New York is draped in commemoration, many of the city's Muslims will be grieving and seeking solace; but some Muslims say that on that day, Sept. 11, they will feel resentment. Still others will fear an echo of anti-Muslim backlash. Some will look to prove they are good Americans. Others will bristle that such a thing should even be expected of them.

headline.main: From State Dept., Advice For Muslim Convention

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: American Muslims met with Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes on Friday at an Islamic convention here to offer advice and assistance as she began an initiative to improve the flagging image of the United States among Muslims overseas. Ms. Hughes began overseeing ''public diplomacy'' for the Bush administration last month. She said she and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice would hold a public forum and announce a new ''public diplomacy'' strategy next week. She gave few details, but said the initiative would involve exchange programs, debates and interfaith dialogues.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Chirac Urges Nation Guard Against Bias

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: President Jacques Chirac called on the French authorities to use ''the greatest firmness'' in dealing with racist and religious attacks, after heightened tensions in France between Muslims and Jews. Muslims have complained of greater hostility and aggression against them since the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks in the United States. Jews have denounced a rising wave of anti-Semitic incidents, which have intensified in recent months with Israel's crackdown on Palestinian militants and the war in Iraq. Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline.main: Muslim Leaders Confront Terror Threat Within Islam

Persecution of Muslim People.lead_paragraph: After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, American Muslim leaders insisted that the terrorism had nothing to do with Islam. They cited Central Intelligence Agency reports showing that Latin Americans were responsible for more terrorist incidents than Muslims. They blamed Israel or American foreign policy, and their organizations focused on campaigns to convince non-Muslim Americans that Islam was a religion of peace. Nearly four years after the attacks, American Muslim leaders are changing their message. They are rolling out campaigns to persuade American Muslims -- especially the young -- to beware of preachers peddling extremism and terrorism. They say that terrorism is a poison infecting Islam and that moderate Muslims should take responsibility to root it out.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; 4 REBELS KILLED IN PHILIPPINES

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Philippine troops shot dead four Muslim guerrillas in an offensive to rescue two American hostages held by a group linked to Al Qaeda, the military said. Two members of a Philippine army patrol were wounded within earshot of American troops and four Green Berets entered the combat zone to try to retrieve the wounded. Officials said American detection equipment was helping pinpoint the Abu Sayyaf rebels, aiding chances of rescuing an American missionary couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Hostage Freed

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Government troops rescued the last of three Indonesian seamen taken hostage last June by the Muslim separatist group Abu Sayyaf. One hostage escaped earlier, the other died in captivity on the southern island of Jolo, home to the group. The group is still holding five Filipino women, four of them Jehovah's Witnesses. The Abu Sayyaf group is thought to have some ties to Al Qaeda and is known for financing its operations by kidnapping. Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline.main: BOMB IN PHILIPPINES

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A homemade bomb exploded early on Saturday at a market on the southern Philippine island of Jolo, killing two people and wounding 45, the authorities said. The explosion occurred as American troops began military exercises with the Philippine Army on the nearby island of Basilan. Col. Romeo Tolentino said the blast ''could be an act of retaliation'' by extortion gangs at public markets,'' or possibly ''a diversionary attack'' of Abu Sayyaf, an Islamic group linked to Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Militant Leader Captured in Philippines

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: The Philippine military said today that it had captured a leader of Abu Sayyaf, a gang of Muslim militants that the United States has linked to Al Qaeda. Merang Abante, a middle-ranking leader of Abu Sayyaf with an $18,500 bounty on his head, was arrested near the southern city of Zamboanga, Lt. Gen. Narciso Abaya said.

headline.main: Philippine Group Denies Ransom

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: In a Radio Mindanao interview, Muslim guerrillas with suspected links to Al Qaeda denied today that they had received a $300,000 ransom for the release of an American missionary couple held for almost a year in the Philippines. The family of the couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham, spoke last week of a release deal with Abu Sayyaf, the guerrillas, but said the guerrillas reneged. The family hinted at a ransom.

headline.main: The Philippines: Army and Rebels Clash

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Soldiers attacked Muslim militants linked to Al Qaeda at a southern encampment on Thursday, and 12 government soldiers and 4 rebels were killed in the fighting, the military said. Maj. Gen. Ricardo Rainier Cruz said government forces struck after the military pinpointed an encampment of Abu Sayyaf militants blamed for past attacks in Sumisip on Basilan Island. Violence in the southern Philippines continues despite efforts by American-trained Philippine forces to put an end to decades of bombings and ransom kidnappings by Muslim extremists.

headline.main: Rebel Seized in Philippines

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A leader of an Islamic militant group considered responsible for the abduction and murder of Filipinos and foreigners, among them Americans, was arrested Sunday during a firefight with soldiers in the southern Philippines, officials said. They said the arrested man, Galib Andang, also known as Commander Robot, was wounded during the battle on Sulu, one of the two islands where the militant group Abu Sayyaf operates.

headline.main: The Philippines: No Word From Abductors of Three

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Philippine officials said Wednesday they had received no word from the abductors of a naturalized American woman, her teenage son and Filipino nephew a day after they were seized by gunmen. More than a dozen men seized Gerfa Yeatts Lunsmann, her 14-year-old son and 19-year-old nephew from the house of the relatives they were visiting in a village near Zamboanga city. The area is a stronghold of the Qaeda-linked Abu Sayyaf extremists. Philippine military officials said they were also looking at the possible involvement of an Islamic separatist group.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Bomb Kills Soldier

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A Philippine soldier was killed and two were wounded Saturday when a bomb exploded outside a restaurant on the island of Jolo as they were searching for explosives after a bomb threat, the military said. Jolo has long been a stronghold of Muslim rebels seeking an Islamic state in the largely Catholic country, including the Abu Sayyaf group, which is linked to Al Qaeda. The bomb went off while security forces were searching the commercial district of Jolo town, the military said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: U.S. Advisers To Help Against Muslim Rebels

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: American military advisers arrived in the southern Philippines to help train Philippine troops who are fighting Muslim militants. The rebels are holding at least 12 hostages, including two American missionaries. They are believed to have links with the terrorist network of Osama bin Laden. Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline.main: Release Said to Be Near for U.S. Couple Held by Philippine Rebels

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: The Philippine military said today that it was optimistic that its troops would soon secure the release of an American couple who have been held hostage since May by Muslim insurgents in the south of the country. The couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham, were seized, along with another American, Guillermo Sobero, and 17 Filipinos, by the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas at the Dos Palmas resort off southwestern Palawan island.

headline.main: Philippine Court Convicts 14 in Kidnapping Case

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A Philippine court on Thursday convicted 14 members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group in the 2001 kidnapping of 20 people off an island resort, including three Americans, two of whom were eventually killed. The 14 were sentenced to life imprisonment. Four others were acquitted.

headline.main: Philippines Reports Killing 21 Rebels

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Military officials said today that 21 rebels had been killed over the last two days in fighting between Philippine troops and guerrillas linked to Osama bin Laden. In an apparent attempt to ease military pressure on their forces on a nearby island, Basilan, the rebels set off small bombs in three hotels in Zamboanga early Monday; there was minor damage but no casualties, the military authorities said.

headline.main: Top Militant Leader Is Arrested in Philippines
headline.print_headline: Top Militant Leader Is Arrested in Philippines

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Khair Mundos, 50, a leader of Abu Sayyaf, was arrested on Wednesday morning in southern Manila, according to a statement from the police.

headline.seo: Soldiers in Philippines Attack Militant Group, Abu Sayyaf
headline.main: Filipino Soldiers Attack Militants
headline.print_headline: Filipino Soldiers Attack Militants Tied to Al Qaeda

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: The troops killed at least 20 gunmen and seized bombs that had been set to explode, military officials said.

headline.main: Red Cross Hostage in Philippines Is Free

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A worker for the International Committee of the Red Cross who was kidnapped 11 weeks ago with two colleagues by an Islamic extremist organization has been freed and is in the custody of the Philippine military, officials said Thursday. It was unclear if the worker, Mary Jean Lacaba, 37, had been rescued by the military or was released by the Islamist group, Abu Sayyaf, which is known for kidnapping Filipinos and foreigners.

headline.main: Americans Aiding Philippines In Fight Against Terrorist Group

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: American military officers are in the Philippines providing advice in the fight against a terrorist group linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today. About 30 American personnel with counterterrorism skills are on the southern island of Basilan to advise the Philippine Army on how to fight the Abu Sayyaf group, which is holding hostages, including two Americans, officials said.

headline.main: FILIPINO REBEL REPORTED KILLED

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: A top commander of the Islamic militant group Abu Sayyaf reportedly died yesterday from wounds suffered during a government assault on his hideout a day earlier, a Philippines military commander said. The militant, Mujib Susukan, whose capture or death carried a $92,500 bounty, was shot in a clash on Tuesday outside the town of Talipao on the island of Jolo, said the army commander, Col. Alexander Aleo. Mr. Susukan was the leader of one of several factions of Abu Sayyaf, which has been linked to Al Qaeda and is on a United States list of terrorist groups. Colonel Aleo said other guerrillas and villagers carried Mr. Susukan into the jungle. Intelligence sources and villagers reported he died Wednesday and was buried in a shallow grave in the village of Bandang near Talipao. Colonel Aleo said a search for the body had been ordered. The death toll has risen to 15 people in two days of fighting.

headline.main: Feared Terrorists And Sketchy Ties

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Evidence of their link with Al Qaeda is sketchy: There were meetings some years ago with a brother-in-law of Osama bin Laden, and some contact with one of the terrorists now imprisoned in the United States for the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993. But the guerrillas in the Philippines known as Abu Sayyaf are among the most feared terrorists in the world. The band's goal is to carve an Islamic state from a heavily Roman Catholic country. The group's speciality is kidnapping. An American missionary couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham of Wichita, Kan., are being held as hostages of the group.

headline.main: U.S. Couple Held in Philippines Describe Their Ordeal on Tape

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: An American missionary couple who have been held for six months near here by Muslim guerrillas described the hardships of captivity in a videotape shown on television on Sunday and Monday. The videotape was the first shown of the couple, Gracia and Martin Burnham, since they were taken captive with 18 others in May by Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who have been linked to Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: 23 Filipino Soldiers Killed in Clashes
headline.print_headline: 23 Filipino Soldiers Killed in Clashes With Militant Group

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Twenty-three soldiers and at least 20 suspected terrorists have been killed as troops stormed camps of the Islamist separatist group Abu Sayyaf.

headline.main: Islamist Militants Kill 18 Civilians in Philippines
headline.print_headline: Islamist Militants Kill 18 Civilians in Philippines

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Islamist militants in the Philippines killed 18 people on Monday in revenge for their clan's support of government efforts to bring stability to the resource-rich region and the military warned of more bloodshed.

headline.main: Filipino Troops Plan Rescue of Three Hostages

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Philippine soldiers say they will come in shooting when the moment arrives to rescue two American missionaries and a Filipino nurse who have been held hostage in dense jungle here for nearly seven months. ''This is the endgame,'' said Lt. Gen. Roy Cimatu, chief of the armed forces southern command. The rescue could come at any time.

headline.main: 3 Red Cross Workers Abducted in Philippines

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: Three workers from the International Committee of the Red Cross were abducted Thursday by men believed to be members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group in the southern Philippines, officials said. The abductions, the latest in a string, took place in the town of Patikul, on Sulu, a southern island province where Abu Sayyaf and other rebel groups have been active.

headline.seo: Philippine Forces Clash with Abu Sayyaf
headline.main: Rescue Effort in Philippines Turns Deadly
headline.print_headline: Rescue Effort In Philippines Turns Deadly

Abu Sayyaf.lead_paragraph: At least seven Philippine marines and seven Abu Sayyaf militants were killed in a clash in a government offensive aimed at rescuing six foreign and Filipino hostages.
